Each of those families can still receive $125,000 of support. In the legislation before the House we have ensured that there is a flexibility mechanism which will enable the government to move, considering how the drought progresses, after 30 June next year to do further assistance, should that be required.

We are responding to the drought. We will continue to respond to the drought, and people in rural and regional communities know that. Yesterday we met with the National Farmers' Federation and there was enormous overlap between the measures we're putting in place and the measures they are calling for. Obviously things like rate relief, which they have raised, are a matter for the state and territory governments. One of the things that the state and territory governments are also responsible for is freight and fodder subsidies, which I note the NFF did not call to be increased during the course of this drought. We will continue to work with the NFF and all of those in our rural districts and communities, because on this side of the House there are just so many members from rural communities who are affected by this drought, and they will continue to provide an excellent conduit for the development of policies. (Time expired)
Economy

Mrs McINTOSH (Lindsay) (14:04): My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister outline to the House how returning the budget to balance and keeping it there guarantees the essential services that people and families, including in my electorate of Lindsay, rely on? What are the risks to services from other policy approaches?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister and Minister for the Public Service) (14:04): I thank the member for Lindsay. The member for Lindsay, along with so many others on this side of the House, is in a rare position for people who have come into this House, and that is they're actually in this chamber as members of parliament and as part of a government that is actually delivering a surplus this year. We haven't seen that for some time.
Mr Frydenberg: Twelve years!

Mr MORRISON: Twelve years, as the Treasurer reminds us. The reason they are in a position to do that is the stable and certain financial management that has been pursued by this government since we first came to office. There are three key things we've done to achieve that budget surplus which will be achieved this year. Firstly, we have been getting spending under control—the reckless spending that was implemented by the previous government. People say that we're in Labor's debt. Well, that's true. We are in Labor's debt. There is a debt that Labor left the following government. We are in Swanny's debt. We are in Rudd's debt. We are in the debt of all of those Labor members who presided over the reckless spending, and we're paying that debt off now because we have got spending under control. We have ended the reckless spending of Labor and we have got spending under control. We also budgeted cautiously. We didn't spend money we didn't have, like the mining tax, where revenues never happened but the money was spent anyway. Estimates of iron ore prices at US$183 forever—it never happened, but they spent the money anyway. And we've been getting Australians off welfare and into work for the last three years. For 36 months, every single month, employment has gone up and up and up. When you get people off welfare they go from welfare recipients to taxpayers, and that has a positive impact on the budget.

When you do that, it means you can provide tax relief to Australians, like those in the member for Lindsay's electorate, as we did as the first action of our government after being re-elected in May of this year. It also means you can provide $20.5 million for breast care nurses through the McGrath Foundation; $13.7 million for the National Action Plan for Endometriosis; $39.5 million to immunise pregnant women against whooping cough, provide new diagnostic imaging services and prioritise perinatal health; $503 million for youth mental health and suicide prevention, which is a cornerstone objective of this government; $11½ billion in benefits and support to veterans and their families; and $30 million to establish a network of six veterans wellbeing centres across the nation. When you have a strong budget, that's what you can do. (Time expired)
Drought

Ms CHESTERS (Bendigo) (14:07): My question is to the Prime Minister. In the face of the drought crisis, what additional measures are being provided by the government to people like farmhands, stock hands, shearers, jackaroos, jillaroos—people who depend upon agriculture for their livelihoods but are not farmers?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister and Minister for the Public Service) (14:08): I'm happy for the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, to respond to the answer. The second phase of our drought plan involves investing in local communities, which keeps local communities actually turning over their economy. What the member may not be aware of is the additional taxation incentives we provided to farmers, particularly in the building of silage, which is done by the very contractors and farmhands you're talking about. There was also $350 million in grants to farmers to support to work they're doing on on-farm water infrastructure. The member may not be aware, but that's also done by people who work on farms—the turkey nests and all of that sort of infrastructure. It's our comprehensive drought response. Those recommendations came from directly engaging with our farming communities. I'll ask the minister for drought to add further to the answer.

Mr LITTLEPROUD (Maranoa—Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management) (14:09): It is a good question, because it actually underlines the complexity of the drought. It reaches far beyond the farm gate; it goes into the communities, as the Prime Minister has clearly articulated. Some of those programs are about making sure there is a stimulation within the communities and also at the farm gate. Adding on that is the commitment we've made over the lifetime of this drought, which has been eight years. We didn't just start this yesterday; we've been on this journey for over eight years.

Over $50 million has been put into pests and weeds. Let me tell you what that has done. I can give you a perfect example from my own electorate. In central western Queensland they have built these things called 'dog fences'. While they have been destocked, our farmers, with the aid of their workers, have built fences to exclude wild dogs, so that when it does rain, and we see lambing rates going from five per cent to 85 per cent, shearers will come back into these communities. It's about making sure that we diversify the economic base. Bringing in shearers, means the shearers will invariably leave more money at the cafes, the pubs and the servos. That is the complexity.

That is why our three-pillar approach to this drought is about the here and now. It's about making sure there is money in farmers' pockets in the here and now to keep them going with dignity and respect and to put an environment around them with rural financial counsellors and concessional loans. It's about the community and understanding that it goes further than just the farmers: it's about the families that support those farmers. That's why we've looked at these programs and at the Future Drought Fund. It will continue to deliver programs and give farmers the resilience they need in the future. That's how you tackle this insidious disease that is drought. It's not the same as other natural disasters where you can measure it by fixing a house or a road. It depletes landscapes and bank balances. So you have to escalate your approach and your delivery right through the community, from the farm gate to those that work within the communities, to make sure regional and rural communities survive. (Time expired)
Infrastructure

Mr DRUM (Nicholls—Chief Nationals Whip) (14:11): My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development. Will the Deputy Prime Minister inform the House how the Morrison-McCormack government's stable and certain budget is guaranteeing delivery of infrastructure for regional Australia, particularly in my seat of Nicholls, in this current year? Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware of any alternative approaches?

Mr McCORMACK (Riverina—Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure,Transport and Regional Development and Leader of the Nationals) (14:11): In this year and beyond we are certainly going to be helping the good people of the electorate of Nicholls, who are very well represented by the member for Nicholls. This government have, of course, a $100 billion, 10-year pipeline of investment, and we're getting out and we're delivering it. I would like to acknowledge the member for Nicholls for his unwavering advocacy—
Mr Gosling interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Solomon is warned.

Mr McCORMACK: for better projects and better roads, making sure that the people of Nicholls have the projects that they need and the infrastructure that they expect. We've made commitments such as the first-stage rebuild of the GV Health site on Corio Street in Shepparton. Matt Sharp, who's the CEO of GV Health, is in the building today. He said that the reason this is so important is:
… it will give us the chance to increase the access available for children, young people and their families across the region … to … receive these really important health services.

In addition, we have the Echuca-Moama bridge and upgrading the train line to Shepparton. We've also committed $208 million to the Shepparton bypass. It wouldn't have happened without the member for Nicholls's advocacy. It wouldn't have happened without his campaigning. He made sure it was front of mind for myself and the government. We're getting on with it and we're going to deliver it. All these job-creating projects in the Goulburn Valley—
Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Hunter. The Deputy Prime Minister still has the call.
Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—
Mr McCORMACK: He's very noisy today.
The SPEAKER: The member for Hunter is warned.

Mr McCORMACK: He also must be very delighted with the infrastructure rollout that we're doing. Right across Australia we're seeing excavators on site and hi-vis vests everywhere. Since 2013, we've announced 900 major projects, 300 of which are completed and 160 of which are under construction. These projects are job creators: NorthConnex, $412 million and 8,700 jobs in New South Wales; the Bruce Highway Upgrade Program, $10 billion and more than 7,200 jobs; Monash Freeway upgrade, millions of dollars and a thousand jobs; WestConnex, $1.5 billion and 10,000 jobs; METRONET in Western Australia, $2.3 billion and 17,000 jobs; M80 Ring Road in Victoria, $500 million, which should delight the member for Jagajaga, and 1,350 jobs; Midland Highway upgrade in Tasmania, $400 million and 1,068 jobs; and the Parkes to Narromine section of the Inland Rail, 890 jobs. For communities along that section, where 10 jobs would be a bonus, 890 jobs are being created by that 1,700-kilometre corridor of commerce. We're getting on and we're delivering it. We're building it. Through a stable and certain budget we can build even more infrastructure, and we will. There will be more jobs, more projects and more delivery than ever occurred under those opposite.
Economy

Mr ALBANESE (Grayndler—Leader of the Opposition) (14:14): My question is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that corporate profits are growing at six times the pace of wages, the increase in electricity prices has been triple wage growth over the last three years, the increase in medical and hospital service prices has been triple wage growth since 2013 and the increase in childcare prices has been double wage growth since 2013? When will the government present a plan to get wages moving again?

Mr FRYDENBERG (Kooyong—Treasurer) (14:15): I can confirm that real wages are growing at 0.7 per cent, which is above the historical average of 0.6 per cent, compared to just 0.5 per cent when Labor was last in office. I can confirm that the growth in the national wages bill, otherwise known as compensation of employees, is five per cent higher through the year compared to just 3½ per cent when Labor was in office. I can confirm that since the coalition came to office the minimum wage has never dropped below inflation but, when Labor were last in office, those on the minimum wage were hit by real wages cuts for three out of six years, and I can confirm that the RBA governor has said of our tax cuts, 'We estimate that they'll boost household disposable income by roughly 0.6 or 0.7 per cent of income, and that is a sizable boost.' Don't look at what Labor says; look at what Labor does. And, when it comes to the economy, we're the only party that delivers more jobs, lower taxes and a balanced budget.
Mr Brian Mitchell interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Lyons is warned.
Environment

Mr BANDT (Melbourne) (14:16): My question is to the Prime Minister and it's about the connection between thermal coal, global warming and drought. When will the Prime Minister apologise to the communities being told that—
Government members interjecting—

The SPEAKER: The member for Melbourne will resume his seat. Members on my right will cease interjecting. The member for Melbourne is entitled to ask his question and I'm entitled to hear it. The member for Melbourne.

Mr BANDT: When will the Prime Minister apologise to the communities being told that they might run out of water and the farmers suffering through record drought for exporting record amounts of thermal coal and making the climate crisis worse?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister and Minister for the Public Service) (14:17): I can confirm that, based on the discussions I've had particularly with the New South Wales government, the situation being faced by particularly those towns in New South Wales which are confronting those dreadful water shortages, they have measures already in place to ensure that those towns will continue to get access to water until the first quarter of next year and they have plans in place then to see how that needs to be rolled out beyond that point. Whether it's state governments or the Commonwealth government, we are taking all the measures that are required and that are being urged, and we are working with the rural sector to ensure that they're getting the financial support and the other forms of support they need to be able to work through what is this dreadful drought.

The member makes references to our resources industry and seeks to blame the resources industry for our drought. I don't share that view. I don't share that view because the resources sector has also been one of the greatest supporters of rural communities in this country. During those dreadful and devastating floods in North Queensland, which I visited so soon after, do you know whose machinery and equipment came in to get those rotting carcasses off those farmers' properties, which were breaking their hearts? It was the mining companies, and it was coalmining companies lending a hand with local communities, putting their arms around them and helping them restore.
The SPEAKER: The Prime Minister will resume his seat. The member for Melbourne on a point of order.
Mr Bandt: The point of order is on relevance. There are 1½ minutes left to go and the Prime Minister hasn't mentioned global warming or the climate crisis once.
The SPEAKER: The member for Melbourne will resume his seat.
Government members interjecting—

The SPEAKER: Members on my right will cease interjecting. I'm just going to say to the member for Melbourne and other members asking questions that, just because members mention something in their question, ministers aren't required to mention those words in their answer. They have to be relevant to the question. There's no point of order. The Prime Minister is being relevant to the question. The Prime Minister has the call.
Mr MORRISON: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Let me make it really clear. I don't think our mining industry is responsible for the drought.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The SPEAKER (14:19): I'd like to inform the House we have present in the Speaker's gallery this afternoon Sonya Ryan, the CEO of the Carly Ryan Foundation. As many members will know, Sonya is a child protection campaigner and is dedicated to keeping children safe online. On behalf of the House, I extend a warm welcome to you.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Employment

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (14:19): My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer explain to the House how the Morrison government's stable and certain approach to jobs creation has helped to strengthen our economy in the face of international headwinds? Is the Treasurer aware of any policies that might jeopardise this strong jobs growth?

Mr FRYDENBERG (Kooyong—Treasurer) (14:20): I thank the member for Berowra for his question. He's a former councillor, lawyer, advocate—fierce advocate—on behalf of the constituents in his electorate. He may not have received a knighthood, like the member for Rankin, but he is certainly a very fierce advocate. When we came to government, unemployment was higher. When we came to government, unemployment had been higher, at 5.7 per cent. The participation rate had been lower than it is today, $240 billion of deficits had been accumulated and, in Labor's last year in government alone, 65,000 small businesses had closed their doors. Now, with that record in office from the Labor Party, you can imagine how astounded I was to read the member for Rankin's book called Glory Daze, where he described Wayne Swan's legacy:

... a combination of the best macroeconomic management in the developed world combined with a reform agenda headlined by carbon pricing and resource taxation, the fruits of which are yet to be properly understood.

The fruits of which are yet to be properly understood. They're probably not properly understood because they gave us a mining tax that produced no revenue, they gave us cash for clunkers, they gave us pink batts and they gave us accumulated deficits of $240 billion.

Yesterday, I may have inadvertently misled the House, because I described the book Glory Daze as historical fiction. Well, I now think it is a romantic novel, because it looks at the Labor Party's time in office with rose-coloured glasses and fails to look over their failures. In contrast, we have helped create nearly 1½ million new jobs. As the Prime Minister has said, our tax cuts, our investment in infrastructure, our new apprenticeships, our free trade agreements and our cutting of regulation have seen, for the last three years, for every single month, jobs growth. That is a record that has never been seen. We have never before seen three years of jobs growth every single month. And we are committed to a surplus budget in 2019-20 after delivering the first balanced budget in 11 years. Only the coalition will continue to cut your taxes, create more jobs and deliver responsible economic management with a surplus budget.
Workplace Relations

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (14:23): My question is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that cuts to penalty rates and attacks on unions are deliberate design features of the Morrison government's plan to keep wages low?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (14:23): I thank the member for his question, absurd as it is. Of course, the point he seeks to make is completely wrong. Let's consider this for a moment. In my portfolio, part of the carriage is consideration, through the FWC, of the minimum wage. Let's think about the minimum wage for a moment. The minimum wage has increased by a total of 9.8 per cent in recent years. In the last three years, that has been far in excess of inflation. Right at the moment, our lowest-paid workers have never seen a real-wage decrease under the coalition.
Mr Brendan O'Connor interjecting—
Mr PORTER: Our lowest-paid workers have never seen a real wage—

The SPEAKER: Could the Leader of the House just pause for a second. Every time the member for Gorton interjects, he prevents me hearing part of the answer. I don't want him to interject; otherwise I'll have to try and negotiate getting him shifted with the Chief Government Whip. The Leader of the House has the call.

Mr PORTER: I am happy to put that fact again. Our lowest-paid workers have never seen a real-wage decrease under the coalition. Under Labor, the minimum wage was cut in real terms in three out of six years. Under the coalition, the minimum wage in Australia is the highest minimum wage in the world.

We are happy to receive questions day in, day out about the way in which our policies are benefiting every working Australian. When you look at wages and entitlements, we've done enormous work with the FWO. The Fair Work Ombudsman has received more than $60 million in additional funding in recent years. They are recovering 64 per cent more in lost wages and underpaid wages than when Labor was in office. And it is the case that we now have the lowest rate of welfare dependency since the 1980s. Whereas you moved hundreds of thousands of people from work into welfare, our government has moved hundreds of thousands of people from welfare into work. Our track record in ensuring that working Australians are better off than under the disastrous policies that you enacted is clear for all to see.
Energy

Dr McVEIGH (Groom) (14:26): My question is to the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction. Will the minister update the House on how the Morrison government is reducing power prices for hardworking Australians, including in my electorate of Groom? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

Mr TAYLOR (Hume—Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction) (14:26): I thank the member for Groom for his question. He lives in and supports one of the energy capitals of Australia: Toowoomba and surrounding areas. As this House knows, just a few hours ago we passed the 'big stick' legislation in this place. That legislation puts energy customers back in control. It stops the big energy rip-offs that we've seen in the past. The ACCC described the behaviour that has been going on in this market as unacceptable and unsustainable. This legislation deals with the distortion of and manipulation of the wholesale market, a failure to contract with small new entrants coming into the marketplace, and a failure to pass on substantial and sustained savings to customers, all of which will deliver a fairer deal on electricity for Australians.

But this is just one piece of our broader plan. On 1 July we put in place price caps, a default market offer on standing offers, which ensures that the most vulnerable Australians get a better deal on energy—up to $663 in New South Wales, for instance. We have also put into place the reference price, which ensures customers can choose the best plan for themselves on an apples for apples basis, and we have seen results. Already the ABS are telling us they're seeing downward pressure on prices.

But there is a risk. Those opposite are calling for a climate emergency. We know from the Greens what that means. It means no oil, no gas and no coal. It means no towers, no cars, no jobs and no idea from those opposite. That's why the member for Hunter and his merry band have said: 'Enough. It's time to join with the coalition and be bipartisan more broadly on these policies.' But the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Hindmarsh have taken a leaf out of Extinction Rebellion's book by gluing themselves to the Greens. That's right, 'Nigel no friends' over there, the member for Hindmarsh, declared a climate emergency on his own—
The SPEAKER: The minister can pause for a second.
An honourable member interjecting—

The SPEAKER: And that's exactly the problem. So ministers will refer to members by their correct titles; otherwise we're slipping back—well, I'm not; ministers are slipping back—into that habit and members of the opposition are. I'll take you back a year or so: the way I fixed this was simply to sit ministers down—and I'll starting doing it again—and it fixed it within a day. So take some corrective action.

Mr TAYLOR: Mr Speaker, I stand corrected. The member for Hindmarsh has found a friend: he's found the Greens! He's glued himself to the Greens, with this climate emergency. Whilst those opposite dither around, we get on with delivering our commitments to the Australian people.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The SPEAKER (14:30): I'd also like to inform members that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Chris Pearce, former member for Aston, former parliamentary secretary and former electoral neighbour of mine. Welcome, on behalf of everyone.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Vocational Education and Training

Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney) (14:30): My question is to the Prime Minister. Why did the Prime Minister say, 'We want to really lift the status of vocational education in Australia,' when the truth is that, under his government, there are now 150,000 fewer apprentices and trainees, the Australian Industry Group says that three-quarters of businesses surveyed can't find the qualified staff they need, and TAFE training and apprenticeship programs have been short-changed by nearly $1 billion?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister and Minister for the Public Service) (14:31): I've learnt from long experience with the member for Sydney never to take at face value any information—including on geography—that she presents to this House. The figures she refers to, regarding the spending of the government, she knows full well relate to estimates variations for a demand-driven project, and the only difference in expenditure from previous estimates relates to demand and the measures that are required to meet that demand. That member would also know that if that is the case, if there's an adjustment between a measure that is published at a particular amount and then demand is less than that, then the amount spent is less, and she would know that because, when she was Minister for Health, if that's the case, there was a $1½ billion underspend on hospitals, or there was a $1½ billion underspend on schools under the Labor Party, or a $500 million underspend on carers, or a $400 million underspend on veterans—
Ms Plibersek interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Sydney knows the rules on props.
Mr MORRISON: or, indeed, a $1.2 billion underspend on seniors, or a $350 million underspend on carers. She can come to this dispatch box and put these mistruths—
Ms Plibersek interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Sydney will cease interjecting.
Mr MORRISON: as an attempt to buy relevance and to seek to smear the government, but the facts just don't bear out what the member is saying.

When it comes to the serious issue, though—oh, as well—when it comes to the number of apprentices, we have that commitment to establish 80,000 additional apprentices, as we set out at the last election. We agree—and I would hope members opposite would agree, because I'm certainly making constructive progress with the state premiers and chief ministers of the territories—that our skills system needs big change, because it is not delivering the outcomes that we have wanted to achieve. These programs are run by the states and supported by the Commonwealth. We need a completely different approach to how we're doing this, and that's what we're working with the states and territories to achieve. I'm looking forward to our next round of COAG meetings.
Ms Plibersek interjecting—

Mr MORRISON: Mr Speaker, I'm happy to keep speaking over the interjections. She's asked the question. I'm happy to answer her. So we're going to continue to work constructively with the states and territories to reform our vocational education system.

The third point I'd make is this. When we came to government, we had to pick up the absolute debacle and mess of VET FEE-HELP. The figures, even the ones that the Leader of the Opposition is pointing to, referred to it, because the reason the number of people came off was that we fixed the VET FEE-HELP mess and were no longer paying people for courses they weren't doing and were being registered as being trained in. You see, on our side of the House, we want to get people actually trained for real jobs. (Time expired)
Infrastructure

Dr MARTIN (Reid) (14:34): My question is to the Minister for Population, Cities and Urban Infrastructure. Will the minister please update the House on how the Morrison government's stable and certain financial position is enabling us to deliver congestion-busting infrastructure across Australia this year, including in Western Sydney, which creates jobs and gets Australians home sooner and safer? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

Mr TUDGE (Aston—Minister for Population, Cities and Urban Infrastructure ) (14:34): Can I thank the member for Reid for her question and for her outstanding advocacy of Western Sydney. Because of our strong, stable, certain financial management, the government are able to invest a record $100 billion in infrastructure right across this country over the decade, which means that right now there are 130 major projects underway, supporting 50,000 people in work. One of those giant projects being supported is one I know the member for Reid is very supportive of, and that is the WestConnex project. To put the size of this project in perspective, this $17 billion project is more than double the investment, in today's dollars, than the investment into the iconic Snowy Mountains hydro scheme back in the day. That's just one of the giant projects that we're doing. And, as the member for Reid knows, we're halfway through the construction of this project in partnership with the New South Wales government and it is already making a massive difference for families in Western Sydney. As the member for Reid knows, if a resident is travelling from Parramatta to the CBD and back each day in peak-hour traffic, they are saving over five hours a week in travel time because of the work of the WestConnex project, and that's just one project.

In Western Sydney as well we have the giant Western Sydney Airport under construction as we speak. It's supporting 11,000 jobs in the construction phase, and 28,000 jobs will be supported in the delivery phase. Further afield, we've got the Inland Rail project—$9 billion. Coming up we have the Tullamarine rail in Melbourne, $5 billion; and fast rail to Geelong, $2 billion. All of these giant nation-building projects are able to be done because this government is able to manage the budget.

I am asked about alternatives, and the alternative is stark. When the Labor Party were last in government, for six long years, and the Leader of the Opposition was the transport minister for the entire time, they weren't able to invest at the same rate we are able to. They talked a lot about investing in nation-building projects but they couldn't deliver. When you look at WestConnex, for example, the member for Grayndler as transport minister said that this was vitally important for Western Sydney families but didn't invest a cent. When talking about the Western Sydney Airport, he actually said that we needed to start the work then, in 2009, but didn't invest a cent. In relation to Inland Rail, not a sod was turned. In relation to fast rail, he talked and he talked but, of course, it was the fast rail that never came. They were all talk, no action because they couldn't manage the finance. (Time expired)
Workplace Safety
Mr HUSIC (Chifley) (14:37): My question's to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Minister, how many workers have died in workplace accidents over the last year?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (14:38): I'll have to take the question on notice and provide the number but, of course, any number above zero is too many. This government takes enormously seriously those issues, and those are matters that are part of a very broad approach. Indeed, recently, at the ministerial council for ministers for industrial relations, those issues were front and centre, including the way in which laws around manslaughter could be better drafted or better enforced. It is a very serious matter. I apologise; I do not have the exact number to hand but I'll take the question on notice and get the answer for you.
Broadband

Mr RAMSEY (Grey—Government Whip) (14:38): My question is to the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts. Will the minister update the House on how the Morrison government's stable and certain approach to the rollout of the NBN is successfully connecting rural and regional Australia right now? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

Mr FLETCHER (Bradfield—Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts) (14:39): I do thank the member for Grey, who represents one of the really big electorates in this place. He knows, as do so many members on this side of the House, just how critical modern communication is to the people of regional and remote Australia so they can stay connected, they can stay safe, they can do business, their children can be educated and they can enjoy all the benefits of connectivity we take for granted in the cities.

Of course, on our side of the House, we are absolutely committed to rolling out communication services to regional and remote Australia. That's why it's so important that we've been able to take a stable and certain approach to the rollout of the National Broadband Network, in contrast to the alternative approach that I'm asked about, which was the chaotic mess we inherited from Labor when we came to government in 2013. After six years, Labor had spent $6.5 billion. There were barely 50,000 premises connected to the fixed-line network. Every target that Labor had set had been missed. By contrast, today over 10 million premises are able to connect, over six million premises are connected, and every week 35,000 premises are being connected, in contrast to the grand total of 50,000 that I mentioned Labor had achieved across six years.

Thanks to that stable management, we are also able to focus on getting better services in regional and remote Australia—services like Sky Muster, the satellite service. In the electorate of Grey, over 15,000 premises are able to be served. Recently, in Dubbo, I joined with the member for Parkes to launch Sky Muster Plus. Under this evolution of NBN satellite services, we now provide unmetered data for essential daily tasks such as accessing banking, health or government services, software updates and emails. None of this will count towards a household's monthly data allowance. That has been very well received in regional and remote Australia. Members of parliament on this side of the House don't live inside the goat's cheese circle, like most of the people on the other side of the House; they live in regional and remote Australia and they understand the needs of the people of regional and remote Australia. That is why we are tailoring the products delivered over the NBN to the needs of people in regional and remote Australia, including the new satellite service, Sky Muster Plus.
Mr Bowen interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for McMahon is warned.
Workplace Relations

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (14:42): My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Federal Court found Liberal Party member and donor Gerry Hanssen was driven by a blind hatred of unions when he blocked safety inspectors from a site where a worker had died. Can the minister confirm the only new penalty that the government currently has before the parliament for Gerry Hanssen is that he won't be allowed to run as a union official?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (14:42): All those people who breach the industrial laws of Australia should be prosecuted. They should go before the relevant courts and be fined and punished in accordance with the law, as of course was the case with Mr Hanssen. As the shadow minister knows well, the laws that we have placed in the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Amendment (Ensuring Integrity) Bill that apply to the disqualification of members of registered organisations as officials are designed to apply equally to organisations that represent employers and to organisations that represent employees. As the member knows, the changes in the ensuring integrity bill that go to the issue of a potential deregistration after evidence is put to a court via the Registered Organisations Commission and after their dutiful consideration of that evidence apply equally to organisations which are registered as employer associations or as employee organisations. The very point of those laws is to ensure lawful conduct of both employer and employee organisations according to the same standards.
Indigenous Australians

Ms HAMMOND (Curtin) (14:43): My question is to the Minister for Indigenous Australians. Will the minister outline to the House how the Morrison government's stable and certain economic management is helping to close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians by guaranteeing essential services?

Mr WYATT (Hasluck—Minister for Indigenous Australians) (14:44): I thank the member for Curtin, particularly given her former role as the Vice Chancellor of the University of Notre Dame Australia, where her work focused on creating opportunities for Indigenous people studying to go on and be successful in their careers and contribute to our economy. I also want to acknowledge the member for Kooyong and the member for Cook for the work they've done in establishing a strong budget to enable us to grow initiatives for Indigenous Australians. In the 2019-20 budget we confirmed $5.2 billion towards investment in key and critical areas that will make a difference to the lives of Indigenous Australians—areas of employment, job creation, educational opportunities and getting kids to school. That's what we're focused on. We're focused on making a difference in the lives of all Indigenous Australians across this nation.

The Indigenous Procurement Policy has resulted in 1,765 Indigenous businesses being extremely successful in taking on 16,460 contracts. That is $2.49 billion going into the pockets of Indigenous people who have established very successful businesses. But what they're doing is employing other Indigenous members within their communities. They are taking them off welfare dependency and creating job opportunities that are providing a tremendous way forward.

Equally, we're tackling suicide. The number of young Indigenous Australians committing suicide is far too high. What we're doing is investing in initiatives that will see a whole-of-community approach. What I've noticed in some of the reports is that school plays a critical part in the networks of connectivity. In the Kimberley coronial inquiry there were suicides occurring during the school holidays, which demonstrated the importance of our work in engaging our children in educational pathways from preschool through to tertiary studies. All of us are working in that direction, and a strong budget gives us the capacity to have the resources.

The Jabiru tourism venture, the work we have announced in terms of $40 million for tourism in Indigenous communities, will add to the work that we do collectively in this House to make a difference in Indigenous communities. But our continued work around our economy will give us greater capacity to make a difference on the ground in the way in which we provide opportunity. I want to see—collectively, we all want to see—success, because that is the way in which we will change the dynamic within Aboriginal communities. I thank those involved for the work that we are collectively doing.

Mr ALBANESE (Grayndler—Leader of the Opposition) (14:47): on indulgence—Labor stands with the government on recognising that Indigenous youth suicide rates are just horrific. We stand ready to partner with the government to support any initiatives to reduce that rate, as a matter of urgency.
Workplace Relations

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (14:47): My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Previously in the House, the minister refused to acknowledge that industrial action taken by unions against James Hardie on behalf of asbestos victims would have seen those unions potentially deregistered under the government's ensuring integrity bill, had it been in place. Why won't the minister admit his legislation would give companies like James Hardie a weapon to avoid scrutiny and get away with appalling behaviour?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (14:48): I wondered about that, because it's not true. It is patently false. Indeed, the falsehood of that goes back to, I believe, the ACTU media release that was released on the day the Manager of Opposition Business first asked these questions. That release, I recall, said something to the effect that the ensuring integrity bill would make it harder for individuals to get right of entry to workplaces to check for occupational health and safety concerns. That is 100 per cent false. Nothing in the ensuring integrity bill changes one iota of the law about the present rights to access workplaces for occupational health and safety reasons. That is a falsehood. It's that falsehood that forms the premise of the question the Manager of Opposition Business has just asked.

If we're talking about occupational health and safety, which we are in the subject matter of the question, one fascinating thing is that there's great concern for occupational health and safety shown by members opposite, yet they ignore the fact the Queensland Community and Public Sector Union, which has in its membership inspectors for occupational health and safety, has instructed its inspectors not to go to worksites where the CFMEU is present because of fear for those workers.
The SPEAKER: The Manager of Opposition Business, on a point of order.

Mr Burke: It's on direct relevance. There's no example the minister has gone to that in any way relates to the sorts of actions that were taken by unions with respect to James Hardie over asbestos victims.

The SPEAKER: I will say to the Manager of Opposition Business that some of the points he was seeking to make by way of interjection prior to raising the point of order weren't immediately clear in the question, and the minister can only answer the question he's been asked. What I'm really saying is: if you want him to be more specific on the points you were making in those interjections, you need to have been a bit more specific in the question. I've got a summary of the question, which went to a previous answer and then there was quite a general point about companies being able to get away with, I think you said, appalling or harmful activity.

Mr Burke: The question is specific. It's referring to the industrial action taken by unions against James Hardie. It's not referring to occupational health and safety inspections. It's referring to the industrial action that was taken after James Hardie had transferred their assets offshore.
The SPEAKER: And that's the point I was making.

Mr Burke: The assets offshore I respect, but there is nothing in the question that refers to right of entry on an occupational health and safety inspection. It's about the industrial action, which he hasn't referred to at all. That's what the entire question is premised on.
The SPEAKER: All right. I'll make two points. The Leader of the House and minister has been asked the question and given some context. The point about moving assets offshore—
An honourable member interjecting—

The SPEAKER: Someone says, 'You should know.' Well, if you want to ask a question, just ask the question. That's the simplest thing to do, whoever that was. That's not a good way to try and get ministers to answer something they weren't specifically asked.

Mr PORTER: Again, nothing in the ensuring integrity bill stops lawful industrial action. Nothing in the ensuring integrity bill prevents occupational health and safety inspectors from entering workplaces. But one thing that is stopping health and safety inspectors entering workplaces is the militant, bullying behaviour of the CFMEU, which members opposite refuse to call out, refuse to do anything about. The effect of that is that occupational health and safety inspectors in the Queensland public sector union will not go to 17 of the largest construction sites in Queensland. That displays the sort of concern that you have for the realities that these people are dealing with.
Mr Bowen interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for McMahon has already been warned.
Budget

Mr CONNELLY (Stirling) (14:52): My question is to the Minister for Veterans and Defence Personnel. Will the minister update the House on how the Morrison government's certain and stable budget position has helped to deliver essential services to veterans and their families?

Mr CHESTER (Gippsland—Minister for Veterans and Defence Personnel and Deputy Leader of the House) (14:53): I thank the member for Stirling for his question and I note his service in the Australian Army. I say to him, as I say to all members in this place on both sides of the chamber: thank you for your service.

Australians can be proud of the support we provide to our veteran community and their families. More than $11.5 billion in this year's budget will go towards supporting around 280,000 veterans and their families. It's due to the strong budget position that we've been able to have record investment in the transformation of the Department of Veterans' Affairs over the last three budgets. In fact, an additional $500 million has been provided to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for that transformation program, which has made it faster, easier and less stressful for the majority of veterans making their claims through the digitisation of records, which has been welcomed right throughout the ex-service community.

I say also that that strong budget has allowed for greater investment in mental health programs across our nation. In fact, $230 million per year is provided to support our veterans if they're suffering from mental illness or need some assistance of a professional nature. This government has been able to introduce free lifetime health care for all veterans and their families. For those veterans listening today who may be struggling with their own mental health, I encourage them to contact Open Arms on 1800011046.

I was also pleased to announce that during the election period and since that period there has been bipartisan support for the six new wellbeing centres that are being developed across our nation, many of them in the seats of members opposite as well as the crossbench, and several of them in seats of members on this side of the chamber. Also in this year's budget there was $16 million in additional funding to assist with veterans employment initiatives, working with the ex-service community. These are all initiatives that have been made possible through a strong budget position.

Just yesterday in this place we had bipartisan support for legislation that seeks to better recognise and offer respect to our veterans on a daily basis—not just on Anzac Day, not just on Remembrance Day but throughout the year. I was pleased to receive the support of those opposite in terms of the new veterans card, that nationally identifiable veterans card, which we made available to veterans throughout our nation; the Veterans' Covenant, which has had strong support right throughout the nation over the past 12 months; and the new veterans lapel pin. I'll be making the information about the distribution of the veterans lapel pin available to members opposite and members on this side of the chamber in the coming days—how they can be involved personally in the distribution of those pins in their own community if they wish to be involved. I realise, Mr Speaker, that props are unparliamentary, but in this case I would like to demonstrate to the House this new pin, which will be available for everyday public recognition of our veterans throughout the nation. It's a simple way that I think, as a community, members of parliament—
The SPEAKER: The minister's fine to display that. I don't regard it as a prop.
Mr CHESTER: we can all acknowledge our veterans on a daily basis and say to them, simply, 'Thank you for your service.'
Workplace Relations

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (14:56): My question's to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister has assured the House that the ensuring integrity bill would have no impact on a campaign like the one run by unions against James Hardie. Does the minister even know what actions the unions took to bring James Hardie to account?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (14:56): The member's completely mischaracterised the answer. What I've informed the House is that the ensuring integrity bill does absolutely nothing to prevent lawful protests, lawful strike, lawful entry to premises. What is it that members opposite are suggesting—that as a government we should accept any action at any time, even if that action breaks the law? That is what the opposition members are asking us to accept. That might explain why they have this passive acceptance of what the CFMEU does. That might explain why they are willing to accept $16 million in fines for the CFMEU. That might explain why they're willing to passively accept 2,164 offences by the CFMEU without ever taking action.

What our government has always said is that behaviour on worksites—with respect to workers' benefit fund bills—whether that is employee organisations or employer organisations, must be within the law. This bill ensures that there are appropriate standards in place, as there always should be, to ensure that organisations that repetitively break the law are placed before a court so that a court can make a determination as to whether it is just, in all the circumstances, for that organisation or a part of that organisation to be deregistered. And the only organisation in Australia that looks even close to meeting that important standard would be the organisation that you regularly accept enormous amounts of money from—that being the CFMEU.
Economy: Women

Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (14:58): My question is for the Minister representing the Minister for Women. Will the minister outline to the House how the Morrison government's stable and certain budget position is supporting women's services and economic security? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

Ms LEY (Farrer—Minister for the Environment) (14:58): I thank the member for Robertson for her question and acknowledge her past record in promoting women in positions of leadership and her ongoing role as a mentor in her electorate and here in the parliament. Australian women have benefited from the coalition government's success in growing an economy that creates jobs, pathways and careers and supports an education system that nurtures talent and ability, because part of managing the economy well is getting the best people in the workforce—the best person for the job—and women are a very big part of that. Our government is investing $151 million through the 2018 Women's Economic Security Statement to ensure that women are well positioned to play that full and equal role in every aspect of our economy. Nearly 1.5 million have been created since September 2013, and, importantly, most of these jobs have been taken up by women.

For example, in the recycling industry and the work we are doing with the circular economy, we know that for every 10,000 tonnes of waste recycled correctly there are nine new Australian jobs created, with more and more women entering that industry. That's fantastic. This morning I was sorry to miss the Women of Waste Leadership Breakfast held in Sydney, hosted by the Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association's dynamic CEO, Gayle Sloan. This event recognises women who are driving change in the industry, creating new career prospects for women coming up in the ranks.

Increasing opportunities across all industries for workforce participation helps build women's financial security and independence. Under the Morrison government, women's workforce participation is at a near record high of over 61 per cent. Over six million women are in employment. The average weekly ordinary time earnings for women increased 3.6 per cent just over the last year. And the gender pay gap is at a record low, with, of course, more work to do in this space.
Ms Plibersek interjecting—

Ms LEY: The member for Sydney continues to interrupt me. The member for Sydney's misunderstanding is the misunderstanding of the modern Labor Party, because women's policy covers all portfolios. But at its heart—at the heart of women's policy—is economic policy. You need employers, you need trade agreements, you need the small and medium enterprise business sector, you need jobs, you need lower taxes—you need so much more than just glib statements and glib slogans. They've got the slogans; we've got the plan—the plan and the commitment to carry it through.
Employment

Dr MULINO (Fraser) (15:02): My question is to the Prime Minister. When this government oversaw a cut in penalty rates, it said there would be more jobs. Will the Prime Minister now admit that penalty rate cuts have not created a single job?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister and Minister for the Public Service) (15:02): Mr Speaker, I don't accept the premise of the member's question. But I am asked about jobs. I have been asked about a matter that was actually determined by the Fair Work Commission—not by the government but by the Fair Work Commission—which was actually set up by the former Leader of the Opposition through an independent process. So I will leave those matters to the Fair Work Commission, which was actually set up by the Labor Party. But I'm asked about jobs. I'm asked about jobs, and I can confirm that almost 1.5 million jobs have been created by this government, by this government supporting a framework which means business can create jobs in our economy. We've done that by lowering taxes. We've done that by investing in infrastructure. We've done that by reducing the costs of doing business. We've done that by expanding the trade borders of this country, where we've gone from 26 per cent of what we export covered by our agreements to now 70 per cent.
The SPEAKER: The Manager of Opposition Business on a point of order?

Mr Burke: On direct relevance: if the Prime Minister wants to link that these figures are because of a penalty rate cut, then it would be completely relevant to the question. But he's not being relevant. The question is entirely with respect to both jobs and the penalty rate cut and the extent to which they are linked. The Prime Minister is simply reacting to one word and not being relevant to the question he's asked.

The SPEAKER: I will just say this was certainly a very tight question that talked about penalty rates. The reason I was hearing the Prime Minister is—without putting words into this mouth; I wouldn't want to do that—the area he was covering can, if the Manager of Opposition Business thinks about it for a bit, certainly be construed as his answer to the question about that topic. I will continue to hear him but remind him it was a very tight question about penalty rates and jobs.

Mr MORRISON: Thank you, Mr Speaker. The member for Watson seems to think that this chamber is some sort of debating society for 14-year-olds. I'm talking about people's real jobs and what our government is doing to support people getting jobs, and he wants to play semantics. I'll be very clear. No, we don't believe that the decision of the Fair Work Commission is the reason why Australians are getting jobs in this country. We think it's because we're lowering taxes; building infrastructure; putting trade policies in place, which those opposite have to be dragged kicking and screaming to the table to support; taking on big energy companies to ensure that companies and consumers can get a fair deal; and continuing to keep our budget under control so that we can support the essential services that Australians rely on.

Unemployment has fallen from 5.7 per cent to 5.2 per cent on the watch of this government. We've ensured that the participation rate has risen to a record high. Over the year to September 2013 there were 85,000 jobs. That's what happened under their watch over that period of time. Over the same period of time under our watch there were 311,600 jobs created. There are more full-time jobs and more part-time jobs—more jobs, more jobs, more jobs. That's what this government is doing. Those on that side took jobs away from people and they want to take more jobs away from people with their reckless policies and their higher taxes.

The shadow Treasurer served at the knee of Mr Swan and he presided over job wreckage. He's at one with the former Treasurer. He's 'Obi-Swan Kenobi'. As he looks up to his great mentor, with whom he merges, he hears him say: 'Use the taxes, Jimmy. Use the taxes.'
National Security

Mr GOODENOUGH (Moore) (15:06): My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs. Will the minister outline to the House the importance of the Morrison government's stable and certain approach to border security? Is the minister aware of any risks associated with alternative approaches?

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Home Affairs) (15:07): Mr Speaker, on indulgence, I want to quickly acknowledge Sonya Ryan, who is up in the gallery today. We've been doing a lot of work with Sonya and the Carly Ryan Foundation. Her story is a tragic one. Her beautiful 15-year-old daughter was befriended online by a male who made out that they were 18 years old. He turned out to be a 50-year-old sexual predator. He eventually lured Carly to a remote spot, and it resulted in a terrible tragedy. Sonya has now dedicated her life to keeping children, online and in real life, as safe as humanly possible. I want to thank her very much for the work that she is doing with the Federal Police and my department. Thank you.

I was asked about the very important issue of border protection. This government has been working day and night to keep our borders secure. We warned the Labor Party and the Greens that the passage of the medevac bill not too long ago would result in people coming to our country who posed—
The SPEAKER: Members on my left!
Ms Kearney: This is ridiculous!

The SPEAKER: I don't need the assistance of the member for Cooper. Just stop the clock for a second. I say to the minister—and I should have addressed this in an earlier answer he gave—you are entitled to be asked about the government's policy and answer that and you are entitled to be asked about the alternatives and answer that, but I don't think you can go to the alternatives without having outlined the government's policy, otherwise it is the alternative to what?
Honourable members interjecting—

The SPEAKER: That's my ruling. I'm going to make it very clear because I'm not going to have grumbles on either side. If a minister is asked what the government's approach is and then what the alternative to it is, it's very hard to say what the alternative to it is if you haven't outlined what the government's approach is. You're left responding to something that you haven't addressed.
Mr DUTTON: Mr Speaker, I'm very happy to deal with it sequentially.
The SPEAKER: I haven't called you. I don't decide the order in which the questions are asked. He's entitled to answer both, but there has to be a structure to it. The minister has the call.

Mr DUTTON: As the Australian public knows, the border protection policies of this government are clear and consistent, they're stable and certain and they were endorsed at the last election. They're well known. If we're talking about alternative approaches, those opposite have presided over disaster for a long period of time—
The SPEAKER: The minister will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition, on a point of order?
Mr Albanese: It goes to the dignity of the House.

The SPEAKER: The Leader of the Opposition will need to resume his seat. I made my ruling clear; the minister responded to that. I didn't say that he had to go for exactly half the time; he had to address the substance. The minister has the call.

Mr DUTTON: As we know, under the legislation passed by those opposite, we've had people now who have come not for medical reasons. Frankly, it's a con. It's a backdoor way into Australia that the Labor Party were warned about at the time. They can feign all the indignation they want, but the fact is that—
The SPEAKER: The minister will resume his seat.
MOTIONS
Minister for Home Affairs
Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (15:10): I move:
That the Member be no longer heard.
The SPEAKER: The question is that the Minister for Home Affairs be no further heard.

body.p:
The House divided. [15:15]
(The Speaker—Hon. Tony Smith)

p.span: National Security
The SPEAKER (15:18): The Minister for Home Affairs has the call.

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Home Affairs) (15:19): The government has introduced into the parliament the Transport Security Amendment (Serious Crimes) Bill 2019, and we would expect the Labor Party to support this because it is a very important part of keeping criminals away from our airports and away from our seaports. The Labor Party has previously rejected this legislation.

The reason this legislation is needed is that, in Australia at the moment, we have 277 security card holders at airports and seaports who either have an association with an outlaw motorcycle gang or are on the National Criminal Target List. We know that the National Criminal Target List reads like a who's who of the CFMMEU, but the fact is that we cannot allow these people into secure areas. The Labor Party opposed this legislation in the past, but, if they are serious about securing our borders, they need to put that opposition into the past and support us.

We know that there are serious links between outlaw motorcycle gangs and the CFMMEU, and that is the reason why the Labor Party would oppose this position. Who do we know in the CFMMEU? We know Mr John Setka. He had this to say earlier today about the Leader of the Opposition:
Mr Albanese claims I have brought the ALP into disrepute. Nothing has hurt the Labor Party's reputation like Mr Albanese's leadership over the past 5 months.
Now, that is a pretty insightful remark from a criminal, wife-bashing thug whose donations the Labor Party is still happy to receive to this very day.
Mr Morrison: I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
Industrial Relations
Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (15:20): I seek indulgence to add to an answer provided earlier today.
The SPEAKER: The Leader of the House may proceed.

Mr PORTER: With respect to the question from the member for Chifley on workplace deaths, the figures I've been provided with show that, as at 10 October 2019, there were 121 deaths in Australian workplaces in 2019. That's the year to date. In 2018, the data, which is preliminary, to be confirmed, showed there were 144 workplace deaths, and the number which is final data for the 2017 calendar year is 119.
DOCUMENTS
Presentation

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (15:21): Documents are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable members earlier today. Full details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
Workplace Relations
The SPEAKER (15:21): I have received a letter from the honourable member for Watson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The Government’s failure to look after the interests of Australian workers.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

span.span: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

p.span: Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (15:22): The government have been keen to give answers in question time and speeches to the House concerning lawlessness, and they often want to rush to the chamber reporting on what the Federal Court has had to say. Funnily enough, when the Federal Court made a decision roughly 10 days ago regarding raids, where the media turned up before the Federal Police did, that Federal Court decision never found its way into the parliament. That Federal Court decision isn't one of the ones that the minister decided he needed to tell us about. Why? Because the form of lawlessness that had been uncovered was lawlessness from the Registered Organisations Commission itself.

We have a Federal Court decision which had to take place because the Registered Organisations Commission had commenced an investigation that was found to be beyond their power—an investigation that was found to be unlawful. What's the government's response when the Registered Organisations Commission does something unlawful?
Mr Stephen Jones: Crickets.

Mr BURKE: Behind me, people are saying 'Is it crickets? Is it quiet?' It's actually worse than that. Their response is to say, 'Let's give them more power.' If an organisation created by this government is acting unlawfully and is doing so in a way which is unlawfully acting against unions, its response is to give the organisation more power. There's lawlessness from the government's friends. The Registered Organisations Commission is not the only example of it. There's the ABCC. We had Nigel Hadgkiss, the leader of that, go when he had breached the act. What was his breach? He was telling employers to break the law. He was telling employers to break the law—that's how he broke the law. So those opposite keep wanting to give that organisation more power as well. Gerry Hanssen is a big donor to the WA Liberal Party. This is not someone who has bought a few raffle tickets. We are talking $175,000 to the federal and WA Libs and Nats over the last five years or so. In 2008, he was fined $174,000 for exploiting foreign workers. A decade later, an auditor alleged 93 employees were underpaid by him more than $270,000, an amount of money even bigger than what he donates to the Liberal Party. What's the punishment for him under these laws? It's not just that he's underpaying people; it's after there was a death on his worksite that he blocked an occupational health and safety inspection from a union. And what was the government's response? Oh, well, there will be a punishment for him; he won't be allowed to be a union official. That's the punishment. That's the new law that's responded.

I don't know if those opposite appreciate it but the public are onto the fact their attack on unions is simply an attack on workers. That's all it is. When you defend the people who underpay, you attack workers. When you defend the organisations that attack unions, that are responsible for arguing for better pay, you attack workers. Every time, they block and support their Liberal-donor mates who block access for health and safety inspections.

Even today, we had the minister wanting to go straight from James Hardie to health and safety inspections, to desperately talk about another issue. But everything those opposite want to do is about blocking access to safer workplaces and better remuneration for workers and that is the simplicity of the strategy coming from the government. It's no accident that those opposite voted for the changes to penalty rates.

Every time the Prime Minister says, 'An independent agency made that decision,' we know how the government deal with independent agencies. When there was an independent agency meant to make sure that truck drivers had safe rates of pay and those opposite didn't like the decision the independent agency made, they didn't just abolish the decision; they abolished the entire agency. But here, when a decision is made that they support, they back it in every time. And the reason they supported it was because it meant less pay for workers—simple as that.

If lawlessness was in fact the issue for those opposite, if lawlessness was something they wanted to act on, they would have abolished the Registered Organisations Commission, they would have deregistered 7-Eleven as a company and they would have prevented Gerry Hanssen and a series of celebrity chefs from employing people in the future. The question I have is: if someone is in breach of the law and therefore should not be able to do that job again, how come every single person engaged in wage theft goes on to continue to employ people and probably rip them off again? Why does that happen? Why do we get no response there?

We got these sudden thundering comments from the minister today. I think we were onto it that he has no idea what happened in the James Hardie dispute, absolutely no idea. If he thinks that the problem there was unlawful industrial action, well, he's following a fine tradition of members of the Liberal Party from his state in spending a whole lot of their time defending James Hardie against asbestos victims. The former member for Curtin had a proud record of it as well. What happened in the James Hardie dispute was the actions taken by the unions were not during an official bargaining period. They were not actions that would have ticked the box of authorised industrial action. It was a series of actions that would have breached section 28G of the legislation in front of us right now, the ensuring integrity bill, where the test is an entire union can be deregistered, whether or not their action—unless it was protected in the act, which none of this was—interfered with the activities of a federal system employer. Well, of course it did! And it needed to. They engaged in an escalating series of protests, work stoppages, work bans and boycotts, as well as marches, investor activism and political lobbying. But, had they not engaged in the work stoppages, the work bans and the boycotts, James Hardie would have got away with it. James Hardie would have got away with the massive transfer of funds offshore to make sure that people who were dying of asbestosis never got the compensation they deserved.

I thought maybe we would have got a better response last week, when we had victims of asbestosis in the gallery and we told the government they were there. And what was the response? The minister goes off on his rant about the CFMMEU, and the Prime Minister, sitting in that chair—after I'd pointed to exactly where they were sitting—swings his chair to face the minister and turns his back on them. We often talk about this government turning its back on workers, but you rarely get a demonstration of what this government is all about—when there are people who, if ensuring integrity legislation had been in place at the time, never would have been eligible for compensation. The money would have gone offshore and James Hardie would have got away with it had those union protests not happened.
Mr Pitt: That's rubbish.

Mr BURKE: And, please, the response over there is: 'That's rubbish; that wouldn't have happened.' The people on your side were acting for James Hardie—acting for James Hardie—and it was the unions that took the action that made sure people ended up getting compensation and James Hardie was held to account.

Now, let's not pretend that the James Hardie issue is in the distant past and it's never going to happen again. We know that, as long as there are employers like Gerry Hanssen, as long as there are operations like those we saw with some of the franchisees of 7-Eleven, as long as there are employers like TV celebrity chefs who make millions of dollars for themselves but, because of the complexity, they claim, of industrial relations, even though they comply with all the volumes of tax law they can't check an award to make sure they're paying people the right amount, as long as employers like that exist, there will be a need for employee representation. This government, in attacking employee representation, is attacking workers. It's part of the low-wage strategy that is a deliberate design feature of this government.

Mr TEHAN (Wannon—Minister for Education) (15:32): Nothing gives me more pleasure than to speak on this MPI about how this government is looking after the interests of Australian workers. And we are doing that in a way that we know the best interests of workers are served—by ensuring that they have a job. No government has an employment record like this government does. Under the Morrison government, the number of Australians in work is at a record high. Almost 13 million Australians are now in work. It's worth repeating that: almost 13 million Australians are now in work. Almost 1.5 million more Australians are in jobs since the coalition was elected in September 2013.

Then there is the record to end all records. We have seen 36 months of continuous monthly jobs growth to September 2019, the longest period of continuous monthly jobs growth since records began. What an extraordinary record. It is something that everyone on this side of the House should be extraordinarily proud of, because the greatest thing that we can do as a government is ensure that every Australian worker, where possible, has a job, and we are doing that and we are delivering—36 months of continuous monthly jobs growth, the longest period of continuous monthly jobs growth since records began.

We've seen a record level of Australians in full-time work, with almost 60 per cent of all new jobs created being full-time jobs. Full-time employment is at a record high of 8.8 million workers. We have a near-record-high participation rate of over 66 per cent and a record-high female participation rate. Wherever you look, the government is delivering for Australian workers, and we will continue to do that because it is our primary focus.

When Labor left office in September 2013, unemployment was at 5.7 per cent and rising, having risen from 4.4 per cent when they came into office in November 2007. You don't hear them talk about that much, do you? Their unemployment rate was climbing when they were in office. An extra 205,300 people joined the unemployment queues under Labor. In the last 12 months of Labor, full-time employment fell by 19,700. Under the coalition, unemployment has fallen to 5.2 per cent as of September 2019. We are happy, every day of the week, to contrast our performance with theirs, and we will continue to do that until the next election. Labor failed working Australians, yet we have this MPI today. Under six years of Labor the jobless queues grew by around 206,000. Across Labor's time in office, around 127,000 manufacturing jobs—around one in every eight—disappeared completely. This is a sad stat: under Labor, youth unemployment increased from 9.6 per cent in November 2007 to 12.6 per cent in September 2013. Young workers, when they left school, were faced with the prospect of unemployment. Not only were they faced with the prospect of unemployment; Labor cut over $1.2 billion from employer incentives in just two years. The number of apprenticeships and trainee commitments fell by 85,000 in a single year in 2012-13, the greatest fall in history.
Mr Irons: Huge.

Mr TEHAN: I know the member sitting here next to me will have a lot more to say on this, but that is the greatest fall in history. We had to fix up the rorting. We had to fix up VET FEE-HELP. They failed dismally. $241.3 million in incentives were cut in Labor's 2013 economic statement. This was the record that we were still trying to fix. Since 2016, over 37,000 students have had VET FEE-HELP loan debts recredited by the Commonwealth. That's 37,000 students, who are often vulnerable, with a cost to the taxpayer of repairing this disastrous program totalling just under $250 million. Look at our side and contrast. We have, at the moment, more people in work and fewer people on welfare than in over 30 years. That is our record: record jobs growth, fewer people on welfare, more people on work.

The member opposite, as part of this MPI, mentioned looking after workers and donations. One set of donations that he failed to mention were donations by the CFMMEU. How much have they totalled, Member for Watson? Was there any mention of that? Since 2013, I'm advised, it is $4 million. Do we hear reference to that? 'The most recidivist corporate offender in Australian history' is what Justice Vasta had to say, yet we hear nothing from you with regard to those donations. Sure, you'll look at an individual donation to try to make your point, but over $4 million and you will do nothing about the CFFMEU. You are a disgrace.
Ms Kearney: CFMMEU.

Mr TEHAN: Sorry, I said two Fs and one M; I should have said two Ms and one F. You are right. The point, though—and I would hate to get distracted—is the $4 million in donations that we never, ever hear mentioned.

Let's look at what's happened with wages growth. The latest ABS wage price index increased by 2.3 per cent over the year to the June quarter 2019—up from a 2.1 per cent increase over the year to the June quarter 2018. The ABS Average Weekly Earnings publication showed that total weekly earnings for full-time and part-time employees increased by 2.5 per cent over the year to May 2019. The most recent ABS Characteristics of Employment publication showed that median earnings for employees increased by 5.4 per cent over the year to August 2018—the largest increase since 2005. Wage increases continue to outpace increases in cost of living, and, importantly, living standards also continue to increase, with real net national disposable income per capita rising one per cent to be 2.7 per cent higher through the year. We are supporting wages growth. The government is setting the right conditions for a strong economy and jobs growth. In particular, a healthy labour market will help drive wages growth for workers. This is why our employment record is so critical.

I thank the member for Watson for this MPI, because it enables us on this side to talk about our record of providing jobs for workers. That is the single most important thing that any government can do. Our record surpasses that of any government when it comes to what we are doing in creating employment in this country, and we will continue to make sure our focus is on creating jobs. We want to build on that extraordinary record where we have seen 36 months of continuous monthly jobs growth—the longest period of continuous monthly jobs growth since records began.
