Do you know what that jobs growth enables us to do? It enables us to provide the essential services that the Australian people need. That's why we can make sure that funding is there for the NDIS. It's why we can ensure that funding is there for health. It's why we can ensure that funding is there for each occasion. We're going to continue to grow the economy. We're going to continue to make sure the budget is in balance. We're going to make sure that we continue to deliver jobs growth for this country, because it is vital for workers and the provision of services.

Ms KEARNEY (Cooper) (15:42): I am very pleased to rise to speak on this matter of public importance today, because this government's failure to look after the interests of Australian workers is an outrage. It seems that every day brings a new opportunity for them to attack working people around the country, whether it be their ensuring integrity bill—which seeks to give any interested party the ability to have a union deregistered—or their failure to address the scourges of insecure work or how they've turned their backs on more than eight per cent of working people who are underemployed or the number of workplace deaths.

The fact is that working people simply aren't this government's priority. Not only does the government ignore the issues facing working people, not only do they turn their backs whilst wages are stagnant and working families are finding it harder and harder to make ends meet, but they actively work to make it harder for them. They've put in place policies that suppress wages growth—Senator Cormann said so—like cutting funding from TAFE and skills training programs that help workers get higher skilled jobs or voting to cut penalty rates. Not only that; they make it harder for workers to organise, to collectively bargain for pay rises, when everybody knows the economy is screaming out for a pay rise.

I've worked in my role as ACTU president with teachers, shop assistants, care workers, kindergarten teachers, childcare workers, aged-care workers, pharmacists, doctors and hairdressers. They all rely on the collective power of their unions, who work tirelessly for their members. Thousands of union organisers are out every day in workplaces, trying to protect their members and get their members pay rises. I come from a great union, the mighty Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation, that fights for nurses, for the public health system, for their patients' rights. They took unprotected action not for pay rises, not for better conditions, but for workloads to protect their patients so that they could deliver safe care. Under these new laws, as the Manager of Opposition Business described before with James Hardie, they could be deregistered—that great union that has done great things for our health system. This government put the blame for their shoddy policies on unions—the only way workers get a pay rise.

The classic chant at a union rally goes: 'When workers' rights are under attack, what do we do? Stand up, fight back.' It is no wonder this government is afraid of unions. Under this government, workers' rights are constantly under attack. Working people in this country are having to worry about whether they'll have a shift tomorrow, whether their jobs will be outsourced or offshored, whether they'll be able to pay the bills or whether their contracts will be renewed. We will have almost a whole generation of workers who won't know what it's like to have a paid holiday. They are fighting back against wage theft, insecure work and the exploitation of workers in the gig economy. Unions are fighting against sham contracting, out-of-control casualisation and the exploitation of migrant workers. The government talks about the lawlessness of the union movement while the union movement fights daily against employer lawlessness. They're fighting against employers whose business models are based on lawlessness and whose profits are driven by undercutting people's rights. They fight against bodies like the ROC or the ABCC. In the presentation given by the Manager of Opposition Business before, we heard exactly what that means.

If this government is looking for lawlessness, it doesn't need to look any further than its own regulatory bodies to find it. But, instead, it's spending taxpayer money on pursuing unions and working people. Every week we hear of more employers doing the wrong thing—ripping off workers or putting their lives at risk. Thousands of workers all over the country are affected, yet those opposite come into this chamber, time after time, with bills like 'ensuring integrity' and 'protecting workers' entitlements' and bang on about the same things over and over.

The union movement is the largest organisation in this country, with nearly two million paid-up members, and I'm telling you that that's bigger than the Liberal Party. And I ask those opposite: do you really think that the people in those unions don't understand what these bills are about? Working people in this country know what's up. They know that their unions are fighting for them and that your government is doing nothing of the sort. If you genuinely cared about working people or working families, you'd be acting on wage stagnation. You'd be trying to ensure that people are being paid the superannuation they deserve. You'd stop treating union members and union officials like criminals, because they're the ones who are standing up for working people, while you continue to erode their rights and protect the real criminals. You are failing to look after the interests of Australian workers. You're actively working against them.

Mr IRONS (Swan—Assistant Minister for Vocational Education, Training and Apprenticeships) (15:47): I rise to speak on the MPI. I hear the members on the other side talking about lawlessness. I've had a few personal experiences with the lawlessness of unions. I didn't even hear the member for Watson mention the name of the MPI he put on the Notice Paper. He didn't mention it once during his whole 10-minute speech. But let's get back to my experience with unions, now that you've raised it.
Mr Burke: You don't need to move it; it's an MPI. It's read out by the Speaker. There are standing orders.

Mr IRONS: Thank you. I can hear him interjecting and saying I was right. He didn't mention it once during his speech. My personal experience with unions and their lawlessness requires a bit of family history—the member for Watson may be aware of it. The union that my uncle was the secretary of was the Painters and Dockers Union in Melbourne. I understand that no member in this place would say they weren't lawless. They were definitely lawless. Anyone here who's read any books on it—whether it be on Billy 'The Texan' Longley or all the people involved in the unions at that stage—knows that that is the finest example of union lawlessness that Australia has ever seen. But we never hear from the opposite side about how perfect the unions are, because they know they can't use those sorts of examples. I worked for Gas and Fuel in Victoria at one stage and was forced to be a member of part of a union. The union had a meeting one night to which six delegates turned up. The union proposed that all the overtime bans would be put onto all the members—all the people who worked and relied on those overtime efforts every Sunday. Every second Sunday we used to work for Gas and Fuel and every member of that particular employer was able to get overtime. But the six delegates from the union said, 'We are going to ban overtime.' They called another meeting—an extraordinary meeting—and over 1,000 people turned up and defied the unions—they defied the unions taking the extra money off them that they earned each week because they wanted to rule the roost and take over. We never hear about those examples from that side.

Also, in another company I worked for, we had a national transport company doing work for us across the nation. The unions then imposed a $20-a-week pay rise on that particular transport company and, because of that, directly put over 200 people out of work. So that's the work of the unions—the unions who 'stand up for people' across Australia. They want to take away our benefits and they also want to take away the jobs of people, because what they say has to be followed.

We heard the A-G in here during question time. He also talked about the minimum wage. We heard about the wages and looking after their interests. He also mentioned that the minimum wage has increased by a total of 9.8 per cent in the last three years, far in excess of inflation. Also, our lowest paid workers have never seen a real wage decrease under the coalition, but, under Labor, the minimum wage was cut, in real terms, in three out of six years. Under the coalition's stewardship, the minimum wage is now the highest in the world.

We heard the member for Watson, towards the end of his speech, talk about underpayment of wages. I agree: underpayment of wages by employers is a terrible thing. It shouldn't happen—it shouldn't be done by anyone at all. This government has zero tolerance of any exploitation of workers. That includes the underpayment of wages and entitlements by any employer.

It is the coalition that has put in place stronger protections for Australian workers and their entitlements. We have taken unprecedented action to date to protect vulnerable workers, including over $60 million in additional resources and more powers for the regulator, the Fair Work Ombudsman, as well as increasing penalties against law-breaking employers up to tenfold. As we speak, this government is drafting legislation to introduce criminal penalties for the first time for the worst forms of worker exploitation—one of the key recommendations of the Migrant Workers Taskforce.

We, on this side of the House, have committed to further improving the system. We know that the vast majority of employers try to do the right thing by their workers, but it's important that we have a strong deterrent for the minority of employers who deliberately exploit their staff. That's why we have released a discussion paper focused on identifying further improvements to provide protections of employees' wages and entitlements.

The government has supported the Fair Work Ombudsman, the FWO, with over $60 million in additional funding in recent years, including $20 million in the 2019-20 budget, to conduct more investigations relating to underpayments and sham contracting and to take action to deter noncompliance, and I'm sure the members on that side of the House would agree that that's what needs to be done to protect against underpayments. This government will provide stability and certainty to workers and their entitlements all across Australia, and we're the only government that will do that.

Mr HAYES (Fowler—Chief Opposition Whip) (15:52): I think the member for Watson is right: this government has failed working Australians. Just think about it: when was the last time you heard anybody on that side of the parliament talk, in a positive way, about the role of the trade union movement? They never talk about the role of unions in society. They never talk about what workers do to protect wages. And they certainly don't talk about what unions do with respect to safety—although, I'll give it to you: you are going to talk about the CFMMEU, and I will come back to that, about safety.

By the way, the Attorney-General also was right today—I know because I went and checked his figures. Up to October this year, there have been 121 workplace deaths. Seventy per cent of those deaths occurred in the building and construction industry, the transport industry and the mining industry. So, when you're talking about the CFMMEU, make sure you actually use those figures. When we're talking about workplace deaths in those areas of operation, the Transport Workers Union, the CFMMEU and other building and construction unions are in the most difficult, most dangerous workplaces. So, having two sons who work in those industries, I don't mind having an extra pair of eyes looking out for their safety, and I think most parents of tradies would probably take the same view.

Let us just look at this government's record when it comes to industrial relations. The Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison government couldn't wait to put $250 million into a royal commission into trade unions—$250 million. They were going to smash the union movement. They were going to expose all the excesses of power. Do you know how many prosecutions emerged out of that? Not one. This was all a political exercise. They've brought down a raft of anti-worker legislation. They're making it very hard. They could have actually joined with Labor to save the penalty rates of 700,000 of our lowest paid workers in the hospitality and retail industries—and I commend the work of Gerard Dwyer and the SDA to try to protect those workers—but where were they when this debate was going on? They were lost.

We saw what occurred in respect of the AWU raid. As the member for Watson indicated, not only was the actual investigation an excess of power but the staff of the minister responsible actually briefed the media about a police raid that was about to occur in Sydney. They walked away from that. No wonder she hid behind a whiteboard for weeks! Now we see what they want to do with the 'ensuring integrity' bill. They want to make it easier to deregister unions and to disqualify union officials, who are there to stand up for workers. I suppose I should let the other side in on a secret: there is no God-given right for unions to exist; it's not some form of divine mandate. Unions exist only to fulfil a need, and that need is to represent workers. If there were no need out there, employers were doing the right thing and governments over there were ensuring that workplaces were properly protected, there probably wouldn't be a union movement.
Mr Simmonds: Except they need to fund the Labor Party.
Mr Burke: You know you can't interject from there. You'll be named.

Mr HAYES: I'll take the interjection. Unions actually do exist to fulfil a need. If you did more, you would lessen that need. There's one other thing I want to talk about. We have bipartisan support for something that was called the Industrial Relations Commission, at least I thought we did. It started as the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It had representation from people from union backgrounds and people from employer backgrounds. When we were in government, there used to be an appointment from each side to ensure that there was fairness, decency and balance in their decisions. This year the head of Fair Work Australia asked the government for one extra appointment. They appointed six, all from the employer side—
Mr Irons: Didn't you appoint him?

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): The member for Ryan is in the incorrect position in the chamber and he will be removed if he utters another word from there.

Mr HAYES: I went back and I checked. The last 20 consecutive appointments to Fair Work Australia all came from the employer side. When you think about it, they have removed fairness and decency from our industrial relations system, which was designed to protect workers. That's their track record. That's what they think of workers. There's nothing about fairness and decency in the way they've acted.

Mr PITT (Hinkler) (15:57): First and foremost I agree with some of the most recent comments from the previous member. I've described them this way before and I'll do it again: unions are a necessary evil, just like banks. They do play a role. They are an important part of what happens in the industrial relations system, just as employer organisations are. Over a long period of time they've genuinely done some good things. I was here for the contribution from the member for Watson, and I genuinely like the member for Watson. It's rare that I'll stand here and give advice, but I'll give him some advice on this: be very careful about politicising fatalities in workplaces. I spent some time, when my hair wasn't grey, as a principal inspector, and I know those individuals who are out there every single day, every week, every month and every year getting called to workplaces to investigate incidents where people have been very seriously injured or lost their lives. We in this place should all be incredibly cautious about how we look at these issues. Individuals around the country are distinctly affected.

This brings me to my next point. I know the individuals who do this type of work. They are ex-tradespeople, ex-engineers, ex-construction workers, ex-nurses, ex-union officials—it doesn't really matter. They are doing an incredibly difficult job at a time when those workplaces are in absolute crisis. They are not wilting wallflowers. These are individuals who go onto some pretty heavy-duty construction sites and deal with some roughnecks, I have to say, and they have done so for a long period of time. Yet on 30 January 2019 we saw a report in Queensland's Courier-Mail that says:
The … Government's own … inspectors are so fearful of "occupation violence" from unions and workers they are refusing to attend 17 construction sites across Queensland.

That is in no-one's interest. These people are highly skilled at identifying challenges and problems and ensuring they are fixed. So, regardless of what we are doing here in this debate, we need to ensure that those individuals can continue to do their jobs, and I'd say to everyone in the chamber that is what we need to be doing because this is about ensuring that no-one loses their life on a worksite. Once again, I will acknowledge the member for Cooper's genuine work for the union movement and her absolute commitment over a long period of time. If we look at asbestos, and this seems to be the topic of the day, standards around asbestos—working with it, the removal of it, getting rid of it from workplaces—have genuinely improved over a long period of time with consultation between unions and employers, and we need to continue to do that.

I would say to those opposite, who are calling us out saying we don't look after workers, that we're not interested in workers and that we don't do things for them, I will give you some examples. Mr Deputy Speaker Hogan, I know you were involved in this. You were interested and you certainly worked hard to make sure we had a solution to the exploitation of foreign workers, particularly in horticulture. We have a real problem with these issues across the country. But what happened? We on this side actually did something about it. We established Taskforce Cadena, a multijurisdictional task force which cracked down on those bad seeds in the industry, ensured there were prosecutions and protected workers. What did those opposite do? They had another inquiry. That's what they did when they were in government—another inquiry with no real action.

When we are talking about looking after workers, the government are absolutely doing those things and we are acting in their interests. Labor, when last in government, cut the staff from Fair Work by 20 per cent. How does that ensure you have fair workplaces and can crack down on foreign worker exploitation and on individuals not being paid the correct wages and superannuation? Let's face facts: that is absolutely what happens. If you don't have that oversight, if you don't have the enforcement, if you don't have these inspectors, if you don't do that work then individuals will take advantage of the system.

What we know is we are doing things for workers in this country. We are ensuring that workplaces are as safe as possible. We need to be very careful with our rhetoric in this place when we're discussing those types of issues. We know what happens on the other side. We have a Labor Party now that are completely lost as to what they stand for. You only have to look at Deputy Premier Trad in Queensland, who went out, stood in front of a microphone and said to every single worker in the resources industry that they need to transition out of their job. The best thing we can do for any individual in this country is ensure they're employed and that they have long-term jobs they're committed to, that are highly skilled, well paid and go on until they are ready to retire. It's how they pay for their families, it's how they pay for their kids to go to school, it's how they pay for their house and their needs, and we need to ensure that that continues. Those opposite are completely lost. They no longer stand for working people any more, and I think that is a great shame.

Mr DAVID SMITH (Bean) (16:02): Six years into the Morrison government, we know they have no economic plan, no plan to turn this economy around and no plan to improve growth across the economy. However, what we do know is that this Liberal-National government are no friend of Australian workers and they love to talk down the organisations of workers. Just in the last speech, they talked about worker organisations being a necessary evil. We had no greater evidence of this government not being a friend of Australian workers than the extraordinary responses from the Attorney-General in question time today in relation to questions on James Hardie and Gerry Hanssen. This government often talks about lawlessness in Australian workplaces. You won't be surprised to hear the party of Work Choices is not interested in lawlessness that involves wage theft, is not interested in laws that protect workers and is not interested in laws that assist in building better workplaces.

I spent most of my working life in the labour movement, working with police on the beat, in counterterrorism, in close personal protection, with the Federal Police Union and with engineering and science professionals across the public and private sector with Professionals Australia and APESMA. The intent of members in those unions was always to make their workplaces better. They wanted their organisations to be successful. Describing those organisations in any sense as evil is absolutely outrageous.

For the last six years, as an employer of so many of these great Australians, this government has waged war against its own workforce's pay and conditions, the security of their employment and the value of their work. It's no surprise that wages have stagnated when this government has led the way in suppressing wage growth across Australian government employment. It has tried to silence dissent and gag whistleblowers. It has undermined the certainty and stability of the public sector workforce through relentless outsourcing and labour hire. Expertise across all levels of government has been eroded. The growth of conflicts of interest at every level in the Public Service has been led by a government that has effectively shredded a meaningful Ministerial Code of Conduct. Morale and productivity in these workplaces have dropped through the floor. This what is this Liberal government is like as an employer. This is how it leads by example. We shouldn't be surprised that this is its approach to the rest of the workforce as well.

Sometimes you hear of taking an 'all care and no responsibility' attitude. This government have a 'no care and no responsibility' attitude. While they are prepared to undermine the rights of workers across the country, they have a particular agenda to target the most vulnerable in the workforce. Those opposite won't stand up for workers against weak regulation, but they also won't stand up to improper regulation. As the member for Watson said earlier, in the case of the Registered Organisations Commission, it was found they did not have reasonable grounds to launch the investigation into the Australian Workers Union. It's actual lawlessness from one of their own organisations—an organisation they wish to empower greatly through the ensuring integrity legislation.

This government is absolutely missing in action when it comes to standing up to lawlessness across our workplaces. It's not tackling wage theft and not appropriately dealing with repeat offenders. Workers must be paid what they're owed under Australian law. It's incumbent on employers of any size to make sure they understand their obligations under the Fair Work Act. Yet this government attempts to blame the award system for recent examples of wage theft. It's pathetic. The award system has been with us for generations. It's not a recent invention. In fact, LNP governments have simplified them to the extent that even those opposite can understand them.

It's simply not good enough for employers to take seriously their compliance with tax laws, planning laws and health and hygiene laws and then disregard legal obligations to their own workers. Wage theft is employer lawlessness, nothing less. The current attack from this government will only lead to more wage theft as unions are caught up in red tape rather than ensuring that Australian workers are treated fairly.

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (16:08): This is the sort of matter of public importance motion that you get from an organisation that is controlled by another organisation that has the respect of only 15 per cent of the total workforce and only nine per cent in the private sector. But it's an organisation that nonetheless owns 100 per cent of a political party. The Australian Labor Party are, were and always have been the political wing of the trade union movement. This has real consequences for the country and for the rule of law in particular. They look at the CFMMEU, with its beatings, and say, 'Nothing to see here.' They look at the CFMMEU, with its intimidation, and say, 'Nothing to see here.' They look at the CFMMEU, with its links to organised crime, and say, 'Nothing to see here.' They look at the CFMMEU, with its run-throughs, and say, 'Nothing to see here.' They look at the CFMMEU's multiple contempts of court and say, 'Nothing to see here.' They're the Sergeant Schultz of Australian politics.

Why do they do this? They do this because they're addicted to the financial support of the CFMMEU—$4 million since 2013. That represents a quarter of the total money that the CFMMEU has been fined by courts. They have been fined by courts to the tune of $16 million. Not only are they addicted to the money; they're addicted to the instructions of the trade union movement. We can see this in the conduct of the Labor Party since the election. The Labor Party have repeatedly engaged in a political tactic which Annabel Crabb has described as the 'bitch and fold'. We will bring legislation into this place, they will make a lot of noise about it and they will try to amend it, but, ultimately, they will vote for it. They did that with the tax cuts. They did that with national security. They even did it with drought funding. But there is one class of legislation that they will fight like Kilkenny cats not to amend and not to support, and that is any change to industrial laws. Why is that? It is because, as I said earlier, the Australian Labor Party are the political wing of the trade union movement.

There is nothing wrong with trade unions per se. Robert Menzies, the founder of my party, represented trade unions throughout his career as a barrister. While we are thinking about Menzies and celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Liberal Party, I thought it was worthwhile quoting from Menzies about trade unions and law and lawlessness. Menzies said in the 1940s:

The Liberal Party stands for good wages and conditions … It believes in Trade Unionism and in the protection by law of the rights secured by wage-earners. And, because it believes in all these things, it stands for a fair industrial law which will be enforced without fear, favour or greaten, against employer and employee alike.
… Law and lawlessness are irreconcilable. The time has come, in this country where the rule of law is so frequently attacked, for law-abiding people to defend the law.
Those words were true in the 1940s, and they are even more true today in 2019. Labor didn't do anything about union lawlessness in the 1940s, and they are certainly not doing anything about it today.

In the 1940s, union density was over 50 per cent. Today, as I said, it's down to 15 per cent across the board—nine per cent in the private sector. My friend the member for Fowler said that it's important to have unions in industries where the work is dangerous. Let's look at a couple of industries where the work is dangerous and the union density in those industries. Union density in mining is down to 9.6 per cent, and it's down to 8.5 per cent in construction. So, in the industries where the CFMMEU are operating, they represent a tiny fraction of the total workers. Where the unions still remain strong are areas like education and health. You are more likely to hear 'no ticket, no start' in a classroom than on a building site or on a mine.

What does that say? It says that the CFMMEU is a criminal organisation. It represents almost no workers in the industries that it involves itself in, and yet it continues to have the political protection of the Labor Party, because it gives them instructions and it gives them money. And so the Labor Party constantly fights against changes to industrial law in this place which would apply the rule of law to working people and give people the right not to be intimidated every day when they go to work, would apply the same standards that we expect from company directors to union officials and would lift the standard and the productivity of this country.

As for the maritime section of the CFMMEU, we all remember the waterfront, where the maritime workers union said, 'Oh, we couldn't do anything more than nine crane lifts an hour.' After the reforms to the waterfront, the crane lifts were up over 20 per cent. We stand for the rights of workers. They stand for the rights of unions.

Ms THWAITES (Jagajaga) (16:13): As the member for Watson outlined, this government talks a lot about lawlessness in the union movement. We have heard a lot today from that side about the union movement—how terrible, how scary and how they break the law. We've heard much less about the rule-breaking that rips off ordinary Australian workers. I will grant you that the member for Hinkler has been forced to acknowledge that unions do some good things, and the member for Ryan has been flirting with his own brand of lawlessness here in the chamber this afternoon. But what we haven't heard about is the way this government is failing to look after the interests of workers by allowing them to be underpaid and exploited. That is what is happening out there, and Australians see it and are concerned.

In my home town of Melbourne, we've recently had a succession of high-profile wage theft cases in the hospitality industry. Well-known restaurants, hospitality industry stalwarts, have been underpaying their workers for years. I, like perhaps many of us here in this chamber, started my working life in the hospitality industry. I've worked in the fast food franchise, in a cafe and behind bars. I know that it's hard work, with long, unsociable hours on your feet. It makes family life hard when you're working hours that others are not. And it's uncertain. You're often working on a casual basis and dependent on getting on well with your boss for your next shift. These are not the people who should be cheated out of their wages, yet, on this government's watch, we have case after case of underpayment in the hospitality industry.

I'll give one recent high-profile example from Melbourne. The MAdE Establishment, which runs the Press Club, Gazi, Hellenic Republic and Jimmy Grants restaurants, was investigated by the Fair Work Ombudsman, who found significant underpayment over a number of years. In fact, the underpayments, they claim, occurred because they failed to correctly apply annualised salary arrangements to some of their staff, including by failing to conduct annual reconciliations to check that workers on annual salary arrangements were paid for overtime and penalty rates were applied. We hear from the employers in these cases that it's all too hard, that it's all too confusing. Well, in these cases, it's the unions that stand up for these workers and make sure they get paid. MAdE Establishment has now back paid $17.8 million to 515 current or former employees. But what a failure of this government that, on its watch, vulnerable workers were systemically underpaid for years and years. Instead of asking why, instead of trying to fix this broken system, this government focuses on trying to shut down the very organisations that support these workers—unions.

But Australians are onto this government. I've been struck by how, when I'm out and about in my electorate, I am routinely approached by people concerned about low wages and poor working conditions. The people who are approaching me are grandparents concerned about their grandchildren. They know that their grandchildren face a very different working world from the one they held jobs in. They know that their grandchildren are working in a casualised, low-wage environment. They see that their grandchildren aren't going to get the sort of stable working conditions that allow them to take out a home loan with a bank, to have a decent family life or to know that they can take a day off when their child is sick. And they see the government doing nothing about it. They see them coming in here day after day with nothing but smugness and attacks on workers and their unions, with no plans to help protect young workers at risk of exploitation.

Of course, another area where workers are being routinely exploited is in the gig economy. Those opposite would have us believe that working in the gig economy is a choice—that people go into these jobs because of their flexibility. That may be the case for a very few, but in the main people are working in the gig economy because they don't have a choice. We know the Fair Work Ombudsman has looked into Uber. Unfortunately, that investigation concluded that the relationship between Uber and its drivers is not an employment relationship, and therefore these drivers are left with no protection, underpayment and no security. Across industry, across jobs, this government is letting down workers, yet I've heard no concern today and no plans to improve the lives of these people. The member for Berowra thinks that we on this side are ashamed to be associated with unions. Well, that is not the case. We stand proudly beside the people standing up for workers, standing up for Australians who want fair work and who want fair wages. This government should be ashamed it's not doing the same.

Ms FLINT (Boothby—Government Whip) (16:18): I'm just going to address the member opposite's points. On the matter of unions, they are not working in the interests of their members. We know, for example, that they're spending the hard-earned money of their members on funding the campaigns of those opposite. I don't see how that helps a single worker in Australia. Worse than that, we've heard so regularly from the Attorney-General recently about the disgusting behaviour, in particular of the CFMMEU, that is directed at individual workers in workplaces around the nation. I'm just going to quote from the Attorney-General. And I'll keep putting this on the record because it's important for each and every Australian to understand the disgusting behaviour of the CFMMEU. The Attorney-General said to the House recently, 'One of the very important reasons that unlawful behaviour on worksites must be stopped is that it puts the safety of workers at risk.' These are really important issues. As the Attorney-General went on to say: 'We know that the CFMMEU has racked up $16 million in court fines for unlawful behaviour for over 2,000 breaches. What is less well-known is that many of those breaches themselves relate to violations of occupational health and safety standards.' The Victorian public sector has been targeted and we know that the Queensland Public Sector Union now has a list of 17 sites that they will not let their safety inspectors visit because they don't feel safe, and that's because of union activity on those sites. This is just appalling behaviour. No-one deserves to be treated like this. No-one deserves to feel unsafe in their workplace. We need Australian workers to feel safe when they're working on a government site and most certainly when they are on building sites and other private sector sites that we know the unions and, in particular, the CFMMEU are constantly targeting.

But what I really want to talk about today is the importance of jobs. You don't have workers when you don't have jobs, and we on this side of House understand that. That is what the Labor Party time and time again fails to remember. When we talk about looking after the interests of Australian workers, we are looking after their No. 1 interest, which is making sure that they have a job. Since 2013, we on this of the House have created over 1.4 million jobs—and we are getting on with the job of delivering 1.25 million more over the next five years.

Over the last year, full-time employment has increased 2.2 per cent, with more than eight out of 10 jobs created in the last year being full-time jobs. We've lowered the tax rate for small and medium businesses—which employ more than seven million Australians—so that they can grow and employ more people in their communities. We're investing in $100 billion worth of nation-building infrastructure projects, which will create jobs in each and every state across Australia. I'm very fortunate that my electorate of Boothby is seeing a lot of road upgrades and level crossing grade separations, which is creating a huge amount of work in my home state of SA. We're also investing money than $200 billion in our national defence capability, which includes the delivery of 57 new naval vessels—each one being built in Australia, using Australian steel and creating more than 25,000 jobs for hardworking Australians.

Only our government is interested in creating jobs for Australians and making sure that our economy is in the position to do so so that businesses can get on with employing other Australians. As a result of our responsible economic management, wage increases continue to outpace increases in the cost of living. Importantly, living standards also continue to increase, with net disposable income per capita rising one per cent—to be 2.7 per cent higher through the year. To support wages growth, our government is setting the right conditions for a strong economy and for jobs growth, and a healthy labour market will help drive wages growth for workers. Also, thanks to our government's plan for lower taxes, workers will keep more of the money they work so hard to earn.

Those opposite like to lecture us and make all sorts of wild and incorrect claims, but we know the truth: we are the party that are completely focused on Australian workers and on delivering jobs for Australian workers—and we will continue to do so through a raft of different mechanisms, whether it's lowering taxes for small and medium businesses, investing in our defence capability or fixing our roads and busting congestion around the nation.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): The discussion has concluded.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Farm Household Support Amendment (Relief Measures) Bill (No. 1) 2019

p.span: Farm Household Support Amendment (Relief Measures) Bill (No. 1) 2019
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.
to which the following amendment was moved:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:
(1) notes that the drought is severe and ongoing; and
(2) criticises the Government for forcing desperate drought-affected farming families off the Farm Household Allowance”.
The DEPUTY SPEAKER: The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

Ms CHESTERS (Bendigo) (16:23): I rise to support the amendment that is before the House, moved by the member for Hunter, to the Farm Household Support Amendment (Relief Measures) Bill (No. 1) 2019. Let's be frank about where we've got to on the farm household allowance and about this government. The allowance was created when Labor was last in government. It was recognised back then, at the beginning of the drought, that we needed to bring this measure in. This government got elected in 2013, and what is disappointing for a lot of people on this side of the House, as well as farmers and farming communities, is that, since that time, as the drought has worsened, there's been bungle after bungle from this government when it comes to the farm household allowance. Now, when farmers are in the really dark days of the drought, we're seeing this legislation brought before us, trying to patch up the fact that the government have not worked hard enough or early enough to support these families most in need. The worst thing about it is the fact that they were warned. They were encouraged to take action not just by us here in the parliament but by people in their own electorates and their own communities. As we stand here, 600 families have been kicked off the farm household allowance because these changes were not brought to the parliament sooner. That is 600 families who have basically fallen off the cliff in terms of income support.

What is the farm household allowance? It allows farmers who have assets and who are earning income to also claim the Newstart allowance if their income is below a certain amount. It is, it should be acknowledged, a lot more generous than what somebody on Newstart can earn before they start to lose their Newstart allowance. It recognises that a lot of our farmers do have a lot of assets and are earning income but just not enough, because farm enterprises, particularly in some parts of Australia, are very expensive and there is a cash-flow problem that does occur in these houses.

Labor does support the changes that have been put forward by the government but really wants to highlight the situation that faces not just the 600 who have been kicked off the allowance and are left without nothing but also the more than 500 who are about lose their farm household allowance and will get a once-off payment of $13,000—so they will get roughly a year of the allowance before they also exit. Meanwhile, everyone else on the farm household allowance will get the allowance for up to 10 years. That's how long this drought could go on. That is a reasonable time frame, because it also allows farming families and farmers the opportunity to decide whether they stay or transition off the farm. But it's very little comfort for those who applied early to the allowance and are now off the allowance; either they've been kicked off or they'll get this once-off payment. It used to happen a lot in enterprise bargaining. A boss would delay negotiations and drag them out, and then, rather than giving people a decent pay rise, would say, 'We'll roll it over and give you a once-off payment.' It's almost bribery money, in a way, to make the issue go away. It doesn't account for the long term. It represents the chaos of this government when it comes to its drought response and support for farmers.

The other part I'd like to highlight is the lack of support for farm workers, farm contractors and people working in small businesses. I raised this question today in question time, and the response I got from the Prime Minister was, 'Oh, we're helping them in other ways.' But he didn't really go into any detail. He talked about the tax incentives that the government give to farmers, the fact that they're investing in councils and the fact that they're going to help people find alternate work on farms. All of those programs have not demonstrated in any way that they're on the ground helping people on those farms, in those communities, stay in work. I haven't spoken to a shearer who's got work building a fence on a farm. When you talk to farmers about the ability that was introduced in other budget measures for them to claim back these expenses, they say: 'You've got to have the money to spend it. We don't have the money to spend on the drought infrastructure that we could possibly claim back.' These farm workers have left these communities. They might be able to stay for a bit if their partner is in work, but there is a real pressure throughout the supply chain—beyond the farm gate and beyond the farmers themselves.

The government are always trying to talk about small-business truck drivers and owner truck drivers. Yet where's the support for the owner truck drivers who are the contractors that help to cart the grain, which doesn't exist right now because of the drought? There's no support or recognition for a lot of the small businesses that might be based in town, the people who might help with irrigation, the people who might be the electricians or the plumbers who specialise in farm and on-farm equipment, the jackaroos and the jillaroos or the loyal person who has always worked there—not the backpacker who comes and goes for the fruit-picking season, but the person who's been the on-farm hand or the on-farm manager.

The government actually distinguishes these people, if they find themselves unemployed because of the drought, as being on Newstart. So all of a sudden, even though they drew their income and drew their experience from agriculture, they're now put into another category by this government: Newstart. They're now demonised. They now could be subject to drug testing. They are now vilified by this government and placed in a category of 'Newstart'. Yet you talk to a farmer and you talk to that worker and they see themselves in a partnership. Farmers who have got a very close working relationship with their employees say that their farms couldn't survive without these people. Yet, in the government's eyes, that worker is viewed differently even though the drought's impact is the reason they now find themselves unemployed.

Even though the allowance that they're drawing is the same—it's Newstart—that worker is treated differently. When that worker rings Centrelink, they're on hold for a very long time. If they are able to get their phone call answered, then they're struck with all the punitive measures that come with Newstart like every other worker. Yet when the farmer rings up, if they indicate that they're on the farm household allowance, they go straight through. They've got a special helpline. They've got special support. They are assigned a case worker that calls them every two weeks. They get specialised financial counselling to help them out. It's a great support service that we're now starting to build for our farmers and our farming communities. But why can't it be extended? Why can't all people experiencing this drought receive the same support? Why is it just our farmers? Why isn't it the farm workers? Why isn't it the people who work for the small businesses in town? Why isn't it people who live and work in regional communities?

You also have to question why the government isn't rolling out this great support and assistance for people in sectors like manufacturing, with the downturn in manufacturing. When we lose manufacturing jobs, whether it be food manufacturing jobs or jobs that are connected to the supply chain, those workers don't get this special treatment, and there's an argument that they should. Everybody who contacts Centrelink should have the phone answered. Everybody who is seeking the support of a government payment should be treated with respect and given the opportunity to talk to a real person and work through their payment structure.

There are reasons why so many farmers aren't taking up this allowance. One is the complexity of it. The second is that they have to go through Centrelink and the demonisation of people who use Centrelink. The third is the time frames that the government has put around this allowance. Maybe the 10 years will help attract more to it, but these are people who are proud and who are trying to make a tough decision in their life: do they stay and sit it out, or do they go?

I also want to acknowledge the amazing farming skills and the resilience of communities and farmers who decided early to destock. We don't talk about them enough—the people who had a plan ready for this drought. They learnt from the millennium drought that you had to farm differently. They learnt from the millennium drought that you had to be prepared. They—wherever possible—introduced opportunities into their farming business so that they could diversify their income. And they should be acknowledged, because they have not found themselves in these very difficult circumstances—whilst they're down on their income, they did destock early and they did make sure that they enacted their drought plan. This is something that is not being recognised, and I know that within the drought affected communities it's a point that they really are talking about.

I also want to call out the government on their lack of support for regional councils. We've noticed and we've heard in the evidence given before estimates that it was a government decision—an arbitrary decision—about which councils got the $1 million funding and which councils didn't. It was a government decision, a cabinet decision, a ministerial decision about the line where they cut communities off. What we've learnt is that some of the councils to the north of my electorate around the Murray that are drought affected, missed out on funding because they had less than 17 per cent of their people technically employed in agriculture. Those statistics are disputed. How could you say that people who work in the supply chain are not drawing an income from agriculture?

I'm talking about to the north of me, particularly in dairy country. We've had a lot of dairy farmers stop dairying. They're no longer active dairy farms, a knock-on effect of the supply chain. So, in milk processing, technically those jobs, whether they be at Parmalat or Fonterra, are considered manufacturing jobs, yet the core ingredient is a commodity that comes off the land. Those councils have missed out because of the arbitrary way in which the government has allocated funding. They're still drought affected, they're still struggling, but they missed out on funding. If you look at some of the council areas around the Hunter, to the north of where we are, they missed out on funding because, again, those council areas have a diversity of industries. It doesn't mean the farmers aren't doing it any tougher, it doesn't mean that those regions aren't doing it any tougher, but they've missed out on funding because of this arbitrary 17 per cent. And why is it 17 per cent? Why isn't it 10 per cent? Why isn't it 15 per cent? These are questions that the government won't answer because decisions were made—let's be frank—about money, not people.

The other point that I really wish to highlight in this speech about this kind of homework assignment done at the last minute by the government is that it's actually not a long-term plan. It's not a plan for resilience and it's not really focused on where to next—not in the long term but also not in the immediate term. In my part of the world, it is getting very dry. We did have a good winter. We've had some good rains. We are hopeful that we'll get more rain so that we will have a good crop. But to the west of us and to the east of us it's looking very dry. And our council areas, whilst they're not in the severe drought that we've seen in Queensland, New South Wales and northern Victoria, fear that they could be next. But what planning is this government doing? Now is the time to engage with those councils and those regional communities and enact preparation plans for drought. Now is the time to start investing and awarding those contracts to start to do that on-farm, off-farm work so that they can keep employment going in these regional communities—now, not waiting until they're in the dire circumstances where stock is dying on the land.

The fact that stock is dying on the land and the Army has had to go in to clean it up is awful. It's heartbreaking, it's a disgrace and it's an indictment of this government that it let the situation get to that. Where is its shame about letting it get to the situation where the Army had to go in? It demonstrates the chaos of this government. The fact that we have towns in New South Wales out of water, where parents are bathing their children in mineral water—in water that's been shipped in—demonstrates the government's chaos and dysfunction and how it has let these regions down. The government have shown a lack of leadership. In bringing together the states, in bringing together local governments, they've been the missing partner.

It's disappointing that members have stood up in this House and ranted about state governments and talked about building dam infrastructure. That's going to take decades, and there are question marks about whether it will even help. People need help right now, not just farm household assistance but help with the basics. I urge the government to do more right now.

Mr KATTER (Kennedy) (16:38): The Prime Minister very kindly gave me some of his time to talk about the Julia Creek and north-west Queensland floods, and I pleaded with him to go up there and see it. He saw it as a good thing to do, so he went up there. He went, he saw, he acted, and we got an excellent outcome. And I don't think I could use any other word except 'excellent'. I've been a member of parliament through Cyclone Larry, the second worst cyclone in Australian history, and the cyclone that followed it, Yasi, which was very, very bad indeed. But I have seen massive flooding—74 floods. I worked on the flood relief committee as a very young man. So I would use no other word except 'excellent'.

Nothing is ever perfect; we forgot about the roo-shooters, the kangaroo farmers. That's a very, very big industry. There are the vegans that we have with us—the brainless class, in my opinion. You've got to explain things to them, but it's a bit of a waste of time. Because there's water everywhere there now, we have a massive kangaroo population and there is enormous pressure on the grasslands, the native grasses, that wasn't there before because the kangaroos weren't there before. With cattle, it doesn't matter too much. With sheep, because we have a drought, the land is spelled for a couple of years. It takes a while for them to build their numbers up again, and we get a reasonably good outcome as far as nature goes. But we do need the kangaroo harvesters in there, otherwise nature's going to get very badly out of balance.

Having said those things, and turning to the bill, I thought the government had a fair bit of an idea, particularly the drought minister, in saying, 'What we're doing for the drought is the family farm assistance.' Well, the ALP did the family farm assistance. It had absolutely nothing to do with the government side of the House. The Rural Action Council—one of the most aggressive and one of the best groups of people I've ever worked with in my life—wanted a drought summit. My own little political party—with Rowell Walton, our president, along with me—secured agreement from Wayne Swan for a drought summit. We wanted a lot of things. We didn't get the drought summit, but one of the things we did get was the family farm assistance grants. We thank very much the Labor government of Kevin Rudd and Wayne Swan for a huge breakthrough for rural Australia. I really don't think it helps any of us for the current government to be running around claiming credit for something that the other side did.

As Alan Jones has delineated in a very emotional and a very aggressive manner, the cattle numbers are simply vanishing. The cattle numbers are simply not there. We had 32 million head of cattle. We were down to 24 million head of cattle two years ago. Now we're down to 22 million head of cattle. We're not all in love with farmers. They're not some special breed that we all look after like a protected species or anything of that nature. As a cattleman, having had cattle almost all of my life—I'm not cattleman. That's a very honourable thing. I'm not in that category, but I've had cattle all my life. We need money for fodder. The previous speaker, quite rightly, said that the dams are decades away. Well, with her government in Queensland, they're centuries away. They're on another planet, with her government in power in Queensland. It's the worst government I have seen in 50 years in parliament. It's easily the worst government. I would hate to be an ALP member in Queensland at the next election. They were given their notice, they were given their warning in the federal election, and they took no heed of the warning at all. They want to close down the sugarcane industry and they want to close down the coal industry. Queensland only has two industries: cane and coal. And, if there is a third one, it's cattle. We've got as much chance of getting money for fodder from the state government as I've got of becoming the abominable snowman in Bedourie! It's simply not going to happen. They are naive to state that. I plead with the Prime Minister to not go down that pathway. They will never help us, and we know they will never help us.

Let me give you an example of how they're looking after drought affected farmers in Queensland. There is a tree called mulga—I think that's the technical name for the tree—and it grows in the desert, in country which is called Heartbreak Corner—right out there like the corner of South Australia and the Northern Territory; it's in the corner of New South Wales and Queensland, in the corner which is just getting onto the desert. People forget that 52 per cent of Australia is in the world register of deserts. This is not on desert country, but it's adjacent to desert country. The mulga tree grows very deep roots and survives through droughts and dry times. When you buy a station, you don't buy a station for the dirt. You're not a miner. You buy the station for the vegetable matter upon the land, which the moo-cows or the sheep will be able to eat. Since time immemorial, in the days when there were no whitefellas here, blackfellas broke off the trees, kangaroos would come up to eat the trees and they would catch and harvest them. Today we break the trees, and the moo-cows, sheep and kangaroos come up to eat them, and the tree keeps growing. It's called coppicing. Some trees coppice; some don't. Some you can damage by breaking their top off. But these are not coppicing trees; in fact they flower—that's not the word I'm after. They are much more successful at growing—a crude expression, I know—when they're cut, so continuously cutting them gets more and more foliage. They yield more vegetation.

The Queensland government is prosecuting Dan McDonald and has fined him the best part of $250,000 because he broke the trees off. We've been doing that for 30,000 or 40,000 years, and he has been fined $250,000. This is the help we're getting from the Queensland government in drought? This is the government we expect to provide us with funds to buy cattle fodder? They believe their greenie wet dreams where, if you have a moo-cow, all the ground collapses and it goes into the ocean and destroys it. I challenge the greenies continually: we can get in a motorcar and drive from Townsville to Mount Isa, about 1,200 or 1,300 kilometres; you can stop any time you like, climb onto the bonnet of the car and look out; and, if you can count more than 2,000 hard-hoofed animals in those 1,300 kilometres, I'll give you $2,000. I don't have a hooknose for nothing; I don't like parting with money! You have just seen something like 40,000 square kilometres and you can't even count 2,000 hard-hoofed animals on it. We do not have intense vegetation, so we have an extremely light footprint.

We're here to talk about family farm assistance. We applaud the government for extending that to four years but, unfortunately and sadly, if you want to look at an average figure for droughts—not that there is an average figure—you're probably looking at about seven years. Under intense pressure they have added a cash payment at the end of the four years. We appreciate that as well. But you did not institute this vitally important measure. You did participate, with the ALP, in the sell-off of all of the banks that provided us with reconstruction money. I hate to use that word. Every government in Australian history, state and federal, since the time when King O'Malley set up the Commonwealth Bank, has had a very simple reconstruction approach when farmers get into trouble. All they do is go in and buy the bad debt. The farmers are in trouble, so they pay out the bank. If the farmer owes the bank $1 million, they say, 'Mr Bank, we'll give you the $1 million; we now hold the mortgage.' This protects the government's money, because we now hold the first mortgage. If we take a second mortgage, the government is not protected and almost certainly the government will get none of its money back. So we take a first mortgage. Since we are buying a bad or in-danger debt, we expect a discount. We buy for 100 years in Australia. We bought the farm debt at a discount of 15 to 20 per cent—in that sort of range.

I speak with authority because I was the minister responsible for the state bank when the sugar industry in Queensland went down, and went down badly. At that time the sugar industry in Queensland was our premier industry, our biggest employer. It was still bigger than coal at that stage. There was a drop to one-third in the price of sugar and it stayed down for two or three years. So we had to consider going in. Even there, you don't go in unless the industry is viable. The government should not be in the business of propping up non-viable industries. Our cost of production was lower than southern Brazil, so we knew we would be the last man standing. We had very solid property values. The sugarcane farms are in the super-wet belt, where it's green—the only part of Australia that's green—and in the area of holiday land, such as Airlie Beach and Port Douglas and all of these places. So we borrowed the money—I think it was at about 2.5 per cent—and, if memory serves me correctly, we loaned out about $700 million. We took all the mortgages. When I was told that I had responsibility for that, I said, 'Like bloody hell—I'm not taking the reconstruction bank. No way. I'm not taking all the cripples.' They said, 'There aren't any cripples.' I looked into it and found that there were only 13 farms that had to be foreclosed on. Over a 10-year period, we had loaned out to thousands of farms, but there were only 13. At the present moment, if you're on $1 million you've got to pay the bank about $55,000 every year. If they've only got to pay interest-only at two per cent then you're coming down to about $16,000.

So there has to be a grant for the fodder. The cattle numbers have gone down from 32 million—this is arguably the third-biggest export earner for this country. After coal and iron ore, the cattle industry is No. 3. We are not doing it to help farmers. As Alan Jones said, we're doing it to preserve for the future this great and wonderful treasure: the Australian cattle herd. It's gone from 32 million down to 24 million two years ago. In the last two years, it's now gone to 22 million. When are we going to act? When it's down to 10 million? How many meatworkers are we going to throw out of jobs? Thousands in Australia. So we need money for fodder, and that's got to be from grants. There's no other way out. The reconstruction board accounts for the debt and should bring almost all of those farmers through. We're not going to bring people through who are stupid and lazy and irresponsible. There's always got to be some people who go down with the ship. (Time expired)

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (16:53): I've met with dairy farmers in my community and I've listened to how their industry, and the challenges in their industry, are impacting not only on the future viability of their own individual businesses but also on their physical and mental health. So I welcome the agricultural minister's announcement of the early introduction of the mandatory code of conduct, a measure designed to increase fairness and transparency between dairy farmers and processors. While the code is unlikely to be a silver bullet, as some in the industry believe that it will be, I hope that this will help to improve the precarious financial position of our dairy farmers, as detailed in the recent ABARES data on debt in the dairy industry.

The ABARES data shows that, in South Australia, the average total farm debt for dairy farmers is around $1.3 million, a substantial debt to service when accompanied by the predicted decrease in farm-cash incomes of around 24 per cent for the 2018-19 financial year. On a national level, the average farm cash income of Australian dairy farmers is likely to decline by around 42 per cent to just $93,000 per farm. Unsurprisingly, ABARES concludes that the major influence on the financial performance of dairy farms is the drought.

The code is a start but more work needs to be done to ensure the long-term financial viability of our dairy industry and agriculture more broadly. The farm household allowance forms just one part of a possible solution. The allowance currently provides eligible farmers a maximum of 1,460 days, or four years, of financial support during their lifetimes to meet basic household needs. The financial support comes in the form of a fortnightly payment, with modest mutual-obligation requirements tied to the payment.

Firstly, the Farm Household Support Amendment (Relief Measures) Bill (No. 1) 2019 amends the farm household allowance scheme such that farmers and their partners would now be eligible to receive the payment for a maximum of four years in every 10-year period. The measure recognises that farmers may face more than one hardship in their lifetime, be it ill health, family breakdowns or long periods of drought. Secondly, the bill increases the income offset provision from $80,000 to $100,000. The income offset provisions allow a farmer who has incurred a family farm loss to have their ordinary income reduced by $100,000 under the allowances income test. Finally, the bill provides a once-off lump sum payment to farmers who have received the allowance for a period of four years prior to 30 June 2020. Single farmers will receive $7,500, while couples will receive a total of $13,000.

The Minister for Agriculture has previously stated that the once-off payment is consistent with the aims of the allowance scheme designed to help assess their sustainability to continue, their succession options or, in some instances, their choice to sell. However, an independent review of the scheme prepared on behalf of the department in February this year queried whether the fortnightly payments actually encouraged long-term sustainability. The report entitled Rebuilding the FHA: a better way forward for supporting farmers in financial hardship made six strategic recommendations, including strengthening the mutual obligation requirement to prioritise a meaningful mutual obligation process and putting the focus on long-term viability and structural change.

The report recommended a change to the mutual obligation requirements process whereby farmers work closely with the Rural Financial Counselling Service to engage in a viability assessment, and either plan through the current financial hardship and adequately prepare for future financial shocks or, alternatively, exit the industry with dignity. Specifically, it recommended the Rural Financial Counselling Service take on a coaching role, and farmers would be required to meet with their RFCS counsellor every three months to discuss their financial situation. This would result in a tailored and flexible approach to help farmers understand their financial situation and, where appropriate, develop a better business model.

Currently, recipients of farm household allowance are required to sign onto a financial improvement agreement negotiated between the farmer and the case officer of the Department of Human Services. The agreement must contain at least one objective and a series of approved activities designed to assist them achieve their goals. Recipients must undertake at least one of those activities. The independent panel expressed concern over the current mutual obligation requirements, believing they would be viewed as a tick box rather than a tool for long-term financial assistance and change. Notwithstanding those concerns, the bill makes no change to the mutual obligation requirements. It may be that the Senate committee will make recommendations following the conclusion of the inquiry process to ensure the scheme meets its dual objectives of income support and structural change, because our farmers do not need band-aid solutions and nor do they want a handout. What Australian farmers need is a comprehensive plan of attack to give them the best chance of a better future. The government should make no mistake: rural Australians are waking up to the hotter, drier, harsher future that awaits them. And they know that the government has no coherent plan to address the medium- and long-term impacts of climate change upon Australian agriculture. If the government refuses to minimise Australia's contribution to climate change then it can at least minimise the impact by helping our frontline farmers to prepare their farming operations for the hotter, drier, harsher future that awaits them. Finally, the government must design and then implement the national strategy on agriculture and climate change that the member for Indi and I raised last week.

We need to make sure that we support our farmers. I know that, in my community, our farmers are integral to the culture of our community and what we grow. We are so proud of the fact that we are the food bowl for South Australia—we're the dairy farms, the apple farms, the cherry farms, the pear farms and the strawberry farms; we have some broadacre farming; we have cattle; we have sheep. We want to make sure that, in South Australia, our farming families continue on the land, with the dairy farms, and we want to make sure that those farms continue to exist for generations to come. I commend this bill to the House.

Ms OWENS (Parramatta) (17:01): A girl from the city is about to speak about farms, so I ask the forgiveness of any farmers out there if I get this slightly wrong! But I think it's really important that people who live in the cities—as I do, in the geographic centre of Sydney—recognise how much support our farmers need, as they are going through a terrible time currently, in possibly the worst drought we've seen in Australia, but also as they necessarily prepare for the changes in our climate that we're going to see over the next 10 years.

We know, from even basic reading, of the extraordinary rise in mental health issues among our farmers. We know of the high suicide rates. We know, all of us, how people are suffering out there. We really do need to give them the support they need, in encouraging the government to make the plans that they will need, to transition as well as possible, in the way that they will need to, over the next decade.

We know Australia generally is getting drier. We're already the driest continent there is. We know that bits of it are drying quite substantially, and, for some parts of Australia, the drought they are currently experiencing will be pretty much the norm. For others, there will be more volatile weather patterns—storms; cyclones, where there weren't cyclones; and more drought. So we know that we're going to see a climate which is changing. In spite of the fact that we've had droughts and flooding rains, the climate was consistent, over centuries, and we know that we're going to see that change quite a bit. So farmers are going to need to make changes, and they know it and they are asking the government for a long-term plan.

Can I commend the members who have spoken on that—the member for Hunter, the member for Mayo, the member for Macquarie and the member for Bendigo—and on the need for government to sit down, seriously, in a bipartisan way, and address the long-term challenges of our farming community, because we all lose when our farming community loses. It is such a major part of our economy and such a major part of our identity. We all lose: every time we lose the investment that a farmer has made over decades, when a farm goes, when a farm becomes unviable, we all pay a small part of that price. If large numbers go, it affects us all, financially as well as personally.

This bill, the Farm Household Support Amendment (Relief Measures) Bill (No. 1) 2019, goes some way to improving what is known as the farm household support amendment. Again, I think it's worth people in the cities understanding what this is. The FHA, as it's called, or the farm household allowance, is an income support payment which supports eligible farmers and their partners who are experiencing financial hardship and is paid at the same rate as the social security payment the Newstart allowance, or at the same rate as youth allowance if the recipient is under 22 years of age. The payment is time-limited. Farmers can only receive the payment for up to four cumulative years over their lifetime, at the moment, but this bill changes that to four years in 10, and that recognises that, in the increasing droughts, in particular, we will find farms that have to face drought several times through their lives, unfortunately, not just once. So that's a good change.

Farm household allowance recipients are also granted a healthcare card, which enables access to discounted medicines under the PBS and other concessions, and they can receive a $4,000 activity supplement to pay for approved activities, such as training or professional advice. Recipients required to have a farm financial assessment can receive a separate supplement worth up to $15,000 to assist with the cost of the assessment. So, while they get the health card like Newstart recipients, they will also get some additional payments to help them adjust to and get training for the new circumstances that they find themselves in.

With this bill, there'll also be an additional payment at the end of the four-year period. When a farm household is cut off after four years, they'll receive a one-off payment worth about six months. So, at the end of that four years, they will get a one-off lump sum payment. So, effectively, it's 4½ years instead of four. Also in this bill is an increase in the amount of income a farm household can earn before it affects their payment. That has been increased from $80,000 to $100,000 a year—again, much, much more than Newstart recipients. The bill also increases the amount of assets the farm household can have—up to $5 million. Again, that is much more than it is for Newstart recipients—and, of course, farmers don't have to apply 20 times a week for jobs either. When you compare the farm household assistance to Newstart, it appears very generous. But, again, I would ask people in considering this to understand the circumstances that farmers find themselves in and the extraordinary ongoing costs they have. Whether their farm is viable or not and whether their farm is in serious drought, their ongoing costs are extraordinary. So they're in a different situation.

The one thing, though, that does concern me about this bill is that there is no additional assistance for workers who work on the farms. If the farm is downsizing its stock or if its crop is not the ground, or whatever is going on in the farm because of the drought, that means the workers are out of work as well. Workers that come in for the harvest season, workers that work in town, workers that do piecework or workers who work full time on the farm will also be affected by drought, yet they're left just on Newstart.

It is quite problematic when you understand how fragile some of these towns are. In good times and bad, the towns change dramatically. They don't have the depth that we have in larger towns where we can as a group, across an economy, see a community through hard times. And good times can kill a town just as much as a bad time. I was down in the Snowy Mountains recently and heard from communities how they are very concerned that Snowy 2.0 has doubled the house prices. People who have lived there for decades were taking the quick cash and moving. So they were actually losing their sense of community because the town was doing well for the short term. Their worry was that, when Snowy 2.0 was finished being built and all those engineers tried to sell up, the land prices would slump again and the town would be in trouble. You see that sometimes in the mining booms as well, where the locals move out because the land prices become so high and, effectively, a town loses its history and its character quite quickly. So good times can be quite damaging in the long run, but so can bad times.

If you lose your permanent workers who have a connection to the area, they can be very, very difficult to replace. From all of the assistance the farming areas need in bringing in workers for the peak seasons, we know how difficult it already is for them to find the workers they need. So when workers leave town—when they sell their utes, sell their tools and are struggling financially and are forced to move to a bigger town to work—small towns and small farming areas can be substantially damaged. So I would question whether or not the government is right in considering the needs only of the farmers and not of the workers, who are also affected by drought.

Again, from a city perspective, we need to understand that this is quite a unique situation—because, when a drought hits an area, it hits the whole area. We had similar situations in cities during the millenium drought, as I now know it is called. My area of Parramatta, in Western Sydney, lost just about every nursery that existed, because the water restrictions meant that no-one could water their garden and so no-one bought plants. Nurseries that had been in business for 30 or 40 years and which supported whole families went broke, with some incredible debts. Some of them are still crawling out of those holes now. Now in Western Sydney, if you want plants, it's basically Bunnings. We lost the diversity, we lost the range and we lost a lot of businesses. But in a community like Parramatta, we have enough depth of other businesses to see us through that. There's individual pain for a number of people, but as a community we have some depth.

Regional communities do not always have that depth. They have large numbers of farm workers, farm machinery goes down and people there lose their jobs, so no-one's shopping at the shop down the road. It becomes quite a downward spiral. It is different. It's very easy when you first hear this stuff to go, 'Hang on, we don't get that.' And we don't get that in cities. We have businesses that go out because of the high dollar.
