The dollar hits parity and businesses that have been viable for years are suddenly not viable, and they go to the wall for something that is not their fault and something that is cyclical. Again I would suggest to the government that they might want to slightly expand the way they think about cyclical things, because it's not just farmers. But in the case of farmers, the whole community is affected in a way in which we're quite often not in the city.

I also want to return to that point I made earlier about the need for us all to support the farmers in the changes they're going to have to make. I know there are some on the government side who don't believe in climate change. I know there are others who believe it's happening but don't believe that human beings are causing it. I know there are others who think it's happening and that human beings caused it, but there's nothing we can do about it. I believe it's happening and I think we need to act, but even if you're one of those three groups, there are still things that must be done because we must adjust to the reality of it. Even if you don't think we can stop climate change or do anything to stop emissions rising, we still need to work to live in the world of climate change. You can already hear the growing voices around the world against broadacre farming because of the killing of insects and the degradation of the soil. You can hear people saying, 'You can't afford to use 2,700 litres of water on one single cotton T-shirt.' We already see growing criticism against certain sectors of the farming sector who use a lot of water and broadacre farming with lots of pesticides.

We as a nation must recognise how good we are at finding answers to those things. We are one of the most productive cotton growers in the world. I have issues of cotton, as a lot of people do, mainly because of what we do with it after it's grown—we make rubbish stuff and then throw it in the tip. If we actually used cotton for the great fabric it is, it would have 100 years of life, which it should have. There are now companies in the US who have figured out how to recycle cotton by extruding the fabrics like viscose. So there is life after its first use, but that's a different matter. You will hear the growing concerns around the world about really water intensive crops.

We are really good at finding answers. Australia is one of the great innovative farming nations, and we are really good at it. I know we're one of the most productive cotton growers. I know we already have drones in the sky that are seeking out the first infestations of pests so that we can reduce the amount of insecticide. We know we are doing water-wise farming. We are good at this stuff. We need to recognise that, as people in cities, and get this government to act a bit more on how we can help our farmers adjust to the future which they're going to have to face. There will sectors that won't be as large as they are now because they just won't be able to be. The pressure will be great. The longer we wait, the greater that pressure will be and the harder it will be to adjust.

Now is the time, as the member for Hunter says, for both sides of politics to get together with the experts around the country and start sitting down and working out what the world and the different regions of Australia will look like in five, 10 or 15 years, and how to make sure our farming sector in 15 years is as good as it is now. It will be different than it is now in some areas; in some areas it won't be. There will be changes, and we need to plan those changes so that the extraordinary skills we have, the people who have that commitment to the land, the people who have been there for generations and the people who have extraordinary research skills can use that for the benefit of us all.

I met with some representatives of the university sector recently who are working on protein levels in rice. We often hear this about climate change from people who don't understand: that carbon dioxide is plant food and therefore it makes the plants grow faster. Well, it does, but it's like sugar in a human body. Your cells get bigger, but you don't have more nutrients, so you get less protein per kilo. If carbon emissions go up even enough to cause a two-degree increase, we'll have less protein in rice, less protein in wheat. But we have universities in Australia that are working really hard and really well on finding solutions to that by breeding rice which has a higher protein level. We're good at this stuff. This is where we should be. We should be leading the world, exporting our smarts and finding solutions for our farmers.

To all the farmers out there who might be listening to me and thinking 'okay', there's more to it than this. I know there is but, again, I want to say to you all that we are all in this together. We need as a nation our farming sector to be strong. We need the government to act now to ensure that it is. We need the government to recognise the difficulties some of our farmers are going to face in some sectors and act now so the transition from where we are now to where we need to be is as gentle and as effective as possible. There are great opportunities in this for Australia as well because of how good we are at adjusting and because we are incredibly innovative in our farming sector. We should use that. We're good at it, we should be better at it and we should find a pathway for our farmers through to the future.

Mr LITTLEPROUD (Maranoa—Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management) (17:16): I thank the member for Parramatta and all those who contributed. I say to the member for Parramatta: it's not about starting; we already have. Proudly, our primary producers are at the cutting edge of science and technology. We have been on this journey since we first put a till in the soil and we have been adapting ever since. In fact, every year, governments and farmers themselves have been contributing over $1 billion in research and development so that we are at the cutting edge of genetics and new seed varieties to be able to adapt, to grow more with less.

I think it's important we as a parliament acknowledge the heavy lifting the agricultural sector has already done and will continue to do because we have had to. Our farmers have proven to be the best at that because they have had to be. This fact, obviously, has been highlighted during this quite difficult time of drought. We need to understand this drought hasn't just been the last 12 months. My own electorate of Maranoa in western Queensland and central west Queensland are going into year 8. So the government's response, and, I have to say, that of the government before us, has been around making sure we continue to support those farmers. But addressing drought is like going up a set of stairs—as it escalates, you take another step. Over that seven- to eight-year journey, we have continued to take steps.

One of the steps we have taken has been around the farm household allowance. It's a safety net, as are a lot of our social security payments, to provide the dignity and respect our farmers deserve during tough times. When the Farm Household Allowance was first created, it was created with the premise that if you were a farmer, you would be eligible to receive this payment for three years in a lifetime. Obviously the world has evolved and governments have changed. It was only fitting that we as a government look at this support payment with experts, go and listen to farmers to understand the makeup of it and ask: was it fit for purpose and was it fit for the future? Proudly, Georgie Somerset, the general president of AgForce, the peak agricultural body in Queensland, led that review, and recommended quite clearly that droughts will continue to be more prevalent, and having a three-year in a lifetime limit for a farmer to receive this payment does not reflect the true nature of farming and the hardships they face. It also needs to be acknowledged that the agricultural sector, farming sector, has evolved considerably over the years in being more self-reliant but, again, this is a safety net measure to make sure those most vulnerable in the sector are protected. We've taken that recommendation.

In fact, this bill reflects much of that report in making sure that we now change the period that a farmer can receive the farm household allowance to four in every 10 years. We are making sure that farmers understand that we'll be there to support them, not just through this drought but in future droughts as well. It's important to also appreciate, and I think the Prime Minister articulated it very well in question time today, that while we're respecting the review and this legislation is reflecting that review, it's also around the supplementary payments. While we acknowledge that there will be some who have used up their four-year period, we will continue to be agile and we will continue to supplement this with supplementary payments, as was announced only recently—only last week—to make sure that $13,000 per family is provided.

Obviously, if this drought continues—God forbid—and we get to a position in May next year, then we'll continue to be agile. I know that those opposite will work with us constructively to ensure that we get through this drought. These are the agile steps that we'll continue to take with FHA in particular, understanding its importance as part of the three pillars of our drought strategy policy that we have been implementing for some time. It forms part of our first pillar, about the here and now. We understand that having that money in farmers' pockets is giving them the dignity and respect they deserve and need to make strategic decisions. We've complemented it also. Those who go on farm household allowance are given a rural financial counsellor to help them and support them to not only fill out the paperwork but also to create an environment where they can make strategic decisions about their future. We're giving them four years to make a strategic decision about where their business should go and how they can achieve that with professional advice and support.

The payment itself is not just about keeping bread and butter on the table; it's about creating the environment, complemented by the rural financial counsellors. We put on an additional 49 of those over the last 18 months to help support the demand of being at the kitchen table, helping our farmers make those decisions, filling out the paperwork, directing them to professional advice and supporting them with financial institutions. It's important to understand that this isn't just a payment; this is also a vehicle in which we are providing an opportunity for our farmers to be able to make the decisions they need to make about their future, their family's future and their business's future in a dignified manner. There are complementary measures around support and training that are also important. It's about understanding that as a key pillar of the here and now.

It's also about keeping money flowing through towns. Over the period of four years, many of the recipients will receive over $120,000 in support from the Australian government, the Australian taxpayer. You've got to understand that it also flows through the local communities. That money is spent at the local supermarket, the butcher, the baker and the servo, and that flows through the town. In a sense, it's also an economic stimulus. When farmers don't have money, they don't spend it unless they really have to, and that's normally on overdrafts. They're able to use this money to keep stimulating the local economies. Also, with respect to the Regional Investment Corporation, there are concessional loans that are saving tens of thousands of dollars, complementing farm household allowance and putting money back into farmers' pockets, so it's going back into the local towns.

The second pillar is about the community, understanding that the drought extends, as the member for Parramatta articulated, to not just the farm gate but beyond that. The complexities of local economies need to be respected and supported as well, on top of the money that we're providing through farm household allowance and concessional loans, and through the stimulus package, which is directly targeted towards growing the economic base in these communities—getting tradies to build projects for the community with materials procured from a local hardware store. Also, around the mental health piece, it's about making sure it's targeted at a local level.

There is the third pillar of our drought policy that we continue to implement. For the first time, governments have been criticised for being reactionary to drought. This government is the first government to create a fund for the future, for the next drought. We're not only looking at the here and now, through our first pillar and through the communities, in the here and now, but we're also looking to the future—a Drought Future Fund that will pay a dividend every year, in the good and the bad. It's legislated. In fact, the panel will give me that plan in the coming week. That will go out. The panel has been legislated to go out and consult for 42 days amongst the community to make sure that the plan will provide the stimulus that's required to give our farmers the tools for future droughts. That will be through extension work—R&D in particular—by making sure our R&D is targeted around droughts, with extension work to ensure that our farmers take up the tools that they need.

The other piece that has been quite important—in fact it has been one that we've driven, around our future approach to tackling droughts—has been tax concessions, through the Farm Management Deposits Scheme, allowing farmers to put away money in a term deposit in the good years, with tax incentives, and bring it back in the hard years to minimise their tax. That's a smart way for farmers to prepare for droughts. In fact I've been able to also get a commitment from the major lenders to allow the farm management deposits to be offset against their term debt, much like, when you can walk into any bank to get a home loan, you can offset your savings against your home loan. It's the same principle. Some of our banks have been better than others. Tomorrow we're having another financial task force with the banks to make sure they are moving towards the creation of these products, because that will also save tens of thousands of dollars for these people who put money away into farm management deposits, putting money back into their pocket and putting it into the communities.

We also provide tax concessions around having write-offs for building infrastructure to store fodder to prepare for future droughts. The Australian taxpayer puts out over $500 million every year in concessions to support farmers to prepare for the next drought. That will complement the future fund. Thirdly, it's about building infrastructure: $3.2 billion has been there, prepared to work with the states, to take their hand, to build infrastructure, to harvest the rain when it comes. That's so important to provide resilience for our farmers to get through one drought to the next but also grow our regional communities. This is an opportunity we can't let go. It's great to see that, finally, New South Wales has taken our hand, and we've announced an additional $500 million to partner with them on two projects. The third one is being planned and scoped as quickly as we possibly can.

Our drought strategy has been in action for some time. We continue to add to it as the drought escalates. But it's quite clear: it's about the here and now. We cannot forget the here and now. These changes will make sure the here and now is respected both now and in future droughts. We have respected the review that Georgie Somerset and her team undertook and those principles that she has provided, and we will continue to make sure the stimulus we provide to these communities will be meaningful. We ask the states, who also have a responsibility in this, to come with us as well. We have a unanimous and bipartisan approach to drought with the states. They look after animal welfare; we look after farmer welfare. It's important that they take our hand and work constructively on making sure they live up to their responsibilities.

This bill is one that respects that review. It enacts for the future; it enacts for here and now. It doesn't preclude our continuing to be agile in making sure that those supplementary payments, if required—as we proved last week—will be rolled out until this drought is over. This drought will be over only with considerable rain, and the one thing none of us in this place can do—I haven't found anyone who can—is make it rain. But it will rain. We need to be positive and make sure we do not talk agriculture and regional Australia down. This is so important. While I understand the severity and urgency of what we're doing, we cannot talk down the important role of our primary producers for our nation and their important future. The story of agriculture is, 'Just add rain.' It will, and when it does our regional communities will flourish. This is an opportunity for us to get them there. When it does happen, I can see a bright future not just for regional Australia but for our entire country, because of the significant role that the agriculture sector plays for this nation.

It's important that, while the emotion is there and raw and real, we must make sure it's kept in check. We understand that there are bright futures, and we need the next generation to come through and be as proud as their forefathers of what they produce in this country. I believe we're setting the foundation stones for that to happen with our drought policy in the here and now and in the future, and with the rest of the work we've done around the agricultural sector. This is another piece to that complex puzzle of addressing drought, a very complex natural disaster that needs a specific approach. That's what this government does. I commend the bill to the House.

span.span: A division having been called and the bells having been rung—

p.span: Mr Burke: Point of order: it might assist the House if you made clear the question that is actually before the House, given what's on the screens. We on this side are not voting that the member for Hunter be no longer heard.

The SPEAKER: They've just fixed it now. I would have been fascinated in the vote, actually! The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hunter has moved as an amendment that all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. So the immediate question is that the amendment be agreed to—and I'm grateful that the screens now reflect that.

body.p:
The House divided. [17:34]
(The Speaker—Hon. Tony Smith)

Question negatived.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

p.span: Third Reading

Mr LITTLEPROUD
(Maranoa—Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management) (17:40): by leave—I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Amendment Bill 2019

p.span: Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Amendment Bill 2019
Second Reading
Ms PRICE (Durack—Minister for Defence Industry) (17:40): I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Amendment Bill 2019 amends the Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Act 2011 to give effect to the government's decision to implement recommendations arising from the review of the impact of the TEQSA Act on the higher education sector.

This review was conducted in line with section 203 of the TEQSA Act, which required that the minister, before 1 January 2016, cause a review to be started of the impact on the higher education sector of the TEQSA Act.

In December 2015, terms of reference for the review were determined, with Deloitte Access Economics engaged to undertake the review between July 2016 and March 2017. The review was a substantial body of work: 36 written submissions were received, 33 stakeholders were interviewed, and the TEQSA Act was extensively analysed.
Overall, the review was positive about the establishment of TEQSA as the national regulator in 2012, noting that the TEQSA Act is broadly operating effectively and as intended.
The review noted that the higher education sector's views regarding the regulatory system established by the act, and TEQSA as the regulator, are positive.

The sector sees in TEQSA a regulator that is seeking to reduce the burden imposed by its activities, tailoring its requirements to meet individual features of providers and engaging more fully with the sector. The review therefore did not recommend changes that would significantly alter the regulatory framework or the role of TEQSA as the independent national higher education regulator.

The recommendations made by the review are largely technical in nature. They are designed to place TEQSA and the regulatory and quality assurance system established by the act on a stronger footing. This bill gives effect to the review recommendations that require amendments to this act.

The measures contained in this bill will improve the already effective and efficient higher education regulatory system, enabling the sector to continue its focus on delivering the highest quality teaching, learning and research, maximising the quality of educational outcomes for students and protecting Australia's international higher education reputation.

The bill simplifies the legislative framing of the Higher Education Standards Framework by removing references from the TEQSA Act to specific categories of non-threshold standards that have never been made and are not needed. The capacity to make additional standards will be retained, however, if the need ever arises.

The bill requires that TEQSA inform the minister and the Higher Education Standards Panel before it undertakes quality assessment under section 60 of the act that engages the majority of higher education providers. This will ensure that the resource implications of any such activity and the regulatory burden it would create for providers are appropriately considered before undertaking such an assessment. This amendment will remove the need for the current tougher restriction placed on such assessments by Ministerial Direction No. 2 of 2013, which the government will repeal once the amendment act commences.

There are amendments made in relation to the Higher Education Standards Panel. The bill will expand the skill set that the minister must ensure is encompassed by panel members so that, collectively, the panel has contemporary experience in the provision of higher education by both university and non-university providers. This amendment is important for the panel's oversight and regulatory roles, ensuring its advice is balanced and reflects a collective understanding of issues relevant to different service providers.

The bill also expands the functions of the panel to more appropriately reflect its role to provide oversight of TEQSA's strategic and operational planning and approaches to deregulation, which were functions of the former TEQSA Advisory Council.

A new provision will allow TEQSA to disclose higher education information about a regulated entity to a person who has lodged a complaint where TEQSA is satisfied that the information to be disclosed relates to the subject matter of the complaint. Currently TEQSA can publish such information but cannot disclose the information to individual complainant students. This amendment will improve TEQSA's capacity to respond appropriately to complainants, facilitating better engagement between TEQSA and students of higher education providers.

Finally, the bill provides for a number of technical amendments, mainly suggested during the review, including minor adjustments to the capacity to disclose both higher education and personal information to the Department of Education and to the minister, to facilitate the disclosure of information for research purposes with appropriate safeguards and to clarify quorum provisions for meetings of the commissioners.
I commend the bill.

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (17:47): I rise to speak on the Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Amendment Bill 2019. This bill makes some changes to the higher education agency, TEQSA. These changes flow from the recommendations of the Review of the Impact of the TEQSA Act on the Higher Education Sector, commissioned by the government in 2016. It's important to note that the review of the TEQSA Act did not find any major failings in TEQSA's operations, and I thank the TEQSA staff for the great work that they do.

The provisions proposed in this bill aim to strengthen and simplify the act to improve the functioning of TEQSA. The changes include: simplifying the legislative framing of the higher education standards framework by removing some specific categories of non-threshold standards, such as the teaching and learning standards, the research standards and the information standards, that have never been made and are not needed, but retaining the capacity to make additional standards if the need arises; removing references to the research minister—that is, the minister responsible for the Australian Research Council Act 2001—in provisions that relate to appointments and acting appointments of TEQSA commissioners and panel members, and to the functions of the panel, and requiring that advice on new standards need only be sought from the research minister if the minister is not also the research minister; requiring TEQSA to advise the minister and the panel before it undertakes a quality review; amending the offence provisions of the act to reflect that an overseas university not registered by TEQSA can offer a course of study that is not wholly or mainly provided from Australian premises, and using the word 'university' to represent its operations without committing an offence; amending quorum requirements for TEQSA meetings to require a majority of commissioners; and expanding the skill set that the minister must ensure is encompassed by the Higher Education Standards Panel members.
The new provisions will require the minister, when appointing members to the panel, to:
… ensure Panel members collectively have contemporary experience in the provision of higher education by higher education providers that are universities and that are not universities.

The changes also include expanding the functions of the Higher Education Standards Panel to more appropriately reflect its role to provide oversight of TEQSA's strategic and operational planning and approaches to deregulation. The changes improve the information-sharing and disclosure provisions to allow TEQSA to operate more effectively by: providing that it is an exception to the offence of unauthorised disclosure or use of information if the entity the information relates to has consented in writing to the disclosure or use; allowing TEQSA to disclose higher education information to officers in the department in addition to the secretary, and to also disclose personal information that relates to TEQSA's functions to the minister, a member of staff of the minister, the secretary or to officers in the department; allowing TEQSA to disclose information for research purposes; and, finally, allowing TEQSA to disclose information to a complainant in relation to a complaint without the consent of the body to which the information applies, provided TEQSA is satisfied that the information relates to the subject of the complaint. As I said earlier, these amendments are designed to strengthen and simplify the act to improve the functioning of TEQSA.

TEQSA was established by the Gillard government in 2012. It is Australia's independent national quality assurance and regulatory agency for higher education. The TESQA Act required that the minister cause a review to be commenced before 1 January 2016 on the impact on the higher education sector of the TEQSA Act. The former Minister for Education and Training determined the terms of reference for this review. Deloitte Access Economics undertook this review between July 2016 and March 2017. It was an extensive review. Thirty-six written submissions were received, 33 stakeholders were interviewed, and the TEQSA Act was extensively analysed.

The review was positive about the establishment of TEQSA as the national regulator. It noted that the TEQSA Act was broadly operating effectively and as it was intended. The review did not recommend changes that would significantly alter the regulatory framework or the role of TEQSA. The review recommended amendments to the TEQSA Act that are designed to improve the act's administration, strengthen TEQSA's regulatory role, and better reflect the role of the Higher Education Standards Panel as the statutory advisory body established under the act.

Labor supports this bill. It makes some minor changes to the operation of TEQSA that will improve and strengthen the functions of that body. What is concerning is that the recommendations of the review of TEQSA, to which this bill responds, were provided to the Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison government almost three years ago. The coalition government is now in its seventh year. Why has it taken the coalition government so long to implement the sensible set of recommendations from that review? It's typical of this government's treatment of Australia's world-class higher education system.

Sadly, the only interest this Morrison government has in education is to cut. The education sector has had six years of cuts and chaos. Students have been hit particularly hard. They now have to pay off HELP debts sooner—putting more pressure on their household budgets. At the same time, they are desperately trying to compete with property investors to buy their first home. Universities are turning away students after this Liberal government capped places, leaving regional and outer suburban communities worse off. At the 2017 MYEFO, the government went after research—ripping $328.5 million from university research, which will devastate our critically important research sector. If Australia is to succeed in this Asian Century, we need to broaden participation in higher education, not reduce it. We also risk being left behind when other similar economies in our region are boosting their investment in science, research and higher education. This government is doing exactly the opposite: capping undergraduate places, slashing research, cutting vocational education and training, and leaving 2.5 million public school students in this country worse off by failing to properly fund public education.
Labor knows that education, at all levels, is the key to our future prosperity and to a stronger society. As I said, Labor supports this bill but I wish to move the following amendment. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that the Government has damaged the quality of Australia's world-class higher education system, having cut billions from universities by effectively capping undergraduate places, and slashing research funding".

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Ms Claydon ): Is the amendment seconded?
Mr Neumann: I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Ms PRICE (Durack—Minister for Defence Industry) (17:55): I thank the member for Moreton for his contribution. The Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Amendment Bill 2019 amends the Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Act 2011 to give effect to the government's decision to implement recommendations arising from the review of the impact of the TEQSA Act on the higher education sector. The review recommended amendments to the TEQSA Act that are designed to improve the act's administration, strengthen TEQSA's regulatory role and better reflect the role of the Higher Education Standards Panel as the statutory advisory body established under the act. In combination, these recommendations will improve the regulation of Australia's higher education act. I commend the bill to the House.

The SPEAKER: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Moreton has moved as an amendment that all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question before the chair is that the amendment moved by the honourable member for Moreton be agreed to.

body.p:
The House divided. [18:00]
(The Speaker—Hon. Tony Smith)

Question negatived.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

p.span: Third Reading
Ms PRICE (Durack—Minister for Defence Industry) (18:04): by leave—I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019, VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019, Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019

p.span: Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019
VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019
Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019
Second Reading
Cognate debate.
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That these bills be now read a second time.

Ms KEARNEY (Cooper) (18:05): I rise this afternoon to contribute to the cognate debate on the Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019, the VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 and the Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019. These bills seek to introduce a tuition protection scheme for students who use student loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses at public and private providers, including TAFEs, in cases of provider or course closure. The measures contained in the bills were first proposed by the Liberal government in the Midyear Economic and Fiscal Outlook, MYEFO, in 2018-19.

I will say up-front that Labor will not seek to oppose these bills. Students should be protected and assisted in the case of provider or course closure. We welcome the practical effect, which is to create simpler arrangements for some students and processes for decision-making, student placement, and VSL and HELP loan recrediting. However, as with all things, the devil is in the detail. This government seems incapable of managing detail or the detail is full of devils.

Nearly all the stakeholders in the sector support the intention of these bills but have noted concerns with the legislation. TAFE Directors Australia, or TDA, have summarised it best. The three bills, they say, 'fail to establish a coherent approach for the operation of tertiary education in Australia,' and we agree. The tertiary education sector is a mess. But specifically, the TDA have also raised concerns over the requirement for TAFEs to take on students who may have received less than adequate training at a failing provider. They note TAFEs should be given the right to reject students or force them to start the course afresh if there's evidence of poor training practices against the training package requirements.

So let's face it. We've all heard about the lack of quality and rigor of some providers. These concerns are legitimate and they're not an indictment on the students but on those providers who sought to exploit the system at the expense of their students. The TAFEs can actually incur penalties if they do not accept students and to force them to take students who are either bound to fail or who need to start all over again is a major problem that is not dealt with by these bills. It's not fair to either the TAFE or the students to raise expectations that are simply not deliverable.

Independent Higher Education Australia raised concerns around the lack of coverage for fee-paying students. Under this legislation, students who fully fund their own education will not be protected by the government in the same way that students with a loan are. IHEA note that, if the government doesn't assure these students, providers will be required to go to market to source their own tuition protection insurance. This means that: 'There is no guarantee that they'll be able to access an appropriate scheme after 1 January next year,' and this is deeply concerning. Ironically, as IHEA point out, entrenching of different protection arrangements for different cohorts of students creates significant additional regulatory requirements on providers who are registered and accredited Australian education businesses. So, for a government who loves to talk about cutting red tape, here they are adding more to higher education and vocational education providers.

Apart from the concerns for the providers, there is still no protection for the students themselves—those who opt to pay upfront and, through no fault of their own, find themselves left totally in the lurch. I've spoken with young people devastated, after paying all or part of their fees, to have to try to find money to start over again when their providers fail them. We are talking thousands of dollars lost, down the drain. It's a lot of money to a young person, or to an older person who finds themselves having to retrain to re-enter the workforce. When a person, particularly a young one, starts a course, they are filled with hope and excitement about the future, about where their hard work gaining a qualification will get them. And it's hard to cope, watching their disappointment.

Labor understands that this legislation is designed to deal with the loan scheme specifically, but the government must address these valid concerns. They can't ignore full-fee-paying students who may be left in the lurch through no fault of their own. The Independent Tertiary Education Council Australia, or ITECA, have noted that the levy will likely be passed on to students. They are frustrated by the growing trend of government cost-recovery programs and schemes in the higher ed and vocational training sector.

So we have referred these bills to committee, to ensure that these concerns are addressed and so that stakeholders, both provider and student, have a chance to have a say about these issues, so that we can indeed examine the shortfalls and the broad implications of the legislation. But, more broadly, this legislation is just a tweak to a sector that requires a genuine reform package.

The Liberals have trashed the quality of Australia's world-class higher education system and vocational education system. They have cut billions of dollars from universities by recapping undergraduate places, and they've slashed research funding. They have torn out funding from under TAFE and training, let apprenticeship numbers freefall and presided over a national shortage of tradies, traineeships and apprentices. Apart from the $3 billion they have cut from TAFE funding, we've found, in a new report released just this week, that the Prime Minister and this government have short-changed TAFE, training and apprenticeship programs by an almost $1 billion underspend. Is it any wonder that, under this government, our TAFEs are in disrepair and apprentice and trainee numbers have fallen off a cliff?

They keep referring to what happened in Labor's time. Well, we were actually trying to stop a well-used rort by employers who were putting trainees through certificates—sometimes, without the employee's knowledge—using dodgy providers. And we stopped that, quite rightly. But, you see, we had a plan—a plan to revitalise the public provider, TAFE, restart the VET system and rebuild the sector.

This government has learned nothing. It has no plan to rebuild and revitalise. Numbers have fallen to a lower point than a decade ago. They can't keep blaming everyone else. They can't keep blaming anyone other than themselves. 'Oh,' said the Prime Minister today in question time, 'there's nothing to see here,' when he was asked about this underspend, 'because it's a demand-driven system. We pay on demand,' he said. 'We pay everything that is asked of us.'

He said the same about the massive NDIS underspend. The same trickery applies here. No-one believes that all the NDIS clients are getting what they need. We all know how many people are being left in the lurch by the NDIS. They can't get equipment, can't get services, can't get their plans renewed and can't even get anyone on the phone to help them. There are families who can't get respite for their children and who tragically end up relinquishing them to the system, something that any normal person would find not only heartbreaking but completely unacceptable—normal people, I say, not those opposite. They don't seem to care. They just want to bank the leftover billions into their surplus account.

Nor do they care about vocational education and training. Do they really think anyone believes that the underspend is because of lack of demand? They are kidding themselves if they do. Youth unemployment is at an all-time high. Employers who are desperate for skilled workers can't get them; 75 per cent of employers are telling us that they can't get skilled workers for their businesses. Kids who would love an apprenticeship or a traineeship could fill those skills gaps in a minute. I know young people who would jump at the offer of a decent future with a qualification for life. And employers would employ them.

In my electorate of Cooper, I have manufacturers in textile, clothing, footwear, food production and the automotive industry. I have businesses that are desperate for skilled workers, and they see me every other week and tell me they can't get them, and they would in a minute snap up people on traineeships and apprenticeships. I have parents, young ones and—we mustn't forget—older workers needing to reskill telling me every day that they would jump at a training opportunity. So don't tell me and don't tell the people of Australia that the demand isn't there. It's complete rubbish. By saying so, the Prime Minister is misleading the Australian people. They are underspending on vocational education and training the same way they are on the National Disability Insurance Scheme, and it is totally on purpose. They are chasing a surplus at the expense of people with a disability and people desperate for a qualification and a job. Australians deserve excellent TAFEs and universities. They deserve a first-class tertiary education. They deserve the skills that the state can provide. And they deserve a decent, high-quality job. But it seems that the government doesn't think that's true.

The effect of overzealous application of competition policy and privatisation in the VET sector, coupled with chronic underfunding, has had devastating effects on the sector. Under the Liberal government, there are 150,000 fewer apprentices and trainees and a shortage of workers in critical services, including plumbing, carpentry, hairdressing and motor mechanics. The number of Australians doing an apprenticeship or traineeship is lower today than it was a decade ago. There are more people dropping out of apprenticeships and traineeships than finishing them. There are myriad reasons why that is happening, and the government is not addressing any of them. There has been a nearly 10 per cent increase in the number of occupations facing skills shortages. As I said before, they have slashed $3 billion from TAFE funding.

In too many towns and regional centres across Australia, TAFE campuses have closed, courses have been scaled back and fees have increased. We have heard recently that the Alanvale Campus of TasTAFE in Launceston is possibly closing. How can we let that happen? If anywhere needed a properly funded TAFE, it's the north of Tasmania. Young people in regional areas, keen to stay near home and family or unable to afford to move away to study, benefit greatly from regional TAFEs enabling them to gain skills that give them a start in life. Regional TAFEs are often the hub of a regional town's community. They offer employment. They offer business to local enterprises. They bring communities together for events and provide an oft-needed boost to morale. This abject failing of the government has a real effect on people's lives.

The Australian Industry Group, as I said before, has a survey that found 75 per cent of businesses are struggling to find the qualified workers they need. This isn't about young people not wanting to work, as the government and some media outlets would have us believe; this is about training and skilling opportunities simply not being available where they are needed. This government is not supporting industry and workers to get the skills they need. So, while businesses are crying out for more trained staff, there are about 1.9 million Australians who are unemployed or underemployed. Why isn't the Prime Minister taking more responsibility for getting these people into jobs in industries where there's a shortage of workers? It can't be rocket science. I think it's because the Liberal government see this simply as a cost—a threat to their precious surplus, just like the billions of dollars that they underspent in the NDIS and just like they cut funding to TAFE and training.

The minister makes noises, and lots of them, about how important the sector is, how we need to encourage enrolments and how we need to get people to take up courses. Well, what is the minister going to say to the young people in Launceston? Maybe she'll say that one of her industry training hubs will do the trick—the hubs that we hear so much about from the other side. Labor will support any measure that gets young people into training and into jobs, but we need a lot more than 10 hubs. I'd really like to know exactly what the hubs are. Is it a person? Is it a building? Is it an institution? How will it get the kids into TAFE courses if there aren't any TAFEs or vocational education and training providers around the hub? And how do they plan to get them into decent, secure work? We're a little bit scant on the detail of this brilliant idea.

People and businesses need a skills training sector that is properly funded, properly resourced and has educators who are properly trained—and properly paid, I might add, through decent jobs—with the ability to skill these kids and unemployed adults as a pathway to meaningful employment. The government haven't delivered on a single element of those. Day after day, I hear of young people who do their best. They're trying to skill up, they're trying to get a job, but they're up against a system which is actively pushing them away. They're up against funding cuts and a government that are actually hostile towards vocational education, and, by extension, a government that are dismantling the already limited pathways for young people to gain employment. They're simply not tackling the problem full-on.

The latest statistics from the ABS show that we have a youth unemployment rate of 11.8 per cent, and we know that it's so much higher in many of our regional areas. That's around 295,000 young people who are actively searching for work but are coming up short. Interestingly, as I said, I've been meeting with employers in my electorate and around Victoria who are crying out for skilled workers. They can't get them. Manufacturers, people in food production, disability equipment manufacturers, and many more are all worried about how they will attract a productive and skilled workforce. This is not simply because nobody wants these jobs; this is symptomatic of a skills shortage crisis gripping Australia. Maybe, and I'm just speculating here, young people aren't gaining the skills needed to take up these jobs because this government have cut $3 billion from vocational education. Maybe it has something to do with the fact that their $525 million skills package includes only $54.5 million of new funding. Maybe it has something to do with the continued funding cuts, the closure of TAFE campuses around Australia or the government's refusal to listen to the sector, to young people or to educators screaming out for real investment. The government's answer to all this is a few hubs. We're not sure what they are, as I said.

And the government have hired Scott Cam. Scott Cam has been snapped up by the government to promote trades to Australia's young people. Don't get me wrong: I'm absolutely sure he's a good bloke and I take no offence at the promotion of trades. He is a role model. Young people should be taking up trades and we should be promoting secure, decent jobs in trades. I do, however, find it shocking that the government are paying a National Careers Ambassador—I don't know how much—while they cut $3 billion from the sector, and underspend by nearly another $1 billion; while they see fit to cut all of that money from vocational education and training, to cut funds from group training organisations, to cut TAFE funding, and to put educators out of work; while their policies have caused the number of apprentices and trainees to fall by 150,000; while they have let apprentices in this country be more likely to drop out than finish. And, even when all of that is true, when all of this is happening right around them, when there is a perfect storm coming their way with regard to skills shortages and youth unemployment, what do they do? They hire a celebrity. Great! Just great! At least this announcement provided some comic relief from the reality of this government's plan for employment and skills training in Australia, because the situation we currently face is an indictment of this government.

We are simultaneously experiencing a crisis in youth unemployment and a crisis in skills shortages. It is bad enough having to deal with one of these, but both of them at the same time is hard to imagine. If we continue down this path, we will severely jeopardise our future economic growth, we will undermine the opportunity for individual Australians to meet their full potential and, very importantly, we will compromise our ability as a nation to compete with the rest of the world, using the skills, knowledge, discoveries and inventions of our people.

We know that nine out of 10 jobs created in the future will need a post-secondary-school education, either TAFE or university. So we need to increase participation in both universities and our VET sector to make sure that we as a nation are prepared for the world of work. This third-term government simply refuses to deliver a genuine reform package that overhauls the higher education sector and properly funds both vocational training providers and universities to deliver the services their students need. Consequently, I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(1) the Government has:
(a) damaged the quality of Australia's world-class higher education and vocational training system;
(b) cut funding to TAFE and training;
(c) let apprentice numbers fall; and
(d) presided over a national shortage in skilled tradespeople; and
(2) Australians deserve excellent TAFEs and universities and the Government has gutted both."

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Ms Claydon ): Is the amendment seconded?
Mr Giles: I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Ms RYAN (Lalor—Opposition Whip) (18:28): I am absolutely pleased to rise tonight to support the member for Cooper's amendment, because every word of it is true. Labor find ourselves in this position: after six years, this government is finally taking some action in an area that we've been asking them to take action in for at least six years. They are finally bringing in a piece of legislation that will help, practically, to alleviate some of the stresses faced by students, particularly where they could potentially have a debt without certification. So Labor will not oppose this legislation. We will, however, take the opportunity to remind the government of its failures in this space—and we're not alone.

While key stakeholders largely support the intention of the bill, some have expressed concerns which do need to be taken into consideration and which are worth highlighting this evening. Notably, Independent Higher Education Australia has concerns around the lack of coverage for fee-paying students, and of course, amongst those fee-paying students, there are going to be international students. TAFE Directors Australia have concerns around the requirements to take on poorly trained students in the event of course closures, and of course they do, because they would be being asked to work triple time to bring those young people—or those people, if they're mature-age students—up to speed at their expense while somebody else walks away. Further, the Independent Tertiary Education Council of Australia have raised concerns regarding providers eventually passing the cost of the levy, this cost recovery measure, onto students. These are genuine concerns coming from the peak bodies in this sector. In order for those concerns to be properly considered and addressed Labor will refer the bills to the Senate Education and Employment Legislation Committee for an inquiry to do some due diligence and ensure there aren't unintended consequences in other areas.

Students in vocational education and training and higher education are increasingly facing high amounts of stress and pressure, with many having to balance their coursework with jobs and outside commitments just to stay afloat. These bills address the question of how to best protect students who use loans to pay for vocational education and training. They are part of an ongoing effort required to counter the increases VET FEE-HELP has caused in course fees and unrecoverable student debt. The bills will have tangible and practical effects on the lives of students who access loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses. They will create simpler arrangements for students in student placement and VSL and HELP recrediting. Further, they seek to protect and assist domestic students who are taking out a loan in the event that the provider where they receive their education closes or if their course is discontinued.

Unlike the Liberals, Labor values the vital role that a properly funded VET sector plays in driving our economy and enhancing our industry. Unlike those opposite, Labor understands the critical role of TAFE as a public provider, the value of skills and apprenticeships and the value of hardworking and passionate public TAFE teachers. This government has, time after time, let this sector down. As the member for Cooper put it, they have gutted this sector with their cuts. Since this government was elected six years ago, universities have faced constant cuts, with attempts at fee deregulation, policy chaos and uncertainty and the threat of $100,000 degrees. They've done exactly the same in TAFE. We now find ourselves in a space where this government knows full well that it's lost 150,000 apprentices on its watch. It stands here in question time with soaring rhetoric about the 80,000 apprenticeships it's going to create, without a TAFE sector to assist in that process, with the TAFE sector decimated, with state governments scrambling to find ways to rebuild the TAFE sector at the state level. We know that, without a strong TAFE and VET sector, and unless young people and those wanting to retrain have access to appropriate quality training, the 80,000 apprentices are an absolute dream.

I raise my real concern about what this means for fee-paying students. In my electorate that's international students. I want the government to think carefully about those in this space. We often hear excitement and celebration from both sides of the chamber about higher education where international students come to Australia to study. We hear huge figures about what this industry is worth to this country. I want to go through a few of those figures. At the moment in VET we have 194,600 international fee-paying students in this country. They're not going to get any support from this piece of legislation. In higher education we have 430,000, a lot more. I want the government to think about what it means if international students aren't covered by this. They're open to being exploited and to being enrolled in courses that aren't going to deliver the quality of certification that we're assuring for our domestic students who take out a loan. I want the government to think about what long-term impact that may have on the international reputation of an industry that is of high dollar value to this country and, more importantly, is creating well-paid, high-quality jobs in the education sector.

I would want to see this looked at by the Senate inquiry, because in my electorate we have many international students who are studying and who are studying in VET providers. I want to make sure that (a) they are getting the quality that they're paying for on entry into the country and (b) we're not put in the situation where the risks being taken there actually have an impact on the higher education sector, where we have double the number of students coming to this country. Government needs to know that, internationally, people think Australia is a destination for international students for higher education—in the university sector and in the VET sector. The two go together in the eyes of those countries that are accessing them, and there is a real risk here that we are not providing the same guarantee to our international students, and that would put the industry at risk.

Unlike the Liberals, Labor values the role of a properly funded VET sector and the vital role it plays in driving our economy and enhancing our industry. We understand how important it is to have domestic students trained and to have people ready to take up the trade positions that are available. We know that we have a skills shortage. We know that, because we keep hearing about it. We know it, because business tells us so. We know it, because you can't engage even with small business in my community without them raising this issue, without them asking me about it. I met with someone who worked in my electorate for years as a carpenter, who had apprentices most of his life, and he said to me just the other day: 'Jo, what's happening in this sector? There's no clarity. No-one seems to be able to tell me how you become an apprentice these days or how you become a tradesman these days.' There is no clarity, because this government is asleep at the wheel.

We have plummeting TAFE enrolments while the fees skyrocket, and yet the Liberals seem to question why more students aren't choosing to pursue vocational education and training. They're busy having a culture war. It's all about the rhetoric. They come in here and say: 'You don't need a university degree. You should just go and study at VET.' People should be tradesmen—notice the 'man' on the end of that sentence! People should be getting a trade. Well, what's the government doing about ensuring that there are facilities available across our electorates so that young people and people who want to retrain can access them?

Even if it solves some of the problems in youth unemployment—if it's funded properly, if the certification is ensured, if there is a guarantee that young people are getting value for the money that they're spending, if there are jobs in the areas where they are being trained—it's still not really going to help. It's still not going to assist the fact that the highest newest emerging number of people who are now homeless are women over 55, who I don't think are going to retrain, motivated by Scott Cam, to become a carpenter. And it's not particularly going to help the people in my electorate who are over 55 who may have lost their jobs because of the Toyota closures. It's not particularly going to help them to have Scott Cam telling them that they can now become a carpenter at 55.

It seems to me that this government has completely lost its way in terms of the vocational education and training sector. I think the answer is really simple. I think the answer is because none of them know anything about it. None of them have been exposed to it. None of them spend any time with the people involved in it. I think that's really what's going on here. As someone who has worked in education for 27 years, who has been close to this sector, it is of critical importance. It's important that our young people trust that, if they take out a loan to seek to get a certification, it's going to lead to a job and there is going to be a meaningful transition. What we know on the ground, what I know in my electorate from people who support students into transitioning meaningfully into work, is that young people need support in that area and that TAFEs used to be part of that program. Our public TAFE sector used to ensure that people were connected. They assisted young people who had completed their training in securing that. They also had a good nose about where the skill shortages were.

Under this government, they have completely lost their way, and nothing tells us that more than seeing the latest marketing ploy employed by this government. You have the rhetoric on one hand and then you have a marketing ploy on the other, and the marketing ploy, of course, is Scott Cam. I've heard many in this place say that they know that Scott Cam is a good bloke. I don't know if he is a good bloke, because I've never met the man. So I'm not prepared to say he is if I don't know. But I've got nothing against the man except this: under the last Prime Minister—remember him?—Malcolm Turnbull, we had the 'fake tradie' and now we've got the celebrity tradie. It's just marketing 101 wheeled out again.

Scott Cam is not going to motivate young people in my electorate to pursue a trade. How on earth is he going to connect to them? What are we doing here? What message is this sending to our media-savvy youngsters? Is it: 'Do a trade so that, when you retire, you can become a television celebrity'? What sort of message is that? Young people aren't stupid. They're far from stupid. Young people want to know, specifically: 'Where are the shortages? Where will I get a job?' Then they want to be able to access a certification or get an apprenticeship first and get their certification—whichever way it works.

I've been here for six years and, for six years, I've heard that we've got skills shortages in areas where it is stupefying to think that we've got a ramping-up in skills shortages, a decrease in apprenticeships and the destruction of the public VET sector. It is absolutely insane. If this government really want aspiration, they need to understand (a) how young people in the suburbs think and (b) the connection and how media-savvy young people are. In my electorate, I know young people will seek the certification if the certification is going to lead to a job.

That leads me to the last point that I want to make in terms of this government's track record in this area. Across the last 12 years, I suppose, we've spent money on trade training centres and we've spent money on Australian Technical Colleges—the Howard years Australian Technical Colleges—and nowhere can I find anybody with a view of how VET in schools is interacting with the certification happening post school. I've got lots of young people in my electorate who tell me that they've got a certification, a cert III in a particular area, only to find that, when they walk out into the real world, there is no skills shortage in that area. Who's looking at the way these two sectors interact? Who's looking at what we put on the ground in terms of facilities across those spends in schools and in communities, with stand-alone Howard colleges? Who's looking at those and what they're doing? Who's checking to see what's being taught in those facilities? Who's checking to see whether those facilities are in need of a refit and whether we could refit them into areas where we've got skills shortages? I am very tired of hearing young people tell me that they're shattered—that they did VCAL in Victoria and they've got a cert III, and now they're being told they need to do a cert II in a completely different trade.

Ms PAYNE (Canberra) (18:43): Labor will not oppose these bills, the Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019, the VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 and the Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019, because they work to protect students. Labor has always sought to protect students working hard to get a high-level qualification, because higher education, whether in the university system or in the TAFE system, is an expensive undertaking.

Australian governments have long sought to support students to undertake higher education through the provision of a world-leading student loan system—either VSL or HELP—because we know that it is good for our economy, good for business and life-changing for students who gain further education after high school. Anything we can do to ensure students can complete their qualification, even if their training provider disbands, is a good thing to do. These bills seek to introduce a tuition protection scheme for students who use student loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses at public and private providers, including TAFEs, in cases of provider or course closure. Unfortunately, as has become typical with this government, though, these bills are a bit sloppy and there remain concerns on how the bills will operate.

As outlined by my Labor colleagues, including the shadow assistant minister for skills, the sector is concerned that the legislation will not operate as it needs to. Fee-paying students aren't covered by this legislation, and Labor believes that these students should be able to obtain the same protection as those who have a government loan. The sector is concerned that some of the costs of the levy associated with these bills will be passed on to students. TAFEs are also concerned that they will be left to pick up the pieces when students come to them with poor training from a since-closed institution. The process for dealing with these scenarios needs to be worked out, as Labor is not confident that the bills cover this as they currently stand. As the Senate is best placed to ensure that the bills deliver on what the government hopes to achieve, Labor will refer the bills to committee to assess these valid issues raised by the higher education and TAFE sector.

However, these bills remind us yet again that the government has systematically decimated the skills and training sector over the six years that they have been in charge. Much like the ABC bill currently before the House, the government is simply tinkering about the edges when there are real issues that need to be addressed. Rather than delivering the funding and reform required by the higher education sector in Australia, and especially the TAFE system, we see these inconsequential changes—good, but not good enough. The government continues to distract from the bigger issues at stake with amendments here and there. These bills, while important, are an example of this government's lack of agenda and lack of ambition for Australia and its people.

The government speaks ad nauseam about skills, jobs and jobs growth, and yet they decimate the very system that will empower Australians to get jobs. The Liberals have slashed $3 billion from TAFE and training. That $3 billion in cuts means Australia now faces a crisis in skills and vocational training. There's a national shortage of tradies. Despite this, Scott Morrison has cut funding to TAFE and training. He's let apprentice and trainee numbers fall off a cliff, and now he's trying to blame young people for not choosing a trade. Under the Liberals, there are 150,000 fewer apprentices and trainees, and a shortage of workers in critical services including plumbing, carpentry, hairdressing and motor mechanics. The number of Australians doing an apprenticeship or traineeship is lower today than it was a decade ago. There are more people dropping out of apprenticeships and traineeships than finishing them.

If Scott Morrison doesn't care about the young people aspiring to be tradespeople who aren't able to get an apprenticeship, surely he can stand up for his quiet Australians who want their house fixed up, their toilet unblocked, their car serviced or their hair done. In Scott Morrison's economy, there's nearly a 10 per cent increase in the number of occupations facing skills shortages. The Australian Industry Group says 75 per cent of businesses surveyed are struggling to find the qualified workers they need. However, while businesses are crying out for more trained staff, there are about 1.9 million Australians who are unemployed or underemployed. We should be training Australians to do the jobs our businesses need qualified workers for, but how can we when our training providers are threadbare and turning away students?

It's not just a problem with the TAFE system. With funding attached to students, the Liberals capped the number of places at our universities. In doing so, they have cut funding to universities and cut the dreams of Australian students and future employees into pieces. Since the election of the government in 2013, universities and students have been under constant attack with cuts, attempts at fee deregulation, policy chaos and uncertainty. Our universities should be focusing on doing the best research and providing the best training and learning. Instead, they have been fighting governments for decades to retain the funding that they have. Again, the government goes on and on about building the Australian economy. Guess what—research and education does just this. It contributes significantly to the Australian economy through innovation and through the provision of education services to a large cohort of international students, in addition to the economic benefits of educating Australians.

But guess what—Australia is but one player in the international education market. As the government forces down the quality of our institutions cut by cut by cut, the international students will go elsewhere—to the UK or the US, or even stay at home—because the quality of our institutions will no longer be considered reputable enough or value for money. You only have to look at the global university rankings to see the international universities rocketing up the charts as Australian institutions struggle to hold onto their positions. The government will tell you that university funding has increased, but a closer look at the data shows it isn't true. According to Universities Australia, most of the increase to university funding is due to HELP loans, and 80 per cent of these loans will be paid back by students.

Despite the growth in funding, Australian government total higher education spending as a percentage of GDP only increased from 0.9 per cent in 1989 to one per cent in 2017. Excluding HELP loans, higher education grants for teaching, learning and research have declined from 0.7 per cent in 1989 to 0.6 per cent in 2017. It is a damning reality that this government has cut funding to the tertiary sector. Australia's investment in tertiary education funding is below the international average. Australia's public investment in tertiary institutions as a share of GDP is amongst the lowest in the OECD—ranked 24 out of 34 countries. Australia's public investment was only 0.77 per cent of GDP in 2015 compared to 0.98 per cent of GDP for average OECD countries.

International student enrolments have more than doubled since 2001. This represents an average annual growth rate of 5.5 per cent over that period. In 2017, 27 per cent of students enrolled in Australian universities were from overseas, compared to 19 per cent in 2001. Australia has 6.6 per cent of the world's international students studying at the VET, or higher, education level. International education is Australia's third-largest export and the largest services export industry, generating $35.8 billion in export income in 2018. This is an incredible industry for Australia. We should be very proud of our universities and of our TAFEs. They are the envy of the world. But it is clear from these stats that the government is using the international education system here in this country as an excuse to halt funding to the sector. But their actions put the golden goose at risk. If we don't invest in the tertiary education system we will lose it, and our international customers will go elsewhere.

The 2017 MYEFO decision to cut $2.2 billion from universities included the recapping of undergraduate places, and the changes to the Higher Education Loan Program were reckless and unfair. Two hundred thousand students will miss out on the opportunity of a university place over the decade, due to the government's cuts and the capping of places. How do we become the high-skilled economy of the future that Australia should be, without giving 200,000 of our citizens the ability to become a member of the workforce of the future?

Of course, the demonisation of the poor spreads to every area of policymaking under the Liberals, including higher education. The Liberals have already forced students to start paying off HELP debts when they earn as little as $45,000, which is only $9,000 more than the minimum wage. On this side, we know that debt is a barrier to study, particularly for students from low-income families, so our higher education loan scheme needs to be as well-targeted and fair as possible in order to ensure people don't choose to forgo education because of the loan that they will be taking on to do their study. We want to see greater participation in higher education in Australia. Labor knows that when you lock someone out of education you are locking them out of a job, out of the chance to get ahead and out of the opportunity to create a good life for themselves and for their family.

The Liberals' decision to recap undergraduate places is devastating participation rates in higher education. Two hundred thousand students won't get the opportunity of a higher education. It's simply not fair that students in more privileged areas, like the North Shore of Sydney, are five times more likely to go to uni than students in areas like the Moreton Bay region of Queensland. We want to change that. Labor wants to give the opportunity of a tertiary education to every student who has the ability and who is prepared to work hard. In contrast, the Liberals want to slam shut the door to university to more than 200,000 Australians. Unlike the Liberals and Nationals, we believe that education funding is an investment in our nation's future prosperity, not a cost burden.

A government without a plan for education and training has no plan for Australia's future. So I call on the government to do more than just tinker around the edges of education policy reform. I call on them to utilise the opportunities afforded by an increasing international student market to build a tertiary education system, both universities and TAFEs, that is truly world-leading. Yes, these bills will help students, but the government should be doing more. We are a wealthy nation. We have an incredible human potential. Let's go and harness it so its full potential will build prosperity for all Australians to go through TAFE or university. Thank you.

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (18:54): Before I start, I just want to commend the member for Canberra. Under incredible circumstances, with her voice going, it showed a real commitment to education. I'm very, very proud of you, member for Canberra. I, with a healthy voice, rise to speak on the Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019, the VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 and the Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019, as well as the amendment moved by my good friend the member for Cooper. The object of these bills is to protect students with VET student loans and non-university higher education FEE-HELP loans from provider or course closure by identifying alternative providers to allow students to continue their study or offering a refund of tuition fees if there are no replacement providers. The approach taken by these bills is similar to the Tuition Protection Service established to protect overseas students if a higher education or vocational education training provider in Australia is unable to fully deliver their course due to course or provider closure.

Labor won't oppose these bills. In fact, we welcome the practical effect of them, which is to create simpler arrangements for students and processes for decision-making, student placement and VSL or HELP loan re-crediting. This will give students confidence that they will not be left in debt and without a qualification if their training facility fails before they have finished their course, which, sadly, does happen. We've seen it too often. I've seen it in a former life, working for a union. The usual story, too often, is that they're dodgy providers that are overloaded with students and are hoping to make a quick profit. They rent a room for six months and put up a whiteboard, and they don't invest in capital infrastructure, teaching staff or decent wages. Then what happens? They go belly-up, leaving the students out of pocket and without the qualifications they need to get a job. It leaves students damaged, poorer and wary of learning, and that's not a good outcome for society, obviously—not a good combination. My big question, obviously, is: why has it taken the Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison government so long to act to protect these students? I do not know.

So who will these bills protect? They will protect students who use student loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses at public and private providers, including TAFEs. They do not protect students studying at public universities, as they are exempt from newer arrangements entirely. Those students are already protected under existing arrangements to manage course closures. There is, one would hope, a low risk of default amongst Australia's wonderful universities. It will not protect students who pay up-front fees. For students under current arrangements, those accessing state funding or subsidies are referred to their state or territory department of education. Those who have paid more than $1,500 are asked to contact ITECA, and those who paid less than $1,500 are referred to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. There has been a concern raised by stakeholders regarding the exclusion of fee-paying students.
