The bills impose participation on non-exempt providers in a tuition protection scheme and payment of an associated levy as a condition of continuing approval as a provider via VSL or FEE-HELP. For domestic students who pay up-front fees, the provider is not compelled to participate in the tuition protection scheme. There are also some concerns that providers will pass on levies to students and that TAFEs will be forced to take on poorly trained students in the event of a course closure. It is because of these concerns that Labor supports referring the bills to committee to ensure these issues are addressed and fully considered.

While Labor does not oppose the bills, we recognise that it is not the genuine reform that this sector actually needs. We have the Morrison government in their seventh year. I know it seems longer, as the brute from Bronte lurches us back towards the cave, but so far what have they done? They've trashed the quality of Australia's world-class higher education and vocation system. There is a national shortage of tradies in critical services, including plumbing, carpentry, hairdressing and motor mechanics, and that's a crisis that won't be solved any time soon. There are 150,000 fewer apprentices and trainees, and the Morrison government has ripped $3 billion from TAFE and training. On top of the $3 billion ripped from them, TAFE, training and apprenticeship programs have been short-changed by almost $1 billion. It's no wonder the number of Australians doing an apprenticeship or traineeship is lower today than it was a decade ago even though the Australian population has surged in that time. More people are dropping out of apprenticeships and traineeships than are actually finishing them—
Ms Kearney: Correct.

Mr PERRETT: as I'm sure the member for Cooper knows and is horrified by. It's not just the opposition that's concerned; it's big business—it's all business basically. The Australian Industry Group says 75 per cent of businesses they've surveyed are struggling to find the qualified workers they need under the coalition government.
And what does the Prime Minister for marketing do? He hires a celebrity. It is such a classic flim-flam response. I've got nothing against Scott Cam; I'm sure he's a great bloke.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mrs Wicks ): Member for Moreton, I'll just remind you of the standing order to refer to members by their correct title. It's happened on a couple of occasions. I'd like to remind you of that.

Mr PERRETT: Thank you, Deputy Speaker. I'm sure that Scott Cam is a great bloke, who will value-add on some block somewhere. But, if the Prime Minister really wanted to fix the schools crisis that he has created, he would fund TAFEs and apprentices, not hire a celebrity. It's not even an original idea. It's actually straight from an episode of Utopia, but I would suggest that Rob Sitch actually did a little bit better than the Prime Minister!

Meanwhile, there are almost two million Australians who are unemployed or underemployed, and the Australian Industry Group says 75 per cent of businesses are struggling to find the qualified workers they need. So why isn't the Prime Minister ensuring that people are being trained for jobs in industries where there's a shortage of workers? Because this Liberal and National Party government has not only cut $3 billion of funding to TAFE and training but has short-changed TAFE by almost another $1 billion. This underspend is actually a problem for everyone.Undermining vocational education and training has a profound effect on productivity and the international competitiveness of our economy.This Morrison government just doesn't get it.

span.span: And obviously the minister at the table doesn't actually understand ministerial arrangements and funding arrangements either, but it's nice of him to interject with that one! I'll make sure that goes on the record.

p.span:
Labor understands the critical role of TAFE as a public provider , Labor understands the valu e in skills and apprenticeships a nd Labor un derstands the value of the hard working and passionate public TAFE teachers. TAFE Queensland SkillsTech
at Acacia Ridge is in my electorate . It' s a wonderful training campus f or many trades and apprentices. I've been there many times and have met with students and the wonder ful and dedicated TAFE teachers, s o I understand the passion those teachers feel about imparting the valuable knowledge of a tr ade to their eager students, a nd I understand how gutted those teachers and students feel when their funding is cut .
It has had a devastating effect on the sector , which has then flowed out to business. TAFEs in regional areas, those that focus on agricultural and mining orientated courses, are vital in the bush for young people who want to stay near home and family or who can't afford to move away from home to study. What's happening to them? They give those students the opportunity they otherwise would not have, but we see a government moving away from the bush.Labor values the role of a properly funded VET sector for the training, skills and apprenticeships they provide to so many Australians, and its vital role in driving the economy and enhancing industry.

Since 2013, universities and students have been under constant attack with cuts, attempts at fee deregulation, policy chaos and uncertainty. The 2017 MYEFO decision to cut $2.2 billion from universities and recap undergraduate places and the changes to HELP loans were reckless and unfair. Two hundred thousand students will miss out on a university place over the decade. And we know that the coalition government would have introduced $100,000 university degrees in this country if they had their way. Students are now forced to pay off their HELP debts when they earn as little as $45,000—only $9,000 more than the minimum wage.

We want to see greater participation in higher education in Australia. By locking Australians out of education, the Liberals are locking Australians out of good jobs. By presiding over a skills crisis, the coalition is holding Australian business back. Australians deserve world-class TAFEs and universities, and the Liberals have gutted both. The Liberals have slammed the university door on 200,000 young Australians. Shame on them! Every young school leaver should have a choice about their future based on their ability, not their postcode or their parents' credit card. It's just not fair that a student in the North Shore of Sydney is five times more likely to go to university than a student in the Moreton Bay Region of Queensland. Funding education is an investment in our nation's future prosperity, not a cost burden. A government without a plan for education and training has no plan for Australia's future, and, if it's not planning for the future, why is this government here at all?

Mr DAVID SMITH (Bean) (19:05): I also rise to speak on the Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection And Other Measures) Bill 2019, the VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 and the Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019. The bills give effect to a mid-year economic and fiscal outlook 2018-19 announcement that long-term arrangements for tuition assurance would be introduced. And the bills are in response to a review in January 2018 of the National Vocational Education and Training Regulator Act 2011 that cited a range of concerns from students about the sector-led tuition assurance arrangements. As noted by our shadow minister, the member for Cooper, Labor won't oppose these bills. We welcome the practical effect, which is to create simpler arrangements for students and processes for decision-making, student placement, and VSL and HELP recrediting. During my time as an organiser for Professionals Australia and working alongside the ETU and AMWU, I witnessed firsthand the loss of confidence in the VET sector, and the students should not be the ones left carry the can. Students should be protected and assisted in the case of provider or course closure.

As noted in the bills digest, the bills attempt to address the question of how best to protect students who use student loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses at public and private providers, including TAFEs, in cases of provider or course closure. The bills propose to replace sector-managed tuition assurance arrangements with two new tuition protection schemes—one for each sector—modelled on the existing Australian Government Tuition Protection Service, which has been in place for overseas students since 2012. Each new scheme will be responsible for managing the process of determining if there are replacement courses for affected students and, in cases where there are not, making recommendations about recrediting the student's VET student loan or Higher Education Loan Program borrowings related to the course. Each new scheme will be managed through a special account which will be sector funded by a levy made up of three components: an administrative fee component, a risk rated premium component and a tuition protection component.

So why are we here? Why is the House considering these bills? This package of bills is part of ongoing efforts to address the impact of the program that preceded VSL, VET FEE-HELP, which ran from 2008 to 2016 as part of HELP. VET FEE-HELP has ultimately become known for enabling increases in course fees and unrecoverable student debt, and that is putting it mildly. These bills attempt to clean up the ongoing mess of this government and their carriage of VET-FEE Help. No-one on this side of the chamber will forget the millions in debt lost and the dodgy providers allowed to operate on this government's watch.

So who is covered and who is not covered by these bills? The bills cover students who use student loans to pay for vocational education and training and higher education courses at public and private providers, including TAFEs. Australian public universities will be exempt from the new arrangements entirely, as they already have appropriate arrangements in place to manage course closures and have a low risk of default. Students who pay up-front fees are not covered by the proposed new tuition protection schemes. Instead, under current arrangements: those accessing state funding or subsidies are referred to their state or territory department of education, those who have paid more than $1,500 are asked to contact the Independent Tertiary Education Council Australia, and those who paid less than $1,500 are referred to the ACCC.

As noted before, one of our major concerns is that these bills do not cover all students, and of particular concern is the lack of coverage for full-fee paying students. It is not surprising that key stakeholders also have concerns. Independent Higher Education Australia have raised significant concerns around this point. They warn this may leave a cohort of students at risk of having no tuition protection.

ITECA also have concerns around providers passing the cost of the levy onto students and, broadly, the growing trend of cost recovery in the higher education and vocational training sector. TAFE Directors Australia have concerns around the requirement to take on poorly trained students in the event of course closures. Given these concerns, we will work with the Senate to refer these bills to committee to ensure that these concerns are properly addressed.

But, let's be honest, this sector needs more than tweaks. We know that we need genuine reform in this sector. A sector that so many on this side of the chamber are passionate about is almost at crisis point. Those opposite talk about caring about trades and about workers' skills. They talk about training the workforce of tomorrow. But like so much else to do with this government, it's all marketing. It's all tip and no rest of the iceberg. It's all about the line and not about the reform.

Let's look at some recent data: completion rates for apprentices and trainees who commenced training in 2014 have decreased to 56.7 per cent; 22,000 fewer students have enrolled in government-funded vocational education and training compared to 2017, representing an almost two per cent drop in student numbers; and, in the past six years, government-funded full-year training equivalents have decreased by 30 per cent. We have members opposite who have ticked off the cutting of more than $3 billion in funding in this sector. They have presided over a drop of 150,000 apprentices, the closing of TAFE campuses and allowing dodgy for-profit providers to gouge the system. The government have had six years to turn this around and have failed to take action.

If you can believe it, ashamedly, the number of Australians doing an apprenticeship or traineeship is lower today than it was a decade ago, despite the population growth. There are more people dropping out of apprenticeships and traineeships than finishing them. There will be nearly a 10 per cent increase in the number of occupations facing skills shortages if this continues. The Australian Industry Group—that well-known radical organisation!—says 75 per cent of businesses surveyed are struggling to find the qualified workers they need. We have also seen all too often dodgy providers overload with students for a quick profit and then go belly-up, leaving those students out of pocket and without the qualifications they need.

Just this week, estimates showed that this is getting worse. We saw reported in the media today that the Morrison government fell almost $1 billion short of budgeted spending on vocational training programs over the last five years, a gap that has persisted despite the skills crisis facing Australia. The level of incompetence by this government is pretty staggering. We have a $919 million underspend in vocational training, and it took estimates to reveal it. The Liberal Morrison government has short-changed and starved the training sector, even as Australia faces an ongoing skills shortage.

On this side of the chamber, Labor has been saying that our TAFEs are in disrepair and apprentice and trainee numbers have fallen off a cliff, and we have more proof this week with this underspend. If the government doesn't do something serious to fix the skills crisis they have created, we could be looking at the extinction of the Australian tradie. These funds were meant to go to programs such as apprenticeship incentives, scholarships, migrant English support and trade loans. By any measure, it is fail, and it is on the watch of those opposite—on the watch of the government's minister for skills and the watch of this Prime Minister.

And the Nationals are no better. I think we can safely conclude that the Liberals and their weak National cousins—the Liberals in moleskins—have severely damaged our vocational education system. You would think the Nationals would get it. I'm sure they try. They're always trying, those Nationals, but young people in regional areas are keen to stay near home and family and to study at regional TAFEs, benefiting greatly from skills that give them a start in life. Those regional TAFEs provide ongoing employment for locals and inject money that is sorely needed now into those local economies. They're often the heart of the town, a hub for the community to gather and engage. In the electorates of Page or Maranoa, we see youth unemployment as high as 25 per cent. That is one in four young people looking for work.

We need more regional VET investment not less. We need a proper reform plan for regional TAFEs. But, as we know all too well, this is a government without a plan. The Liberals and Nationals have trashed the quality of Australia's world-class higher education system and vocational system. This is not just about statistics and facts; this abject failing of the government has a real effect on people's lives. This government is not a new government, despite the fact that it likes to try to pin the blame for every policy failure on the last Labor government. This third-term government simply refuses to deliver a genuine reform package that overhauls the higher education and VET sectors—a plan that properly funds vocational training providers and universities to deliver the services that their students need and employers are crying out for. Employers are crying out for more trained staff.

There are about 1.9 million Australians who are unemployed or underemployed. There's a national shortage of tradies. The Prime Minister has cut funding to TAFE and training and he's let apprentice and trainee numbers fall off a cliff. His latest marketing tactic is to hire a celebrity chippie and make the kids feel guilty for not choosing a trade. That is not going to be a fix. I'm sure Scott Cam is a good bloke, and he may even support a unionised workforce, collectively bargaining for decent conditions from the beginning of careers to the end of careers. But, if this government wants to fix the skills crisis it has created, it should stop hiring celebrities and start funding TAFE and apprentices.

However, the government's approach to VET is not different to the approach of this government more broadly. As I said earlier, this government has no plan for our country. It has no plan to deal with wage stagnation and rising prices. The cost of essentials across Australia is skyrocketing; electricity prices are increasing; and child care has become unaffordable under this government. Australians right across this country are worried about the economy, but the Prime Minister and his government are pretending that there is no problem. We recently had the lowest rate of growth since the GFC, and per capita GDP is flat-lining. It is time for this government to wake up and produce a genuine plan to get the economy moving again.

When it comes to VET this government must undertake immediate and urgent reform. The government must put TAFE back at the centre of the sector, tackle the failures of privatisation and fund the sector properly. As others who have spoken in this debate have said—and which I fully endorse—with youth unemployment stuck at more than double the national average, young people need a decent skills sector that leads them to secure work. Australians and the businesses that employ them deserve excellent TAFEs and universities, whatever region you live in across Australia.

Unlike the government, Labor gets it. Unlike those who sit opposite us, we value the role of an appropriately funded VET sector for the training, skills and apprenticeships they provide to so many Australians. We on this side know that debt is a barrier to study, particularly for students from low-income families. We want to see greater participation in higher education in Australia. Labor knows that, when you lock someone out of education, you are effectively locking them out of a job, out of the chance to get ahead and provide for themselves and their families. Labor wants to give every student who has the ability and is prepared to work hard the life opportunities that come from a world-class VET and university sector. We believe that funding education is an investment in our nation's future prosperity, not a burden.

Ms MURPHY (Dunkley) (19:19): I rise to speak on the Education Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection and Other Measures) Bill 2019, the VET Student Loans (VSL Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 and the Higher Education Support (HELP Tuition Protection Levy) Bill 2019 as a Labor member of the federal parliament who believes in and understands the importance of education and vocational skills and training for the future of young people. I am also standing here today as a representative of a community which proudly boasts both Chisholm TAFE and the Monash University Peninsula Campus. In Dunkley, we understand how important it is for our young people to have educational opportunities, particularly educational opportunities in the public sector. Chisholm TAFE is an institution that Frankston residents, Dunkley residents and people from the Mornington Peninsula are rightly very proud of, because it has given young people opportunities that they otherwise would never have imagined that they could have.

I am very proud to be married to someone who is a graduate of what is now Chisholm Institute but was Frankston TAFE. My own husband's story is one of not finishing high school, of going out and working, and then returning and doing his VCAE at Frankston TAFE. If it hadn't been for that publicly funded institution that was there for him, he would not have been able to go on to the career that he has had—which includes, now, being a professor at Monash University, which brings, possibly, the educational cycle full circle. His story is not a unique story in my community, because of Chisholm TAFE. But it's been a hard struggle to keep that institution alive and functioning and where it is.

We are very lucky that, under the current state Labor government, Chisholm TAFE has had a massive investment. We've just opened phase 1 of a redevelopment. Our institution is now a magnificent modern building, but, more importantly, it's a magnificent modern site for our young people—and the older people in our community—to go and access training and skills for the jobs now and the jobs of the future. If it weren't for the state Labor government, that wouldn't be the case, because not one single cent—not one single cent—of federal funding has gone towards that redevelopment. The state Labor government has contributed $46.9 million to the $83.4 million project and will put in another $67.6 million for stage 2. And what have we got from the current Liberal federal government? Nothing. The Chisholm TAFE now boasts a state-of-the-art health community centre, early childhood education and hair, beauty and wellness facilities, innovative new student spaces and classrooms, and redeveloped trade facilities, including a purpose-built, flexible, integrated design centre. We are so proud of what we have at our TAFE. But, as I said, it has required the community to back it and has required the state Labor government to back it.

I've been to that TAFE countless times in the last 12 months, and I've visited, many times, the young women who are doing a VCAL program there—young women who are teenage mothers, who have not been able to complete their education and are determined to get the education that they need for a brighter future. They go to the Chisholm TAFE facility and they bring their children, and they are seeking an education. They are the people who we should be backing. They are the people who require a federal government that will properly invest in our TAFE system. They are the people who suffer when we have a federal government that underspends in our TAFE and our vocational education system.

The other people in my community that I'm very concerned will suffer from this government's underspend on and ignoring of the TAFE system, particularly in my community, are the young men who need to get the trade and manufacturing skills—and, mind you, the young women who need the same, because, I'm very pleased to see, their involvement in the trade training at Chisholm TAFE is growing—for the jobs of the future, in smart manufacturing, in high-tech manufacturing. That's what my TAFE and my community want to work with local industries on: to teach our young people so that they can work in the jobs of the future. They need a federal government that will back them in, to be able to achieve it.

We've got an economy at the moment that is crying out for skilled workers. Everyone in this place knows that that is the case. We've had surveys that have said to us that three-quarters of employers say that they cannot find the skilled workers they need. I've had local manufacturing businesses tell me that they can't find apprentice plumbers and local mechanics tell me that they can't find apprentice mechanics. That's just not good enough. We need to do better for our young people. We have two million Australians who don't have a job or want more hours of work and we have a skills shortage across the economy in so many areas: plumbers, electricians, carpenters, hairdressers, pastry chefs. We have a skills crisis. We have a desperate need for skilled workers yet we have Australians who want more work. We have people in my community, such as young mothers, young men, older women wanting to go back to work and older men looking to retrain, who want to be able to get the education and the skills and vocational training they need. But they can't do it, because they don't have a federal government that is backing in the sector that would provide it for them. We have a government that has underspent the TAFE and training budget. It's just not good enough—$200 million last year, and over the last few years up to $919 million. The federal government has close to a $1 billion underspend in the crucial education and training sector, which is important for now and into the future. $3 billion worth of cuts. I stand here more in sorrow than in anger. Like many people in my community, I am angry, but I am sad that we have a federal government that won't back in my community.

Labor is not opposing these bills today. We are welcoming the practical effect, which is creating a simpler arrangement for students and for the processes of decision making, student placement, and VSL and HELP re-crediting. We understand that students should be protected and assisted in the case of provider or course closure. This package of bills is part of an ongoing effort to address the impact of the VET FEE-HELP program, which saw increases in course fees and unrecoverable student debt. There are good outcomes from this legislation, but stakeholders have raised concerns about the exclusion of fee-paying students, the cost of the levy being passed on to students, and for TAFEs to take on poorly trained students in the event of a course closure, which is why we in Labor, although supporting these bills today, also want them to go to a committee to ensure that the issues are addressed.

I join with my fellow Labor members in this place to say that this sector just can't be tweaked at the edges. We need a proper reform package. We will continue to advocate on behalf of our communities for that reform package. The reforms of the Andrews Labor government—the free TAFE courses—have made an amazing difference for people in my community who otherwise would not have been able to go to TAFE and could not afford to be part of it. Fully 36,000 students have started free TAFE courses in Victoria in the nine months to the end of September. The Chisholm Institute has played a major part in that growth, with more than 6,000 students starting free TAFE courses. I went to a graduation ceremony recently at Chisholm TAFE, and it was joyous. The looks on the faces of the people who were graduating—young and old and from many places across the globe, across our state, and from Frankston—was pride. Their families were there proudly supporting them. That's what I want for every young person in my community and every young person in Australia who wants to get vocational qualifications.

I join with my Labor colleagues who point out that appointing an ambassador for trades is no replacement for reforming a sector to train young Australians, and older Australians who want to be retrained, to get trades. We need a government that will properly fund and invest in TAFE and universities, that won't cut research funding from universities, and that will back in people who want to access education but can't afford it. The people of Dunkley know how important education and vocational training are to a good future. They want a government that understands this in the same way that they do. I give them this promise: they have a federal member who understands it in the way they do and will take every opportunity to stand up and support the public provision of education and training in Dunkley and in the wider Mornington Peninsula region.
Debate interrupted.
ADJOURNMENT
The SPEAKER (19:29): It being 7.30 pm, I propose the question:
That the House do now adjourn.
Parliamentary Debate

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (19:29): I want to address the House tonight on something that could give rise to a tone of outrage, but I don't want to deliver it that way, and that's because I believe there is a very significant issue at stake in terms of the relevance of this chamber to Australian democracy.

We all accept and we all know that there will be spin on each side on any agreed set of facts. Whatever's happening, different people will have their perspective on it, and that will form the nature of debate; that's why we have different political views. In the last few years, quite distinctly in the last few months and even in the last couple of days, I am seeing more and more an argument about not how you view the facts but whether or not facts are in fact true—where something which is demonstrably true is just denied.

It struck me yesterday when the Minister for Home Affairs gave an entirely prepared answer to a dixer which was based on the premise that, in 2014, Labor had opposed legislation which we had supported. It was on the record that we had supported it. His office would have known that we had supported it and, when he was preparing the answer, everyone would have realised that the claim that was the basis of the entire prepared answer was untrue. So we followed the normal procedures of the House at the end of question time. Our deputy leader stood up and explained this; it's done. But I don't think for a minute that will change the behaviour.

I've dealt, in my own portfolios over the years, with claims—from one of the members who is in the House, but not the only one who has repeatedly claimed—that Labor never built a dam. I know as both a former agriculture minister and a former environment minister that I attended the opening of dams built under the Labor government, approved under the government, like the Headquarters Road dam and the Milford Dam. There was the approval that I gave for the expansion of Chaffey Dam, the augmentation of Chaffey; the approval I gave for stage 3 of the Ord; and the approval that we gave to the Millstream Dam expansion, the Duckhole Rivulet Dam, the Glebe Weir expansion, the Hinze Dam upgrade. All of that's true. All of that's on the record. And yet the claim 'Labor never built a dam, Labor never approved a dam' will continue to be made in this House, even though it is demonstrably untrue.

We will continue to be told by members of the government that they have to pay down Labor's debt, even though the national debt now is more than double what it was when the change of government occurred. So, if the debt belongs to anyone, more than half of it belongs to those opposite. And yet the claim will continue to be made.

We will continue to hear people make a claim with respect to emissions—that somehow we are meeting an emissions target which requires emissions to go down, while emissions are going up. Now, I accept that within the House there will be arguments about what those targets will be. There will be some people who will want to argue that there shouldn't be any at all. But the concept that we're having an argument about whether they're going up or down, when the evidence is unarguable that they're going up, troubles me about what the parliament then becomes.

One of the most extraordinary examples was at the National Press Club, during the election campaign, when the Prime Minister was asked about a report that had come out that day with respect to extinctions. His response was: 'We've already introduced and passed legislation through the Senate actually dealing with that very issue, in the last week of the parliament.' No such legislation existed. Nothing went through in the last week of the parliament relating to extinctions. There was something about chemical testing on rabbits—not exactly about to be extinct, not exactly a native species.

But this is simply what I want to remind the House about. In terms of the game of politics, people might think, 'I got away with it; I played the game.' Outside of this chamber, people live in the world of facts. If their wages aren't moving, false claims here won't change the fact that their wages aren't moving. If the climate is changing, denial in here won't alter the fact that the climate is changing. I simply remind all members that, if we are not starting with agreed and obvious facts, the relevance of this chamber only declines.
Drought

Mr JOYCE (New England) (19:34): I'd like to start with one fact: when I returned to New England, Chaffey Dam wasn't built. It wasn't built because they couldn't get the environmental approvals through because of, among other things, the Booroolong frog, for which they needed environmental offsets. This is where the Labor Party live. They live in this mystery world where they talk about building Chaffey Dam. That was not correct. It was not true. It didn't happen. It wasn't there. We built it. We built it because we forced through the approvals to make sure that happened, and we put more money in so it could happen. After we attained government, it was built, and that is a fact.

I want to talk about something pressing: the drought. The drought in regional areas occupies most of the time of my colleagues in the National Party because it is so seminal. I want to clearly note that, when we say that if a person has not made a profit in the last 10 years they should consider what they do, that does not mean that they should leave the land; it means that they should consider how they can earn extra money—whether they go to a trade, whether they become a cartage operator, or whether they go back to other jobs. I refer this to the people I know—go back to shearing, go back to driving a truck, start a small business. They have to look at other ways to bring in an income, because they can't just live in perpetual poverty.

What I want to tell the Australian people in the regional areas tonight is that we are working on drought in the National Party. We have been. We absolutely put this at the forefront of our view. The Nationals have a developed policy to make sure that we deal with this. We believe that a drought committee should be set up in each drought shire affected. It would include such people as the local mayor; a local community leader, such as the president of Rotary; the rural financial counsellor that covers the district; the local federal member and the local state member and/or their appointed representatives; a local business leader, such as a local stock and station agent, with a clear understanding of the area in drought; and a representative of a local charity that has so much to do with trying to manage the people who are dealing with drought.

The committee would be given access to a drought fund to be dispersed for any issue that has a clear nexus to the drought requirements of the shire. We say that because the requests that come to us are many and varied, and now we need local knowledge to make the contract between the many and varied requests and the local knowledge that would be apparent in a local committee. The fund would be furbished with $10 million per shire—a fifty-fifty contribution from the state and the federal government, so the state understands their part of this responsibility. The fund only becomes active when both have contributed to that fund, to keep the political pressure on them. Just because a shire would be allocated $10 million doesn't mean it would spend $10 million; it would spend as much as required, knowing that the stewardship of that respected committee has oversight of that money. The federal member or state member would have a right of veto, so if some untoward proposal came forward, they would have the capacity to say, 'No, we're not going to accept that.' If the committee needed to go in camera to deal with the personal issues of someone, it could, so that it has the capacity to hear people who are privy to the private details of someone who is under stress or under duress and be able to help them directly. This would be able to deal with a whole myriad of issues, like fodder, AQIS fees, and the people out in the western districts where there are no high schools—making sure those kids don't come back from boarding school, because if they come back from boarding school, that's the end of their education. They're not going to go back to working like a man—or as a girl—on the place and then go back to boarding school; their life has changed. We would make sure that if further funds are required down the track, we would deal with this.

I know how politics works; I've been in it for long enough. We keep on thinking—and colleagues have also said this to me—that if we just do enough to catch up, we're there. Well, the drought is going on, and we have to now reach ahead of it. We have to reach ahead of it or be dragged later on down the track. My message to the Australian people tonight is that the National Party does have their shoulder to the wheel on this issue. We are driving agendas. We are making sure that we are looking after the people, our core constituencies. We are proud of the fact that we do build dams. We've announced Dungowan Dam and Upper Mole River Dam, and we built Chaffey Dam. We are building dams in Tasmania—we are actually doing that. We would build Rookwood Weir if a state Labor government weren't so attached to the green movement that they would never, ever get out of bed to help regional people.
Scotdesco

Ms BURNEY (Barton) (19:40): Earlier this month I visited the South Australian Aboriginal community of Scotdesco, approximately 100 kilometres west of Ceduna. I visited Scotdesco as part of my visit to remote Indigenous communities around Central Australia, from the Pilbara in Western Australia to Ceduna in South Australia to Kata Tjuta in the Northern Territory. I had the opportunity to meet the community's chief executive officer, Robert Larking. Robert informed me about the severe water emergency currently confronting the community. Due to its location, Scotdesco is not connected to the main water network. It depends on water from the local catchment. It has received minimal rainfall over the winter period. During this time it has relied on a sheeted water catchment and bladder storage to secure its water supply. I saw the water catchment and bladder storage for myself. Let me tell you that it was absolutely shocking.

I can understand why the community is so anxious about the situation. The water west scheme provides for subsidised delivery of tanker water within the Ceduna region. A semi-truckload of water can be delivered within the area for $280. However, as Scotdesco is located just 10 kilometres outside this prescribed area, that very same semi-truckload of water will cost the community $1,400, almost five times what it costs with the subsidy. This is an absurd and unacceptable set of circumstances. This community cannot be expected to fork out thousands of dollars a pop for the very same water the rest of us take for granted. The Scotdesco community is home to about 50 residents, a dozen of them children.

As we can all appreciate but take for granted as well, water is essential to so many aspects of daily life, from hydration to cooking and cleaning, washing clothes and taking showers. This water crisis presents serious real-life consequences for the local community. Access to clean water was a prevalent issue throughout my visits to remote communities in Central Australia. I have seen how this issue has contributed to and compounded other health related issues. I have seen how the lack of clean water has pushed many to rely on soft drinks and sugary drinks for hydration. I have learned about how the lack of clean water inhibits the provision of healthcare and health services and procedures such as administering dialysis machines.

The water supply in the Scotdesco community is now reaching severe emergency levels. This is unsustainable and unacceptable, and a permanent solution needs to be found. If weather forecasts are correct, South Australia is in for a long hot summer. These conditions will be difficult to live through in a capital or major city, in particular during this time of drought; I can only imagine how difficult it would be for a remote community such as Scotdesco. As shadow minister for Indigenous Australians I've joined with the South Australian shadow minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Kyam Maher. Together we have called on the South Australian Premier and his government to act now on this issue. We have also drawn the attention of the Prime Minister and the federal Minister for Indigenous Affairs to this unfolding water emergency. We urge the governments to urgently intervene and develop a reasonable solution to improve the Scotdesco community's water security situation.

The people of Scotdesco have been incredibly diligent and waterwise. They have played their part. It is now time for the South Australian and Commonwealth governments to show some leadership and play their part. I commend the Scotdesco community CEO, Robert Larking, for his tireless advocacy on this issue. I also commend the South Australian opposition for standing with Robert and the Scotdesco community. This should be straightforward. I sincerely urge the South Australian government and the Australian federal government to have a look at the desperate situation that the people of Scotdesco find themselves in. As I said, this community is not connected to any main water network; it relies on a dam which is covered by a bladder. As I said, I went and had a look at the water supply there. It is desperately low, and this community is about to run out of water.
Morrison Government

Mr HOGAN (Page—Deputy Speaker) (19:45): I want to take this opportunity to address a number of different pieces of legislation that have been going through the parliament lately or are about to. The first one I want to talk to is the cashless welfare card. There have been about four trial sites across the country. The latest trial site was in Bundaberg and Hervey Bay. It covered people aged between 18 and 35 on Newstart, youth allowance or parenting payments. They would get a debit card and 80 per cent of their Newstart allowance could be used with that card to buy normal groceries and normal things that they need, and 20 per cent would go into their bank account. This is certainly not necessarily the majority, but some people who are on Newstart or some of those allowances have alcohol or drug or gambling addictions. What this is about is trying to help those people and especially those families to break that cycle they are in. A delegation from one of the more isolated communities that was one of the first trial sites came to this House. I spoke to some of the mothers and grandmothers involved, who said this trial changed their lives and their children's lives overnight. I commend the government. I commend the fact that we're doing this trial. The statistics on these trials show that hospital presentations are down, school attendance is up. Everything you want to see go up is going up and everything you want to see go down is going down in the trial sites. I commend the government for extending the trials of that program.

The government recently announced the trial sites for drug testing new Newstart recipients. The trial sites are in Logan in Queensland, Canterbury-Bankstown in New South Wales and Mandurah in Western Australia. What is this about? There will be some random drug testing of people who are applying to go onto Newstart. This is not unusual. I mean, there are millions of Australian people in the workforce who undergo drug testing for the different jobs that they are in, so this isn't specifically peculiar to Newstart. Why are we doing this? Obviously some people on Newstart are just down on their luck but, statistically, people on Newstart do tend to have more drug or alcohol dependency than people who aren't on Newstart. So, especially for young people, what we do not want is to give up on people. If they test twice to having drugs or alcohol, they will get assistance. They will get rehabilitation services. Again, it's a trial. What we want to do is see how this runs out, see how the trial works and, if the statistics are good, then obviously we would look to expand this. But again, it is a wonderful initiative to try and help people who are down on their luck and who may also have an addiction that we could help them with.

Another thing I wanted to talk about tonight is I was quite surprised when I heard a statistic recently that 28 per cent of child sex offenders convicted in 2018 did not spend one day in jail. I don't think you'd find many Australians who would say that that is okay. The government has introduced mandatory jail time for child sex offenders. Police received almost 18,000 reports of child exploitation involving Australian children or Australian child sex offenders just last year. A jail term is now the starting point for child sex offenders. It won't matter how good their lawyer is, a prison cell will be waiting for them if they are convicted, and so it should be.

Another thing that we were speaking about earlier this week in this chamber was the benefits of the free trade agreements. I'd especially like to highlight the free trade agreement that we've negotiated with Indonesia. I still sometimes get surprised when I just think about the population of Indonesia, our closest neighbour. We in Australia have a population of, let's say, 25 million. Indonesia has a population 10 times that, of close to 270 million people. Our closest neighbour has 10 times the population of Australia. They have one of the fastest-growing economies in the world. I'm excited about this free trade agreement for a number of reasons, not least of which is my own local economy. I come from an area that has blueberries, macadamias, beef, dairy, fishing, forestry, and a lot of other products. I commend the government in negotiating this agreement and look forward to it boosting not just Australia's economy but also my local economy.
Small Business
Racism

Mr BURNS (Macnamara) (19:50): Tonight, in my adjournment speech I'm going to cover two different topics. The first topic I want to talk about in this place is the growing crisis in retail and small business in this country. What we have at the moment is a number of small businesses in retail at crossroads in this country. The internet is changing the way in which we're buying things and fewer and fewer people are shopping retail, and it's having an effect. In my electorate of Macnamara, we have some of the most outstanding small-business and retail strips in the entire country. We have Acland Street in St Kilda, where my office is located. We have Fitzroy Street, Bay Street in Port Melbourne, Middle Park, Albert Park, amazing cafes and shops in Elwood, Carlisle Street in East St Kilda, and Caulfield. We have amazing shopping strips. But, more and more, we're seeing vacant stores. More and more, we're seeing high streets leaving their old charm and being taken up by the only businesses that can afford the rent, which is large international companies. It's having an effect, yet we don't have a plan to support these businesses, we don't have a plan for small businesses in this country, and we don't have a plan, from this government, to help the ongoing retail crisis. If we don't see the government actually doing something to tackle energy prices, if we don't see the government actually doing something to ensure that vacant properties don't just sit there, if we don't see things that are going to support small businesses and traders, it's going to get worse.

Before the election, I went with the member for Rankin to speak to many traders in my electorate. We heard from them that the cost of energy is a massive issue and the cost of rent is a massive issue, and, quite frankly, the government doesn't have a plan to support small businesses. Retailers are doing it tough. Since the election, I've been meeting with many of the traders associations and, more and more, we are hearing that they are doing it tough with the cost of rent, and the cost of doing business is hard. Because the nature of business is changing, Australian small businesses, Australian retailers, are doing it really hard. So it would be good to see the government with a plan. I'm not going to hold my breath, but we will continue to advocate and support our small businesses on this side of the chamber.

The other thing I want to talk about tonight is a matter of increasing importance: the growing tide of white supremacy. I remember that, when I was advocating for the visa to be cancelled of the British conspiracy theorist, David Icke—a visa which had been granted by the minister for immigration earlier this year—the amount of vile hate I received was pretty overwhelming. It was pretty confronting. Thankfully, it was something that you could just put aside and know that you're doing the right thing. In fact, every piece of bland hate mail almost reaffirms that we're doing the right thing.

I want to pay tribute to a local in my electorate, Dr Dvir Abramovich, of the Anti-Defamation Commission, who joined me a few weeks ago, along with the signatures of 28,000 people, to stand against a white supremacist concert that was planned to be held in Melbourne. Dvir, every single time, calls out racism and bigotry in any form, whether it is anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or some of the really awful and nasty comments we heard from people about young African men, especially last year. Dvir calls it out. He, along with the support of John and Pauline Gandel, who support the Anti-Defamation Commission, do an amazing job. I pay tribute to Dvir tonight.

Only a few weeks ago, we were reminded of the importance of this when Stephan Balliet, who was radicalised by the Far Right, tried to march into a synagogue in the German city of Halle. Fortunately he wasn't able to get into the synagogue, but he did open fire on the closest person he could find, who was an innocent woman who was coming from the bus stop. He also went into a Turkish kebab store and opened fire. This curse of white supremacy is not going away. We need to stand against it every single time it rears its ugly head. We will not rest, because, every single day, we are not better by having intolerant and racist views heard.
China: Human Rights

Mr HASTIE (Canning) (19:55): Tonight I rise to speak on behalf of those who are vulnerable, persecuted and separated from their loved ones. Tonight I speak for Uygur Australians who have family and friends facing systematic persecution and internment in Xinjiang province in the People's Republic of China. But first I want to say a few words about the role of Australian investigative journalism and its importance for a free, democratic society.

As this House is aware, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security is conducting an inquiry into freedom of the press. As the chair, it would be improper for me to make remarks about committee deliberations or what conclusions we might reach in our report, but I do want to say that we all agree that public interest and investigative journalism is vital to a thriving liberal democracy, particularly when it comes to national security or human rights issues.

A superb example of good investigative journalism is the July Four Corners episode 'Tell the world' by ABC reporter Sophie McNeill. The program detailed the plight and suffering of more than one million Muslim minorities who have been rounded up, detained and forcibly indoctrinated by the Chinese communist regime. Australian citizens or permanent residents have been targeted and jailed. Others are trapped under state surveillance, their passports seized. I was deeply moved by those who courageously shared their story on the program. I was moved by those who have been separated from their loved ones. I think of Sadam Abudusalamu, who is separated from his wife and child—a child he has never met in person.

These individual and personal stories helped us understand and humanise the greater tragedy that is unfolding in Xinjiang province, China. I, along with many other Australians, am very troubled by the repressive surveillance state and how the Uygur people are being banned from practicing their religious faith and how they are being oppressively monitored in their homes, in their communities, 24/7. I am very troubled by the way that Uygur culture and identity is being systematically assaulted, deconstructed and scrubbed out by the authorities. I am very troubled by the clear evidence of re-education camps, where one million Uygurs have been forcibly detained and indoctrinated into communists thinking. The ABC, along with the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, have managed to identify 28 detention camps using satellite imagery. Most of those detained have never committed a crime. I could go on. It was a heartbreaking episode that we all needed to watch and absorb. I congratulate the ABC for running it and for the work that went into it.

Last month, I met with members of the Australian Uygur community in my parliamentary office. That delegation was led by Nurmuhammad Majid. It was my great honour to host them and hear their personal stories. Every single one of them sitting in my office had family and friends interned or trapped in Xinjiang province. They have shown great courage and perseverance despite the tears, heartache and pain. I made a commitment to them that I would raise their plight in this House, and tonight I fulfil that commitment. I say to them: we might not see resolution soon, but we will continue to work with you and make sure your loved ones are not forgotten.

Finally, the Four Corners episode identified a range of Australian businesses that were sourcing cotton from Xinjiang province, potentially using Uygur forced labour. Cotton On and Target Australia were two of them. Subsequent to the program, both businesses conducted internal reviews of their supply chains and have ceased sourcing cotton from Xinjiang province. I want to note the actions of Cotton On and Target Australia in this House and applaud them for the action that they have taken. Australia is a country that lives by the values of freedom and fairness, and so it is right that we acknowledge when our businesses do the right thing. I thank the House.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hogan)
took the chair at 10:00.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hogan)
took the chair at 10:00.
CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Ms O'NEIL (Hotham) (10:00): The NDIS is a good system. It is a system that was proudly pioneered by Labor to support Australians living with a disability. I acknowledge at the outset the critical role that Bill Shorten, our former leader, played in bringing the scheme to life. Unfortunately, under the Liberals we're seeing the NDIS spiral into crisis. Earlier this year the Treasurer propped up the budget at the expense of Australians with disability by ripping $1.6 billion out of the National Disability Insurance Scheme—that is $1.6 billion less for people with disability. While the Treasurer shamelessly short changed the NDIS by $1.6 billion, Australians with disabilities are missing out on the support and care that they need. Waiting times are out of control and applicants are having to wait months to have their plan reviewed or get technical support.

One of the most frustrating and offensive things that has happened in the debate about NDIS funding is the claim of those on the other side that the NDIS is a demand-driven scheme and that the reason it has been underspent is that there is not enough demand. There are two Labor MPs sitting behind me, and I know I speak for them when I say that our offices are inundated with people who are trying to get things out of the NDIS but, because of the staffing caps in that organisation, are not able to get the help they need. We want the government to open its eyes and acknowledge that the NDIS is not living up to its promise today. It can do that, but it's not doing it today.

I want to speak about some of the constituents who have come to me for help with NDIS issues. One constituent in Wheelers Hill contacted my office about her son, who requires special foot orthotics to prevent further deterioration and deformity in his lower limbs. Their request of the National Disability Insurance Scheme to secure funding was submitted almost a year ago today. My constituent followed up with them many times and finally came to my office for help. The matter was then resolved within three days. This story, where you have to get your member of parliament involved in the NDIS to get the outcome that you deserve, is happening all over the country. Another constituent, from Mulgrave, had a first NDIS plan for her severely autistic daughter. The whole plan was about the support coordinator, but the funding for the support coordinator wasn't included in the package. My office requested a review, which is going to take three months. All the while, that family is sitting there without the support they need. Another constituent in Mulgrave contacted me about her twin daughters. They both have disabilities and need home modifications. Her request to the NDIA went months and months and months, and even with the advocacy of my office it is taking a further two months to get this claim processed.

We can do so much better. This scheme has enormous potential to improve the lives of millions of Australians, but I fear that we are going to need a Labor government to make sure it lives up to that promise.
Flynn Electorate: Dairy Farming

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:03): I rise today to support the dairy farmers of Central Queensland and of Australia. The issues that faced the industry—gate price and severe drought, in that order—continue to threaten the future of dairy farmers in Queensland. The dairy industry continues to be one of Australia's most important agricultural industries. Generating over $13 billion across the whole supply chain, dairy is Australia's third-largest rural industry. It generated $4.3 billion from gate production in 2017-18—a retail value of $6.8 billion—and $3.4 billion worth of products exported. The Australian dairy industry employs approximately 39,000 people. Central Queensland dairy farmers are vital to their local economies and to rural and regional areas of Flynn. In my electorate there are approximately 29 farmers left. There are only 29 farmers left in the whole of Flynn, which is twice the size of Tasmania. It is a small number compared to what used to be in Flynn. There were thousands.

On a particular dairy farm in Biloela, which is run by third-generation people, they milk 400 cows a day. Their power bill has doubled in the last 10 years and fodder prices have increased, especially due to the drought. They are extraordinarily high because of the drought and the cost of bringing in this product when there is drought across the whole eastern part of Australia. Their concerns are that order needs to be brought back to the industry. There is no order there at the moment—often the processors get more than the farmer gets—so that's why I'm glad my government is taking action.

The government supports Australian dairy farmers being paid a fair price at the gate for their milk. The Australian dairy industry mandatory code of practice will come into effect in January 2020, months ahead of schedule. It aims to improve the contractual arrangements between the dairy farmers and the dairy processors. The fact remains that it's the third-largest rural industry in Australia. There are 5,700 dairy farmers in Australia now, but that is declining, and 98 per cent of those farms are family owned. The government understands the importance of the mandatory code being delivered as soon as possible in order to provide a clearer safeguard for those farmers who are left, who must be treated as members of the supply chain and appreciated.

subdebateinfo.title: Cure Blindness Australia, Macquarie Electorate: Infrastructure

p.span: Cure Blindness Australia
Macquarie Electorate: Infrastructure

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:06): I had to eat dinner in the dark recently, and it was harder than I thought it would be. Danielle Verhoeven, from the Blue Mountains, has a rare condition—Usher syndrome—which causes hearing loss and progressive blindness. At 41, she still has some useful central vision. She works as a telephone triage nurse and is mum to a four-year-old. In spite of her challenges, Danielle feels she has been lucky and she wanted to raise some money for Cure Blindness Australia. Our job during dinner was to see what it was like to eat a meal with little vision or no vision at all. We were inspired by hearing from world blind motorcycle land speed record holder, Ben Felten, another Blue Mountains resident. Ben hit a record 272.596 kilometres an hour last year in South Australia.

My aspiration was more modest—I just wanted to eat my meal. My first attempt was with the all-in eye mask, which meant I had no sight at all. As forkfuls of pork made their way slowly to my mouth, I had no idea if I was going to be chewing a big bit or a little piece. I was grateful for the mashed potato and missed half of the asparagus completely. It was easier with the glasses that simulated tunnel vision, but it still required huge amounts of head movement and concentration. It was a terrific fundraising idea and great experience for those of us who only have to cope with things like being a little bit blurry when we take our specs off.

The concerns continue for Thompson Square and Windsor Bridge as the replacement project rolls out. I've already called for a better incorporation of some of the salvaged bricks and stones into the new park area, and that the New South Wales government keep the old, heritage listed bridge, which provides a fantastic tourism opportunity to link the two sides of the river. But we've just learnt that more terrible decision-making is happening around this project. I'm outraged to hear that the RMS has just admitted it needs to take an extra 300 metres off Thompson Square because the intersection at George Street will otherwise fail to meet traffic needs. It was obvious from the start of this project that you couldn't merge two lanes into one lane at an intersection just in front of a bridge. It was always a bad plan, but the RMS denied that. But you have to ask: was this their plan all along? Is this why they had a $137 million contingency fund in this project's budget? If it was, why was none of this disclosed to the Hawkesbury community?

The lack of transparency on this project by the New South Wales government has been shameful from the start. The community has fought to save this historic square from this appalling modern concrete monolith going through. Now we know that even less of the oldest public square in Australia will be available for the community. It's an outrage and it should not be happening. We should have had a bypass there from the start.
141st Assembly of the Inter-Parliamentary Union

Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (10:09): Last week I had the privilege of joining the member for Robertson, the member for Bruce and Senator O'Neill in representing Australia at the 141st Assembly of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. The Inter-Parliamentary Union, or IPU, was formed in 1889 and today represents 179 parliaments which come together with a shared vision: a world where every vote counts and where democracy and parliaments are at the service of the people for peace and development.

In Belgrade last week, we joined over 1,800 other parliamentarians from all over the world in sessions which addressed the IPU's core work: peace, democracy, human rights, gender equality, youth empowerment and sustainable development. I was honoured to have the chance to address delegates concerning Australia's leading contribution on the abolishment of all forms of chemical weapons. I was pleased to reaffirm to our international colleagues that Australia consistently and strongly condemns the use of chemical weapons by anyone, anywhere, under any circumstances.

I can report to the House that the 141st IPU assembly adopted an important resolution. It called on all parliamentarians to put in place legislation to achieve universal health coverage by 2030. This supports the political declaration adopted at the 74th Session of the United Nations General Assembly high-level meeting in September. The resolution calls on parliaments to use all their power to hold their respective national governments accountable for the effective implementation of this commitment. It calls on them to monitor the impact of universal health coverage policies and programs and to establish parliamentary mechanisms to measure progress on achieving access to health care for all by 2030.

We are, of course, very fortunate in Australia to already boast one of the world's finest universal healthcare systems. Many nations cannot say the same. Indeed, having listened to the many challenges faced by people all over the world, I was reminded forcibly that, once again, Australia is truly the most magnificent country in the world: no war; no endemic corruption; universal health care; generous social security; a strong defence force; a stable democracy; relative safety and freedom for all, including our elected representatives; a national budget back in the black; respect for the rule of law; and a beautiful environment. We have a lot to be thankful for in this country. We should all be encouraged and reassured. Despite the gloom and doom peddled by some in our society, the world is not going to come to an end tomorrow nor in 2030. Australia is forging ahead and I am very, very proud to be part of a government that is doing just that.

subdebateinfo.title: Indi Electorate: North East Solar Benefits program

p.span: Indi Electorate: North East Solar Benefits program

Dr HAINES (Indi) (10:12): I stand today to acknowledge a wonderful community initiative in my electorate of Indi. It brings together some of my great passions: renewable energy, affordable housing and support for low-income families. BeyondHousing is the largest community housing organisation in Victoria's Goulburn and Ovens Murray regions. It provides supports for people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. It's working at the frontline to help them in a constructive, grounded way. Many households have cost-of-living pressures. High energy costs are one of them, eating into valuable household budgets. Wodonga is in the top 30 Victorian postcodes for electricity disconnection, and across the regions the rate of disconnections is higher than in our cities. People who cannot afford to pay for power are at risk of homelessness.

This project responds to both challenges: affordable housing and affordable power. It's an inspired collaboration between BeyondHousing and Renewable Albury Wodonga Energy, a community group advocating for renewables uptake on the border. As one of the first projects of its kind, four-kilowatt solar systems supplied by Solar Integrity have been installed at 10 BeyondHousing properties. The systems include digital monitors. So, for the first time, householders can see their energy use: when and how they're using it. The BeyondHousing chief executive, Celia Adams, says, 'Reducing natural resource use through renewable energy uptake is a key priority for the organisation and the householders it supports.' The new solar scheme reduces power costs in these homes and allows householders to keep the savings for other costs such as medical and school bills. It also encourages householders to talk about sustainability, renewable energy and power use.
Jackie, who shares her home with her five children, was one of the first project recipients. She says:
I now have a chance to see how we use energy and to make some practical changes that help my family pay less on electricity and have more for my children's health and education.

For Katie, whose home was fitted with solar power systems, her household budget is better off. So is the world beyond her roofline. 'On a tight budget and renting, you don't think you've got the means to reduce your impact on the environment and use solar power,' she says, 'But this solar system has given us the chance to be part of caring for our planet in an everyday way.' I salute the householders, BeyondHousing, Solar Integrity and the Victorian government for taking the lead on this important initiative, and I look forward to the program's ongoing development in Wodonga and its rollout in Wangaratta, my home town.
Sneesby, Ms Gwenyth

Mr FALINSKI (Mackellar) (10:15): I rise today to acknowledge Gwenyth Sneesby and her ongoing service to our country. Gwenyth was born in Northbridge on 17 June 1924. Following her father's retirement from the Navy and a short time of living in England, her family moved back to Australia, settling in Turimetta Street in Mona Vale.

Gwenyth, at the ripe age of 18, became one of the first females to enlist in the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, on 9 December 1942. When asked why she joined the Navy, she exclaimed, 'My father was a Navy man, so the Navy was in my blood.' After completing her basic training on the HMAS Penguin, Gwenyth was one of only 10 females who served on the HMAS Kuttabul. Fatefully, she was off duty the night two Japanese midget submarines entered Sydney Harbour and sunk the ship. Gwenyth's gallant service persisted throughout the war. Her artistic aptitude saw her selected to draw charts on a degaussing range in Bradley's Head. Her job was to help electrical officers eliminate the magnetic field surrounding Australian ships, keeping them safe atop of the perilous magnetic mines.

To this day, Gwenyth fondly reminisces on her time in the Navy, cherishing the camaraderie of her female compatriots. It is with this camaraderie that Gwenyth continues to contribute to our community. Although Gwenyth has retired from her role as a diligent volunteer for the charity Meals on Wheels, she has taken up a new role as an activities officer at Pittwater retirement village and she continues to contribute to the wider community as an active branch member of the Pittwater RSL. Her affable attitude and compassion are commendable. It is within this community service that we can see Gwenyth's life motto in action: 'Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.'

I'm proud to recognise Gwenyth as an outstanding member of the northern beaches community. I'd like to pay tribute to the considerable contributions she has made to both our country and our community. To this day, Gwenyth continues to bring her imaginative, considerate and adventurous attitude to our community. After calling Mona Vale her home for 86 years, Gwenyth faithfully maintains that she 'wouldn't want to do anything else apart from live in Mona Vale'. It is on that note that I am more than proud to declare: we are fortunate to have her in our community.
Pension Loans Scheme

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong) (10:18): In the raucous hubbub of parliament, it's amazing how some of the most important issues in this country can sometimes go little noticed, barely remarked upon. As is often the case, the quiet voices of the powerless carry the most important, powerful messages. The relationship between MPs and their constituents is important, because our constituents rely upon us to be their champions. As local members know, when the phones start running hot, when the letters come piling in and when people stop us in the streets, it tells us that someone somewhere has done something right or, more commonly, done something very wrong. It's a great part of the straight-talking, non-deferential, egalitarian Australian character, as well as the vital lifeblood of how our direct democracy works.

As the opposition spokesperson for the NDIS and government services, it is my job as an MP and a shadow to speak truth to power. Having reimmersed myself in the world of disability and NDIS, I want to speak about the problems that some parent pensioners, and therefore their families, are facing, including financial pressure from the government. There is an issue that many out there have not heard much about, but it is very real to a good number of pensioners. It is an issue that can be fixed if the quieter Australians are not just cited by the Prime Minister but respected.

We have a thing in this country called the Pension Loans Scheme. It enables older people who own property to get a boost to their cash flows. In effect, the government takes a part mortgage and charges an interest fee, and the older person gets to unlock some of the equity in their home to meet their financial expenses. The government is essentially acting as a bank for older people with mortgages. It has a good-hearted public service goal at heart. But, when the Reserve Bank cut the official cash rate to a record 0.75 per cent on 1 October, this led to bank loan rates at three per cent and, indeed, as low as 2.9 per cent while the government's Pension Loans Scheme is still charging older Australians at 5.25 per cent. Even private sector versions of the Pension Loans Scheme like the ME Bank have dropped their rates of reverse mortgage to 5.15 per cent.

There are good, important questions here. Why is the government-run scheme no cheaper than a bank? Why is it that the banks have a bigger heart than the Liberal-National government? Why won't the government, who calls upon its mates in the banks to pass on the Reserve's interest rate cuts in full, do what it's telling others to do? Will the Treasurer investigate himself as he's asked the ACCC to investigate the banks? Why should the government be able to borrow money at about one per cent and massively profiteer from old-age pensioners by not cutting their own rate? The unkind might call this a pensioners tax, a retirees tax or, indeed, a Morrison death tax. I call upon the government to fix this shocking situation, stop being hypocrites, pass on the cuts and stop gouging older Australians and pensioners, who have done nothing to deserve this.
Swan Electorate: Roads

Mr IRONS (Swan—Assistant Minister for Vocational Education, Training and Apprenticeships) (10:21): I'm taking this opportunity to report to the House and to my electorate that work has actually commenced on the Manning on-ramp in my electorate of Swan. This important infrastructure project has been planned since the mid-1980s, and I really appreciate the fact that the federal Liberal government's $28 million commitment in 2016 has finally made this construction a reality. This government's contribution represents 80 per cent of the cost of the project. In doing so, the government is supporting the 100 jobs that will be required to deliver this project. I know you might find this hard to believe, but federal Labor opposed this project. We actually had Labor senators making speeches in their chamber, opposing this project.

Earlier this year, works began to relocate power and light poles around Lockhart Street and Ley Street as well as demolish buildings to prepare for the project on Canning Parade, Lockhart Street and the corner of Manning Road and Clydesdale Street. Roadworks to build the new freeway on-ramp connecting to the southbound freeway lines will begin in the coming weeks. Works will be undertaken on and around Manning Road between Ley Street and the Kwinana Freeway in Como and continue until mid-2020.

This project will deliver a series of key road network changes that include a new southbound lane on the Kwinana Freeway from the Canning Highway on-ramp to the Edgewater Road footbridge in Salter Point, the construction of a new merge lane from the on-ramp to the freeway heading south, closing off access from Lockhart Street to Manning Road, providing left-only access at Edgecombe Street to Manning Road and the installation of cabling for future signals at the intersection of Manning Road and Clydesdale Street, and constructing a right-turn pocket from Manning Road to Clydesdale Street south as well as providing for the further installation of traffic signals at that intersection. This project will not only provide a new route for users to travel south on the Kwinana Freeway from Manning Road but will also reduce travelling time and congestion, which is part of our congestion-busting program. In doing so, this project will significantly improve safety for road users within my electorate and reduce traffic numbers.

I know this has been a key issue for many years for residents along the Manning Road corridor, and I'd like to thank residents and community groups who have provided support for the project and have allowed me to put this issue forward and deliver the funding. I'd also like to acknowledge John McGrath, the local MLA, who put this matter on the state government's agenda back in 2016 and secured a funding commitment from the previous Barnet government.
We will continue to deliver congestion-busting infrastructure for residents in my electorate of Swan and for electorates all across Australia.
Trade

Mr GOSLING (Solomon) (10:24): Trade is good. I welcome the passage of the Indonesia, Hong Kong and Peru trade agreements through the House of Representatives. I represent Darwin, the northern capital of Australia. As far as the Northern Territory is concerned, having an agreement with Indonesia, in particular, as one of our closest neighbours, and increasing engagement with Indonesia, is an overwhelmingly good thing. We face north and we ask the parliament to face north towards us in Darwin and the Northern Territory, but more broadly to face north into the massive opportunities in the Indo-Pacific region.

I was very proud to have been appointed by the Labor leader, Anthony Albanese, as the chair of the Indo-Pacific trade task force. I've been working closely with our shadow trade minister, Madeleine King, the member for Brand, who has been working hard to get some commitments from the government on the trade deals that have been passed by the House of Representatives this year. Well done to the shadow trade minister. She secured commitments from the Morrison government to ensure that the implementation of these three trade agreements will safeguard Australian jobs and address the real concern of exploitation of foreign workers.

Ms King wrote to the trade minister, Simon Birmingham, who, in his response, has made a number of commitments, including: the termination of the existing bilateral investment treaty with Indonesia, the BIT; a review of older-style investment dispute settlement regimes to ensure they contain modern safeguards, which is going to be overwhelmingly good for previous agreements as well as future agreements; an assessment of the operation of the ISDS mechanism in a review of the Indonesia agreement that the government has agreed to mandate five years after the agreement enters into force; and a commitment not to use the provisions of the Indonesia agreement to extend any labour market testing waivers in any future agreement on contractual service suppliers. These are important commitments to have confirmed.
