Further, there is a commitment to ensure working holiday-makers are not exploited and that they are qualified for work that is undertaken— (Time expired)
Lyne Electorate: Community Events

Dr GILLESPIE (Lyne) (10:27): Over the weekend I was delighted to participate in a couple of really important events in the Lyne electorate. The Camden Haven Show at the Kendall showground was an outrageous success. The grand parade had vintage cars, fire service people, all the stock and display animals, and a lot of youth in their comical make-up for their horses. I would also like to congratulate some of the exhibiters, particularly in the beef cattle industry. The reserve champion, Chloe Bisley, and the grand champion, Jasmin Madden, are both still at school and have already established their own cattle breeding studs.

I'd also like to give a shout-out to the organisers and volunteers at Wingham Akoostik Music Festival, which kicked off last Friday evening. Donna Ballard and her husband and the team have done a tremendous job putting together an enormous festival. I was really proud and delighted to be able to secure $20,000 from the community stream of the Building Better Regions Fund to allow this wonderful festival, in its 13th year, to grow and build. Thousands of locals turned up.

I'd like to congratulate the ladies of the Port Macquarie Hastings Breast Cancer Support Group, who have been getting out and about all over the Hastings Valley in the last couple of weeks. The local coordinator of the support group, Judith Hutchesson, and her wonderful team of volunteers, Gloria Caswell, Daphne Latham and Carolyn Gorton, were on hand at the Wauchope IGA the other day to share resources and raise awareness as well as to secure funds for the Breast Cancer Network. There were 100 pink lady silhouettes on display to remind people of those in the region who have died of breast cancer. Selling raffle tickets to raise money and awareness is a really important role in the fight against a very common disease. Unfortunately, breast cancer affects 50 people a day in Australia. Support groups like this do a valuable job for everyone involved in the journey of living with cancer.

I would like to congratulate them because they're not a flash in the pan; they've been doing this for years. The cancer spectrum of treatments has been a really exciting space to be involved in; we have so many new wonderful drugs and treatments because of the cutting-edge pharmaceuticals that we list on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Many of the people in this support group are alive and well now because of these wonderful new treatments. This period running up to summer is a great time for everyone in Hastings valley. I wish all similar community groups all the best.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): In accordance with standing order 193, the time for members constituency statements has concluded.
GOVERNOR GENERAL'S SPEECH
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That the following Address in Reply to the speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein) (10:30): By all accounts, Vida Goldstein made her mark in 1902 as the first Aussie to visit a US President in the White House. Prominent abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison described the suffragette as carrying a youthful, audacious, unrestrained and free spirit, embracing Australia's absence of an immoral shackle against progress. This is the spirit that I bring to my second term in the House of Representatives, and I thank the people of Goldstein for the privilege and for their trust.

You can't represent Goldstein if you are not fiercely proud of your liberalism. On 18 May, Goldstein voted for a forward-looking, modern liberalism that reflects our community's values to shape the direction of the nation. Sir Robert Menzies understood that defining Australia's future is not a choice between the accelerator of progressivism and the brake of conservativism; it is a choice about whether we want to steer either to a socialist or to a liberal future. Menzies knew that for Australian liberalism to enjoy a social licence it must be built on the pillars of freedom, justice and responsibility, empowering individuals, families and communities in pursuit of national, economic and social progress. Menzies knew Australia needed a liberalism built on pluralism and respect, recognising that there are a lot of people we will encounter who think that there ought to be a species of drab uniformity. This passion for uniformity is not to be encouraged. What we need in Australia is for every person from some particular race or faith who comes into the Australian community to retain their quality in that sense but add to the qualities of all the other people.

Menzies' modern Liberalism fostered equal opportunity and social mobility while safeguarding dignity and respecting sacrifice, delivering intergenerational justice through economic, social and environmental stewardship not only between those who are living but between those who are living, those who are dead and those who are to be born. Menzies' audacious modern liberalism was captured in his 1965 address to the Liberal Party's federal conference, when he said:
The effect of this forward thinking, this liveliness, this being modern, being prepared to be a little adventurous …
… we have won because we have been the party of innovations. Not the party of the past, not the conservative party dying hard on the last barricade, but the party of innovations.
These were innovations, these were evidences of a lively mind and a forward-looking heart.
He finished by saying:
This is the whole thing that we must remember and that we must continue to remember and act on in the years to come …

The years to come have arrived. Menzies' words of 54 years ago called us to the restoration of this vision and to bring these values alive in contemporary debates. They are more contemporary now than ever. In the past two years, Australians have had two opportunities to vote for the type of country they want to be—first, for a forward-looking social liberal agenda and, also, for a lower-tax economic liberal agenda. Both were in the affirmative.

But there is more work to be done. Liberalism strengthens citizens and communities, not centralised capitals or corporates. This should be the anchor by which we approach Indigenous Australians seeking self-determination through their freedom to take responsibility. One of the most unifying developments of recent years has been the integration of Indigenous history, culture, symbols and language into our national civic life. It's a yearning to recognise that we are all part of the continuum of this continent's journey and story through empowerment in the pursuit of national unity. As Indigenous leader Rachel Perkins argued, the pathway to reconciliation can be a two-way mirror. We acknowledge you; you acknowledge us; we become one. As we say in the Arrernte community, country: one land, one mob.

Last term we turned Liberal values into action. Among many achievements, we incentivised investment and cut taxes, leading to the creation of more than 1,000 new jobs a day. New PBS listings for medicines brought the frontiers of biomedical research to the bedside. We empowered working parents through childcare reform and secured Australia's future by building 50 new ships for our defence industry plan. From the backbench we led the abandonment of the China Extradition Treaty. And, as evidenced by recent events in Hong Kong, which I have witnessed, this was the most significant yet unremarked event of the last parliament. We took a strong stand against the politics of race in One Nation, who drape themselves in the flag and concurrently fan social division with the purpose of empowering themselves at the expense of our national unity. We succeeded in having government adopt an objective standard definition of harassment to limit the possible excesses of section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act. We redefined proposals to confront the inequity of unlimited tax- free income and superannuation, while encouraging sacrifice and saving for a secure retirement for millions of Australians. We secured greater medical privacy protection for the My Health record system. With the Australian people, we delivered marriage equality, and I'm sure fellow rainbow rebels are proud of the journey we took to enlarge the freedom for couples to make voluntary commitments of mutual respect. And we stood up to Labor's smear campaign to shut down the economic committee's inquiry on refundable franking credits. Our inquiry gave Australians a platform to voice their opposition to Labor's insidious attempt to steal the overpaid tax of nearly one million Australian retirees and low-income earners.

At the last election, the Goldstein Liberal team ran on three pillars. The first was lower taxes. We promised a plan for lower taxes and we have already delivered it. You should keep more of what you earn. You should have the freedom to choose not have your choices dictated to you by people in this chamber. It's your money not ours. The second was retirement security. At the election retirees saw their bank balance on the ballot. Retirement security depends on certainty and the re-election of the coalition government stopped Labor's retiree tax. And we will deliver on our promise not to change superannuation taxes for the life of this parliament. The third was improving lifestyle. Goldstein is a residential retreat. While lacking much industry we are industrious. Every day thousands of residents grow small businesses and commute to professional jobs. They don't want a government to solve their problems; they want a government who protects their rights while improving their quality of life. Our government will deliver, having committed $24.5 million for Bayside and Glen Eira to develop hundreds of new car parking spaces at local railway stations to ease daily commutes.

Every parent wants to see their child succeed. We are backing the next generation of Australians by delivering record public, Catholic and independent school funding. We're addressing the inequity faced by young women in sporting infrastructure through an additional $4.7 million investment in a new regional netball facility in Sandringham, as well as many other local investments in sporting grounds. That's in addition to our record investment in local hospitals and full Medicare licensed MRIs at Cabrini Brighton and Holmesglen Moorabbin.

Our lifestyle also comes from stewarding our local environment and protecting the health of Port Phillip and taking proportionate action to safeguard the climate. The coalition has twice taken Australia's commitments to cut emissions under the Paris Agreement to an election, and voters expect it to be honoured through a range of measures to lead the transition of the energy grid and to improve industrial energy efficiency through our Energy Productivity Plan, and we will deliver it. Our local cities of Glen Eira and Bayside are leading the way by enabling residents to recycle their food waste as part of a holistic package for the country. Port Phillip already faces challenge from pollutants, water quality and coastal erosion. We can show how local leadership can deliver environmental outcomes of national importance.

Recently a Labor MP said the worst thing he could do is mislead workers. The same is true of Liberal MPs to citizens. Put simply, business as usual won't secure another 29 years of uninterrupted economic growth. At elections governments seek mandates based on a specific set of circumstances and from time to time events provide their own. In those situations governments are rarely judged by the circumstances that they find themselves in; they are judged by their response. As chair of the House Economics Committee, again I carry a responsibility to lead discussions on the economic health of the nation and will. The environment we presently find ourselves in is one which is highly exposed to external shocks, with high public and private debt, limited fiscal levers and very low interest rates.

At the beginning of this term I deliberately communicated my concern about the Reserve Bank continuing to cut interest rates. In 2012, the RBA identified that low rates are an increasingly fraught stimulus strategy. Retirees have more interest-bearing assets, and households with a large amount of interest-bearing assets may also adjust their spending in response to a change in interest rates. Interest-bearing assets are expected to grow over time as the population ages, and it has continued on that trajectory.

Most people approach policy in politics based on their stage of life. Over time, the youthful desire for opportunity gradually turns to a desire for security as people look to their retirement with an aspiration for independence, dignity and choice. The recent focus on the impact of deeming rates on disposable income highlights this point. Some are now, rightly, questioning the wisdom of cutting rates and following the rest of the world down the economic sinkhole of the low-interest-rate-growth path. As one observer noted, the derivatives markets expect the cash rate to average below one per cent for the next five years, and we're now there. Of course this now seems optimistic.

Deliberate cultivation of higher debt through low interest rates is a one-way journey, with scant opportunity for a U-turn. Security for older Australians is akin to opportunity for younger Australians to get a good education, a rewarding job, to buy a home and to raise a family. Yet that is compromised when monetary policy is inflating house prices, thereby making it harder for young Australians to get their first foothold on the property ladder. The RBA's own model of the Australian housing market identifies that much of the strength in housing prices and construction over the past few years can be explained by the fall in interest rates. As Menzies himself understood, our people are entitled to good homes at a cost which bears some proper relation to their earnings.

What we also know is that rising house prices deny a disproportionate share of the nation's scarce capital to investment and productive activities, and needlessly eat into the economic equity of the nation. Disturbingly, the legitimacy of quantitative easing has been socialised and, as Rupert Murdoch argued in 2014, quantitative easing increases the price of assets such as stocks and real estate, and that has helped first and foremost those who already have assets.
A 2018 study from Wei Cui and Vincent Sterk from University College London concluded:
… QE interventions come with strong side effects on inequality, which can substantially lower social welfare.

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Mr TIM WILSON: Before the break I was speaking about quantitative easing. If introduced in Australia's current economic environment, it will keep asset prices high for those who've had a go and be paid for by higher prices for those who want a go.

Most people view the tax system through a specific prism based on what is contributing horizontally across today's societal spread, according primarily to income. A modern, liberal tax system would also reflect the vertical contribution across people's stages of life and respect the need for intergenerational equity and the assistance parents provide for their vulnerable children, as well as when the situation is reversed. To quote the Productivity Commission:

On average, families in the under-60 age groups pay $15 300 more per year in taxes than they receive in transfers. By contrast, families in the 60+ age group receive an average of $10 900 more in transfers than they pay in taxes. …. In total, families in the 60+ age group account for 51 per cent of all transfer expenditure.

The data is just the symptom, it is not the cause. The rise of transfers is being driven by rising healthcare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme costs at the most expensive stage of people's lives, along with increasing demands for pensions and aged care support.

We should respect that older Australians have paid taxes throughout their lives and at different rates to today, but not through a tax bondage on the next generation which constrains their freedom to choose. With nearly half of all federal taxes coming from income, the only solution governments have found is to increase migration of working-age people to help shoulder the increasing expenditure burden, putting economic, infrastructure and environmental pressure on our nation and contributing to the perception that our economic model is fundamentally flawed.

One of our strengths is that Australia has found peace and prosperity as an open economy and a liberal society, but the lessons of human history educate us on its fragility. The cost of inaction will hit every Australian in the form of lower growth, higher unemployment and structural imbalances that favour the established against the aspirational. With many states failing to use their stamp duty windfalls during property price peaks to rebase their taxation receipts, the Commonwealth has an opportunity to put new revenue sources on the table to redress the legacy of vertical fiscal imbalance. As Charles Adams wrote in his inspirational tome, For Good and Evil: the Impact of Taxes on the Course of Civilisation:
Taxes which touch a broad range of economic activities, even with equal rates, will inevitably be mildly progressive.

The challenge we face collectively is one of exposure. Resulting from the United States embracing quantitative easing in the past, comparable economies have had no choice but to exhaust their monetary policy options as well. Their balance sheets are also thin, with little left in the fiscal tank. Meanwhile, structural reform is politically challenging and the dividend is slow and diffused; it is low GI. Yet redress of structural imbalances inevitably leads to a modern, liberal economic reform vision for the 21st century, one which works to confront the productivity challenges of a modern Australia in a competitive global economy.

On tax, there should be flattening of discrepancies between income, company and capital gains tax, as well as broadening the use of consumption taxes that multinational businesses and individuals pay across business and life cycles. On energy, we're embracing the fact that the debate is no longer defined solely by the price of the fuel but by the combination of the risks to return from long-run investments that are exposed to finance network risks, as well as an environmental legacy footprint. On industrial relations, moving away from a confrontational model that assumes employers want fewer employees will assist them to understand that the greatest struggle for businesses is the hiring and retention of talent by having a system designed to ease hire over constraining legitimate fire.

None of us stands here alone. To the Goldstein campaign team, led by campaign director Gavan Macrides, with Harvey Allatt, Hana Hartney, Hanife Bushby, Josephine Goss and Greg Wills, we give thanks. The Goldstein executive was led by chair Ian Farrow, with Greg Cheesman, Jason Berek-Lewis, Carolyn Brown, Jan Cooper, Simon Farrow, Vicki Grove, Frank Papa, Dearne Revelle, Peter Snedden and Jennifer Gaskell, as well as Louis and Ella, who never strayed from their pug ambassadors-in-chief duties. There are the party members, campaigners, booth captains, workers and donors that form the frontline of Australia's political defence. The SMS whisperers of Daniel Bevan, Mike Poutney, Susie Bartlett, Constantine Franteskos and my brother Simon always make me laugh and give me inspiration. There are Tim Wildash, Michael Stillwell, Nicholas Healy, Shaun Levin, Jeannette Rawlinson, Pete Gaunt, Colleen Harkin, Shaun Gross and Bayside Forum members. There is the Goldstein office team: Claire Ewart-Kennedy, Kristin Vidovich and Amy Green, as well as Mason Sugars, Kurt Fong and Daniel Redman, Cale Dobrosak, Sandra Tomlinson, Susan Vale, Tara Whitehead, Penny Lanigan, Thomas Morrissey, Angela Gledhill, Daniel Elberg, Andrew Priestly and Zach August. To James Stevens, who organised our nationwide refundable franking credits inquiry and local re-election campaign concurrently, I particularly say thank you. We all share this journey together.
Finally, thanks to my husband, Ryan. In my first speech I reflected:
No matter what happens from here, we have already achieved more than many who come and go from this place because we have lived the change we seek in the world.
'Here' happened, and we live these words together—and we are only warming up. Thank you.

Mr CONROY (Shortland) (11:06): It is indeed an honour and a privilege to have been re-elected to serve as the member for Shortland for a second time. I am only the fourth person to serve in this role in the seat's 70-year history, so I am particularly aware of the special responsibility I have to the people I represent. I sincerely thank my constituents for placing their trust in me for the next three years. It has indeed been a privilege to represent them in the national parliament for the past three years, and I am excited by the opportunity to continue to be their voice. This is my third term in the House, having served my first term in the 44th Parliament as the member for Charlton. I am as aware today of the awesome responsibility I have as the representative of the people in my electorate as I was on the first day I spoke in this place in 2013.

I want to begin with some words of thanks, most importantly to my wife and children for their unwavering love and constant support for me in my job. Each of us in the House is aware of the huge burden our representation places on our families. My family is everything to me, and I want them to be the first of my acknowledgements. I also want to acknowledge the rank-and-file members of the Labor Party who again gave me their confidence to be our party's candidate in Shortland, I thank them and all the many supporters and volunteers who assisted in assuring that Shortland returned a Labor member of parliament. Finally, I thank my dedicated staff for their coordination of the campaign and their ongoing support of me and our constituents.

I'm also honoured that my Labor colleagues have supported me to be a shadow minister, and I thank my friend the Leader of the Opposition for giving me the chance to serve as the shadow minister for international development and the Pacific, shadow minister assisting for climate change and shadow minister assisting for defence. These three policy areas are enormously challenging and inextricably linked. Fighting climate change is an issue of international and intergenerational equity, and our closest neighbours in the Pacific deserve our support and leadership. With shadow foreign minister Penny Wong, I am working to advance our agenda to engage with other nations in the Pacific as part of our efforts to foster and preserve peace, prosperity, stability and security in the region—efforts that are fundamental to Australia's own national security.

Australia has a deep interest in contributing to global poverty alleviation, but coalition governments have abandoned our commitment to aid funding and slashed our International Development Assistance Program budget by an incredible $11.8 billion in the six years they have been in power. This is a source of international embarrassment for Australia and, indeed, is at odds with the generous spirit of Australian people.

Despite advocating the Pacific step-up as a signature foreign policy, the government continues to demonstrate that this step up is cynical window-dressing, as it merely funnels $500 million of existing aid funds to the Pacific, which has resulted in the withdrawal of aid funding from other parts of the world. For example, Pakistan has been denuded of Australian aid funding. Given that Pakistan is at the heart of the struggle against Islamic extremism, this is a very short-sighted and counterproductive move.

Despite the so-called Pacific step up, the Prime Minister has let down our Pacific neighbours by failing to act on climate change, which they have identified as the most important issue they face and one that threatens their very existence. Australia signed up to the Boe declaration last year, when we acknowledged and agreed that climate change was the No. 1 existential threat to the entire Pacific region, including Australia. Mr Morrison had the opportunity to commit to real action on climate change at the Pacific Island leaders forum in August, but he let the Pacific down and he let Australia down when he watered down the Pacific Island leaders communique on climate change, removing the word 'crisis' and replacing it with 'reality'. Yes, climate change is certainly a reality for people in low-lying Pacific islands, but it is also a crisis—a crisis for which this government has no plan. We saw the Prime Minister's arrogant attitude to the people of the Pacific, repeated in the words of his deputy not long after. In a leaked video, the Deputy Prime Minister said the Pacific Islands would survive climate change because their workers could come to Australia to 'pick our fruit'. It was a disgraceful comment, and the ramifications of that remark were felt widely across the Pacific, further damaging our reputation and credibility with our important neighbours. In fact, I was talking to a key stakeholder group, and one particular individual had just come back from Fiji. His taxi driver on the way to the airport actually raised the Deputy Prime Minister's remarks with him directly. This is permeating all through the Pacific.

The government has also undermined the Pacific Labour Scheme, which was designed to bring Pacific workers to Australia to help fill worker shortages here as well as provide an economic and skills boost to Pacific countries, when at the same time it was loosening the controls around the backpacker visa. Instead of attracting 2,000 workers in its first year, the Pacific Labour Scheme attracted only 200, meaning $8 million worth of wages that would have been repatriated to Pacific nations was not paid. That happened because the foreign minister was clearly rolled in cabinet by the Nationals, who were trying to loosen the backpacker visa to introduce an agriculture visa by the back door. This undermines the Pacific Labour Scheme and is having a really negative impact in the region.

Just this month, the Morrison government has shown its mean spirit towards some of the world's poorest with its disappointingly modest contribution to the Sixth Replenishment Conference of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. While Australia pledged $242 million, that fell well short of the 15 to 20 per cent increase from other developed countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Canada and France. It should be noted that the government has so far contributed only half of the $220 million it pledged to the Global Fund 2017 to 2019 round. We'll be keeping a close eye on that.

In the area of defence, it is a pleasure to return to a policy area I'm familiar with, having worked as a principal policy adviser to the former member for Charlton, Greg Combet, when he was Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science in the Rudd-Gillard Labor governments. During that time I had the honour of contributing to Labor's defence industry policy, the establishment of the projects-of-concern process and the Mortimer procurement reforms, which were the most substantial reforms to defence procurement in a generation. Yet under this government with its revolving door of defence ministers we have seen more than a dozen critical Australian Defence Force capability acquisition projects running years behind schedule. These schedule blowouts across multibillion dollar projects could have a real impact on the ground for Defence Force personnel. The delays have been worsening this year, which indicates that the government is failing to manage defence capability acquisition projects effectively. In the three months from December 2018 the government allowed six defence projects, worth more than $6 billion, to be delayed for nearly a cumulative 10 years. That is a 10-year delay in only three months of project administration. In total, 14 major defence capability acquisition projects worth nearly $15 billion are running late by a cumulative total of 310 months, or 25 years. The revolving door of defence ministers under this Liberal government is clearly contributing to project blowouts.

In the six years since the Liberals came to office, defence ministers have conducted only three project-of-concern summits, despite defence policy stating that a ministerial summit should be held every six months. In fact, in news coming out of the Defence annual report, only this week, we've seen a $570 million blowout in Defence's sustainment budget in only one year, and it's clearly related to the fact that project delays are leading to the ADF being forced to run existing equipment longer and harder than they planned for. We also saw a $3.7 billion typo in the Defence budget, where they had part of the Future Submarine project in the wrong column. That's a very significant typo and yet again reinforces the fact that this government simply cannot be trusted to administer such an important portfolio as Defence. In parliament last month the Minister for Defence Industry, Melissa Price, said:
As the Minister for Defence Industry, my priorities are clear: defence capability is built on time, on budget and on spec.
She is clearly failing the test set by herself.

On the issue of climate change, I continue to work with the shadow minister, the member for Hindmarsh, in this important policy area, and this week I seconded his private member's motion calling on this government to declare a climate emergency. This is not empty tokenism or alarmist politics, as those on the other side might suggest. Climate change is a significant threat to our economy, our natural environment, our farming communities and our national security. Australia's emissions have been rising every year under this government and are projected to continue to rise. Australia must take serious action to meet our commitments under the Paris treaty, and yet all this government is interested in is fudging the numbers, using dodgy accounting tricks with our Kyoto carryover credits to make it appear we are actually doing something. Well, the Australian people know better. The hundreds of thousands who marched—

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Mr CONROY: As I was saying, climate change is a significant threat to our economy, our natural environment, our farming communities and our national security. Australia's emissions have been rising every year under this government and are projected to continue to rise. Australia must take serious action to meet our commitments under the Paris treaty, yet all this government is interested in is fudging the numbers. The Australian people know better. The hundreds of thousands who have marched and signed petitions know better. But this government maintains this inadequate target—a target that, despite its inadequacy, they still won't reach. Combating climate change is one of the great challenges of our time, but it's also one of the most important, and I will continue to call on the Morrison government to take stronger action on climate change.

I want to take this opportunity to update the House on issues about which my constituents come to me for assistance. Unfortunately, many of them have not changed over the past six years I've been a representative at this place. At the top of the list are Centrelink, telephone scams, the NDIS and aged care. Unfortunately, one of the main complaints I still continue to receive from constituents relates to Centrelink and particularly to waiting times—both waiting endlessly on hold on the phone to speak to someone and also waiting for applications to be processed. It's no wonder the government has changed the title of the minister responsible for Centrelink from Minister for Human Services to Minister for Government Services; the people I represent who rely on Centrelink certainly wouldn't identify humanity as being an objective they'd use to describe their experiences with Centrelink.

This is not a criticism of the professional, hardworking staff who are employed at Centrelink. My criticism is aimed directly at the government for slashing and burning this vital public service. One of my constituents waited over 180 days for her application for the pension to be processed. This should be taken in the context of the average application taking 49 days to be approved, which in itself is absolutely appalling.

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Mr CONROY: As I was discussing, one of my constituents had their pension application take over six months, which is over three times as long as it should take. This is, of course, not surprising from a Prime Minister who has told senior Australians who have worked all their lives, paid their taxes and played by the rules that they should not rely on the age pension because it is a welfare entitlement. What disgusting contempt from the man who holds the highest office in the land. Judy, who had to wait the 180 days for her pension, had to stop working because of illness when she was 60. While she was waiting for the pension to be processed she had to use nearly all of her bank savings. Judy said, 'It shouldn't be this hard for people who are honest and have worked all their lives,' and I agree with her.

It is not just elderly Australians that this government treats with such contempt. Another constituent waited over 200 days to have his youth allowance application processed. He applied in January this year and the application wasn't processed until August—well into semester 2 of the university year.

The government has also shown its disregard for people on Newstart, who are also left waiting and are forced to use their meagre savings before they can access the payment. Despite a chorus of calls from many segments of our society, including, ironically, former Prime Minister Howard, and the member for New England, the government will not raise the Newstart allowance, despite it being a lowly $40 a day. I am yet to hear anyone credibly say that they can survive on $40 a day, let alone equip themselves with everything needed to find work.

Another major issue in my office is telephone scams. More than one in five people I represent are over the age of 65. This age group is particularly vulnerable to scams and are harassed the most by them. There are tangible ways the government could be acting on this increasing problem, yet they continue to drag their heels on what is a daily nuisance for many of my constituents. I note that the communications minister has very recently issued a formal directive to the Australian Communications and Media Authority that from April next year all telecommunications companies must use a two-factor authentication process when transferring mobile phone numbers from one provider to another, and that is a welcome decision. But, considering Telstra, Optus and Vodafone already use this authentication process, this directive is a drop in the ocean compared to what is needed to combat telephone scams in this country. Around the world governments are trying out different systems and technologies to stop the scammers. In the United States, the United Kingdom and New Zealand tackling scammers is a priority. But in Australia we are still waiting for a report from ACMA as part of the scant technology project it has led since 2017. This report must be delivered two years after it was initiated and must lay out a plan to deliver real protections and noticeable improvements for the elderly and vulnerable people who are being harassed in their homes every day.

The NDIS is another issue on which my office is regularly asked for help. I'm proud to be a representative of the Hunter and Central Coast regions. The Hunter was one of the trial sites for the NDIS, so my constituents who participated in the NDIS trial have been involved in the system for six years now. Feedback I too often receive is that one of the fundamental flaws of the scheme is that it relies too much on the advocacy skills of a participant or their family to navigate the system and address issues when they arise. This should not be the case. The NDIS is helping some of the most vulnerable Australians, and participants should not have to rely on family and friends or the office of their member of parliament when they face a hurdle with their plan. The scheme should be much more streamlined and user-friendly. It is shameful that the government have underspent on the NDIS to the tune of $1.6 billion and then tried to hide behind the excuse that the scheme is demand-driven. They are stomping down on the demand through their cuts and mismanagement.

It is shameful that they have not fully staffed the National Disability Insurance Agency. By their own actions this month the Liberals finally admitted the rigid staffing cap they imposed on the NDIA in 2014 has been hurting people living with disability and depriving them of much needed goods and services. While Labor welcomes the lifting of the cap by 800 employees to 4,000, this is still a long way short. The NDIA originally estimated that staffing levels would be 10,595 by 2018-19, more than double what has actually been achieved. To add insult to injury, the bill to the taxpayers for consultants and contractors has ballooned from $70 million in 2016 to $430 million in 2018.

All MPs know that people seeking help under the NDIS wait too long for their plan, too long for reviews and too long to access support. They find the agency and the online portal very difficult to negotiate. They find it hard to understand why their plans are cut and impossible to find a person to talk to. Once again, it should not be this hard. The government should fully fund the scheme, fully staff the agency and deliver people the support they have been promised and the supports they need. Sadly, when the mission of the NDIS moved covertly from choice and control of the participant to what is deemed reasonable and necessary by the planner, a fundamental change occurred in the NDIS that has been very detrimental. The NDIS as a contract is about who we are as a people. Australians are fundamentally decent and generous and believe that people living with disability should live their best lives. It is not good enough that they struggle as they do.

Another issue that is raised frequently by my constituents is access to aged care—in particular, home care packages. Some of the stories of neglect and abuse in residential aged care emerging from the royal commission are truly shocking. It's just as alarming to realise that 120,000 older Australians are waiting for care at home—some up to two years—and that 16,000 have very sadly died while waiting for these home care packages. I have written to the royal commissioners asking them to hold a hearing in the Hunter, which would service the large population base of Newcastle, the Hunter Valley, Lake Macquarie and Port Stephens and allow relatively easy access for those on the Central Coast and Mid North Coast, all of which have large aged and retirement populations.

Our older Australians deserve quality care. They must be treated with dignity, and the concerns of their families and loved ones must be taken seriously. It seems older Australians are the unfortunate target of many of this government's failings. Those who have managed to put away some meagre savings for retirement are punished by a government which refuses to lower the Centrelink deeming rate, even as the Reserve Bank cuts and cuts interest rates and then cuts them again.

Finally, I want to talk about the economy, because it is also an issue that my constituents raise with me. Economic growth is at its slowest since the global financial crisis, wages are stagnant, almost two million Australians are looking for work or for more work, productivity is going backwards and living standards are going backwards. Collapsing confidence and weak growth are the economic consequences of a government with no plan. This government could raise Newstart, because we know that recipients of Newstart would inject money into the economy. This government could bring forward infrastructure spending, as suggested by the Reserve Bank, by Labor and by many other voices in the community. Unfortunately, in contrast, in five budgets the Morrison government have underspent on infrastructure by more than $5 billion. They talk up the infrastructure plan, but it's off in the never-never.

In conclusion, Australians are doing it tough, and this government has no plan. It will not even acknowledge there is a problem nor even debate it in the House. It has no plan to deal with low wages and rising prices. The cost of essentials is skyrocketing. Electricity prices are increasing. The cost of child care has become unaffordable under the Liberals. Australians are worried about the economy, but Scott Morrison and the Liberals are pretending there is no problem. Labor will continue to hold the government to account on important matters like the economy and their failure on climate change. The people of Australia expect no less from Labor and the people of Shortland expect no less from me as their representative.

I finish where I began—to acknowledge that I'm honoured and privileged to be the fourth representative of the people of Shortland, following in the footsteps of Charlie Griffiths, Peter Morris and Jill Hall and in the footsteps of Greg Combet in Charlton. It is an honour and privilege that I'm forever grateful for, and I recommit myself to the service of the people of Shortland, Lake Macquarie and the Central Coast.

Dr McVEIGH (Groom) (11:42): It is an honour to rise for the address-in-reply to the Governor-General's opening of the 46th Parliament. I certainly congratulate, at the outset, the Speaker and deputy speakers on their appointments. I'm humbled to be appointed a member of the Speaker's panel alongside you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am especially honoured to have been returned as the member for Groom.

We had a significant win for the LNP in Groom. We saw a swing of 5.17 per cent to us, leading to a 70.48 per cent two-party preferred result. I humbly acknowledge this is the highest Liberal result in the country. But let's be very clear: whilst my team and I worked very hard during the campaign and are so very proud of that result, it is due to the efforts of party members and volunteers right across the electorate. It's based on policies that suited our electorate: a focus on infrastructure, tax relief, world-class health and education services, and support for families and small business. This is about a government getting on with the job of getting behind our community so that it can deal with its challenges and pursue its ambitions.

The Toowoomba and Darling Downs region, which makes up the electorate of Groom, is where I'm from. From the Jondaryan farm of my early childhood, starting school at Jondaryan State School; living with my family at Centenary Heights, where I attended St Thomas More's and St Joseph's; and then Highfields, where I finished school at Downlands, I left school and home to strike out and study at what is now the University of Southern Queensland. There was football and soccer at school, volunteering in various activities around our city, school and parish roles and sporting club activities with my wife and family. I was a foundation sponsor of the Armitage Centre at the Empire Theatre, there were Rotary and board roles at the Chamber of Commerce, Condamine Alliance natural resource management body, the Toowoomba Catholic education board and Concannon College at USQ. This region is where my wife has taught. It's where we established our agribusiness practice, prior to politics, and it's where we decided to return to raise our family, having worked across the country earlier in our marriage.

I believe that an election is a test of whether a candidate knows and understands their electorate. I'm confident my team and I know Groom, and, more so, I'm confident in our abilities and networks to update that appreciation quite regularly. Of course, many opponents right across the board have argued, still do and no doubt will continue to argue that I and the LNP don't understand or represent our region. I respect that they have a right to their views, and I certainly take on critique and feedback regularly, but the election result shows that we were clearly in line with the concerns and aspirations of the region. I therefore thank the Liberal National Party, the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and, most especially, the many party members, volunteers and supporters led by Peter Wilson and John Martlew. Whilst we had so many working on roadsides, functions and polling booths, I'd like to especially mention Boyd Scheuber who, yet again, tirelessly led our prepoll teams for over three weeks, and the many others who simply came out to support my wife, Anita, our family and myself.

I'm proud to have played a role in flood mitigation in our city following the devastating events of early 2011. From the upgraded East Creek and West Creek junction in our CBD, the inner-city ring road through to the impending East Creek and West Creek upgrades on James Street at the corner of Kitchener Street and adjacent to our PCYC, it's been important to work alongside state colleagues and the Toowoomba Regional Council. The Toowoomba Second Range Crossing was opened only a matter of weeks ago by the Deputy Prime Minister. It's the largest inland road project in the country, and is certainly one that many stakeholders had a hand in. Ultimately, its funding and agreement to proceed were confirmed by the state LNP and federal coalition governments. Warrego Highway upgrades west to Oakey and beyond and numerous bridge upgrades across the Darling Downs are amongst our other achievements. Others include the first PFAS settlement in the nation between the Commonwealth and a landholder, in Oakey; a new LifeFlight helicopter base in Toowoomba servicing southern inland Queensland and, certainly, into northern inland New South Wales as well; the new RSPCA animal shelter under construction at Wellcamp and funding for renovation of the Soldiers Memorial Hall. I'm proud to note that project is now underway with the Toowoomba Regional Council, because the hall is an important facility to mark those who have protected our country and fought for us in so many campaigns. Significant upgrades are underway at the Beaurabe Living aged-care home in Pittsworth, a very significant facility on the central Darling Downs. I'm pleased that we were able to secure funding for the $15 million feasibility study on passenger rail from Toowoomba to Brisbane in last year's budget. There are also numerous other local projects supporting our school communities, sporting clubs and community organisations across the Toowoomba, Pittsworth, Oakey and Highfields districts.

We continue to deal with significant issues in the electorate. The PFAS contamination at Oakey, at the Army aviation base, is similar to that being considered by Defence right around the country. It's something that we've made some progress on with mitigation, and, as I said, there was the first Commonwealth settlement with a landholder in the country. But there's more work to be done to restore the confidence of the Oakey community. Inland Rail, tracking its way across the Darling Downs—in the planning stages—from Melbourne to Brisbane, has both significant and enormous potential benefits that will flow on to our community and across the eastern seaboard. Most importantly for me, at present there is the need for appropriate consideration of potentially affected landholders, who cannot be left to bear the costs of this magnificent project which promises benefits to the nation at large.

We were at an early rollout site for both the NDIS and NBN and, as members in this House recognise, there have been challenges, particularly in regional Australia, with both, but we're making significant progress. I'm pleased with that progress and I acknowledge the efforts of our current ministers under the leadership of the Prime Minister in that regard.

I mentioned passenger rail from Toowoomba to Brisbane. I'm pleased that the Minister for Population, Cities and Urban Infrastructure, Minister Tudge, visited us recently in Toowoomba to consider that as part of the broader South-East Queensland City Deal project, acknowledging, the significance of fast rail connections to the Sunshine Coast and Gold Coast as priorities, quite obviously.

I note that issues we've had to deal with in our electorate include scaremongering about energy. Many said that this was a climate change election. Well, across the Darling Downs we have an amazing array of solar, wind, bio energy and pumped hydro projects either underway or being developed, complementing our traditional coal and gas based energy sources such that those renewable sources are quickly reaching the stage where they will generate more than the traditional sources. If it was a climate change election, the people in Groom voted on that basis. We want to get on with the balanced energy future based on reliability and affordability and the enormous local industry and job creation potential it has for us as we do transition to a lower-emissions future, and that is what we are doing in the Toowoomba and Darling Downs region.

During the election, as was the case in the last, we saw lies from those opposite about health and education funding across Groom. They were simply not true, with every school in the electorate seeing increased federal funding at the same time as unprecedented health funding across the Darling Downs Hospital and Health Service. Of course, I'm very proud of the private services such as St Vincents Hospital and St Andrews Hospital that complement those services.

We've also in Toowoomba considered many contentious social issues in recent years. I have focused on faithfully representing the views of my electorate, based on as thorough consultation as is possible, which is, as per the oath that I took when I was sworn into this place, my duty and that's what I'll continue to do. We have commitments to road works on the New England and Warrego highways. Money has been allocated. We need to urge progress from the state government to get on with the job, and I'm pleased that the Deputy Prime Minister has focused on that. I mentioned earlier that we need further progress with remediation and the management program around PFAS and around the Oakey community and, therefore, further certainty for landholders. We need to consider the interplay between inland rail, a freight project and passenger rail from Toowoomba to Brisbane, and I formally met with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister Tudge about that just yesterday. We need to continue efforts to find a permanent home for the Milne Bay military museum, and I am proud to work alongside the mayor in doing that. We have more work to do on the Highfields connection road and the Quarry Gardens project, alongside other community representatives.

We have plenty more challenges to face as a community into the future. Most important at present is drought, but there are also homelessness, domestic violence and flat sectors in our economy, such as the retail sector. I'm pleased that since the election we've had numerous high-level visits to the electorate. Minister Bridget McKenzie, as Australia's first female Minister for Agriculture, made her first dedicated electorate visit to the electorate of Groom. I was pleased to receive her and talk about our beef industry in particular. There was also Minister Mark Coulton visit to look at regional services, mobile black spots in the northern part of the electorate and the official opening of the southern Queensland Rural Health training facility in Toowoomba supported by the University of Southern Queensland, the University of Queensland and Darling Downs Health. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg is looking at our infrastructure projects, ag-tech industry potential, small business and certainly banking—particularly Heritage Bank, Australia's largest customer-owned banking organisation, based in Toowoomba. Minister Angus Taylor has an energy perspective, looking at our industry development potential. And Minister Alan Tudge is looking at the South-East Queensland City Deal and Olympics potential from Toowoomba along with the rest of South-East Queensland and especially that passenger rail project.

The Deputy Prime Minister is probably our most regular visitor to Groom over recent years, and I was pleased he was there not so long ago to open the unprecedented Toowoomba Bypass, Australia's largest inland road project, at $1.6 billion, 80 per cent funded by the federal government and 20 per cent funded by the state government. Regarding drought, the Prime Minister was on the Darling Downs recently. He briefly caught up with us in Toowoomba. Just this week, on Monday, I had our mayor, Paul Antonio, and Toowoomba Regional Council CEO Brian Pidgeon, together with the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister, in the Prime Minister's office talking about long-term water supplies—domestic, agricultural and industrial—for Darling Downs and the Toowoomba region. I'm pleased I've got upcoming visits from Minister David Coleman, regarding our refugee program in Toowoomba, and Minister Stuart Robert, regarding NDIS, in the near future.

When visitors like that come to our region, I tell them about Toowoomba firsts. It is the home of the Southern Cross windmill, iconic in our nation's history, and—although Ipswich debates this with us—the home of the lamington. The winner of the 2019 Prime Minister's Prize for Science, given for her contributions to pure mathematics, Emeritus Professor Cheryl Praeger—of the University of Western Australia nowadays—was born in Toowoomba. We are a source of cultural, scientific and industrial innovation.

We're Australia's largest private sector inland city. We are home to Australia's largest customer-owned banking organisation, as I said—Heritage Bank. We are home to the Royal Agricultural Society of Queensland, the first in Queensland, older than the Brisbane Ekka, for example. We have the highest concentration of feedlotting and meat processing in the nation. We have the Pulse Data Centre, the first tier-III large data centre in the country, being established by the local private FKG Group west of Toowoomba. We have the first greenfields development of an internationally capable airport in 40 years, the privately funded Wagners Wellcamp Airport, now linking us across the nation and internationally. Ultimately our diversified economy is our secret. We have one of the most productive agricultural regions in the country. We have a vibrant arts and tourism sector, professional services and retail, health and education facilities servicing southern inland Queensland and northern inland New South Wales, and our emerging ag tech and energy sectors certainly augur well for the future.

In this parliament I'm proud to be chair of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. Given it focuses so much on defence projects, that work certainly relates to Groom, in terms of our Cabarlah and Oakey bases. I'm also a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I chair the PFAS Subcommittee and sit on both the Defence and Trade Subcommittees, all of which are directly relevant to Groom.

I commit to work with the mayor; councillors; my state colleagues Pat Weir, Trevor Watts and David Janetzki; Oakey Chamber of Commerce; Pittsworth District Alliance; Highfields and District Business Connections Group; Toowoomba Chamber of Commerce; TSBE, our regional economic development organisation; our community groups; faith organisations; Indigenous Australians; non-Indigenous Australians; and new residents alike. I'll continue to work with those who work on community housing, domestic violence, small business, the environment, education and cultural pursuits, among so many others focused on our future. I'll do this with the ongoing tremendous assistance of our electorate office team of Leisa, Clare, Britt, Wendy and Colleen, all so ably led by Megan Brown, for whose efforts I am so very grateful.

I've formally represented our community at the local, state and now federal levels of government over the last decade or more and, as I mentioned, informally through many community and business groups prior to that. I've only been able to do that with my wife, Anita, by my side throughout, as she juggles her own busy career and our family. She is simply my greatest blessing in life. All the while I am surrounded by those I regard as my heroes and my angels: our son, Kevin, and our daughters, Bridget, Meghan, Annabelle, Marita and Tessa.

For many, parliament and politics is about fanfare, about drama, about sensationalism and simply the grab of the day. For me, it's not about being driven by Twitter and those commentators that come and go. It's about being considered, diligently going about the task of understanding the challenges and the ambitions of the people of Groom, and faithfully representing and advocating for them here in Canberra. Our election results show that we're on the right track. Challenges remain, but I know that it is all about the people of Groom. That is my continued commitment to the Groom electorate. For its families, its people, its workers, businesses and their aspirations and the challenges that they face, that is my continued commitment in this 46th Parliament.

Mr ROB MITCHELL (McEwen—Second Deputy Speaker) (12:00): Here we are just five months after the election and Australia is coming to a complete standstill. It's a bit of a dim memory now, but many of us still recall the campaign of dirty tricks and lies built on fear instead of aspirations. And, clearly, in our electorate of McEwen, we saw the complete lack of a plan for the future that addresses the needs of our modern communities, because what we do have here is a government that has no plan for this country and no plan to deal with rampant economic insecurity. All the while our working families face lower wages, ever-increased costs of living and insecure work futures. But, instead of addressing these concerns, instead of providing policies that work for everyday Australians, what we see is a government formed in the image of its spin doctor Prime Minister—a Prime Minister who is slowly morphing from an ad man without substance to a tin-pot dictator hell-bent on secrecy and not being honest with the Australian people, a Prime Minister who stands in front of chaos with a plastered-on grin and says: 'Nothing to see here, folks. Nothing here to see.' That's what we've seen this country reduced to since the election.

If recent elections around the world have taught us anything, it's that the economy must work for everyone, not just the select few at the top. Our community is crying out for the growing inequality gap to be reduced. They want to see their pay packets at least match the rise in their daily expenses. Wages are the most stagnant they have been in our nation since the Second World War. Even the RBA, once thought of as the financial cop on the beat containing wage growth in the seventies and eighties, now says that the underlying problem for the Australian economy is the lack of income growth. The wage price index grew a miniscule 2.3 per cent last year, which the government actually tried to frame as a success after record low growth of 1.7 per cent in 2017. And, yet, in the decade and a half leading up to 2013, wage growth was an average of 3.5 per cent a year. That was until Tony Abbott and that well-known friend of the worker came to power.

It's no coincidence that comparatively the highest wage growth in this country is in my Labor-led state of Victoria. These are all, to some, just numbers on a spreadsheet until you think about the people that are attached to them: the struggling single mum on Newstart who sometimes has to work for a minimum wage at Woolies, the father of three who's behind on the mortgage repayment because he hasn't seen his income increase enough to keep up with everyday spending, the public health nurse who's working harder and harder but taking home comparatively less and less. No wonder the people think that the cards are stacked against them because, under this government, they are. This government is still adhering to the worn-out and disproven economic ideology that tax cuts for the richest people and the most profitable businesses will lead to better lives for workers. I've got news for this government, and so does every major economist in the country: after six years in power, wages haven't got any better and people are struggling more than ever. And the government has no plans to do anything about it.

The Libs and the Nats love to talk about their credentials on jobs and growth. You'd be forgiven for thinking that's the only thing they can talk about, yet our nation's unemployment rate hides in plain sight: there's booming unemployment in our workforce. As an example, to be counted as employed in Australia you need to only work one hour a week, and with between one and 26 hours per week you are counted as underemployed. It's not good enough that the government does not have a plan for us and our community. It's weak on jobs and weak on growth but hard on workers.

Another pressing issue for our community is the cost of living. Recently, the price of petrol in Victoria has gone through the roof, skyrocketing by some 40c a litre to $1.74 a litre. This sort of price rise impacts on the ever-narrowing household budget of everyone in the outer north of Melbourne. Add that increase to the interest rate cuts not being passed on by the big banks and the increasing cost of educating our kids, going to the doctor or simple things like switching on the heater in winter or the cooler in summer and there's a perfect storm of headache for the people in my community, who are watching jobs disappear daily.

People in McEwen make the long drive south in the morning for work and then the long drive north in the evening, hoping to make it home in time for dinner. The price of petrol only adds to their frustration about this government's lack of planning on infrastructure. There has been no major infrastructure spending in the northern part of Melbourne or in northern Victoria in the past six years. That is this government's legacy: making us less efficient as a whole while making us pay through the nose for the essentials of life.

The previous speaker, the member for Groom, spoke about health. This Liberal government has continued to ignore the growing need for health services in my electorate. Like so many electorates on the outskirts of major Australian cities and centres, we have an incredible number of youths and young families in the towns and communities of McEwen. The needs of young people have faced particular neglect from this government. Over 75 per cent of mental health problems occur before the age of 25. Mental health is an area we cannot afford to neglect as a nation. Young people in our community identified suicide prevention, support for drug addiction and help for mental illness as their top three priorities. We know that because we went and asked them what their priorities were. They did what many young people do. They stepped up, they identified an issue and they lobbied for action. That's why at the last election we campaigned strongly for a new headspace in Wallan. Young people are telling us what they need, and we should be listening. At the last two elections I've campaigned for the community of Sunbury to receive a dedicated children's health service in Sunbury, as local services are failing to keep up with the needs of this fast-growing urban area. A facility like this would fill the missing gaps and help take the pressure off local families. When your child is sick the last thing you want to be doing is travelling great distances just to get basic health services. You would think that there could be no room for disagreement on such crucial needs in growing communities. You could assume that this would be a great example of something where bipartisanship could happen, with commitments from both sides of politics guaranteeing confidence and security for these towns and neighbourhoods. You'd be wrong. Not only was there not a single dollar committed to any of these projects, there was nothing committed to McEwen at all, full stop.

Perhaps even more galling, even more of a thumbed nose to the north of Victoria, was the 'too little, too late' strategy of my opposition candidate, who, once there was zero obligation, zero responsibility and zero win for him, came out and endorsed the projects that we put forward. If that doesn't take the cake, I don't know what does.

Looking at infrastructure, the worst offender, the most egregious example of this government's thinking, is our infrastructure needs. Like much of the rest of the government's platform, its infrastructure policy is threadbare and is absolutely pork-barrel political. What else can explain why the state of Victoria, which contains 25 per cent of our population, has received less than eight per cent of federal funding for infrastructure under the failed Abbott and Turnbull governments and now this one?

Areas of regional Victoria, especially those like my electorate, are bursting at the seams with an influx of residents escaping unaffordable city house prices, but instead of being met with infrastructure ready for the future they are met with congested roads and paltry federal investment in public transport. Victoria has had and continues to get a dud deal from this failed Liberal-National government. Particularly urgent are projects such as the diamond interchange at the Hume Freeway, Watson Street upgrades and the Northern Highway duplication. Throughout the election, constituents reported to me that this was one of the key gripes they had with local infrastructure. Clearly, when you're getting traffic jams almost daily on a freeway something is wrong. We campaigned on this issue at the last election and we will continue to do so. Only last week, at the Wallan market, I launched a petition calling on the federal government and the state government to come to the table and fix this problem once and for all.

We need to have the interchange on the Hume. The federal government could do that today. They talk about a $100 billion pipeline of investment, but not one cent is being spent. We need Watson Street upgraded. We need the Northern Highway duplicated from the Hume Freeway through to Wallan to remove the traffic bank-up on the Hume Highway. We know what we need is for the federal government to join the Victorian government to get these things done.

Each and every year we get another Prime Minister roll through this failing government, and an ever revolving door of ministers of communication, and yet we are still dealing with the inept approach of this government to deliver a reliable and quality National Broadband Network, and their inept approach at addressing the serious risk to communities like mine during fire and other emergencies through funding the Black Spot Program. We shouldn't be surprised, and it doesn't make it any less galling, that the government has put more into its own pork-barrelling exercises, like it did in round three of the black spot funding, than actually going out and standing by its own criteria for rural and regional major transport hubs prone to natural disaster.

You will remember, Deputy Speaker, my electorate was impacted. Ninety per cent of the Black Saturday bushfires were in our electorate. Yet 1½ towers was all this government was prepared to do, while it went down to save the seat for the member of New England and put 28 towers in his electorate—an area that does not meet the government's own criteria. But that's what this government's become, something that just pork barrels its way through, in secret, to the Australian people and continues on its merry way without giving consideration for Australians and their families.

As with commitments on road, health and education, I would welcome the government matching Labor's commitment on mobile black spot funding. Across the Macedon Ranges Shire, Mitchell Shire and City of Whittlesea we have number of locations with poor and non-existent mobile communications, including those in Bullengarook, Gisborne South, High Camp, Mount Macedon and Woodstock. These are known and proven bushfire-prone areas. More than most they require this constant coverage for updates on conditions in essential fire alerts. Two million dollars is a very, very small investment to pay for coverage that could quite literally save lives. But with the summers getting longer and heatwaves getting hotter, they need to act now if we are to divert a possible crisis. The government, instead of pork-barrelling its own seats, should address genuine and serious safety concerns.

Of course, this is the same government that promised every single Australian home would be connected to the NBN by the end of 2016, but here we are 2½ years past that and over 1.6 million homes still do not have access to high-speed broadband. What are they saying to the elderly in the community who are left without phones because of the dodgy NBN? Or to small businesses, those whose story I raised just recently in this place, losing half of an income stream because of inept installation, blame games and obfuscation by a pathetic minister. This and so many other rollout problems is why Labor took such a considered, detailed NBN policy to the election. Solutions like having qualified technicians being made available to address problems at no cost to the household if a premise was identified as having an in-home wiring problem. This plan would have provided the option for technicians to conduct a health check on in-home equipment, such as modems, which would bring good benefits to the consumers—things that would actually make a difference, a practical difference, to people's lives in this digital age.

What are they saying about the countless mobile phone black spots in McEwen that mean we don't have access to basic needs and emergency services? Absolute silence. I'm sick of the promises time and time again being delayed and changed, jeopardising small businesses and impacting daily lives of people in our towns and communities.

We have communities that are still unable to access the services they previously relied on because of a promised NBN that they haven't seen and certainly can't use. If we look at Malcolm Turnbull I think his legacy to this parliament will be two things: chaos and destroying Australia's opportunity to have a proper, 21st century, modern, fast, reliable broadband. Of all of this, we sacrificed the plan of full fibre-to-the-premises NBN, which even now the government knows is not working. The fibre to the node doesn't work. Now they're going to fibre to the kerb. Just put your pride away for two minutes. Deliver it to the home. Do the right thing by Australian people, not yourselves.

The NDIS is another very important reform that was established by the Gillard Labor government. Its purpose was to give every Australian living with disability the chance to live a good, proper life. Trial schemes were launched in most states, including the state of Victoria, and were positively received. Then the coalition government came into power and, over the course of six years, what started out as teething issues has snowballed into a total mismanagement of the NDIS. Yesterday in parliament we saw the minister stand up and say: 'Nothing to see here. Everything's fine.' If it's so fine, why have we got staffing shortages? Why do we have people coming into our offices each and every day crying because they have to keep telling their stories over and over and over again because the people in charge change and because they can't get access to basic needs and services? It's done this because the government chose to hoodwink the Australian people with that empty promise, that absolute lie, that the budget was back in surplus. It did that at the expense of disabled people's dignity and lives, and it did that at the expense of the mental health of people who have family members with disability. I don't think you can get any lower than using people with disability as a pawn to try to pump up your budget surplus. I think that's appalling, and I think most people understand that and see that.

And what about the budget? The government stood up here before the election, each and every day, and the Treasurer and the Prime Minister said, 'The budget's back in black.' It isn't; it never was. Go back to 2013 and think about old 'Sloppy' Joe Hockey. He stood here, in May 2013, and said, 'We will deliver a surplus in our first year of government and each and every year after.' No-one thought that anyone could be any worse than Joe Hockey as Treasurer, but then along came the member for Cook and now we have the member—I don't remember what his seat name is, but he's the current Treasurer, Mr Frydenberg. None of those three treasurers—Liberal treasurers; proud liberal free marketeers—have delivered a surplus. Not one of them. We find out after the election that it didn't happen. Despite taking all that money away from disabled people, they still couldn't deliver a surplus—and yet the Nats have the audacity to say that Senator McKenzie couldn't deliver a party in a pub.

What we've seen from this government is absolute failure on delivery, absolute failure on honesty and absolute failure on truth. They sit here day in, day out and constantly remind us how bad they are with their secrecy and their untruths. I mean, we've seen Senate estimates turned into a joke. We can't get questions on health answered. We can't get questions on NDIS answered. We can't get questions on security answered. All these things combined together have made Australia a worse place than it was before the election.

The mismanagement is creating bottlenecks in public hospital beds, with people who should be out of hospital straining our public health system because they can't get the support they need. This is an inefficient use of a government. Stressed-out doctors and nurses should be focusing their energy on pressing cases, not worrying about whether someone has support when they get home. You should always value a society by how it treats the most vulnerable. Clearly, what we have opposite are people who do not have respect for people who are vulnerable, do not have respect for people doing it tough. 'If you have a go, you'll get a go' was the mantra. What we've seen day in, day out from this government is people who are having a go, who are trying their guts out and who are getting stomped on by a government that has no interest in their future.

I'm proud to stand up here and fight for the people of McEwen and for the services that are so important to them. I do not take lightly the responsibility, the honour and the opportunity given to me, once again, to be a strong voice for them in parliament. This Liberal-National failure of a government keeps looking for ways to cut, but the cost they are willing to pay is to come off the backs of working communities. It's achieved through the slashing of services, through gutting vital agencies just for the appearance of a surplus. What they never ever acknowledge are the true impacts. They refuse to see that these numbers translate into people; they refuse to see the pain that's felt by every single Australian. Labor will not stop putting those people at the centre of everything we do and the values that we have. That was our election promise. It's the bedrock of the values of the Labor Party, and it's something that I and my colleagues stand firmly behind.

The government may have hoodwinked Australians into voting for them at the last election through campaigns of lies and smears from people like Clive Palmer, but the Australian people woke up very quickly after the election to realise that this is a show bag government: it's very expensive, it costs you a lot and when you get home you find it is full of nothing but rubbish and crap. We will continue to keep fighting to stand up to get the benefits our communities need and to make sure that we look after the people who need our support the most. That is what we are here for.

Mr HOGAN (Page—Deputy Speaker) (12:20): Madam Deputy Speaker Bird, there are 151 of us in the House of Representatives, and I know you would agree that we are all very humbled that we have the great honour and privilege of representing our communities in this place, and the job that we do is very important. We represent our communities and advocate for things that our communities want and need. Also, as members of political parties in government or opposition, we set the direction, the agenda and the focus that we need as a country to maintain the wonderful tradition that we are following. A lot of people, even Australians, like to run us down, but we are one of the freest, most prosperous countries in the world. That is because of the people that have come before us, people in this building that have set great parameters and great focuses for the lives of ordinary and normal Australians to get on with their job and, as we say, for those that have a go to get a go. It is very important that we set rules around the fact that, if people are out there trying to do the best they can in this country, they get rewarded.

Firstly I want to thank my community of Page, which is on the north coast of New South Wales. Madam Deputy Speaker, you probably think this of your electorate, but mine is the most beautiful part of this country. It takes in the northern beaches of Coffs Harbour; goes into the Clarence Valley, with Yamba, Iluka, Grafton; up to the Richmond Valley, with Casino, Evans Head; into the Ballina shire, with Alstonville and Wollongbar; Lismore and all its villages; over to Kyogle; and up to Woodenbong on the border. It is a very beautiful part of the world and a very productive part of the world as well. We have a great exporting section of our community. We have wonderful industries like beef, dairy, blueberries, macadamias and much more. We have a great university as well.

I want to thank my community. At the recent election, I had a swing of over seven per cent towards me, and the margin in Page went from 2.3 to 9½ per cent. I'm very grateful to the community for again, for the third time, bestowing their faith and trust in me. It's not a job I take lightly.
