It's a job that I do very seriously and I'm very grateful every day that I wake up that I have the honour to represent our community. I want to talk about some of the things I'm going to be looking to do and to deliver over the next three years in this term of government, or things that have been completed in the last term of government.

When I'm out and about in the community that I live in, people always talk to me about jobs. They want job security. They want job opportunities for their children so that, if they don't wish to leave the area when they finish school, they have as many job opportunities as they can. Since being elected in 2013, this government has created 1.4 million jobs across the country, which has been a great achievement. In my electorate we're co-investing with Norco dairy co-operative in a $30 million upgrade of their ice-cream factory in Lismore, which I'm very excited about. Over 200 dairy farmers supply milk to Norco. They employ hundreds upon hundreds of people in the processing plant. This is a really important upgrade of their ice-cream factory and will secure demand for milk from the dairy farmers and provide job security for all the people that work in the processing plant.

We're looking to invest nearly $5 million in Lismore Airport for a new ILS. Again, all these things are job focused. Lismore City Council will be looking to bring in pilot training schools, and a lot of other things will be able to be operated from the airport. Negotiations are already in train for the industrial estate around the airport— more job-creating activity.

We have done a lot of sporting upgrades too. A lot of people say, 'Oh, sporting upgrades,' but I don't think some people appreciate the importance of that type of infrastructure in towns. Not only is it obviously good for our local kids, local adults and all of us who might play different sports around the place; it's important economically because you can attract state and, indeed, international types of activities to your town and to your region when you upgrade these facilities. We have many in many centres around my region and, when you're having a big carnival or a big activity like that, all the motels are full, the restaurants are full, the cafes are full during the day and the evening when those things are on, which is an important economic driver as well—one that I'm very much looking forward to with the state government.

Over the next three years, we are going to be doing a $14 million upgrade of the Oakes-Crozier facility set up in Lismore. Nearly all sports are played there. They'll be playing cricket there along with rugby, league, soccer and Aussie rules as well. So it is going to be a great upgrade of that wonderful facility in Lismore. As I said, we're expecting that that will be creating an additional 20,000 tourists to our city every year, bringing extra millions of dollars to our local economy. To add to that: we've also already done some significant upgrades with sporting resources in Lismore. Lismore has produced some amazing baseballers over many decades. It is a very popular sport in our town, and we did a multimillion-dollar upgrade of that and already have attracted significant tournaments and carnivals because of that. We also updated the Far North Coast Hockey centre and since then have had three to four national tournaments. We had a seniors tournament there and then recently we had an under-21s tournament. It was great to see some of our local kids—anyone under 30 I call a kid!—play in the under-21s tournament in our local town. Again, all the restaurants and everything were full for the two weeks they were on.

Some of the exciting things happening in Casino—again, job-focused—include me giving a grant to the meatworks there. They want to upgrade. I don't know if anyone is aware of this even in our region, but the importance of the meatworks is that they employ 1,200 people. If you are employing 1,200 people as a private-sector business, you are a significant business everywhere. They're very important not just to Casino but to the wider region. We have given them a grant to help with a new stripper, which is going to increase their productivity.

Across the road, which obviously complements that business, we have invested again with the state government. We went halves. We invested $14 million in the saleyards there, which means it has one of the best, if not the best, cattle saleyards across the country across the road. Again, it's important because it's a job-focused grant.

The other thing I'm looking forward to there is that we have an application put in for a medicinal cannabis facility near Casino. We have given them a grant as well. When they go through the final approval through the Office of Drug Control, their plan is to employ over 200 full-time workers in that facility. It is a new business and new industry and is very exciting. I was very happy to help them out as well.

We also made a commitment to a tourist thing there—the Rail Trail—so from Murwillumbah to Casino there are some very exciting proposals. At the moment it's just covered by weeds, and we're looking to develop that into a tourism facility, which I think will be an exciting thing as well. Just recently I opened the drill hall there, which was a very important cultural and heritage thing in Casino which we've redeveloped with the council. This is an exciting thing happening in Casino. It has an amphitheatre and tourist information centre as well.

Kyogle is a wonderful part of the world. The local shire is a very beautiful area. They came to me a number of years ago with an infrastructure backlog of wooden bridges. They have over 300 of them, and it's a massive undertaking to repair them. A lot of them were built at the same time, so they're wearing out at the same time. Over the last number of years, we've been working together and have replaced many of them, and in the election campaign I made a commitment to keep fixing more of them as well.

This is very unusual: the federal government often gives money to aged-care providers by funding the cost of a bed in an aged-care facility—we'll give them the money to staff it and maintain the aged-care facility. We very rarely give money to a corporation or an organisation to build the aged-care facility. But the figures didn't quite add up for the aged-care provider in Kyogle to be able to provide that service unless we helped out. It was wonderful to help the Whiddon Group physically build and increase the aged-care facilities that they provide there.

A lot of other things have happened in Kyogle over recent years as well. There was $1 million for sealing the Toonumbar Dam Road and the Culmaran Creek Road. We've also given them some extra money to help seal the Clarence Way, which is an important link. And very exciting things are happening out around Tabulam. It has a very large blueberry industry burgeoning out there, and, again, it's supplying jobs in our region.

Recently, it was wonderful to commit over $6 million to Summerland House Farm. This is a disability service provider in Alstonville, in the Ballina local government area. This is all about providing employment opportunities to disability workers. Summerland House Farm has done great things in tourism—and not just in tourism but for locals to go out there and enjoy the farm as well. It has shops, cafes and the restaurant; it's a wonderful place to hang out and, very importantly, it provides jobs for our disability workers.

Going further south into the Clarence and Grafton: in case everyone has forgotten, they might want to come up in the next week or two as we've got the Grafton Jacaranda Festival, always a highlight of the year in Grafton. It was wonderful to commit to a $6½ million riverside precinct upgrade in Grafton. The Clarence River is seriously one of the most—no, not one of the most, it's the most—beautiful rivers in our country; it's picturesque. It's called 'the mighty Clarence' and we don't call it the mighty Clarence for nothing, because it's got a lot of power to it. It's physically beautiful and it's going to transform Grafton with what we're going to be able to do and how we're going to be able to enjoy the river. That plan has been in place for years, so it was wonderful to commit to do that with the Clarence Valley Council. I'm looking forward to that transforming the riverfront.

The enjoyment there will increase tourism; it will be a destination to come to to experience all that. It adds onto a commitment I made a number of years ago to a riverside precinct upgrade down the river a little way in Maclean. Stage 2 of that has been completed now, again, turning Maclean around to face the river and enjoy the beautiful Clarence that it is, and increasing visitor experience in our region.

This adds to the large commitment I made to the Harwood sugar mill in the last few years to increase their logistic capabilities and to improve their efficiencies, thereby improving and lowering their costs to maintain their competitiveness in the sugar industry. It was great to make that commitment of $4 million a number of years ago. The logistics have been improved. Again, why did we do that? Because we want to ensure the job security of people across the wider sugar industry, which is very important.

There are other amazing infrastructure programs in the Clarence Valley, and I won't go through them all because I'll run out of time. But the Pacific Highway goes through the Clarence Valley, and the Woolgoolga to Ballina section, which encompasses the length of Page, is happening right now. There are something like 3½ thousand workers working directly on that upgrade. We're doing that primarily to save lives—the fatalities on that highway are now at multidecade lows—but any fatality is a tragedy. Indeed, we had the 30th anniversary just last weekend of the disaster that was the Cowper bus tragedy, where over 20 people were killed on that section of the highway. That's why we're doing the duplication but, obviously, as an aside to that there is a lot of job creation activity happening there as well. The Harwood Bridge is almost complete; it cost $250 million itself. So that's been a great economic boost to the region as well.

I missed one—I'll just go back to the bitumen, in Casino. While talking about the riverside precinct upgrades at Grafton and Maclean, we also did one at Woodburn. At the moment people on the highway drive through Woodburn. Woodburn is going to be bypassed, so with the Richmond Valley Council we upgraded the Woodburn riverside precinct and it's absolutely beautiful. We want people to see it before the highway bypassed it, so Woodburn is going to become a destination in itself as well.

Down to the northern beaches of Coffs where, again, physically it's an absolutely beautiful part of our country, it's great because we're going to be opening a new surf club house there soon. The old one was, literally, nearly falling over. This $3.5 million new surf club house is about to open. It'll be a great facility for Woolgoolga and the northern beaches.

Also in the election I committed to building a whale trail, a walk where you can do whale watching. It's going to link the surf club right up to the headland. It's going to be a beautiful walk and great for tourism. We want people to keep visiting our beautiful region. The tourism industry is very important in the northern beaches of Coffs, and indeed my own area, because everyone wants to come for a holiday where we live. In fact, I holiday half an hour from where I live, because why would I want to go anywhere else? But that's another story. There are a lot of other upgrades as well, like Ken Leesen Oval in Iluka and many more, but I won't go through them all.

We're back to some people that I want to thank. Any one of us 150 people who are lucky enough to be in this chamber to represent our communities have had the opportunity, and requirement, to go through an election campaign. Some people would find them more enjoyable than others, but they're a very important part of what we do. We're all out in our communities every day and every week of the year. But certainly through election campaigns, it's more heightened and obviously people are much more tuned in to what we're doing. I had a wonderful team. There were 100 polling booths—it's just shy of that, but let's call it 100 polling booths—around Page, so I had hundreds of people, like we all did, out helping on election day. But, more importantly than that, through prepoll I had six prepoll booths which many people were manning for me, in some cases for over three weeks.

I also want to acknowledge a young team of helpers I had. They were an inspiration to me. They were a group of about 16- to 20-year-olds, some of whom had been with me for a couple of years. We doorknocked, basically, the electorate, and we rung the electorate twice as well. It was great for me. There was great feedback for me and it was great to be in tune with the community about what was important to the community and what people were looking at. I want to name some of these people because of the contribution they made. I want to acknowledge: Jay Gibson on my staff, who led the team with Dave Smith; Eli Coleman; Matt Marchant; Brendan Pearce; Noah Coleman—congratulations too, on your two goals in the grand final; Sarah Venn; Dylan Butcher; Ruby Dardengo; Jed Lisetto; Oscar Stahl; Cooper Manning; Mark Sollom; Maya Layton; Max Condon-Hunisett; Lee Pagotto; Sophie Thompson; Brylea Linch; Elise Hatchman; Nick Albertini; and Emily Adams. I really want to thank that team. They were crucial for me. They were a great support for me on prepoll and, as I said, for the two years approaching that time as well. I have here many names of people who helped out on prepoll and the election day, but I'm not going to read them out—and I can see the member for Bendigo being very grateful for that.

Lastly, but just as importantly, I want to thank my staff, some of whom have been with me for the six years I've been here: Peter Weekes, Jay Gibson, Mark Highfield, Samantha Elley, Sheree Barnsley and Jason Thompson and their families. When you work in an office like an electorate office or for an MP, as you would know, Madam Deputy Speaker Bird, everyone's families are involved in the operation. I want to thank all of them, who make great sacrifices and were very supportive of me.

Lastly, I want to thank my family. I've heard it said a number of times and it's very true, when they call us, the MPs, the volunteers. We volunteer for these roles, and our families are the conscripts; they come with us whether they have chosen to or not. I have the best team of conscripts you could ever wish to have. To my children, Bridget, Sean and Rosie—we have been on this journey together with me in this role for six years now. They've been a wonderful support to me. I'm very proud of them. They come out and do what they do, and just by the very fact they are the people they are helps me in this role, because they're good kids. They're good young people, and I'm proud of them. My wife, Karen, has been on this journey too. She is by my side literally every day, especially on weekends. Physically, we do a lot in this role together. I couldn't do without her, and I thank her very much.

Ms CHESTERS (Bendigo) (12:39): I thank very much the whips on the Labor team and the speakers whom I've jumped ahead of for allowing me to give my address-in-reply today. This is my last week in parliament before I go on maternity leave, so I do thank them for being generous in allowing me to leap ahead.

I want to start with the election itself and I want to acknowledge all of the great supporters that we have in the Bendigo electorate and the people who put in such an effort. Yes, there are 151 of us here, but we represent a very broad network of people who really believe in our democracy. Regardless of party, regardless of politics, there are the true believers in all of our parties—the party faithful who really help get behind us to support the ideas and values. The Bendigo electorate has some of the most active branches across the region, and I want to pay tribute to and thank all of the Bendigo Labor branches: Bendigo South, Bendigo, Castlemaine, Kyneton and Woodend.

I particularly want to give a shout-out to Pauline Brown, our president in Woodend, and Eric Dearricott and Marg Dearricott, our president and secretary in Kyneton. The Bendigo electorate is a large electorate, and they have consistently helped to run our show in the south, making sure that we have not just our polling booth staffed but our prepoll staffed and making sure that we are doing our doorknocking, our street stalls and our letterboxing.

I also want to acknowledge the great efforts of the Castlemaine branch and, in particular, Debbie Lawn. We have had three prepolls in our electorate this year, the first in Castlemaine, and we had probably the best result we've ever had at a prepolling station in Castlemaine. Every time I turned up, there were at least four of us there, and it wasn't until the last week that we actually had some opposition. So we felt pretty good about our coverage and the conversations that we were having with voters in Castlemaine.

In Bendigo, I want to give a particular shout-out to the many volunteers who helped staff the prepoll and on polling day and also did the phone calling and the doorknocking, as well as the letterboxing. I want to make particular mention of my campaign manager, Kate Sutherland. She is the office manager in our team and took time out to help run the campaign. These are the fantastic people in our office who really pulled it together to make sure that we had our strongest foot forward.

We had volunteers and the coordinators of our volunteers, and what I was really proud of was the fact that the people in Labor in Bendigo do it because they believe in it. They believe in Labor; they believe in our purpose. We have a strong campaign team and we've built a very strong brand in Bendigo Labor. I acknowledge our fabulous state MPs, Maree Edwards, Jacinta Allan and Mary-Anne Thomas, who are part of the campaign team as well. We do have a bit of a lock on the region, and, working closely together as a team, we work hard there to ensure that we're representing the community.

I want to make particular mention of my friend Michael Grimes, who passed away this morning. He has always been such a warrior and an advocate for the people of Maldon and for the Labor cause. Even though he was starting to get quite ill, he was still very active in the campaign. Joanna Casey, who is sick at the moment, has done our mobile booths in the south of the electorate for years. This time she took on a trainee, a mentee, because, as she said at the time, she didn't think she'd be around for the next election. I hope she holds on, but I know she is very unwell. I'd like to give her and her family my best wishes. These are real people in real communities who believe in something and make me very proud to be their elected representative and a Labor representative.

Unfortunately, though, when we turned up at a number of the polling booths on election day, not all the people there were volunteers. The Liberal Party had taken the unprecedented step of paying people to hand out how-to-vote cards. It was the first time we'd seen that in our area. Bendigo is a marginal seat; it's a swing electorate. In 2013, the margin dropped to 51 per cent. We just held on; it was a tough election. When you go from that election in 2013 to the election 2019, where the Liberal Party engaged a labour hire agency and paid people to hand out how-to-vote cards, you start to question whether people in our region support their values. And people don't. The results in Bendigo really reflect that.

They were not the only ones. We had a number of candidates who put their hand up at this election for the Clive Palmer party, the Pauline Hanson party or the Fraser Anning party. We had a number of candidates to the right of us who were all working closely together and, on election day, paying people to hand out how-to-vote cards. It's a step in our democracy that I think we should be worried about—that we pay people to hand out party material. It is less about the values, the ideas and that broader social movement and more about who has money. We saw that play out in a number of areas. Whilst parties are still doing their reviews and there is some work for the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to do, I believe that all Australians should be worried that individuals can spend $60 million on an election campaign to have an influence. Money entered this federal election campaign like no other, and it did have an influence.

I also believe we really need to focus on the role of social media and the impact that it is having on our politics, not just in election campaigns but all year round. Some call it fake news, some call it misinformation, but the problem is that, when a lie, or misleading information, is identified on Facebook, all they do is cop a complaint. They are not bound, and have not been bound, to take down that misleading information. If it were in a newspaper, in print, or on TV, there would be avenues for candidates and political parties to pursue that misleading information. Truth in advertising does occur in the mainstream media. There is a process. Sure, it could be strengthened, but there is a process. But the same does not exist for social media engines.

So I hope that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters really looks into the role of social media and the impact that misinformation, fake news, fake campaigning and, quite frankly, lies are having. That's not just the impact they have had on our side of politics but the impact on all sides of politics. We do not want to be a parliament that is elected because of the amount of money an individual or business interest may have. We need to be a parliament that is elected through a genuine debate of ideas, a contest of values, and people who get out there to do the grassroots campaigning and say, 'This is our vision and our plan for Australia.'

I'd like to really thank the people of Bendigo electorate. We ran a tough campaign and we worked hard. We are really proud of the network that we have in Bendigo, not just the Labor network but Labor supporters, our like-minded people. Thank you for returning me again to be your representative here in this parliament, for the third time and on an increased majority. We are at 59 per cent, which is a high-water mark for Labor in Bendigo, similar to the result that we got in 2010.

The reason why I raise that is not to crow but to talk about why it is we had a positive result. It is because we had a plan. Labor had a plan for Bendigo, and we were honest about that plan. We made commitments towards community infrastructure projects that people in the region really wanted to see: funding towards the airport terminal upgrade, to ensure that we could have more flights coming in and out of Bendigo; funding for the rail trail between Daylesford and Hanging Rock, a great tourism infrastructure project for the south; and funding to help Castlemaine District Community Health to find a new home, to build a new home, to ensure that they have a place in the new Castlemaine health and wellbeing precinct.

We committed funding to help our councils build footpaths, to fill the gaps that exist. Some may not realise it, but in areas like Bendigo, where you've got new estates and old estates, sometimes what's missing is the footpath between those new and old estates. The new estate only requires the developers to build the footpaths inside the new estate, so we made a commitment towards helping local councils build those missing links. Even though footpaths are not a federal issue, it's an area where I believe federal government can play a role to help partner with local government to deliver that vital community infrastructure. Just like we have Roads to Recovery and bridges to recovery, we could have paths to recovery, to encourage people to be out and active, riding to school, riding to work, pushing strollers. We need paths where older people can feel safe when they're walking. We need to make sure that we're helping our councils fill in those missing links. In regional communities and regional town centres, there are a lot of those missing links. It's always devastating when someone walks over to talk to you at a listening post, and they've got their high-vis vest on so that they're not hit by a car, because there is no path for them to walk on. That happens a lot in our electorate, because of the nature of the growth that we've had and the expansion of Bendigo and our towns.

I'm hoping that these are the projects that this government will adopt. Unfortunately, this was the first election where the Liberal-National party did not commit any money to Bendigo: no projects; not a dollar. No community infrastructure projects were prioritised, despite the lobbying and campaigning of our local councils, of our Bendigo business group, Be.Bendigo, and of a number of other stakeholders. The Liberal Party committed zero to the electorate. Yet our electorate has a similar make-up and a similar demographic—okay, we don't have the Great Ocean Road—to Corangamite, where they committed billions. So you can accuse them of pork-barrelling to save marginal seats and of deprioritising regional Victoria, where we need our fair share of funding as well. Not one dollar was committed to Bendigo, and now we are engaged in a campaign to, hopefully, see this government adopt the plan for the electorate that we put forward on behalf of the community. The government has a chance to do so in the MYEFO budget coming up. They have a chance to do so by committing to those vital community infrastructure projects that I have outlined.

There are also projects that I haven't yet outlined that should be considered. They include funding for the La Trobe University Rural Road Trauma Research Hub. We have a road trauma research hub at Monash University, but it focuses mainly on metro roads. The idea behind this is to focus on rural roads. We know that, particularly in Victoria, the death toll is higher—fatalities are higher—on our rural roads. La Trobe identified the need to establish a research hub to look into this issue and to look into safety, and I encourage the government and the education minister to pick up that project.

I also encourage them to fund the Macedon Ranges sports hub. To hear that money is going to other electorates— and the government understands the importance of these centralised precincts—is a bit frustrating, because this project has been on the books for a while. It will support not just sports in my electorate of Bendigo but also many clubs and sports in the McEwen electorate. It will actually be based in the McEwen electorate. McEwen and Bendigo share the Macedon Ranges. We know the government, through questions in question time, understands the importance of these hubs. It would be great to see the funding flow to all regions that require it.

I guess that leads me to the groundhog day experience of being back in parliament and back in opposition. So much of what we've seen already since this government was re-elected is same old, same old: old policies, old legislation and old bills that they tried to get through after the 2014 budget just keep coming up. It's like they've run out of ideas already, and we're only in the beginning of the term. The attacks on pensioners continue. Today, we're seeing more legislation that will cut pensioners' incomes, particularly for pensioners who may wish to travel overseas to see family—kicking them off the pension if they're overseas for more than six weeks. It's just unfair. These are people who have worked hard in Australia their whole lives. The government is targeting a demographic of our community who have moved here, established their lives here and worked hard here. These people may, in their twilight years, wish to travel to the country of their birth or to the country of their family, but are having to cut the trip short so that they're not kicked off the pension.

I guess it wouldn't be as concerning if we had decent investment in resources and the reversal of the funding cuts to Centrelink. Since they've been back, we've again seen this government attack people on Newstart, people who are looking for work. One in five people on Newstart are underemployed, meaning they can't get enough hours and so they rely on Newstart to subsidise their income. These aren't drug addicts or dole bludgers or any other name that the government wishes to throw at them; these are people who are working and who simply can't get enough hours in their industry. And that is growing: we have 1.9 million underemployed Australians in this country. It's the highest it has ever been, yet there is no plan from this government to fix that crisis of underemployment.

One in four people on Newstart are over the age of 55. If the government were serious about supporting people on Newstart, they'd meet with them and learn their stories; they'd meet people who had been employed full-time but, because of shutdowns in manufacturing or losing their jobs, haven't been able to find secure employment since. They'd meet people who were working in a profession that they physically could no longer do. I've met nurses, I've met construction workers, I've met cleaners who, after they reach the age of 55 or 60, might incur an injury and they can no longer continue in their occupation. Many have retrained and tried to get work in their new field, but the jobs don't exist. This government has done nothing to address the real issue of age discrimination when it comes to employment.

This government has done nothing to support young people looking for work. They continue to tout their Youth Jobs PaTH program, the exploitative $4-an-hour internship. There's the Work for the Dole program, which evidence and inquiry after inquiry have proven is not a pathway to genuine work. What they have not done is strike a compact with industry about how to rebuild those entry-level jobs. Instead, what we see is more legislation attacking young people, and we've seen that in their proposal to trial drug-testing of Newstart and youth allowance recipients. Instead of engaging with young people to learn about the barriers they face and why they're not in work, this government goes straight for the political attack. It demonstrates that this government is all about rhetoric and impression and not about substance and real reform.

There are some massive challenges in Australia right now and we don't have the government who can take them on. The statistics that came out last week—that is, the fact that one in six children are living in poverty—should be the alarm bell, the wake-up call the government needs to get on with genuine, real and lasting reform. In some of our communities, in regional areas like Bendigo and some of our suburbs, it's 50 per cent of the children. The report went into that level of detail. Yet there is no plan from this government; no commitment, no outrage, no inquiry, no crisis meeting to tackle that issue. We also had the startling statistic that one in four women go without food, go without at least one meal a week so as to feed their children, yet this government hasn't had any genuine conversations about how we're going to tackle food insecurity and other challenges.

I've mentioned the challenges with underemployment; we have problems with long-term unemployment. The economy is not fair and is not delivering for all. It's time we had a government that stopped with the rhetoric and started the reform that's required to ensure that all people in our communities get a decent and fair go. I hope that the next election comes around quickly and that it's going to be a fair contest of ideas and a fair contest on the agendas and platforms, and that it's not skewed by who has the most dollars and who can run the biggest fear campaign on social media.

Mr SNOWDON (Lingiari) (16:00): I'm pleased to be able to speak on the address-in-reply to the Governor-General's speech. At the outset, I want to congratulate His Excellency the Governor-General, David Hurley, and his wife, Linda, particularly for his appointment as the 27th Governor-General of this country. I've known both the Governor-General and Mrs Hurley for many years and can attest to what I think will be a very fine period of service by them for us in His Excellency's role as head of state. He goes to the job with a great deal of lived experience across the country and indeed having served our great nation in the Army.

I want to start off by acknowledging someone who passed away quite recently, Barbara Cummings. She was described in the NT News, quoting Selena Uibo, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Northern Territory, as 'a trailblazer for Aboriginal affairs in Australia and a powerful voice for our Stolen Generations'. I'm going to use, liberally, the words from the citation for the award of an honorary doctorate which Barbara Cummings received quite recently from the Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education, in which they chronicle for us some of the details of her life.

She was born in 1948 at the old Darwin Hospital at Myilly Point. She was separated from her mother at a very young age and was brought up at the infamous Retta Dixon Home. Her mother was herself a member of the stolen generations, being brought up in the Kahlin Compound. I want to speak about Barbara because I knew her quite well and she dedicated her life to service for her community and as an advocate for members of the stolen generations. She was, in all respects, a leader and, indeed, a national leader on these issues for people who were no longer young, but old, as she was, and for those who have passed as well; she was an advocate for those who were forcibly removed from their families. As the citation says, she made an outstanding contribution to the welfare of all people, especially the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory.

I won't go through her life story, other than to say that the citation highlights a number of contributions that Barbara made to the welfare of Aboriginal people, including as a founding member of the Karu Aboriginal and Islander child care agency, which recruited Aboriginal foster parents and reunited children with their families; a founding member of the Danila Dilba Health Service, which is a very vibrant and important organisation still operating in the Northern Territory; a founding member of the Juninga aged-care facility; and a founding member of LinkUp, reuniting families. She was deputy chair of the ATSIC Yilli Rreung Regional Council. Most significantly in the context of advocacy for members of the stolen generations, she was a convenor of the Going Home Conference in Darwin in 1994, which was a defining moment in terms of raising the issues around the stolen generations, which were subsequently given quite important national prominence.

She was a significant voice in the early establishment of the Secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care, SNAICC—National Voice for our Children. She wrote a book in 1990: Take this child: From Kahlin Compound to the Retta Dixon Children's Home. It is an important recognition of the issues that she was so, in a sense, bedevilled by but, most importantly, advocating for. She wanted people to actually see the impact of government policy on communities and families where children were forcibly taken away.

She was a leader in every sense. In this citation, toward the end it says: 'Barbara has been able to uncover, document and disseminate the historical facts and societal attitudes of those times and demonstrate its intergenerational impact. At the same time, Barbara has championed the critical importance of healing for all of the people who have been traumatised, hurt and damaged by those past policies and actions.' She was a very important person in the context of the Northern Territory and a leader in advocacy for the stolen generations. She was focused on getting kids back to country, including, where it was required, being buried on country—back to their home. She was focused, as her life story tells us, on the wellbeing of Indigenous kids. She fought to prevent kids from being removed from their kin.

To our undying shame, we have yet to compensate members of the stolen generation, and it's something which we ought to be contemplating. I know it was a policy which we—that is, the Labor Party—took to the last election. I invite the government to adopt that policy and to ensure that there is a compensation scheme for surviving members of the stolen generation, remembering that too many have passed in tragic circumstances.

I will now go to the election. I think it's important that we note this important thing because of the messages in the Governor-General's speech about 'his government's intention', as it's described, to address issues of importance to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In my electorate of Lingiari, over 42 per cent of my constituents are Aboriginal people, who live in very remote, isolated and disparate locations. You might know, Mr Deputy Speaker Zimmerman, that we had a couple of weeks of mobile polling to secure the rights of those people to have a vote and to exercise that vote in a formal way. There were 21 remote polling teams, who visited large and small communities, outstations and homelands. There were 16,000 votes picked up by those 21 mobile polling teams.

Significant from my perspective and the reason why it's important to note this is that over 75 per cent voted for me. In four of those mobile booths the ALP vote was over 90 per cent. And another 12 teams generated a vote of between 70 and 90 per cent.

That's important, and I acknowledge how important it is, but we need to know why people voted that way. They voted that way because they were very concerned about the direction of government policy and about the failure of the coalition government to address their needs not only in terms of service delivery but in needing better outcomes in infrastructure, for housing, and, most importantly, to address dysfunctional programs like CDP.

During the course of the election campaign, as you would probably expect, Mr Deputy Speaker Zimmerman, I visited many of these communities to talk about what we were proposing and how we would address their concerns. Principal among the concerns which were expressed right across the Northern Territory was the issue of CDP. Also, significantly in the context of the discussions which are currently taking place—and we've heard from the minister responsible, Minister Wyatt—they were concerned that their voice was not being heard. It was that sense of the abolition of ATSIC and that there was no way for those in regional parts of this country to articulate their concerns or to have a role in decision-making. That's really very important.

Whilst, for some, the idea of an event at Uluru which was of national significance was important, what was most important was that their voice be heard at a local and a regional level. And so it was very clear for us, advocating for support for the Uluru Statement from the Heart and discussing what participation in decision-making might look like, that coming from those discussions people wanted to be part of the decision-making process and wanted to be part of it at the local and regional levels. Their primary interest was making sure that their voices were understood and heard, bearing in mind the different contexts that operate right across this country. There is no uniform view, and there wouldn't be in any particular set of communities. But in regions, where it's possible to identify, people were very supportive of that approach. Indeed, they looked at us and said, 'What we would like is for you to mirror in some way the old ATSIC regional councils.' That was a really strong message which was given to me prior to the election campaign. It suited us, in a sense, because it fitted our policy position.

Then, of course, there is the CDP. I don't know of a more—well, I do know—this policy has failed miserably. It was the key issue across the whole of the Northern Territory, the idea that we get rid of the existing Community Development Program, because it really isn't a community development program—it is not—and come up with something different, prospectively built around what might have been the old CDEP, which most people in this place would have no knowledge of. It was the old Community Development Employment Program, which was introduced in the mid-1970s.

Just as a matter of interest, it was introduced because Aboriginal people in communities across the Northern Territory said: 'We're sick of sit-down money. We don't want it. We want to make decisions about how money coming into our communities is spent and how people are employed.' Then a conservative government took the brave decision, and I think it was the correct decision, in the first instance to send the entitlements of a number of communities—I think that Barunga and Beswick were in it, and maybe Wave Hill or Kalkarindji—in bulk and allow them to distribute it in terms of their priorities and work. Out of that evolved the CDEP program under which people were paid the equivalent of part-time wages for part-time work at an award rate, with the work being prioritised and determined by the local community. So what would have been unemployment benefits in those days was transferred to the community as a CDEP payment with a top up of about 10 per cent or 15 per cent, in the first instance, to allow capacity to invest in infrastructure and some capital. Significantly, across the north of Australia, where this was introduced the policy in most communities was no work, no pay. If you didn't turn up to work on Monday for whatever job you were designated to do, on the following pay week, on the Friday if that was payday, you didn't get paid for the Monday unless you had a reason that was backed by a doctor's certificate or some other appropriate reason that was agreed.

These are basic principles. They don't exist with the current CDP program. What the community has been telling us is: 'We want you to develop a program like that. It may not be exactly the same, but the principal should be. Allow us to be decision-makers about how money is spent in our communities.' For example, at a place like Galiwinku, in north-east Arnhem Land, there are probably around 800 potential participants on CDP. Currently about 300 turn up. So there's a massive gap, 500, who are getting no income support—none. That creates enormous pressure, as you would imagine, on those communities. They're not turning up, because they've been breached, because the employment provider, the program provider has breached them. They've not turned up. The money that they would otherwise have got goes back to somewhere, not to them.

What we would propose under the new CDP arrangement would be that that money would stay in the community and be used for things like wages top-up, which used to exist under the old CDEP. It would be an entirely rational thing to do. There was recently a survey. This government did a review of the work for the dole program: The many pathways of the Community Development Programme: summary report of community voices and stakeholder perspectives from eight communities. Thirty-six per cent of participants said their communities were worse off under the scheme. This is the government's own survey. Of the 1,100 survey participants, 21 per cent felt their community was better off since the Community Development Program was introduced and 36 per cent said they were worse off. There are about 35,000 CDP participants, and 83 per cent are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. As a condition of income support, remote area participants must engage in up to 20 hours of work for the dole five days a week. The review found that Aboriginal CDP participants were three times more likely to be penalised for nonattendance and were penalised more often.

This report found that social problems have increased since the introduction of CDP, including an increase in break-ins to steal food, predominantly by children and young people. We know that the stores have recorded a fall in income. The population is rising. People are being breached, so they're getting no income. They can't spend it in the store, so people are not being fed properly, so health becomes an outcome—bad health outcomes. This is all related to poor government policy and a policy that's been implemented badly.

We in this place have an opportunity. We've offered our hand across the chamber to work with the government in a bipartisan way on this and other issues. But, frankly, we need action. We need this program to be abolished, as the people who voted for me in such strong numbers wanted. I'm the voice for those people in this place. It needs to be heard. I don't stand here bashing my gums together because I just want to. I address the parliament in this case representing the solid views of those Aboriginal people across my electorate who have indicated what they desire, and the government just won't listen. Well, it's about time you did.

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (16:20): I'd like to use my time in the chamber today to talk about the local needs in my part of regional Australia, in the electorate of Mayo. I'd like to talk firstly about Aldinga, Port Willunga and Sellicks Beach, which are recent additions to our Mayo community, and it's been an absolute pleasure to represent them here in this place since the election. These communities are the fastest-growing parts of the City of Onkaparinga, and by a wide margin. Partially as a result, there are major infrastructure deficits in the area, including but not limited to the lack of a modern sporting complex.

The demand for an integrated sporting facility is both strong and growing. The current site is in need of major redevelopment and is the home of Aldinga Football Club, Aldinga Bay Bowling Club, Aldinga Bay Croquet Club, Aldinga Bay Hockey Club, Aldinga Soccer Club—go, the Sharks! That's what they're known as; see, it's great that they've got me as their member!—equestrian clubs, Aldinga Cricket Club and Aldinga Netball Club. An upgrade has the scope of attracting not only more men's teams but also women's and junior teams. The planned Aldinga superschool is adjacent to the sporting complex and would also benefit greatly from properly improved facilities.

I also want to take the opportunity to thank the local clubs for discussing their needs and plans with me. I will continue to advocate for much-needed federal funding to upgrade their community sporting facilities for the benefit of current and future generations of local residents in this fast-growing area. It's one of those challenges that we have, I think, right across Australia on the periphery, the edge, of metropolitan communities. We know that they are the fastest-growing communities in Australia and yet they're also the communities lacking the most infrastructure.

I'd like to talk about a very important issue in my electorate, and it's where we have the resting place for the HMAS Hobart. My electorate encompasses some of the most beautiful coastline in South Australia, and one particularly scenic overlook, over Yankalilla Bay between Normanville and Wirrina Cove, is also a place of significance for Australia's maritime naval history. Called the HMAS HobartLookout, this outcrop overlooks the final resting place of the naval destroyer the HMAS Hobart, which was scuttled in the bay in November 2002. The ship, nicknamed 'the Green Ghost' because of her reputation for stealth, is now a marine reserve and a popular ecotourism diving site.

Importantly, the lookout is a memorial to the HMAS Hobart and those who served on the ship during her distinguished career. The destroyer was the first Royal Australian Navy combat ship deployed to fight in the Vietnam War, and it was part of the Royal Australian Navy disaster relief effort following Cyclone Tracy in Darwin in 1974. The memorial lookout features seating and interpretive signage detailing the history of the vessels that have carried the name HMAS Hobart. It also features the destroyer's anchor, which points towards the final resting place of the ship.

But the SA branch of the HMAS Hobart Association would like to do something more there. I recently met with the association representative Stephen Lamb, who is determined to add Vietnam War memorial plaques for Ordinary Seaman Raymond John Butterworth and Chief Petty Officer Raymond Henry Hunt. The men were killed on duty on the HMAS Hobart during what later turned out to be a friendly-fire incident involving the United States Air Force off the east coast of North Vietnam on 17 June 1968. Unfortunately, the Hobart was one of several ships mistakenly attacked by US 7th Air Force jets on that night. The HMAS Hobart Association of Australia, South Australia branch, believes the stories of these two sailors and others injured in the missile attack should be told as part of the lookout memorial, and I agree. In addition to helping the association find appropriate grant programs, I've been advocating for the project with the federal government. Australians place considerable value on our memorials. They are important places to stop and reflect on the service and sacrifice of our Defence Force men and women. Adding plaques for Ordinary Seaman Butterworth and Chief Petty Officer Hunt would add to the collective story of the HMAS Hobart, a story that I think belongs to all Australians.

I'm keen to talk to you about another part of my beautiful electorate of Mayo. Again, it's a relatively new part of the electorate. It is the leafy suburb of Craigburn Farm. Situated 17 kilometres by road from the Adelaide CBD, its close proximity to the city makes it perfect for those wishing to be within easy distance of Adelaide but away from the hustle and bustle and surrounded by nature and wildlife. Craigburn Farm boasts an abundance of open green space, and a large proportion of families regularly enjoy outdoor leisure activities there. One outdoor area frequently enjoyed by local families is the Blackwood Park Boulevard playground, which has proven to be very popular and has made a significant contribution to the lifestyles of local families. Feedback from the community has highlighted the need for improved facilities at the playground, including the addition of toilets, a water fountain, a sheltered barbecue area, a bike stand with pump and tool station, a junior play area and improved walking and cycling paths. These facilities would positively support the existing playground and serve to attract even more local families of all ages, as well as visitors, to this much-valued outdoor space. A relatively small investment in this area would have a significant positive impact on the local community and would encourage more local residents to get outdoors and participate in a healthier lifestyle—a worthwhile investment in anyone's book.

A long distance from Craigburn Farm is another part of my community that I'm sure the member for Bennelong, whom we have here, will take an interest in: the Woodchester tennis courts. The tennis courts in Woodchester form the community sporting hub in that close-knit community. The community-owned Woodchester Tennis Club courts are in dire need of resurfacing, as the current playing surface was laid back in 1991—a long time ago, I'm sure you would agree with me, Mr Deputy Speaker Zimmerman. The club currently has four senior teams playing in two competitions, and they have hopes to fill a junior team in the near future. Because the courts adjoin the Woodchester hall, they are regularly used for community events such as the yearly Christmas party and CFS social days. The club has been working hard for many years to raise the funds to cover the expected resurfacing costs. It hosts biannual open-air quiz nights on the courts, and these are the major fundraisers for the Woodchester Tennis Club. The club has told me, 'We as a club believe it is vital for small communities such as ours to continue to keep these facilities operational for the benefit of future generations. As a club, we want to ensure that tennis continues to be played in small rural communities.' I could not agree more. As a former tennis player until I came into this place and could no longer spend my whole Saturday playing tennis—
Mr Alexander interjecting—

Ms SHARKIE: I have played with the member for Bennelong. I'm not sure that I agree with his comments. But what I will say is that tennis on Saturday certainly brings a whole community together. As much as it's a sport and it's about keeping healthy, it's also very much part of our social fabric. I look forward to visiting the club at the end of the month to discuss their future plans.

Another important tennis club in my community is the Gumeracha Tennis Club. If you've been to the Gumeracha Tennis Club and you've had a look at their courts, they really are at the point of being unplayable. They are full of cracks. They are really on the verge of being quite dangerous. The cracks are huge and, sadly, they are spreading. In community consultations over the Gumeracha oval and federation park master plan, fixing the courts was considered a very high priority by the Gumeracha community and by the local council. The Gumeracha Tennis Club have been active in pursuing funding opportunities, and have a clear and compelling vision for their club's future and the future of the facilities. I look forward to working with that club as well to advocate for much-needed assistance for resurfacing their courts. Across regional Australia, our sporting clubs are the paramount part of our towns; they're the part that keeps us together. Sporting clubs are the glue of our towns. And I really do look forward to working with government to ensure that these facilities are viable into the future.

Like many members in this chamber, I have a thriving network of Men's Sheds. There are thousands of Men's Sheds right across Australia and more than a dozen of those are in Mayo. In fact one of the very first Men's Sheds in the nation was established in Goolwa in 1992, through the Goolwa Heritage Club, by local woman Maxine Chaseling. I'm a huge supporter of these non-profit organisations that enhance the physical and mental health of men in a very local, hands-on way.

One of Mayo's more recently established Men's Sheds is at Yankalilla. The membership is growing, and the group are always looking for ways to increase their footprint. Over homemade sausage rolls recently, the guys told me that blokes can never have a shed that is too big. In the meantime, the Yankalilla Men's Shed have come up with new ways to expand their equipment and facilities, recently building their own kitchen and meeting areas. And while they are handy with their hands, they do need some assistance in fitting out their kitchen, so I've been pleased to advocate to the government, on their behalf, to try to source grant funding to cover much needed items such as a hot-water service, a microwave, some crockery, tables and chairs.

Aside from fitting out their kitchen, top of their list is a defibrillator. I was pleased to ask a question in this place to the Minister for Health about the defibrillator program. With most of the men at retirement age and in the high-risk group for cardiac arrest, they consider, as I think many Men's Sheds do, a defibrillator to be as essential as a fire extinguisher. In April this year, the federal government announced funding to equip every Men's Shed with a portable defibrillator, and the Yankalilla Men's Shed recently contacted me to find out when they would receive this life-saving device. As I mentioned, I raised this with Minister Greg Hunt, and I was pleased to be advised during question time that the program should be rolled out early in the new year. This is welcome news, along with the government's commitment to providing continued and expanded funding for the Men's Shed movement of $11.2 million over four years.

Earlier this year I invited the Minister for Veterans and Defence Personnel to Mayo to meet with the Macclesfield RSL, where we held a roundtable session with more than 50 veterans and their families, who also joined us for morning tea. At the conclusion of the event, and along with Mr Dennis Oldenhove, President of the Macclesfield RSL, I took the opportunity to show the minister the unique Anzac memorial garden that has been created by the local RSL. The memorial garden commemorates the sacrifices made by veterans while also providing the community with a space for quiet contemplation.

The garden continues to grow in both scale and popularity, and it now requires a shelter to provide a protected space for visitors to the garden during inclement weather. The construction of such a shelter has the support of not only the RSL but also the Macclesfield Men's Shed and the Macclesfield Football Club. But instead of seeking financial assistance to purchase an off-the-shelf shed, these groups are going to roll up their sleeves and construct the shelter themselves. Both the Men's Shed and the football club will donate not only their time and expertise but also the funds to purchase a proportion of the materials. This project will provide an opportunity for mentorship, to give local residents the chance to get to know and better understand the ex-service personnel and the contributions they have made to our country.

Notwithstanding the generous community spirit, this venture still requires a modest injection of funding from the government before the project can proceed. As we approach Remembrance Day, I think this investment would be both timely and worthwhile, a legacy for our veterans, and I hope that the government can recognise the value of such a project. I know that I certainly do. I would like to say that the ingenuity of the Macclesfield RSL is absolutely astounding. In every single thing they do they bring the community with them and I applaud them.

The leading cause of death for young Australians aged between 16 and 24 is not car accidents, it's not alcohol fuelled violence and it's not cancer. It is suicide. I welcome the Prime Minister's appointment of Christine Morgan, who is the chief executive of the National Mental Health Commission, as Australia's National Suicide Prevention Adviser. I will work closely with the government to ensure our communities have the support they need.

One of the best supports in our community for young people is headspace. Headspace is often the first place that our families and young people turn to for support and advice, but demand for these services is high and the waiting lists are too long. I recently secured funding for two satellite offices in Mayo, one in Mount Barker and one at the other part of the electorate, on the mainland part of the electorate, in Victor Harbor. Since opening both services are stretched thin, providing outreach services to the surrounding areas of Strathalbyn and Kangaroo Island. The government must recognise the needs of the young people in the Adelaide Hills and the Fleurieu Peninsula. It's time that the satellite offices were converted to standalone headspace offices with the necessary resources and specialist staff required to address the needs of our community.

I've also recently spent time with the young people in the Aldinga region. While the barriers preventing access to appropriate mental health care in rural and regional areas in South Australia , such as Aldinga, may be different to our more metropolitan counterparts the need is just as great. I've spent much time with the headspace, Onkaparinga, and I know that their organisation is ready and willing to provide a regular outreach service to the Aldinga area. I intend to work with the Minister for Health to see what options are available to see this come to fruition.

Headspace is not a panacea. It will not fix all mental health issues for young people but it is certainly a start. We must do all we can to equip young people with the skills they need to navigate life. I am so fortunate. I'm sure everyone thinks that they represent the best part of Australia, but I'm quite sure that I definitely do represent the best part of Australia. I am, again, honoured. It is an absolute privilege to represent my community and continue to fight for everything we need. Thank you.

Ms CLAYDON (Newcastle) (16:38): It's been some five months now since the election, but in this address-in-reply to mark the start of the 46th Parliament I'd like to put on the record my sincere thanks to the people of Newcastle for their ongoing trust and faith in me as their elected representative. I am honoured and humbled to have the support of Novacastrians for a third term. It was incredibly heartening that they got behind the vision of a fairer society that leaves no-one behind. I promise to continue to be a fierce advocate for our city. Newcastle has a critical role to play and, indeed, much to gain from the inevitable transition to a low-carbon economy. I will continue to argue that we should have a key seat at the decision-making table to ensure that workers and communities like ours are not left behind. I will also be laser focused on mounting the case for a Newcastle container terminal to create jobs and help produce a more diverse economic base, both for our port and indeed the entire region.

I am also pleased that Newcastle supported the $25 million worth of commitments that I made for our community, commitments that I was incredibly proud of having secured and would have been delivered by a Labor government. Of course it's very disappointing that Labor wasn't able to form government, especially given all the incredible benefits my community would have seen, but it doesn't seem right that the community has to pay the price. Today, I'd like to go through these commitments in detail, and I urge the government to match them. The people of Newcastle voted in good faith for these projects, and I truly believe their wishes should be respected. To this end, I've also written to individual ministers, outlining the benefits of these commitments, and called on them to listen to the strong endorsement from the people of Newcastle and to deliver these projects from government.

The first project I'd like to discuss is the $3 million rebuild of the Boscawen Street Bridge in Wallsend, which is critical to protect against future flooding. While 12 years has passed since those terrible super storms that wrought a trail of destruction through Wallsend, residents and business owners still brace themselves every night when it rains hard. This project would resolve some serious flooding risks, drive business confidence in the region and bring peace of mind to the whole community. A number of issues have been identified with Boscawen, including the low clearance of the bridge, the handrails and the intermediate piers, which have a high chance of trapping cars, shopping trolleys and items that come down through the drain pipes causing massive blockages. To solve this, the bridge has to be reconstructed and it has to have those piers removed. We need to create a single span bridge which would improve the flow capacity in large flood events.

The second commitment was a fantastic cultural contribution of $350,000 to Atwea College to help create a music hub that would have given young Novocastrians access to professional equipment and the skills and experience they needed to pursue their musical ambitions. Life music has long been the lifeblood in Newcastle, but it's getting harder and harder for young people to find the space to hone their skills. The funding that Labor committed would have been used to create a rehearsal space, a live performance area and a recording studio at the Creative Arts Space on Beaumont Street in Hamilton. Atwea had also committed to provide professional musicians to offer mentoring, training and support for the next generation of artists and to connect them to Newcastle's thriving music community. I was very pleased to support this project, which would have provided training and support to nurture Newcastle's next generation of musical talent.

Also in the area of education, I was pleased to commit $6 million to the University of Newcastle towards nine important equity and research projects. I'd like to put on record that the University of Newcastle is one of those regional universities that is deeply committed to producing not just excellence in their education but in equity of access and outcomes. It is those dual ambitions of equity and excellence that have always driven that university. That's why, in a region like ours, you are now seeing record numbers of children who are the first in their family to attend university and record numbers of First Nations men and women enrolling in university. We have now more than 1,000 First Nations students enrolled at the University of Newcastle, training more than 50 per cent of the nation's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander doctors and specialists. This is a record to be truly proud of. The enabling programs at the University of Newcastle, for which I have fought off attacks from the government on a number of occasions now, are the largest and oldest programs in the country.

I was very fortunate, last Friday night, to attend a celebration for the 20th anniversary of the Yapug program. That's an enabling program aimed specifically at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students. When I addressed the second-year medical students not that long ago, 19 of those students came through the Yapug program and were now in second-year medicine at The University of Newcastle. So we know these programs work; we know that the university deserves all the support it can indeed muster, because it is delivering both quality and excellence at every opportunity.

Back to the projects that we were able to commit to, had Labor formed a government. We would have seen, as I said, $6 million injected into a number of critical projects. These projects included $2.4 million for two cutting-edge research projects that would have helped drive a clean energy future. These projects were designed to look at some of the most challenging problems facing the national energy grid and finding ways to get more renewable energy into the system. Newcastle has long been at the forefront of research to create smart energy, so it's perfectly placed to do the work and to drive the breakthroughs of the future. As I said, the energy smarts that we have that have driven our work in the coal industry for centuries are actually very applicable to a whole range of renewable energy projects as well.

We committed $450,000 for a three-year project to boost job outcomes for young people in the Newcastle and Hunter region. I'm sure everybody in this House agrees that getting work, particularly as a young person, is probably one of the most important post-education tasks that you can undertake. In its first year, this project would have seen up to 100 young people from across the Newcastle and Hunter region with intensive personalised support. Participants would have benefited from individual needs assessments undertaken by career experts and support to boost their skill sets and to develop the personal qualities that employers are looking for. They would also get help to create effective resumes and prepare themselves for interviews.

There was $580,000 for two projects to boost the number of young people participating in science, technology, engineering and maths. This included a $400,000 commitment for the university to extend the fantastic HunterWiSE Network, which is a collaborative network of women in STEM and focused on addressing low female participation rates in the sector for three years. It would have had focused attention on lifting the numbers of women entering into those STEM programs. HunterWiSE exists not just at the university; the program has a very important outreach component to it. An additional amount of funding would have supported the HunterWiSE Outreach Program, which is a 10-week intensive program that links girls in high schools across the region with female mentors working or studying in STEM sectors to tackle problems in their local community.

I've seen this in operation, and it's a most remarkable course. It asks young women to apply the skills that they're learning through STEM subjects to very real community problems. I had the pleasure of attending a graduation very recently, and I could not have been more proud to stand alongside some truly extraordinary young women who are feeling empowered by their knowledge and the access that they now have to some really terrific programs through the HunterWiSE Network.

There was a $1.65 million project to change community culture and to help people with an experience of domestic violence take up higher education. This project consisted of four complementary aspects which would have supported up to 1,400 participants from across the Newcastle, Hunter and Central Coast regions.

Creativity and Learning Beyond Trauma is a program which aims at building confidence and introducing participants who have experienced family violence to study in the university environment through an arts based approach. There was another component called Choice, Change and Opportunity, which would have helped people who've, again, experienced domestic and family violence to engage with learning and education through tailor-made pathways. Students would have had a dedicated support person to navigate enrolment, assessment and other challenges of university life. And there was Supporting Students Beyond Domestic and Family Violence, which was a project that generated knowledge and strategies to address and overcome the different forms of violence affecting university students. Finally, there was the Challenging Gendered Inequalities Leadership Program, which would target high school students and raise awareness about the damaging impacts of gender inequality and provide the tools to challenge harmful attitudes.

I think you would agree with me, Deputy Speaker Zimmerman, that projects that create sustainable pathways for students coming from violence and traumatic experiences are absolutely critical to ensuring that we have equity in our education program. Indeed, it's those students that you absolutely want to have access to a quality higher education to break those cycles in their lives. That's why I championed those projects before my shadow ministers at the time and was lucky to secure that funding. But there was also $750,000 for two projects to give disadvantaged people the skills and support they need to take up higher education. That included a $500,000 investment for the University of Newcastle to develop a self-paced national program designed to provide a taste of enabling programs to prospective students. I spoke about the terrific track record of enabling programs at the University of Newcastle, but we don't want to rest on our laurels here; this is an opportunity to actually expand those programs and take them out into regions and into high schools to enable students to get a taste of the kinds of opportunities and alternative pathways that are available.

A further $250,000 commitment would have supported a pilot program offering important time with staff and support for regional students at community centres in the Upper Hunter, the Central Coast and the Mid North Coast regions. Fifty thousand dollars was also on offer for two parents rooms at the University of Newcastle libraries. There was $120,000 for a project to open up university options to young people in out-of-home care. I don't need to remind people; I know that in this House the massive increase in children in out-of-home care demands that we start thinking about how those kids move into higher education. With about 10 per cent of young people in my area in out-of-home care, we have an extraordinarily high rate of children in the Hunter, Newcastle and Central Coast regions who are in out-of-home care. There is a dire need for greater support. I would have loved to have seen this program going ahead. These projects were designed by the university to meet the very specific needs of our region and they would have delivered significant community benefits. Obviously, I still strongly believe they are worthy of government support. As I said, I've reached out to individual ministers, asking them to, indeed, lend their support.

But schools didn't miss out either, with an investment of $120,000 for priority projects at four public schools. The first of those was $50,000 to upgrade the basketball courts at Glendale public school. The second one was $25,000 towards digital media equipment for the annual Digital Media Festival at Callaghan College. There was $25,000 towards improvements at New Lambton Public School, including a new fence and softball areas. That's very important for a school that has no grass. Those softball surfaces are critical. There was $20,000 for Stockton Public School to create an outdoor learning play area and sensory garden. These much anticipated projects would have improved the amenity of these schools and improved educational outcomes. This announcement was on top of an extra $19.4 million that Newcastle's public schools would have received in the first three years of a Labor government.

The next project was $2.3 million to rejuvenate Throsby Creek and prevent damaging plastics and rubbish from ending up in the ocean. The funding would have allowed for the installation of four gross pollutant traps to catch rubbish at the source, so it doesn't end up in our precious oceans. It would have also provided some funds for landscaping on the northern bank of the creek between Lewis Street bridge and Hannell Street. Those improvements would have been much appreciated by the community, and were part of Labor's planned urban rivers and corridors program, which included $200 million to restore urban waterways and habitat corridors across the country to their natural beauty. I encourage the government to look at such a program for urban waterways and how critical this is.

Labor's $62 million beaches and coastlines climate adaptation plan also would have offered important environmental benefits. Critically, it included a $50 million Coastal Rehabilitation Fund to help communities prepare for and respond to coastal erosion. As I've discussed many times in this House, there's a community in my electorate called Stockton, which is facing diabolical, existential threats from coastal erosion, and it would have been very well positioned to take advantage of this funding commitment. During the campaign, I met with Stockton residents and representatives of the community liaison group, highlighting the potential for this funding to support the work of the state and local governments in addressing the diabolical erosion issues that the community now faces. Since the election, the community has now lost its only childcare centre, and a number of other very important community assets are, literally, being sandbagged to prevent them from being swept into the ocean.

The next funding commitment was $491,000 to reverse the planned Morrison government cuts and to deliver an extra funding boost to emergency relief organisations operating out of Newcastle. Off the back of Anti-Poverty Week, where we saw the true extent and prevalence of poverty in our communities and the human face of poverty, this would have been a very welcome addition. I am truly sad that the Samaritans foundation and the Muloobinba Aboriginal Corporation have not benefited from the additional funds that they could have.

There was also another important regional announcement on our support for the Glendale interchange, and there are opportunities now for the government to really get onboard and see the value of important community projects—to back in things that would help share some of the prosperity of this nation and to ensure that those who are disadvantaged and marginalised in our communities are given a fair start and are given every chance to reap the benefits of being Australian citizens.

Dr FREELANDER (Macarthur) (16:58): Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker Zimmerman. What a delight it is to see you in the chair today. There has been a long tradition on election night that the incoming Prime Minister, having claimed victory or something approaching it, commits to govern for all Australians. The cynic in me says that this is the first lie of any incoming government; my fairer-minded side might simply note that the proof of the political pudding is forever in the eating. For my part, I've always hoped that an incoming government, be it Labor or coalition, would do its best to govern for all and not just some of us, and that it will have the good fortune also to try to honour the commitment to govern for all.

I know it sounds old-fashioned and it doesn't make for a particularly sharp political message, but, deep down, every one of us here wants the country to succeed, whoever is in charge and whoever gets the credit. It's something of a commentary on our times that one has to say that. We know also that success doesn't come easy. Good governments, and good oppositions, for that matter, take risks for which they are invariably judged with the benefit of hindsight, sometimes not always kindly. We know that change is hard to sell and the public isn't always keen on new policies or ideas or even facing up to issues that can't be resolved without creating losers as well as winners. Elections and a new parliament offer one of those rarest of political opportunities—a chance to wipe the slate clean and admit what's working and what isn't. My concern with this government is that, five months into its term, it shows little sign either of admitting that not everything is going well or of governing for all Australians.

The Governor-General's speech, written for him to deliver by the government of the day, is the parliamentary set piece for a newly minted government to outline its plans for the next three years. It provides an early signal as to whether that important election night commitment to govern for all will be met or dodged. Better addresses to the opening of parliament provide a strong indication that the government both knows its own mind and has listened and learned from the election. Having a proper new-term agenda means more than just jotting down a shopping list of disconnected thoughts and ideas that might appeal to the interests or prejudices of its own political base. Government might call it a plan, but it's not. What is needed is a coherent suite of policies that will address the issues of the day and the more deeply-held concerns and aspirations of the Australian people. To remain credible, a Governor-General's address needs to be candid about the true state of the world and give recognition to what might have been done or gone better in the previous parliament. It's a chance to re-establish trust and one of the few chances our adversarial political framework has to offer.
