Sadly for me, and I think for many in the community, this government has yet to demonstrate that it has a clear agenda for this term of government or has learned much about the mood and the disposition of the Australian people. As you'd expect, I would not make that criticism of the great Whitlam government, the Hawke government or the first Rudd government. But I'd equally not make it of the second and third Howard governments either. Each of those two governments had solid plans for what they wanted to achieve and how they were going to get there.

After a shambolic first term and a near loss in 1998, John Howard and his advisers worked out that there was more to governing than winning office and then hoping for the best. John Howard always had a next-term agenda. If you ask any senior public servant who was around at the time, they'll confirm that Howard always had a plan and a plan to follow. Menzies, in his near-election loss in 1961, as I think the much-respected Arthur Sinodinos may have recounted on the ABC on election night, recalibrated his government policies in part by lifting a number of ideas prosecuted by Labor and Arthur Calwell in the 1961 campaign. He'd recognised that he'd lost touch and needed to reinvent himself.

By contrast, the last three coalition governments have arrived ill-prepared for office, short on policy detail or fresh ideas. Unsurprisingly, each has been a captive of the daily news cycle and frequently drawn away from addressing the matters that most concern Australians. The Abbott government arrived rudderless, guided by not much more than a selection of empty slogans. It foolishly outsourced policy formulation to its National Commission of Audit then delivered to order a set of far Right political staples and pipedreams that, when translated into the horror 2014 budget, sealed the fate of the Prime Minister and his then Treasurer. The Turnbull government arrived with a rudder but with competing hands on the tiller and ended in policy paralysis. And we've seen little evidence over the last five months that the Morrison government is governing for all Australians or even knows where to start.

The government's signature tax policy has been bullied through the parliament. It will cost about $300 billion over 10 years and is already being used as an excuse for not funding improvements to important and underfunded government services and programs such as Newstart. Yes, tax cuts were particularly long overdue for those earning less than $80,000 a year, but they could have been more generous to those who were really struggling to get by while still offering something for everyone, and they did not need to be so heavily skewed to those who needed them the least.
As Ross Gittins neatly put it back in July:

Consider the first actions of the re-elected Scott Morrison and his government. First, pushing through its three-stage tax plan, which in time will cut the income tax of those on the minimum wage by 1.5¢ in every dollar, those full-time workers on the median wage by 2.4¢ in every dollar, and those on $200,000 a year by 5.8¢ in the dollar.

Since then, we've had a renewal of government attempts to stigmatise welfare recipients by fresh attempts to extend the reach of the cashless welfare card, drug testing for welfare recipients and the ongoing horrors of robo-debt, (1) punishing the most vulnerable and, (2) ignoring the evidence base for any of these policies.

We've witnessed too the government's stony-faced glare in the general direction of the 700,000-plus Newstart recipients, the majority of whom are over 40 years of age, and who have been paying income tax and GST all their lives. They're being asked to eke out an existence on between $40 and $50 a day, or about $200 a week below the poverty line. If you have a family to support, or a mortgage to pay, Newstart is one of the stingiest unemployment benefits in the entire OECD. And I understand that now, and really for a long time, it's the turn of the refugees to cop another metaphorical beating from those opposite as the government attempts to repeal the medevac legislation over the objections of every medical group in the nation.

Like Paul Keating in 1993, Prime Minister Morrison can lay claim to winning a famous and unexpected election victory. There is no doubt about that. Paul Keating, though, is not simply remembered for an unlikely win, but as a primary agent of economic progress and social change—a national leader who made a difference and the antithesis of a political fence-sitter. All the current PM has proven today is that he can pick his moment and that his years in advertising weren't entirely wasted, given his expert marketing.

In this Governor-General's speech, there is not even the remotest sense of a government with a vision for a fairer, safer and more competitive Australia, one that has plans and aspirations for the low-carbon future that the world will inevitably thrust upon us and which is not too far off. What the parliament was presented with was a hastily written shopping list of truisms that turn out at best to be only partly true. There were claims about the economy that invite ridicule, while ignoring reason and experience. It's a political bucket list, enlivened with only a general sense of confidence that, with luck, something might turn up.

The Governor-General's speech is the chance for any newly minted government to outline a vision for our nation. It's not another excuse for a government to mark its own homework and give itself plenty of positive ticks, and relate to a complete exercise in self-justification. It's not a platform for de rigueur attacks on the usual suspects that the hard Right likes to attack, or for bathing in the stale waters of political hubris, which they have in a large amount—as evidenced by the Minister for Home Affairs and his performance in question time today.

For one moment, imagine you're a hardworking nurse or a junior doctor in one of our underfunded and overcrowded public hospitals; or a harassed and underpaid aged-care worker; or a worker in child care; or a worker just off a long and gruelling shift in one of our mines or factories. How would you react to this Morrison-government-crafted gem from the Governor-General's address on 2 July:
Our economic strength has been won by the enterprise, innovation and determination of a hardworking people, especially those running small and family businesses.

Isn't every hardworking Australian who does their best for themselves and this country worthy of equal praise? Or is it just some groups or callings that are particularly special? I simply ask this: is this the perspective of a Prime Minister governing for all Australians?

From what we've seen to date, this government is no more ready for office than it was 12 months ago, and no more willing or able to meet our national challenges than the failed Turnbull or Abbott administrations that preceded it. This is a government that didn't expect to win, and prepared accordingly. Why else would you call your own victory a miracle? It is at least as ill prepared for office as its two predecessors, without the luxury afforded them by a domestic economy in cruise mode and relatively benign conditions abroad. To borrow a phrase from Malcolm Turnbull, what we've had since the election is a government busily deploying weapons of mass distraction in the hope of providing a bit of political cover while it hastily cobbles together something vaguely approaching a second-term agenda.

We have a government playing for time that steadfastly refuses to tell it like it is on the economy. It's obsessed by one goal, and one goal only, that of securing the bragging rights of being the first federal government since the global financial crisis to deliver a budget surplus—that is, to take more money off taxpayers than it pays out—never mind that the consequences for economic activity of running a surplus may not be good, never mind that you've doubled the size of government debt while in office and never mind that your pie-in-the-sky 10-year tax plan will add further to government debt if your growth assumptions prove too optimistic.

Instead, the economy has been left to stumble along to the exasperation of the Reserve Bank, business and the community at large. Even the Business Council is arguing for an increase in Newstart. The promise of new infrastructure spending remains mostly that, just a promise, and an empty one at that. Government and private debt remain at record levels, unemployment is inching up and the first round of tax cuts seem to have done as little to stimulate economic growth as most commentators predicted they would. Consumer confidence also is on the skids. The level of Newstart payments and the robo-debt fiasco are even more demanding of action than ever before. Robo-debt must be the most conspicuous case of data mismatching since some genius first thought it was a great idea to start comparing apples with oranges. Robo-debt and government intransigence on Newstart each have the potential to further poison the well of public trust. Each could be addressed without placing undue strain on the public purse or threatening the integrity of our unravelling social security arrangements. Any deftness of touch in foreign affairs seems to have departed coalition politics together with the previous Prime Minister and his deputy. We seem to be taking every opportunity to offend our major trading partner while buddying up to a US administration about which the less said the better. We are in a second age of government by sound bites and slogans, perhaps a little better honed than under Prime Minister Abbott but no less pathetic.

With this government, the rhetoric says it is getting on with it while the reality says it is more about getting away with it. The one message for all sides of politics from the last election is that we all need to spend rather more time explaining ourselves and being more candid about things when things haven't gone as well as we'd hoped. Logic tells us that it's much better to correct early first steps than resolutely continue down the wrong path. The government would make a good start by ditching the absolute rubbish it talks on the state of the economy and the jobs market. If there is to be an improvement in our public discourse and a lift in public trust it's going to have to come from the top. The PM can be an excellent communicator—really, one of Australia's best in terms of the way he communicates—and it's well within his remit to have his ministers tell it a bit more like it is than as they wished it was, as Minister Stuart Robert was doing yesterday when he said there is no waiting list for the NDIS. The Treasurer could be more forthright too. It's just so painfully obvious the Treasurer's playing for time that he should just stop the ducking and weaving and admit what's going on. I've not been to the Treasurer's office, but in my mind's eye I imagine the walls are lined with a series of small glass frames marked 'Only break in case of emergency'. Inside each case is a catchphrase to be used when the economy is in trouble. Many of these will be familiar to anyone who has been following Australian politics for as long as I have. The modern day equivalent of the McMahon era is suitably vague and imprecise when he uses the term 'strong economy'. It appears no fewer than eight times in the Governor-General's address and is as fine a case of 'saying don't make it so' as I have seen. I think the idea is much the same as the McMahon-era maxim while reflecting the greater role now played by the independent Reserve Bank. Roughly translated, it means: even this government can't wreck the economy, because the Reserve Bank runs most of the show these days, anyway.

More recent stock phrases we've had include terms like 'the best form of welfare is a job' and 'every extra job is one less person on welfare'. The former phrase rather presupposes that jobs are a form of welfare. They're not. The second forgets that when extra jobs are generated by increases in population both the numbers in employment and the numbers on welfare can increase simultaneously. You'd think that the nation's Treasurer would understand this sort of stuff.

What the Treasurer and this government certainly do know about is how to claim credit for the work of others. Claiming that every job created in Australia over the last six years is all the work of this government is as risible as it is dishonest. The truth is that even in a recession the numbers in employment may continue to grow even though the number of hours worked per employee is in decline, and we all know that there has been a large increase in those underworking in their jobs. Making increases in employment the barometer of national economic health sets the bar extremely low. The Treasurer should desist from further attempts to cloud the issue and get on with levelling with the Australian people about what's going on in the economy and why our jobs market is producing a number of jobs but still can't provide enough work for those who want it.

In truth, there have been three positive developments in respect of jobs over the last few years, but none of those are ones that this government has created. The first is that policymakers at the Reserve Bank have at long last recognised that it's not necessary to hold the level of unemployment at five per cent or above to constrain inflation. In short, for now, we can have rapid jobs growth without blowing the lid off prices. Unnecessarily targeting unemployment so it is at a high so-called natural rate not only ensures that the economy cannot operate to potential; it uses government policy to deliberately deny people a job. The second is that we have generally managed the transition from a mining boom to more broadly based sources of growth relatively well, although there are still some black spots, such as the housing market in Western Australia. The third bit of good news is that 1.4 million jobs, many of them full time, have been created over the last five years. That has been barely enough to keep pace with increases in the working-age population through historically high levels of net migration and natural increase.

But the credit for these gains does not go to this government. It has been slow to increase spending on infrastructure and has held back federal spending, mostly on the poor and disadvantaged, at every opportunity. The Commonwealth might rightly claim to have not stuffed things up, but, in reality, it has been a bit player—a well-placed bystander rather than active participant—in job creation, and we desperately need more infrastructure spending, particularly on transport infrastructure, throughout Australia and in my electorate of Macarthur in particular.

The government has a political, not an economic, narrative on jobs. The government only wants to talk about jobs growth because the labour market is performing below historical norms and less impressively than the economies with which we are usually compared. The OECD figures for harmonised rates of unemployment over the last five to six years in countries I have mentioned show them dropping between 1.5 and four or more percentage points. Even in Canada, a former laggard, unemployment is now down to 5.7 per cent from 7.2 per cent in December 2013. In the UK, unemployment has dropped from 7.2 per cent in 2013 to under four per cent at the present time. Australia under the coalition has barely managed a drop of half a percentage point in unemployment over the last six years—much less than our competitors. The plain fact is that we still have fewer jobs than we need to provide employment for all those who want to work, particularly the young and older people.

When this government talks about labour market reform, it barely gets past the platitudes. It is thoroughly clueless. To hear this government talk of labour market reform, you would think that unions were still as powerful as they were back in the 1950s. They are obsessed with unions. But unions protect workers; we all know that. The failings and conundrums of the Australian labour market barely scored a mention in the Governor-General's speech.

In summary, this is a government that is big on marketing and very poor on much else. It targets the most vulnerable. It's not providing support in employment, housing and education. It's a great tragedy that we don't have more visionary policies.

Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat) (17:18): I welcome the opportunity to respond to the Governor-General's address-in-reply. It's a real pleasure to follow the member for Macarthur, now in his well-deserved second term in this place. He has been, and is, a very real champion for some of the most vulnerable in our community, and I particularly commend his decades and decades of work providing paediatric care in the public hospital system. That commitment to our public system to ensure the accessibility of paediatric care is very critical.

Of course, as we know, the election didn't go the way that Labor had hoped. We did have big plans for the country, both in my old portfolio of health and in delivering more strategic nation-building infrastructure to boost economic growth and jobs across our cities and our regions. We would have invested $5 billion more over the next four years on nation-building infrastructure than that proposed by the Liberal and National government and over $10 billion more over the decade. As we are now learning from the spin of the government when it comes to infrastructure, our projects weren't off on the never-never. We were set to hit the ground running on significant new infrastructure funding now. From our ports to our airports, public transport systems to our roads, rail to coastal shipping we not only believed in greater public investment, we had the policies to make significant improvements to boost our economy and to improve our way of life, with projects carefully designed for boosting jobs in the short-term while lifting productivity and connectivity, connecting communities from the medium to the longer term.

I want to acknowledge the Leader of the Opposition who, for almost a decade, was Labor's Infrastructure and Transport Minister in government and spokesperson in opposition. I had the privilege of serving as his assistant minister in government. The member for Grayndler's passion for nation-building is second to none and he retains a formidable knowledge of the details of this portfolio, both the big and the very small, from the suburbs to our capital cities to our small rural communities.

After six years in the health portfolio, I'm really excited to move back into a key economic portfolio in infrastructure and transport. Infrastructure investment does play a critical role in growing our economy and delivering jobs across our nation. It's a key part of Labor's economic and jobs agenda. Good government requires planning and building for the future. In the highly competitive, globalised world of the 21st century the prices consumers pay, the profits businesses make, the quality of life people enjoy and the export income earned will more than ever depend on the adequacy and quality of our nation's infrastructure. Modern, smart, well-planned infrastructure stimulates growth, it creates jobs and training opportunities in the immediate term but it also sets the nation up for our future growth. But we don't get there by accident.

The Morrison government in failing to articulate an economic plan for our nation has also failed to articulate a plan for connecting and developing our nation's infrastructure, our transport sector and our regions. However, one thing our Prime Minister can do is a marketing campaign. We've learned at Senate estimates this week that the federal government spent some $17 million on a taxpayer funded advertising blitz promising to bust congestion. The national media buy across TV, print, radio, digital and cinema from mid-January this year to when the election was called was over $200,000 a day. That's $200,000 a day spent on advertising. In contrast, 18 months ago the Urban Congestion Fund and the Roads of Strategic Importance initiative were announced with great fanfare. The funds allegedly had budgets in the billions of dollars. How much did the federal government spend from those funds in the 18 months in mainland Australia last financial year? Not a single cent. Despite all the hype, in the whole of the 2018-19 year, not a single cent was spent from the Urban Congestion Fund. In that same year $2.2 million was spent from the Roads of Strategic Importance. I think that's $0.06 million on the one highway in western Tasmania. That means that the Prime Minister, in fact, spent eight times as much advertising infrastructure as he did on actually building anything out of those two flagship transport funds. It is clear that the Prime Minister's infrastructure program is a political document but it is not an economic plan.

In contrast, Labor has always been the party of nation-building. Only Labor governments have had the courage to dream big and to build the infrastructure necessary to unlock our nation's potential. From the transcontinental railway, the Snowy Hydro scheme, the National Highway network and the nation's capital here in Canberra through to the wonder of the Sydney Opera House, to our humble urban sewerage networks, to modern setting in place core frameworks for future infrastructure projects—like the National Broadband Network, the Western Sydney Airport and Inland Rail—Labor's core purpose is that of nation-building to deliver jobs today and to improve productivity and connectedness in the longer term.

While nationally the result of the election may have been disappointing, locally I was touched and humbled by support that I received from the Ballarat community. In every corner of the electorate, from Ballarat to Bacchus Marsh to Daylesford to Warren Heath to Clunes to Elaine, a positive campaign and our plans for the future for our region were given a ringing endorsement.

I love our community. It's my home, it's where I bring up my son and to be our region's representative in federal parliament is the greatest honour of my life. To be re-elected with a positive swing of 3.62 per cent is a fantastic outcome, and it would not have been possible without the hard work and dedication of our wonderful Labor volunteers. In particular, I must thank my campaign chair, Craig Fletcher; my campaign director, Emma Harding; my entire committee and team; and all of my incredibly hardworking staff, who worked so hard through the campaign. I also particularly want to pay tribute to my personal staff in the Health portfolio, Andrew Garrett and Adam Gartrell, who did work incredibly hard through some very difficult times on the campaign trail.

Once again I want to offer my sincere thanks to one of Ballarat's favourite sons, Steve Bracks, who continued his tradition of launching just about every campaign that takes place in our region. He's our good luck charm. On election day we had an incredible 202 volunteers on booths in every single corner of the electorate and, as I travelled around on that bright, sunny day, I was touched by our community, by the volunteers who were out in force and by the smiles that were on everyone's faces. I had my then 10-year-old son with me for his first election day campaign, handing out for the whole day, and he did a sterling job, beating me to the punch most times in getting how-to-vote cards in people's hands.

These people volunteer for Labor because they know that we offer the best for our region. Only Labor have shown ourselves prepared to take our regions seriously and invest in the future of our community. At the election, Labor made clear that regional Australia and Ballarat should not be an afterthought. We went to the election with plans to invest almost $50 million in projects across our community. We planned to finish the job at Her Majesty's Theatre, invest in active tourism infrastructure in Hepburn Shire, build much-needed sporting facilities in Bacchus Marsh, develop Birch into an important regional and health and education hub and invest in turning Ballarat Airport into a facility fit for a growing regional city. This is on top of an additional $21 million that would have been delivered to Ballarat's public schools.

In stark contrast, the Liberals failed to match any of our commitments—not a single one—in our region, offering grants funding to only two projects located within the city of Ballarat. They offered nothing to Daylesford, to Trentham, to Ballan or to Bacchus Marsh and certainly nothing to Darley. They didn't take our region seriously, and the voters of Ballarat recognised that. We know that Labor's investments would have improved our services and we know that investing in community infrastructure helps regional cities and towns to grow and to attract and retain the workers needed to power regional economic development.

Regional Australia shouldn't be an afterthought or, frankly, subject to which seat your local member happens to be a part of. Just next door in the marginal seat of Corangamite, which Labor was able to pick up, there was over $3 billion worth of Liberal Party election commitments. While I hope very much that Corangamite sees every single cent of those commitments, the government needs to explain to other people in other regional communities why those living along the Surf Coast and near Geelong deserve greater investment than those living in the communities like Wollongong, Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh or Daylesford in my community.

Australians deserve investment based on real need and real opportunities, not based on the political needs of the Liberal and National parties. Over this term, the Morrison government has the challenge of proving that it is serious for governing for all Australians and serious about actually investing properly in regional development. If they want tips, they should listen to the people of Ballarat and invest in the facilities, infrastructure in our community.

Again I want to say thank you very much to the people of Ballarat for putting their faith in me. I promise to keep doing what I said I would do when I was first elected in 2001: to keep standing up for our community and for our fair share of federal government investment.

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Ms CATHERINE KING: As I was saying, I just want to say thank you very much to the people of Ballarat for once again putting their faith in me. As I promised to do on the day that I first stood for election back in 2001, I promise to keep standing up for you and our community to ensure that we do get a fair share of federal government investment. And I promise you do have a strong representative here in the federal parliament for the interests of our community.

I want to thank those whose tireless campaigning supported my re-election. I not only want to acknowledge my campaign chair and my campaign director, but also the entire committee. I thank the people who put all of the booth rosters and booth kits together, who came doorknocking with me, who did telephone canvassing, who did the substantial amounts of work that go into a campaign. I particularly want to acknowledge my husband, whose birthday it was this week. He's been through a few campaigns with me. I think this might have been my seventh, or sixth, and he's been there by my side. I very much appreciate that.

Already in this term the member for Gorton and I have raised in this place one of the issues that we intend to focus on as part of the upcoming term, and that's the state of the Western Highway. This is a highway that is basically the artery of Victoria. It runs from the South Australian border right the way through to Melbourne. Under the Labor government, we started the substantial process of duplicating this highway. All of the councils along the highway corridor had an agreement where, basically, they listed a whole heap of priorities about where they wanted the highway redevelopment to go. Councils on the South Australian border basically campaigned and championed projects that had nothing to do with their own constituencies and, subsequently, Labor started funding all of those. One of those priorities was the duplication of the Western Highway from the Ballarat to Stawell. We started that process when we were in government. The funding stalled for that—the project has kept going because Labor's money was still in the pipeline—but I was pleased to see that the government did, in the budget in May, finally bring that money forward to continue that project. It's too important not to.

What is happening now is that, 10 or 20 years down the track from that initial project, the population coming out of Melbourne has absolutely boomed down that bottom end of the highway and there are really substantial constraints there. We have called on the federal government to work with the state on how we can actually improve the road links to Melbourne for this rapidly growing population that starts around Rockbank and through Caroline Springs, which has also had huge population growth.

I love living in regional Australia. I wouldn't live anywhere else. I know millions and millions of others do, including the two members of the Labor Party we have in the chamber with us, and I know millions would relish the chance of being able to do so. That is why we need a federal government that will do the hard work to plan and fund the infrastructure we need to improve living standards in our regions and improve the way in which our regions connect to each other—and not only connect to our cities.

But cities are important too. It shouldn't be a city versus country or bush versus city debate, but for six years we've had the Liberals talking a really big game about decentralisation. I want to say a couple of things about this. The first thing, for many of us who have seen this debate come and go over time, is that we'd just really like you to restore the jobs you've cut already. I've had masses of jobs cut out of my Centrelink office and my Medicare office. We used to have both an AusIndustry and an Austrade public servant living in Ballarat. I've watched all of these jobs, over time, go from my regional community. They were important for helping us invest in export industries, expand our industries and access government grant programs. I wish you would put the jobs back in that you've taken out, for a start.

When you do talk about decentralisation, it has basically been about moving public servants to Adelaide—Adelaide needs some help; I don't want to decry that—and to Perth, Brisbane and Parramatta. It hasn't actually meant anything, other than in the egregious case of what happened with the APVMA. As for sending lots of jobs out to regional centres like Ballarat, it just hasn't happened. The government's own documents show that not a single federal public servant has moved to regional Victoria under its decentralisation agenda.

It can't just be about moving public servants or government agencies to National Party seats. If you're going to talk about that, it's about: what are the services that regional communities need to have delivered, what is the role for the Commonwealth in ensuring there are public sector opportunities for those services to be delivered in our region, and have we got the people there who can do that, partnering with state and local government services? We've got things like Primary Health Networks in our regions as well. We can look at those as a platform to build that good public sector service base for the Commonwealth, rather than the way in which the government has gone about it. For real decentralisation, governments should act as an enabler connecting our regions to our cities and vice versa, to inspire people to look at locating in our regions for economic growth.

We do need a federal government that has a genuine and transparent infrastructure program that does support new road and rail projects while ensuring existing assets are upgraded and maintained. This government is complaining now because we're coming after it on individual projects. We're pointing out issues with their funding profiles for projects which, I suspect, a lot of members who stood beside the Prime Minister for some of these announcements were completely unaware of. You've got election brochures across the country with Liberal and National Party MPs saying, 'Delivered,' and then you look at the funding profile for project after project, and they're not there for, in some cases, five, six or seven years—if at all. You've got communities like Geelong, who absolutely believe that fast rail is going to be delivered and want it delivered very quickly, but you know there's a $2 billion offer on the table and it's probably about a $10 billion project. So we're talking about a very long time down the track before that's a reality. But I'm quite sure the member for Corangamite was telling everyone she'd delivered fast rail and that it would be there tomorrow, and that is people's expectation.

So the government can't complain if we now come after it. They say it's a $100 billion plan. You can see them coming up with this in an office somewhere, going: 'Is it $50 billion? We're spending more than that. Let's chuck in the financial assistance grants to councils. What does that add up to?' There's a funny television program, Utopia, where they might do that. Again, the government has talked this up and there's absolutely no way it's going to deliver the sorts of expectations it's raised in communities everywhere. It doesn't have a proper plan for infrastructure. It had a plan to try to win an election and it's now got to try and retrofit that into things like its national freight and transport strategy and how that connects our ports; it's got to work out how all of that connects. So, when it comes to the future for infrastructure, this government unfortunately has talked a big game but has delivered very, very little, as we've seen.

It is time for the government, now in its seventh year, to end the spin, get to work, deliver a real plan for our economy, deliver a real plan for infrastructure, create jobs, improve productivity and actually spend money on busting congestion, not just on advertising.

Mr MARLES (Corio—Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (17:50): Can I firstly acknowledge the member for Ballarat, who is a neighbour of mine, particularly as she referenced her joy in living in regional Australia, which I know is a joy that is shared with me by members present. It is something that I very much identify with, and there is a sense in which Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong, as the largest regional centres in Victoria, share a lot in common. Certainly the member for Ballarat and I often compare notes about our electorates, the campaigns within them and the sorts of challenges we face. A lot of what the member for Ballarat has just spoken about resonates with me significantly, and I'll talk about that in a moment.

This election was obviously a very difficult one for Labor nationally, but there was a local campaign in my electorate of Corio which had a very good result and saw a significant swing to Labor as a result. I want to take the opportunity today in this speech on the address-in-reply to talk a little bit about that campaign and to thank the many, many people who helped me in it. Ultimately, we certainly do not do any of this on our own. We stand on the shoulders of others, and this is a moment to acknowledge them.

The first point to make is that there had been a redistribution in the lead-up to this election which saw my electorate change the most that it has since I came to parliament in 2007. I lost parts of the Bellarine Peninsula, the townships of Leopold and Moolap, to the electorate of Corangamite but in its stead gained a number of suburbs of urban Geelong—Belmont, Highton and Wandana Heights. I went to primary school in Highton. These were places I had spent time in in my youth, but we become very parochial as MPs and tend to see the world as bounded by the borders of our electorate. So it was nice for me to rediscover a part of Geelong which had been a significant part of my childhood.

A number of very significant issues came up during the local campaign. I was very pleased with the emphasis that was placed on Geelong by the Labor campaign nationally in terms of the commitments that were made. One of the real difficulties in being on the wrong end of a campaign nationally is that so many of the promises that you work so hard to achieve for your electorate obviously don't come to fruition. Nothing is achieved from the opposition benches. It is a place of impotence. It is the Treasury benches where you get to make a difference. But I do want to mention those promises, because they speak to the commitment and the focus that we were placing upon parts of Geelong. They included a $50 million commitment to the new women's and children's hospital in Geelong, such a fantastic initiative of the Andrews state government, which we committed to participating in. There was $40 million for the redevelopment of Baxter House Hospital, including the development of a dedicated elective surgery centre.

There was a $20 million commitment to finally finish the redevelopment of Geelong's Kardinia Park, which now stands where it is, even prior to the final stage being finished, as the biggest piece of sporting infrastructure in regional Australia. It is home to what is easily the largest sporting organisation in regional Australia, the Geelong Football Club, which would be multiple times bigger than the next biggest club in regional Australia.

The existence of the Geelong Football Club in Geelong is far from an inevitability. A way to think about that is the difficulty and the challenge that the state of Tasmania has in getting a team in the AFL. The fact that a regional city like Geelong already has a team in the AFL speaks to how much of an achievement that is and how it is not inevitable. But the existence of Geelong Football Club, the second oldest football club of any code in the world today, does tend to lead us take it for granted. The redevelopment of Kardinia Park is at the heart of making sure that the Geelong Football Club is future-proofed as a team within the AFL, which, in turn, is so profoundly important to the identity of Geelong itself. I was really pleased to see Labor make a commitment to what would have seen the finishing of the Kardinia Park stadium.

There was $15 million for Anam Cara House, which is a hospice, although to call it simply a hospice doesn't do it justice. It is a state-of-the-art facility which is about making what is a special time in people's lives—the moment in which they end their life—one which they can share with their families in the most dignified way possible. Anam Cara exists in Geelong today. It is a remarkable institution. This money would have seen the redevelopment of Anam Cara on a new site.

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Mr MARLES: Before the suspension, I was referring to the commitments that Labor made in the electorate of Corio during the federal election. There was a $14 million commitment to an adult mental health hub to be established in Corio, $460,000 to upgrade facilities in several schools across the electorate of Corio and a partnering with the Andrews government to deliver the South Geelong to Waurn Ponds rail duplication.

There were a number of measures that we committed to that were part of what the Andrews government had committed to in terms of the Geelong City Deal, and particularly through the stage 3 of the Building Better Regions Fund projects. There was $2 billion to improve the ABC facilities in Geelong. There was emergency relief funding of $76,000 for Bethany Community Support. There was $546,000 for Diversitat, which is also known as the Geelong Ethnic Communities Council. There was $5,000 for the Belmont Toy Library. Really importantly, there was $2 million for the GROW project, which looked at tackling issues of joblessness and addressing disadvantage in the areas of greatest vulnerability within the electorate of Corio, which would be the northern suburbs of Corio—places like Norlane and Corio, along with suburbs such as Whittington.

To that end, a large focus of the policies that Labor was putting forward nationally were focused on communities such as those that exist in the northern suburbs of Geelong. It is a real issue that, whilst Geelong itself is actually travelling pretty well across a whole lot of stats in the aftermath of difficult decisions that were made in the private sector and has done well, I think, to get past the big economic shocks—the ceasing of the manufacture of cars at Ford, the closing of the Point Henry aluminium smelter—there are parts of Geelong that are not travelling as well. Norlane and Corio are examples. Whittington is another. It's really important that we are focused on how we address issues of urban poverty in this country, and those suburbs have more than their fair share of that. It is a real focus for Labor to look at how we can best deal with that, and I certainly felt very proud about a number of the policies that were being put forward, particularly in policy areas such as health and education, in terms of the way in which they would have impacted positively on those in Norlane, Corio and Whittington.

What is sad is that, whilst a number of those commitments were matched by the government—and we will certainly be holding the Morrison government to account in terms of the delivery of their commitments—a number of the commitments that I've just gone through were not matched by the government and will not happen because we did not win. As I said at the outset, one of the things that hurts the most about being on the wrong end of election day is that commitments that you've worked so hard to make ultimately are not delivered upon. But we will continue to advocate for those issues and causes over the next three years and will certainly seek to do that beyond then.

Having made those remarks, I want to take this opportunity to thank the very many people who helped support my re-election in the electorate of Corio. In doing so, it really was a very good local result. We saw a four per cent plus swing to Labor on first preferences and a more than two per cent swing to Labor on the two-party preferred result. It's a result that many people who assisted me can feel very proud of. Firstly, I want to thank Bill Shorten, our leader going into the election, and Tanya Plibersek, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party going into the election, for the leadership that they showed and the tireless efforts that they put in across the country. They certainly supported me in the electorate of Corio. The election result was a devastating outcome for both of them in particular, but I want them to know that there are Labor candidates across Australia, of which I am most certainly one, who are ever grateful for the efforts they put in.

I'd like to thank Noah Carroll and Paul Erickson from the national office of the ALP and Sam Rae and Kosmos Samaras from the Victorian branch of the Labor Party for the efforts that they put in at an organisation level towards supporting my campaign in Corio. I would like to acknowledge the Labor team, state and federal, in Geelong: John Eren, the member for Lara; Lisa Neville, the member for Bellarine; Chris Couzens, the member for Geelong; Darren Cheeseman, the member for South Barwon; and Gayle Tierney, the upper house member for Western Victoria. We are a team. They were very much there, supporting me on election day. Both Gayle and Lisa are ministers in the Andrews government. John was a minister in the Andrews government prior to the last state election. They're all very busy people, but they were all incredibly supportive of my efforts in seeking re-election in the electorate of Corio.

I particularly want to thank Libby Coker, who is now—and I feel very proud in saying this—the member for Corangamite. Libby for a long time had been Labor's candidate for Corangamite: back in the 2016 election and in the 2019 election. So, over a very significant period of time, obviously without pay because, when you seek to win a seat off an incumbent, you do so from a very significant disadvantage, Libby had fronted day in, day out, being the salesperson of Labor's policies in the electorate of Corangamite, knocking on doors and making phone calls. Her efforts were tireless. It is, I think, worth saying that her opponent, the former member for Corangamite, now Senator Sarah Henderson, was formidable. Sarah also worked incredibly hard, and I acknowledge her at this moment as well. In acknowledging Sarah as being a very formidable person, it is actually the highest compliment that one can pay to Libby in terms of her efforts ultimately being successful in winning the Corangamite election.

Corio and Corangamite kind of are twins in this place. There's a degree to which we work as partners and, in that respect, that was the case with Sarah Henderson when she was the member for Corangamite, in terms of representing Geelong in the House of Representatives. But it was a joy to work with Libby as a partner in that, and I just feel so pleased for her that she is now able to take her place in the House of Representatives.

There were an extraordinary number of commitments that were made by the Morrison government in the electorate of Corangamite in the lead-up to the 2019 election, and we will be holding the Morrison government to account in respect of delivering on those commitments. There were very many sporting clubs and a whole lot of infrastructure commitments. The member for Ballarat mentioned earlier that a lot of those are on the never-never: the fast rail to Geelong, the $2 billion committed which, in fact, we won't see until the latter part of the next decade despite there being billboards everywhere saying that it had been delivered. It's certainly not been delivered, and there is no station where you can get on the fast train. But we will be holding this government to account in terms of the delivery of those promises.

I'd like to thank my office, who are a huge support to me. A number of them are here now. I am basically the product of their work. Saverina Chirumbolo has worked with me—she did something wrong in a past life, but she has worked with me!—since the year 2000. You get less for much more serious crimes! But I am incredibly grateful that Sav has decided to spend that time with me. Catherine Bergin, Tony Hodges, Simon Furey, Alison Marchant, Haley Bamford, Kylie Nicholson, Geraldine Eren, Michael Tate, Bassel Tallal, Jett Fogarty and Lena De Rosso—I thank you all. There were so many volunteers who participated in the campaign, knocking on doors, making phone calls, standing with me during street stalls, turning up early in the morning at train stations, particularly on those wet mornings and, of course, standing there on election day—actually on the prepoll but also on election day—handing out, and I cannot thank you enough.

I can't mention all of you, but I would like to mention a number. First are Lidija Ivanovski and Ella George, who are enormous supports to me and, indeed, now work in my office but were very supportive during the campaign. There were also Pauline Synot, Kye Cole, Brodie Appleby, Daniel Kovacev, Louie Hehir, Stephen Hogg, Damien Marchant, Vlad Selakovic, Leonie Sheedy, Darren Lamont, Josh Knight, Daniel Garcia, James Rankin, Connor Parker, Kelly Toyne, Ian Trezise, Chris Van Ingen, Justin Mills, Gagandeep Mirankot, Gagan Cheema, Gail Cook, Jake Cranny, Moshtagh Heidari, Harry Adam, Claire Rowe and the many Young Labor members who came down from Melbourne, Rasoul Omid, Samad Rasouli and so many from the Hazara community, and Kevin O'Leary. And there were so many more. Forgive me for not mentioning your names, but I particularly wanted to mention those that I have.

There were, of course, a number from the great Australian trade union movement who also supported me in this campaign, and I find that gratifying because it's where I spent 14 years of my life before entering this place. I'd like to acknowledge Russell and Glenn Menzies from the plumbers union. Russell, affectionately known as 'Ox' in Geelong, was responsible for putting up hundreds of corflute signs, and I very much thank him. Troy Knight and Michael Watson, from the Electrical Trades Union; Dylan Wight and Ian Jones from the AMWU and a number of volunteers from Geelong Trades Hall: I thank all of you.

I'd like to thank the two Liberal candidates, in fact. Murray Angus was the original Liberal candidate preselected to run against me. On the very first interview that Murray gave on the day on which he was preselected, he said that he thought I was a really good bloke. He was disendorsed that night, and so I thank Murray for those comments and I'm sorry that I caused him such grief in terms of his eventual outcome! He was replaced by Alastair Thomson, who was, to be honest, very good company during the course of many days. We stood together at prepolls, and Al is a great guy. Representing a major political party in a federal seat is a big thing to do. Tens of thousands of people vote for you, and I acknowledge that he gave those people of Corio who voted Liberal in the election a voice. I thank Al for the work that he put in in doing that.

Finally, I would of course like to thank my family. My children: Sam, Isabella, Harvey and Georgia are much suffering in having to endure, I guess, the life that I've chosen, which is not their choice. I thank them for the hours that they miss me and, indeed, for the number of hours that they put into helping for this campaign. I can't do what I do but for their love. And, most of all, I want to thank my wife, Rachel Schutze. Again, Rachel is a conscript in this; she is not a volunteer. But she does it with the greatest of humour. Without Rachel in my life I would not be able to be here or do what I do.

I was asked on the Today show on Friday what I do when I get stressed, and there is a very simple answer to that: I ring Rachel and talk to her about whatever it is. Often, I just talk to her about the family, but a conversation with my wife makes all the troubles of this place go away within a minute. I thank her dearly for that, each and every day, and I thank her for the love that she gives me. I love her dearly. With that, I thank her and all of those who were involved in my campaign. I am very lucky to have the people around me that I do.

Ms COLLINS (Franklin) (18:22): I begin by acknowledging the voters of Franklin at the last federal election campaign. I have said in my newsletter to them that I am very humbled and honoured to continue to be their federal member of parliament. Like the previous speaker, the member for Corio, I was first elected in 2007, so to be re-elected again in 2019 is a really humbling experience as a local member. I want to assure the voters of Franklin that I will not let them down. I will continue to fight hard for them, both locally and also for Tasmania as a state, and in my shadow ministerial portfolios of ageing and seniors, and for women.

I want to thank all of the wonderful volunteers who helped on my campaign, but I particularly want to put out a big thank you to my staff. Some of my staff have been with me for a very long time and I want to put on the record my thanks to Lisa Mycko; Liam Carswell; Gabby Morrison; Jackson Tegg; Kayleigh Meumann, who worked for me during the campaign and prior; and Claire Vickers. I also want to thank one of my current team, who since the election has also been helping me, Kelly-Anne Webb.
You can't do this job without terrific staff. To be honest, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilson, they make all of us look good, as you would know—

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Rick Wilson ): Yes.
Ms COLLINS: They put in a tremendous amount of effort, way beyond what they are paid for and way beyond what many people in other jobs would do. So I want to put on the record my thanks to them.

I also want to put on the record my thanks to my local campaign team. As I said, particularly to those people who went on prepoll for me day in, day out. It has been talked about post the election, the amount of time that prepoll was open during that campaign—three weeks was an extraordinary amount of time for volunteers to staff campaigns. I want to thank those people who stood on prepoll in my electorate for me and for the Labor team. I'm very grateful for that.

I want to thank the two local senators. My duty senator, Senator Catryna Bilyk, continued to be a great support throughout the campaign and has been a great supporter since I was elected in 2007. Catryna and I worked the electorate of Franklin very, very hard, and we were able to secure a swing to the Labor Party at the last federal election. Catryna is a big part of that. Senator Carol Brown, has been a great friend of mine for many years, and was a great support during the campaign. Two state members, David O'Byrne and Alison Standen, helped out on my campaign in street stalls and doorknocked with me. We also had an upper house election running two weeks prior to the federal campaign, and I want to congratulate the local member there Jo Siejka, who's the member for Pembroke within my seat. Having both of us working in the electorate hard at the same time certainly helped lift the Labor vote for both of us, so it was a terrific outcome to also see her re-elected.

An extraordinary thing happened in the Franklin campaign during the election. We did a radio forum where the Liberal candidate, Dean Young—and I want to say that he did a terrific job, and I want to acknowledge how difficult it is to put your hand up and nominate for public office—was very, very honest. He was asked what commitments he had for the Franklin electorate. He said none. He was very honest. There were no Liberal Party or government commitments in the electorate of Franklin during the last federal election campaign—not one. Zero. Absolutely nothing.

I can understand why that might be the case, because government actually still hasn't delivered on the commitment it made in the 2016 election, which was for an upgrade of the Hobart airport roundabout. The roundabout is on the border of my electorate and the member for Lyons. This roundabout gets a lot of traffic in peak times and is an issue both for locals who are commuting but also for tourists coming in and out of Tasmania through the Hobart airport. The Hobart airport roundabout is obviously located partly on airport land, state government land and local government land. They made a commitment, copying Labor's commitment during the 2016 federal election, to upgrade this intersection and to do some form of underpass or overpass or slip lane to improve access to the Hobart Airport and for the commuters going straight through. They made the commitment, and we said at the time, 'We don't think that that's enough.'—our commitment was substantially more. And we heard in estimates, just this week, that it turns out we were right. At Senate estimates, held earlier this week, it was revealed that there was a $20-million blowout in the cost of upgrading this intersection. So it's gone, from combined contributions from state and federal government, from $30 million to $50 million to upgrade this. Indeed, when Senator Brown asked the departmental official, 'Has this increased the cost because it's been so delayed?'—this roundabout was supposed to be finished in 2020. It looks like it won't start until sometime next year, so it's certainly not going to be finished as it's at least a two-year project. They said, 'The cost would probably be higher than was originally envisaged.' The $24 million that the Commonwealth was putting in was for a $50-million project, so we don't know how this $20-million black hole is going to be funded, and we still don't know, and we can't tell local residents when they're actually going to be able to drive through this upgraded intersection. It is incredible that in 2019, almost 2020, I'm here saying that the government still hasn't delivered on its election commitment to upgrade a roundabout from 2016. Who would have thought it!

Also, in southern Tasmania, something which affects a lot of people that live in my electorate who regularly drive is the Bridgewater Bridge replacement that is actually in the member for Lyons' electorate. Again, this is a project that has had more announcements and more people saying they're going to build this bridge than any other project I can remember. There have been at least half a dozen announcements that this is going to happen. But we've now found out that the state Liberal government, in its ineptitude, mucked up the business case, and Infrastructure Australia has said it doesn't stack up even though the federal government has put aside funds for it. So we won't actually know what the design is going to look like until next year, let alone get the bridge started and have some construction on it. So there's more chaos on the infrastructure projects in Tasmania post-election.

Even more extraordinary, we heard in estimates this week that the majority of the money for the Hobart City Deal, particularly for the Sorell-Tasman Bridge corridor, which runs through my and the member for Lyons's electorates, won't be delivered until after the next federal election, which is due in 2022. So we have a situation with infrastructure in southern Tasmania around my electorate where the government has made various commitments but none of the projects have started yet. We don't know what one of them will look like, and most of the money for the other won't come in till after 2022. It is quite extraordinary that the government is saying, 'We're delivering all this congestion-busting infrastructure,' but I can't even get a roundabout upgrade to an intersection that was promised in 2016. Work hasn't even started.

Health was a very big issue in Tasmania during the election. We have some really serious situations in our public hospitals not only in Launceston and in Hobart but also on the north-west coast. The Launceston General Hospital and the Royal Hobart Hospital, in particular, have a very serious issue with ambulance ramping. That occurs when people are in an ambulance and it gets ramped because there's no room in the emergency department for the people who are unwell. It got to the point in Hobart a few months ago that we actually had a situation where there were no ambulances available if somebody had had a heart attack, because they were all ramped at the hospital. It is incredible that we can be in a position where the state Liberal government is saying, 'We need to cut more from the health system and more from the hospitals,' when we have this situation happening. Why is this happening? It is happening because people aren't going to their GP. They aren't accessing primary care, because they can't afford the massively increased out-of-pocket expenses because of the extended freeze on the Medicare rebate. That is what is happening. Yes, Tasmania has an older population. Yes, Tasmania has more chronic disease. Yes, we have poorer health outcomes in Tasmania because we are poorer and the social determinants of health are impacting. But when you can't get an ambulance to go and get seen at the local public hospital in the capital city, we have a really serious problem in our health system. Labor had a plan to address that. The government matched some of it but not all of it, and nowhere near enough in terms of commitments for health, during the federal election campaign.

Worse than that was what happened with other commitments from the Labor Party, one in particular for AFL. Tasmanians are very proud of our AFL, our Australian rules football history. We want our own team. We believe that we've sent enough hugely talented players to the mainland to play in mainland teams to have our own team. Federal Labor has always been very committed to supporting a Tasmanian team in the AFL. What the Liberal federal government did during the federal election campaign, with the imprimatur of its state colleagues, was allow them to contrast health funding and AFL, saying that they would rather put the money into health. They tried to divide Tasmanians in the north from those in the south. It was a really dishonest, grubby campaign. It was untrue, because Labor was going to put a lot more money into health than it was going to put into football. They also said the money was going to the AFL, whereas the money was going into infrastructure in local communities to support AFL in Tasmania. It was a complete fabrication. I am disgusted that, post the election, the Liberal Party at both state and federal levels are saying that they support an AFL team for Tasmania. They derailed it during the election campaign. They put back our having a team in the AFL.

The other issue that is really significant and has been topical in the last few weeks is, of course, funding for TAFE. The TAFE system in Tasmania has been decimated under the state Liberal government. There's no other way to put it. We have a tradie shortage in Tasmania because building is going quite well, thanks to quite a few federal Labor projects that were funded and are still going on, such as the Royal Hobart Hospital and upgrades to the University of Tasmania. You would have thought that the TAFE system would have been able to support local businesses to put on apprentices and to train them in local facilities. Unfortunately, in southern Tasmania the local training facilities are more than 30 years old. They're archaic, they're out of date and they're no longer fit for purpose. The state government has made a commitment to fund some upgrades to the TAFE Clarence campus in my electorate. Federal Labor matched that commitment during the federal election, but we've heard nothing from the federal government.

And now, since the federal government has a TAFE fund I call on the federal government and the state Liberal government to ensure that the Clarence campus of TAFE in my electorate gets the upgrades and gets the trades school that it needs to have facilities for young Tasmanians to be able to do the trades training they want to do in southern Tasmania. It is obscene that when my son left school just last year, after year 12, he and his mates that wanted to go to TAFE, five of them, could not get in. They were not accepted because there were not enough places, because the TAFE system is so underfunded and it has not been properly managed by the state Liberal government over quite a few years. They've ripped money out so there's not been enough trained staff to teach people and the facilities are so run down. It is an absolute disgrace. We have young Tasmanians that want to stay in our state, that want to get a qualification, and they can't. They're denied a place by the state Liberal government. That's what's happening in Tasmania today. It's simply not good enough.

Then we have the housing crisis. We have a very significant housing crisis in Tasmania. People are always surprised when I talk about how housing affordability, particularly in Tasmania and particularly in Hobart, is some of the worst in the country. It's some of the worst in the country because the rents are very, very high and the incomes are low. There is a demand because a lot of people are moving to Tasmania and there haven't been enough homes built to house all of the people that want to come to Tasmania. The infrastructure and the planning by the state government has been absolutely woefully inadequate. They've gone around touting an increased population policy and saying how great they are for getting more people to come. What they forgot to do was to build the infrastructure for the people that turned up. The transport infrastructure, the school infrastructure, the community infrastructure has not been built. It has not been planned for by the Liberal state government.

I have schools who are busting at the seams who have got demountables. I have congested roads, as we talked about earlier . We also have an issue about housing. There are not enough homes to house people. We're getting middle-income families ringing my office saying that their rent has gone up $30 a week. They are going to have to move out and they will be homeless. They have nowhere to go. That is what has been happening in Tasmania. We've had a really serious homelessness issue for well over two years—really serious. It was only recently that the federal government took notice and decided to waive our historic public housing debt of $150 million. That $150 million was over 11 years and it pales into insignificance when you consider last time federal Labor was in government. Over six years we invested more than $450 million in public and social housing in Tasmania. That's $450 million over six years versus $150 million over 11. No wonder we have a housing crisis in Tasmania, because this federal government has not done its part over the last six years, and clearly has no intention of playing its part any more over the next three than what it's done to date. It's a real shame for those Tasmanians who are currently homeless, or those Tasmanians who are at risk of becoming homeless at the moment because of their rental increases.

In Tasmania we have also had some issues around full-time work. There has been a significant loss of thousands of full-time jobs in Tasmania. We heard from our state Liberal Premier that Tasmania is the turnaround economy—things are going great, the economy's going gangbusters but the reality is that's only for some Tasmanians. For those Tasmanians who are trying to seek full-time work that is not the situation. For those Tasmanians, as I've outlined, who are at risk of homelessness, or who are renting, that is not the case. For those Tasmanians stuck in traffic, commuting for very significant times of a morning and of an afternoon, because the state government and federal government haven't got their act together and built the infrastructure, it is not going okay in Tasmania.

We have the Premier talking all the time about how wonderful it is and the unemployment rate in Tasmania's better than it has been—all of this rhetoric going on all the time—but for those Tasmanians who have lost their full-time job it is not okay. For those Tasmanians who are trying to live on Newstart it is not okay. Over a third of Tasmanians have their primary source of income on a government support payment. Over a third, because of the poverty in our state, because of the ageing population and because of some of the dispersed regional economies that we have.

When this government ignores calls for Newstart to be increased, it's pretty callous for those Tasmanians who are at risk of homelessness, to those who don't have access to affordable public transport, because public transport in Tasmania is incredibly expensive, particularly if you're in a commuter suburb and trying to get into the city for interviews. I cannot believe the callousness of this government, which says, 'It's unfunded empathy and we're not going to do anything about it.' These Tasmanians, like other Australians living on Newstart, are really struggling. They are relying on family support, neighbour support and charity support to live day in, day out—not just occasionally but day in, day out—because they can't afford to go and get themselves job ready. They can't afford the bus ticket to go to an interview. They can't afford to go and get their medicines when they get sick. They can't afford to go to a GP, because Newstart is too low. Everybody in this place, I think, admits it. The new federal Liberal member for Bass—I congratulate her on that—said that she thinks it should increase. I know there are many people in the government that agree with Labor and that agree with most of the community that Newstart should be increased.

I think this government need to seriously look at increasing Newstart. They need to do the modelling about the best way to ensure that those people in Australia who are currently doing it tough today can actually get the support that they need, because most of them want to work. We know that women over the age of 55 are the growing cohort of people on Newstart. There are a lot of people on Newstart over the age of 55 who've worked their entire lives then been made redundant; they can't get a job. They can't get a job primarily because of age discrimination, not because they don't have the skills and not because they don't want to work but simply because of age discrimination. It's not good enough, and this government needs to do something about it. Rest assured, as I finish my speech, that I will continue to stand up for Tasmanians and continue to stand up for my electorate. I place on record again my thanks to the good people of Franklin.

Mr GEORGANAS (Adelaide) (18:42): After successive years of Liberal governments—the Abbott government, the Turnbull government and now the Morrison government—we've lost that tag of the 'Lucky Country'. We were known around the world as Australia, the Lucky Country—and we were lucky. There were jobs for all. We got to pick and choose where we wanted to work. Our farms and lands were doing well. Unfortunately, in the last decade or so, we've lost that tag.

It doesn't matter whether you're a farmer, a factory worker, a journalist trying to report the news and do your job, a person trying to get work or a vocational education, a pensioner trying to enjoy your twilight years after you've worked all your life and paid your taxes, a worker hoping your wages will rise at least in line with the cost of living, or a family trying to make ends meet, this government is failing you. There's absolutely no big picture agenda. There's no plan, no process for the country. We see piecemeal plans cobbled together when pressure from the media, the constituency, lobbyists et cetera gets too great.

I'd like to speak about the drought. Today we saw the government's response to the drought which is crippling our nation. People are doing it really tough out there. The government's response goes against the recommendations of the Productivity Commission's extensive report, Government drought support. There is no national drought plan from this government. The government is refusing to release the report from the Coordinator-General for Drought, Major General Stephen Day. Close to $6 million in Australian taxes have been spent on this report. It was commissioned by the government, and the government is keeping it a secret. We need to know why this government has such a problem with being transparent. The government want to silence their own commissioned reports and, as we've seen, they want to silence our journalists as well. Who's next and what's next?

I have been contacted by many concerned constituents and residents of my electorate of Adelaide who are quite distressed about the lack of freedom of the press. For example, a gentleman by the name of Tim emailed me just this week. The subject line of the email was aptly titled 'Courage'. His email went on to say:
I am concerned that the balance of 'need to know' vs 'national security' has swung too far in the direction of 'national security'.
I would appeal to you to add your weight to adjusting legislation to rectify this imbalance.

I realise that for many politicians and bureaucrats this exposes them to added scrutiny which may be uncomfortable, but I believe that the measure of a good democracy is one where those who represent us in Government have the courage to put principle above personal discomfort.

That was Tim's email. I would like to say to Tim that on this side of the House we're not afraid of scrutiny, and nor should we be as politicians in a democratic country like Australia. It's not uncomfortable to be responsible and accountable for our actions, as we should all be in this place, whether you're a politician or a bureaucrat. I wrote back to Tim saying that freedom of the press is at the core of our democratic society and is vital to holding the government to account, and Labor is committed to defending this fundamental democratic right.

It was interesting to see a coalition of Australian media organisations launching concerted campaigns known as 'Australia's Right to Know' across television networks and newspapers in Australia to push this government into lifting its veil of secrecy. We saw the print newspapers on Monday where they were blacked out. This comes as News Corp Australia and the ABC have told a Senate committee that journalists at the centre of police raids in June still don't know whether they could be criminally prosecuted. The raids happened in June, and they still have no idea whether there will be criminal charges against them, whether they'll be prosecuted and what will happen to them. As media representatives said, 'The raids have achieved a chilling effect on reporting.' It has had an effect on reporting. This is here in Australia, in a democratic country where we've always had the right to speak out. Regardless of whether you believe in something or you agree with them, we've always had that God given right to be able to speak out, to speak our minds. That is something we do not want to lose in this nation.

Unlike the Morrison government, on this side we believe in freedom of the press and the public's right to know. Journalists should never be prosecuted or face going to jail simply for doing their jobs. Journalism isn't a crime; it's a profession. It's also an essential part of a democratic country, of our democracy here in Australia. The public has the right to know, and with that I share with you that the Labor side of politics calls on the Morrison government to rule out the prosecution of Dan Oakes, Sam Clark and Annika Smethurst and to better protect journalists whose only crime is doing their jobs and reporting the truth.

We also call on the government to fully comply with its obligations under freedom of information laws and to protect a very important part of our community—that is, whistleblowers. If you think back to all of the whistleblowers who have come out and have raised issues, they've blown apart a whole range of things that we'd been kept in the dark about. We're determined to hold the government to account on this issue, and I'm grateful for people in my electorate like Tim, who wrote to me this week, and many others for sharing their concerns with me.

There are many other issues in the electorate, and this takes me onto Newstart and how we're saying the payment needs to be raised. When the amount of money you're receiving from Newstart is affecting you, is stopping you from looking for work, then you know there's a problem. It's quite clear that you cannot possibly be an active jobseeker putting your best foot forward if you can't afford transport, if you can't afford to pay for your mobile to make calls for interviews, if you're struggling to keep your electricity paid and food on the table. We need to alleviate some of the pressures they have in their lives.

Rather than support Newstart recipients getting ahead, this government plans to extend the liquid assets test waiting period for Newstart to up to six months. This is extremely cruel and reckless. The cuts listed for debate this week will particularly impact Australians in their 50s and 60s who have spent their entire lives working, but for some reason see their manufacturing plant or their industry being closed down. They are made redundant through no fault of their own but because of the quick changing world.

Currently, people claiming Newstart, sickness allowance, youth allowance and Austudy must wait for up to 13 weeks to access these payments. This government wants to extend the maximum liquid assets waiting period for middle-aged and older Australians from 13 weeks to 26 weeks. If you look at the experience of middle-aged and older Australians in particular, it is so difficult to re-enter the workforce when their industries have been decimated. If you look at my state of South Australia, car manufacturing has been wiped off the face of the earth. There were approximately 1,000 workers working at GMH. We had Mitsubishi down the road. In total, there could have been 150,000 spin-off jobs. They're gone; they're finished. How do you retrain those people who have done one thing their entire lives?

The people who are being affected more than anyone else are older Australians and middle-aged Australians. These changes will force them to eat into their savings and draw down their assets and will drive them into poverty before they can access any support. We know that Australians aged over 55 represent one in four Newstart recipients. This is the largest cohort on this payment. The number of 55-year-olds on Newstart has surged by 45 per cent under this government. We've seen the reports that have come out. Our productivity is going backwards, which means there's low wage growth, and it affects everything else as well. At a time when Australians are doing it tough and the economy is weak and getting weaker, this government wants to cut support to Australians who need it the most and who are most likely to spend. When those people on very small incomes get those extra few dollars, they go straight back into the economy. They'll go into the economy to buy things that they absolutely need but perhaps couldn't afford previously.

These cuts mean that Australians doing it tough have less to spend on basics and the essentials and perhaps less of that little bit extra for things that they need to buy. It means that they'll have less to spend at local businesses, and that has a spin-off affect where everyone suffers. These cuts to Newstart are not only cruel and vindictive; they're reckless. It's absolutely reckless to do this. This payment is designed to help people get back on their feet, not put them into a downward spiral event.

That takes me to another area: vocational education. It's not just the jobseekers, middle-aged Australians and older Australians that are being done over; it's also those wanting to further their education. A new report reveals the government has short-changed TAFE training and apprenticeship programs by almost $1 billion, despite the fact Australia is suffering a national shortage of tradies. If you look back at all the public entities—railways, the Electricity Trust of South Australia and a whole range of other areas—at the end of the school year, they would have an intake of apprentices. I remember that when I was working as an adviser to the water minister I spoke to SA Water, which was the old EWS government enterprise, and we got some figures. When it was still in government hands, it was taking over 120 apprentices per year. When it was privatised, it went down to three a year.
Mr Katter: You privatised them.

Mr GEORGANAS: It was the Liberal government in South Australia that privatised them. The federal government department's latest annual report confirms that since 2014 the Liberals have failed to spend a massive $919 million of their own TAFE and training budget, an underspend of more than 17 per cent.
