Apprentice and trainee programs have been the worst affected, including apprentice incentives for business, support to help people finish apprenticeships and fund design to train Australians in areas of need. The $1 billion underspend is in addition to the more than $3 billion they have already ripped out of TAFE and training. Is it any wonder that under this government our TAFEs are in disrepair and apprentice and trainee numbers have fallen off a cliff?

This government claims they really want to lift the status of vocational education in Australia, but the truth is there's a short change of nearly $1 billion in TAFE and training. That doesn't help anyone; it doesn't help businesses who require the skills and it doesn't help young Australians who want to get into trades. If the government doesn't do something to seriously look at fixing the skills crisis that has been created, we could be looking at the extinction of the Australian tradie as well. We will be bringing the people in from overseas continuously to work on building sites because we'll be claiming that we don't have the skills here in this nation. Of course you won't have the skills unless you train people up. We've got a shortage of workers in critical services, including plumbing, carpentry, hairdressing and motor mechanics. All of this is in the report. It's unheard of that we should have a shortage of plumbers, carpenters, hairdressers and motor mechanics, a job that kids aspired to get into when I was leaving school. But there are no positions. There are no training places and there is no-one taking them on. Under this government there are 150,000 fewer apprentices and trainees, so the number of Australians doing apprenticeships or traineeships is lower today than it was a decade ago.

There are more people dropping out of apprenticeships and traineeships than finishing them. Businesses are crying out for more trained staff. The Australian Industry Group says 75 per cent of businesses surveyed are struggling to find qualified workers that they need. And what are we doing about it? Nothing. There are almost two million Australians who are unemployed or underemployed, and we're not training people. We know why this government isn't training these people for jobs in industries facing skill shortages: it is because we're starving the TAFEs of needed money and training. By locking Australians out of education, we're locking Australians out of jobs. It's pretty simple. It's not rocket science. It's a pretty simple equation. You lock them out of training; you're locking them out of jobs and we're bringing people in on the skilled migration visas, where we've nearly got 800,000-odd—
Mr Katter: Unskilled as well.
Mr GEORGANAS: And unskilled as well, as my colleague the member for Kennedy says.

By presiding over a skills crisis, this government are holding Australian businesses back, they're holding Australian wages back and they're holding back the lifestyle of Australians that we all dreamt about and for which we were called 'the Lucky Country' many years ago. That's gone. That title has diminished. Australians deserve good training facilities and good TAFEs and universities for those that wish to go on to universities, but both, unfortunately, have been gutted.

It takes me onto the other issue: pensioners. We have good, honest people who have worked all their lives and have paid their taxes their entire lives. Some have fought in wars as well. No-one's safe from this government, not even our pensioners, who are the backbone of this country, the people who have already contributed so much for us to be able to lead the lives that we lead today. They have done the hard yards, and it's now time to allow them some relief in their twilight years.

Labor delivered the biggest rise in the age pension in Australia's history, and the government has constantly tried to whittle away the age pension, which is in their sights for cost cutting. We know this government's history; they're obsessed with cutting the pension, having attempted to cut the pension in every single budget since they've been in government. In 2014 they tried to cut the pension indexation, a cut that would have meant pensioners would be forced to live on $80 less a week within 10 years. In 2014 they cut $1 billion from pensioner concessions support designed to help pensioners with the cost of living. Again, they axed the $900 seniors supplement for self-funded retirees receiving the Commonwealth seniors health card. In 2014 they tried to reset deeming rate thresholds, a cut that would have made half a million part pensioners worse off. And in 2015 they did a deal with the Greens to cut the pensions to around 370,000 pensioners by as much as $12,000 a year by changing the pension asset test.

In 2016 they tried to cut the pension to around 190,000 pensioners as part of a plan to limit the overseas travel for pensioners to six weeks. What's wrong with travelling overseas? If you're a pensioner, you've worked your entire life and you've paid your taxes. That's what you want to do when you retire. But, no, they want to limit pensioners' overseas travel. In 2016 they tried to cut the pension for over 1.5 million Australians by scrapping the energy supplement for new pensioners. What a measly amount to cut. It was $40 a fortnight to help with their energy costs. People have worked all their lives and paid taxes, and what do we do? We attack them and try and take away that measly $40. The government's own figures show this would have left over 563,000 Australians who are currently receiving a pension or allowance worse off over 10 years. In excess of 1.5 million pensioners would have been worse off.

They spent five years trying to increase the pension age to 70. It's all right if you're in an office in a managerial position, but, if you've been a bricklayer, you've worked in a factory all your life or you're on the farm or on the land, your back has gone by the time you're 50. How can you work until age 70? And the government continues with these pushes and continues to short-change pensioners with the inequitable deeming rates, while interest rates remain at record lows. We need a government that respects our pensioners. As I said, they're people who have worked all their lives and people who have paid their taxes.

On top of that, we have a waiting list of 120,000 for aged-care packages at home, and every month those figures are blowing out by another 20,000 to 30,000. We plug a hole in one place and a great big gushing hole opens in another. These are people who just want some dignity and some care at home, once they've retired. When they get into their old age they're frail, and they go on these massive waiting lists, which means they deteriorate—they haven't got the help that's required—and then they end up in aged-care facilities, which ends up costing 10 times the amount of what a home care package would have cost. Or, if they are given a home care package, it's at a very low level where it doesn't really assist them. So they wait for six months to get the package, they're then given a package which doesn't really assist them, and then they apply for another one. I've had people who have come to see me, and they have then passed away waiting for packages. When we receive the package it's too late—they're gone. Or they have older relatives looking after them who also become frail because they too have to wear the added burden of looking after and assisting their loved one. This is not on. These are people who deserve dignity in those twilight years.

Mr KATTER (Kennedy) (19:01): I hope in some future time that someone might read the speeches—the ones that I make, anyway—I really do. I think if you took a survey of this parliament and asked: have they read the speech of Edward Theodore—the second reading speech to the Fiduciary Notes Bill—I doubt whether a single one of them would have even heard of it. Yet, a great Australian historian asked the Clerk of parliament, who'd sat here for 53 years listening to parliament, 'Who was the brightest fellow who ever went through this place?' The Clerk said: 'I'll answer your question this way. Theodore's second reading speech on the fiduciary notes issue was easily the most brilliant speech ever given in this place.' To this very day, it still is. If you read that speech, you understand that we don't have to be scared of recessions and depressions and runaway inflation: there is a complete and full understanding of how economics works. To know of the terrible mistakes we made in the Great Depression by not listening to Theodore and his acolytes, Chifley and Curtin, we can quote Winston Churchill, 'Those who cannot learn from history will be doomed to re-suffer it'. It's a good quote.

I'd like to tell the people of Australia and future generations that this was once a great nation, a nation to be proud of. We built our own motor car. I think my father bought the 310th Holden sold in Queensland. I remember he kept walking around it and saying: 'We Australians built this car. We Australians built this car. Look at this car. Look at it its clearance. Look how cheap it is. It hasn't got the frills of all the British rubbish. It hasn't got a big tank like the Americans. This is a car built for Australia.' He was just so proud of the Holden, Australia's own car. All this place had to do was say that all government cars will be built in Australia. That's all they had to do, and we would have a car industry today. But, no, both sides of this parliament are driven by ideology. Economic rationalism, as it's called, has replaced economic nationalism. I sit with two great pictures on my wall, one of Edward Granville Theodore and the other of 'Black Jack' McEwen. These men would turn in their graves if they saw what their parties, the Country Party and the Labor Party, had come to today—standing idly by and watching the complete destruction of the motor vehicle industry in Australia.

When McEwen was the boss, all of our petrol came from Australia. It was Australian petrol. Now, all bar three per cent of our petrol is imported from overseas. Again, I wish we taught history in our schools, because if we taught history in our schools we would know that the Japanese went to war because the Americans cut their petrol off. We would know that the European war was about Hitler trying to get to the oilfields across Africa and Russia. The whole wall was about oil! But we don't have to worry about it; we've got three weeks supply in Australia!

This is the lucky generation. I wasn't in the lucky generation. I joined up, because everyone was going to fight in Indonesia—we were at war with Indonesia. I don't know about other people, but I didn't join up out of any patriotism—I want to put that on the record. I joined up because I knew everyone was going to go, and if I got in early I might be giving the orders instead of taking orders. It was anything but patriotism there! But I was terrified; I was in the 49th battalion and we were on 24-hour call-up to go over there, to face off against an army nearly 27 times the size of our army.

When we faced off, we had half a million semiautomatic rifles and there were another million in private hands. I had an AK-47 and my brother had an eight-cartridge shotgun. You don't pick a fight with a country which has 1½ million people who've got semiautomatic weapons and know how to use them. That is not a good idea, even if you are the size of Indonesia or China. You don't try taking on a country like that—with Switzerland and Israel being the great examples of that. But now we have 35,000 rifles with which to defend the country. We have no petrol and we have no rifles. We have 200 drones—we're into the modern age with 200 drones—but the drones have no ordnance capacity. So we can look at the enemy but we're not allowed to hurt them, because we've got no ability to hurt them. I won't go on in that area.

Seventy per cent of our whitegoods were made in Australia. When I was a kid my television was made in Australia, the fridge was made in Australia and the stove was made in Australia. Air conditioners were just coming in then, but were made in Australia. All of our household appliances were made in Australia. I don't have to tell anyone in this parliament that none of our appliances are now made in Australia. The last whitegoods factory closed in Orange three years ago. With textiles, footwear and clothing, we've still got some textiles, footwear and clothing in Australia, but 70 per cent of them have gone.

In my homeland, the cattle and sheep industry—through enlightened, fierce and courageous government—has stood up to the big corporations. We watched Dalgety's go, Estes go, and English and Scottish go, and these places were taken over by Australians. The laws in Queensland said: you have a 30-year lease and at the end of that lease, anything over the size of a living area is cut off and balloted out to Australians. Those laws saw all of those industries in the hands of Australians.

We built the Snowy. In Queensland we had a free hospital system—the only place on earth. You could walk in off the street at any time of day or night and get looked after. In Queensland, for those areas which were under the mining act—which was about a 10th of the state—we sold land for between $7,000 and $15,000 a block when in the cities they were $100,000 a block. When Charters Towers was moved off the mining system, the price of a housing block went from $6,000 to $72,000. We provided cheap land for our young couples so that they could get married and bring up their kids with a little bit of space around them.

We built the Snowy mountains scheme, which was one of the 23-greatest engineering achievements in the history of the world. We have not built a weir or a dam in 33 years, yet the government has burnt up $1½ billion in looking at dam schemes. I am sick and tired of ministers, particularly National Party ministers, wandering around North Queensland, announcing a new dam scheme and then giving $50 million or $100 million to have a look at it, to assess it, to have an economic development statement or an environmental development statement. Heavens, if you're the government of Australia and you can't figure out whether it's a good idea to build a dam in Hughenden or not, then you should not be the government of Australia. If you have not got at your hands the knowledge about what is bad and what is good for the environment and nature in Australia then you should get out of government—33 years; nothing.

All of the ports in Australia were owned by Australians—by the Australian people not by corporations. All the electricity was owned by the Australian people—not by corporations in Australia. All of the airports were owned by Australian people. All of the gas was owned by Australian people. The mining companies, the four great mining companies in Australia—BHP, the biggest mining company in the world; MIM, the fourth-biggest mining company in the world; Western Mining; and Normandy—all were Australian owned. There are a couple of others I can't remember. Now there is not a single significant mining company in this country that is Australian owned.

As for the land, all I know is that the AA company; the Consolidated Pastoral Company; Kidman, the biggest farming operation in Australia; Van Diemen's dairies; and Cubbie Station, the second-biggest farming operation in Australia, are all majority owned or controlled by foreigners. There might be a question mark over one of those companies, but I would argue that all of them are owned or substantially controlled by foreign interests. There is no doubt in the mind of any of us who live in non-city Australia that the majority of the land mass of Australia is now foreign owned: 52 per cent is desert, on the world register of deserts; 22 per cent is owned by the First Australians, but they're not allowed to own anything. They've no timber rights, no quarrying rights and no water rights. Apart from that, they own the land! Tribal ownership—tribal ownership pre-dates the Roman empire, the Greek empire and the Mesopotamian empire, so we're getting them to work economically under tribal ownership, are we? That's good fun.

It's not stopping there. I was not comfortable with the government of John Howard bringing in 320,000 people a year into Australia. The incoming Labor government kicked that up to 650,000. I was at a CFMEU dinner the night the president of the CFMEU mercilessly attacked the Prime Minister, who was at the dinner—I'm a proud member of the union—over bringing in 650,000 people a year, and specifically the section 457 workers. There were about 37,000 coming in under the Liberal Party and 147,000 coming in under the Labor Party. They were coming in, undermining our pay and conditions and taking our jobs. To quote Sally McManus of the ACTU, one out of every two new jobs in Australia since 2013 has gone to a temporary visa holder. They say, 'Oh, yes, but they must meet award conditions.' Award conditions? I have been where they live. There are three beds stacked up on this side and three beds stacked up on that side. I measured the distance. It was from my left shoulder to the tip of my right hand. That was the distance. There were no cupboards. They had sticks and poles that they were hanging their clothes on at the back of the beds. Shared toilet facilities were 20 metres away. And these people were paying $150 a week for the rental. So, yes, they're paying award wages, and then the labour hire companies get them through the back door. If they complain, of course, there's a deportation order and they're gone.

The other intriguing thing about the 640,000 people coming to Australia is that they are coming from countries with no democracy and/or no rule of law and/or no Judaeo-Christian 'love your neighbour, make the world a better place'—we may not go to church on Sundays, but we most certainly are brought up in the Christian traditions—no industrial awards and no egalitarian traditions. So 650,000 people are coming to Australia each year and our natural birth rate is under 300,000. In fact, if you take out—God bless them—my First Australian brothers, and you take out people from the Middle East, we have the lowest birth rate of any country on earth. We are a vanishing race. When 20 Australians die, even if you include those groups, they're only replaced by 17 people. So, over five generations, we've got a population in Australia of about 12 million people. Those are not my words; they are the words of Bob Burrell, the economist and demographer. But you can work it out for yourself. You don't have to be Albert Einstein to figure that one out.

Free hospitals? No, we don't have that anymore. We don't have an outpatients. So, if you haven't got a doctor who works after hours, too bad for you. 'Red Ted' Theodore would turn in his grave and Bjelke-Petersen would turn in his grave if they thought that there was no free hospital system in Queensland. But there's not. In Mareeba, a town of 24,000 people, we have no bulk-billing, so if you've got no bulk-billing and no outpatients, then there ain't any free hospital system. Never mind about after-hours or on the weekend—there's nothing at all. Now, how could the much-maligned Bjelke-Petersen government provide you with 24-hour service by a doctor at that hospital every hour of the day, every day of the year, and yet the current government can't supply any service at all? I'll tell you why. Because they've developed nothing, nothing at all. There's not been a single new mine opened, to my knowledge—there probably has been, but I'm not aware of one—in Queensland in the last 33 years. Heavens, we were putting down 300 kilometres of railway line every year to open up four or five mines every year. We built a major dam or a major irrigation construction weir every year for 30 years. The much-maligned Bjelke-Petersen government did that. By the way, the man died penniless; he didn't have two bob to rub together. He was only one of two people that refused to take his golden handshake, the superannuation, because he said it was morally wrong. So he died a pauper. That is the man accused of dishonesty! By the way, 'Red Ted' Theodore is also accused. He's remembered in the history books for the Mungana scandal. He is the greatest man in Australian history by a long way. I didn't say that; Malcolm Fraser said that. I didn't say that; Paul Keating said that. I tell you what, he's on my wall. For those who want to know a little bit about history, he was Clive Packer's closest friend—Kerry Packer's father. They were in business together later on.

I live in a country where there were great democratic traditions. We led the world in democracy—for example, giving women the vote and extending the vote to everyone in society, rich or poor or whatever their background. We led the world in our democratic institutions. We led the world in engineering and building the Snowy mountains scheme. We built a free hospital system which was the envy of the world. We built giant railway systems, owned by the people of Australia. Let me flick back for a moment to why the Queensland government is broke. The Queensland government is broke because they sold the railways. The railways were bringing in nearly $5 billion a year in profits, and the people of Queensland get nothing out of them because Anna Bligh sold them to buy away, building football stadiums, ring-roads around Brisbane, tunnels in the most tunnelled city on earth, and pleasure domes and hurdy-gurdies in Brisbane. Now the dust has settled and, of the $5 billion in railway profits that was coming in each year, not a cent comes in now. That's why the government of Queensland is broke. They have never opened any new mines—there's no new mining money coming in—and those industries that do exist are collapsing.

They've managed to badmouth the Barrier Reef to a point where our tourism is down 30 per cent. We can't go near a single waterway in North Queensland because they're alive with crocodiles. That doesn't help our tourism dollar either. By a combination of all these events, our tourism is down 30 per cent. Our coalmines have all been sold overseas and no new coalmines are opening. We only have two great industries in Queensland. They are the sugarcane industry and the coal industry. Our current government believes the sugarcane industry should be closed down because it's destroying the Barrier Reef. It has been there for 150 years, and the Barrier Reef, according to David Attenborough, is one of the most pristine, pure and beauteous places on earth. That is not the song he sang when he got back to England, I might add, but it is the song he sang when he was here. Of course, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the Australian Institute of Marine Science are saying the reef is in good condition.

I look out on a horror story that, with each increasing year, will get worse and worse. People have no democratic traditions, no rule of law, no Judeo-Christian belief and no industrial awards. They will increasingly be the Australians of the future, and we, the Australians of today, will cease to exist. (Time expired)
Debate adjourned.
QUESTIONS IN WRITING
Pacific Labour Scheme
(Question No. 122)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 09 September 2019:

122 MR CONROY: To ask the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs—In respect of the Pacific Labour Scheme Budget estimates published on page 105 of the 2017-18 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, in making the revenue estimates for the Department of Home Affairs how many Pacific Labour Scheme participants were assumed to pay visa charges to the department in: (a) 2018-19; (b) 2019-20; and (c) 2020-21.
Mr Coleman: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

The detailed assumptions and specific volume impacts that underpinned the revenue modelling are subject to Cabinet consideration. It is a longstanding practice not to disclose information about the operation and business of the Cabinet, as to do so could potentially reveal the deliberations of the Cabinet, which are confidential.
Citizenship Applications
(Question No. 137)
Mr Gosling asked the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 09 September 2019:

MR GOSLING: To ask the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs—For each Northern Territory federal electoral division, how many people are waiting for a citizenship application to be finalised.
Mr Coleman: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
Departmental data regarding citizenship applicants is not available by federal electoral division.
